title: Migrant Shelter Brothers on the Road · Mexico
introduction:
info 2019

Year after year, thousands of people from various countries of the world cross Mexican territory on their way to the United States, pursuing better living conditions and often escaping poverty or violence.  Although this migratory flow has existed for decades, the arrival of migrants has not significantly impacted the population dynamics of either country: immigrants only make 15% of the U.S. population (irregular migrants make 3.2%), and 0.9% of Mexico’s. Yet migration systems in both countries are complicated and time-consuming, and attempting to formalize one’s migratory status does not guarantee a favorable outcome by any means. For this reason, many people choose to –or, rather, have no choice but to– migrate irregularly, even though this may expose them to human and drug traffickers, labor abuse, corrupt authorities, detention, deportation, and many other perils.

 

How to assist people who choose to relocate in search of better living conditions?
short_description: The Migrant Shelter Brothers on the Road offers migrants a safe space on their passage through Ixtepec, Mexico, on their way to the United States, and provides them with comprehensive humanitarian assistance: asylum, food, medical attention, legal advice and other services.
external_link_text: Albergue de Migrantes Hermanos en el Camino

paragraphs.body_html: In 2007, Catholic Father Alejandro Solalinde decided to open a space of rest and shelter to migrants passing through Ixtepec, Oaxaca –an almost obligatory stop for people entering Mexico from the southern border state of Chiapas. His initiative soon became the migrant shelter known as Brothers on the Road (Albergue de Migrantes Hermanos en el Camino [www.hermanosenelcamino.org]), which has since improved its facilities and increased its capacity to offer asylum, food and clothing to migrants, as well as to provide a comprehensive network of services such as legal, medical and psychological support.

In addition, the shelter designed a security protocol with guidance from the United Nations, which includes agreements with local police to protect the shelter's migrants from criminal groups. This means asylum seekers can feel safe if only for a short while, although many migrants do stay at the shelter for longer periods while the Brothers on the Road staff helps them process a refugee permit, a humanitarian visa or some other migratory document. What this means is that the shelter not only provides respite from the immediate needs of such a long journey –in the form of mattresses, showers, food, and so on– but may also make the rest of the journey more bearable and less dangerous by aiding in the formalization of migratory statuses. This is why Brothers on the Road has become a space for the protection and comprehensive humanitarian assistance of migrants.

Although the shelter’s migratory flow varies constantly, it has aided up to 20,000 people in a single year. Most of the aid recipients come from the countries of the Central American Northern Triangle –Honduras, Guatemala and Salvador– and arrive at the shelter on foot or aboard the freight train known as "La Bestia" (The Beast).

What makes Brothers on the Road stand out is the shelter’s aim of improving the conditions of migrants on several levels at the same time, not only in the short term, but also in the medium and long term:

1. Incoming migrants are offered shelter, food and support to recover from their long journey.
  2. Legal advice is made available to those who choose to formalize their migratory status for a safer journey. While they complete the legal process, they are also offered services such as psychological help and a recreational and educational space for children.
  3. Future generations of migrants benefit from the organization’s advocacy and its fight to change current migration policies with a view to guarantee human rights.

Short- and medium-term assistance in the shelter begins upon arrival: migrants are greeted at the office, where they are registered, given a small kit of basic products –such as toilet paper, electrolytes, soap and laundry detergent– and are offered a shower and something to eat. Later, an in-depth interview helps the Shelter evaluate and determine the type of assistance most suitable in each case (medical, psychological, legal) and the length of time that the shelter can offer asylum for. The information from the interview is also shared anonymously with the Documentation Network of Migrant Defenders Organizations (REDODEM in Spanish) to keep a record of the migrants' passage through Brothers on the Road and to coordinate logistics with other shelters.

Because the length of stay depends on the migratory procedures each person decides to take on, the shelter offers everyone a phone call and the possibility of using the internet to get in touch with their families for 20 minutes a day. The library where the computers are is also equipped with books, toys and some learning materials. While the adults use the computers to catch up with their loved ones (for security reasons, cell phones are not allowed in the shelter), children use this space during their long periods of waiting: they can paint, play and sometimes learn when volunteers organize workshops or activities.

The shelter’s operations are run by a team comprised of nuns from the Sisters of the Guardian Angel congregation, security and maintenance personnel, a staff in charge of promotion, administration and fundraising, and national and international volunteers who aid in management, teaching, reception and accompaniment of migrants, among other tasks.

The shelter team meets once a week to address any problems, evaluate progress and make decisions. It also convenes a weekly meeting with the hosted migrants to discuss day to day logistics, and to learn about their views and needs. Migrants take on some of the shelter's tasks in a somewhat improvised manner, as do volunteers, who organize themselves according to what basic tasks need addressing on a given day (welcoming migrants in the dining room, opening the office in the mornings, etc.), what skills each of them can bring to the table and what is suggested by the more veteran volunteers.

Although the shelter’s creator and operators are Catholic, the organization has been flexible to the specific traits and needs of aid seekers. It has established, for instance, a special resting space for transgender people, and welcomes the celebration of evangelical services since a significant number of the migrants belong to that church.

The shelter has scheduled times for eating, using showers and sinks, and for the distribution of sleeping mats. Otherwise, migrants are free to come and go, although there is a check at the entrance for everyone's safety.

Depending on the migration policies in place at any given time, the number and kind of migrants seeking refuge varies greatly (adults, teens, families, etc.), as do the amounts and forms of support that are available to the shelter. Brothers on the Road has decided to stay at bay from this volatile political climate as much as possible, which is why the organization has chosen to not seek public funds, with one exception: the shelter's electricity is covered by the government of the State of Oaxaca as part of their security agreement. The rest of the expenses are usually covered by international contributions (in 2020, for example, UNHCR built a football and a basketball court in the premises) as well as national contributions either in cash, in kind –donations of clothes, shoes, etc.– or in the form of volunteer work. The shelter’s website clearly lays out all the information one may need to contribute to the project, and the processes to do so are simple –although volunteers are asked for letters of recommendation and a minimum stay of three weeks to confirm their commitment to the project before being invited to take part.

Another source of support that Brothers on the Road has managed to secure comes from the local community of Ixtepec. The shelter receives support from the merchants of the local market in Juchitan, for instance, who on a weekly basis share food left over from their sales that can still be put to good use. But in some other instances, support from the local community has not come easy because there have been some complaints about the behavior of some of the migrants. The shelter has tried to redress the situation with different strategies. In 2019, for instance, the shelter aided the Federal Government in drafting the Social Emergency Program of the Welfare Bureau. Thanks to this agreement, migrants waiting for papers are now given monthly economic aid in exchange for work that benefits the shelter and the local community (fixing the streets, cleaning the train tracks, etc.). In this way migrants may get a small salary that allows them to cope with the waiting time and people in the community have more incentives to welcome and support the shelter’s project. In addition, with the support of a team of volunteers from the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine and Zootechnics of the National Autonomous University of Mexico, Brothers on the Road is trying to revive the shelter’s small farm to provide services to the community of Ixtepec. The farm project is also part of the shelter’s larger effort to increase its capacity to produce its own resources –another instance is the vegetable garden’s cornfield, which will help feed the migrant population that takes refuge here.

One of the most concrete ways in which Brothers on the Road has managed to scale the impact of its project has been by opening a new shelter in Mexico City. But Brothers on the Road has come to realize that taking care of the people who are currently at risk is not enough to solve the problem of perilous migration conditions. Instead, it is vital to promote long-term improvements so that future generations do not face the same difficulties as the current ones. For this reason, the shelter has put a great deal of effort into raising awareness amongst politicians, legislators and government administrators on how important it is to create public policies that help guarantee the human rights of migrants. And the project has also worked on building solidarity with the cause within the Catholic Church (to which the shelter’s team belongs) and amongst society at large. As part of these efforts to raise awareness of the problem and advocate for the rights of migrants, the Brothers on the Road shelter has engaged in activism, collaborated with documentary filmmakers to shed light on the issue and on its own work, and established agreements and collaborations with the government (with programs such as the Welfare Bureau’s, for instance) and with other organizations (such as REDODEM).

title: Nochlezhka · Russia
introduction:
info 2019

As elsewhere in the world, thousands of people in Russia migrate from the countryside to the city looking for better living conditions, but many fail in this pursuit. Often, housing costs are high and jobs scarce, and, in the specific case of Russia, another important impediment is that certain rights (such as work, medical treatment, voting, etc.) can only be exerted by people in their official place of residence, which is usually their place of origin. This measure was implemented to discourage migration from the countryside to urban areas, and it means that if someone wants to exert these rights elsewhere, they must apply for an official residence permit –which is not easy to get.

Therefore, many of the people who migrate to the cities face hardships, have difficulties earning a steady income and, some, are not even able to afford rent. These – alongside family problems, addictions, and so on– are some of the reasons why between 30 and 60 thousand people are homeless in St. Petersburg alone –a city notorious for its extreme weather throughout much of the year.

 

 

How to ensure that every city dweller has real opportunities to live a dignified life?
short_description: Nochlezhka supports undocumented and homeless people by providing them with opportunities to build a dignified life as city dwellers.

paragraphs.body_html: Nochlezhka (ночлежка) is a non-governmental organization that goes beyond merely offering shelter to those who need somewhere to spend the night. It aims to provide the homeless and the undocumented people of St. Petersburg and Moscow with comprehensive support until they eventually attain decent living conditions. The project was born in 1990 when a group of young people in St. Petersburg got together to support people who could not access public services or even food for lack of a residence card. Back then, it was assumed there was no need for public shelters or charitable organizations since the State was supposed to guarantee employment, so these types of initiatives did not exist and Nochlezhka had to work underground for a long time.

Public shelters do exist today, but they usually only offer beds to homeless people for two or three months at most, regardless of whether they improve their predicament at the end of this period or not. Therefore, Nochlezhka has decided to continue with its project, guided by the belief that a bed and a warm meal are important, but insufficient. Unlike traditional shelters, Nochlezhka aims to get to the core of the issues marginalizing these populations with two main strategies:
1. The first is to help homeless and undocumented people as comprehensively as possible so they can build a dignified life for themselves.
2. The second is to advocate for policies and legislation that facilitate better opportunities and conditions for this to happen.

Nochlezhka benefits an average of 500-600 people per day through one of its many programs. The comprehensive care it offers aims to meet the immediate needs of homeless or undocumented people –such as shelter, food, showers, clean clothes, personal hygiene products, first aid and free laundry services– as well as to provide medium- and long-term support in the form of psychological consultations, contact with potential employers, counseling on how to access public medical services and centers for vulnerable groups, legal assistance to process IDs and other documents to receive social benefits, and even help finding family members or returning home.

One of Nochlezhka’s major points of contrast with other shelters is the practice of defining a support program in dialogue with those who seek help, according to their specific situation and needs, and up until they themselves agree that their problem has been solved. In other words, when a homeless or undocumented person asks for help, the first action Nochlezshka takes is organizing an interview with a social worker to understand and define the problem in tandem, and to draft a plan with concrete objectives to tackle it. After this rehabilitation plan has been agreed upon, the social worker discusses strategies with the organization's lawyer and psychologist and, if necessary, adjusts and adapts the plan with the person in question in future follow-ups. Nochlezhka is committed to supporting the homeless or undocumented until they feel they can survive in dignified terms and successfully reintegrate into society.

To offer this comprehensive, personalized care, Nochlezhka has put together a diverse professional team of around 50 lawyers, social workers and psychologists who also work with several volunteers. It has also created a space to welcome those in need and attend to their various requirements: the shelter has 5 rooms for 52 people in total and offers a space that serves as library, recreational area and internet café. It has separate rooms to serve people with alcoholism and addiction problems through its Halfway Home rehabilitation program. And, aware of the discrimination that members of the LGBT community might be exposed to, the shelter offers connections to non-governmental organizations dedicated to these and other marginalized groups.

Beyond their open-door policy, Nochlezhka makes an effort to reach out to more people who may be in need. That is why it sets up a Night Bus that distributes hot meals throughout the city Monday through Friday with the help of volunteers. In addition, during the colder months, Nochlezhka sets up Heat Tents in busy public spaces. These tents not only make room for more people, but also bring attention to themselves and, in so doing, raise awareness on the issue of homelessness. This sometimes inconveniences the local government, which would rather not to show this side of the city, but Nochlezhka usually gets its support by giving the government credit for participating in setting up the tents.

Nochlezhka not only tries to comprehensively address the problems of people who are currently homeless or lack a residence permit, but also works to improve and perhaps even eradicate these problems altogether. To this end, it advocates decision-makers to gradually modify laws that aim to uproot these issues in the long term. In this sense, it has managed to make great contributions, such as:
• Creating a form of ID for the disabled and the homeless that is now vouched by many different institutions, allowing these populations to access some services.
• Successfully advocating for state shelters to grant temporary registration to people without residence permits, enabling them to get jobs and receive social benefits.
• Making people without residence permits in St. Petersburg eligible for compulsory health insurance since 2011.
• Successfully advocating for the government to open special polling stations so people without residence permits in St. Petersburg and Moscow get to vote.

• Collaborating with several international bodies to broaden its own impact and ability to exert political influence. Nochlezhka has joined the European Federation of National Organizations Working with the Homeless (FEANTSA), collaborated with the United Nations on reports on civil rights in Russia, and participated in various national and international forums and conferences.
• Launching campaigns in universities and out on the streets to raise awareness on the conditions of homeless and undocumented people, with the help of volunteers.
• Coming up with and promoting the Day of the Homeless in Russia to shed light on the issue at large, as well as on its own project.
• Successfully promoting a "Law on the prevention of homelessness in St. Petersburg" that regulates the care of these populations.
• Fighting against fraudulent transactions by real estate companies.

In addition, the organization has two ambitious projects underway, both of which seek to open pathways for homeless and undocumented people to solve their current predicament. The first is a café that will temporarily employ homeless or undocumented people so they can earn some work experience and money while pursuing more stable employment. To launch this project, Nochlezhka is taking advice from other organizations. The second program, in partnership with the University of Tourism and the Hilton Hotels, is a vocational education pilot project that Nochlezhka has been exploring since 2018. How it works is Nochlezhka's social workers pick suitable candidates, and Hilton Hotels offers them a scholarship to study a career in tourism, as well as temporary employment once they complete their studies. The beneficiaries of this initiative will therefore get both an education and relevant work experience by the time they finish. If the pilot works, the plan is to expand it by creating other similar opportunities with different partnerships. And much like the University of Tourism, other people also support the project with courses that they impart for free (pro bono), but Nochlezhka also pays for some extra courses (such as industrial mountaineering!) through different institutions to further expand the possibilities of the people it aids.

Nochlezhka has managed to secure many varied sources of support. This allows the organization to work with a great deal of freedom and autonomy, and to extend the reach of its project to more people and through more services. Some of their sources of support include:

• Grants and public funds obtained through calls for proposals (although only occasionally, because these procedures are usually very bureaucratic, and funds are limited).
  • Online donations through its website.
• Personal sponsors. In 2018 for instance, 50 people participated in the White Nights Marathon fundraiser race.
• Private donations of hygiene products, food, clothes, and so on.
• Donations from businesses, governments, and national and international foundations.

• Volunteers who organize charity events (such as concerts or talks), offer workshops, provide free legal, medical and psychological consultations, give out support and company, assist in distributing aid at drop-off points (the shelter, the Night Bus or the Warm Tents, for instance), and undertake campaigns to raise awareness on the problem of homelessness or lack of residence permits.
• Corporate volunteers, i.e. organizations or companies that support the project in creative ways, such as:

• The Express help fundraising network, which is an event that Nochlezhka has been putting together for several years in collaboration with various cafes, bars and restaurants. The premise is that on one day a year, these businesses organize fundraising activities (concerts, collection of donations, etc.) and choose a couple of items from their menus to collect proceeds for the organization from. In fact, other businesses have joined this campaign too, such as the Lenta Supermarket chain: every year on Homeless Day, the store selects and displays various products that customers can buy and donate directly to the shelter. And there is also the Hard Coin Barber Shop, which offers free haircuts and shaves one day a year! In return, Nochlezhka gives publicity to these businesses.

• Through collaboration agreements with other social organizations. Such as Spasibo!, which collects second-hand clothes and channels a part of what it gathers to Nochlezhka, in addition to supporting it with funding. Nochlezhka, in turn, channels the clothing donations it receives to Spasibo. Or with companies such as Pratchka, which provides free laundry services for the homeless and for people in need.

• Canvassing and collection boxes.
  • Gift collection on Christmas season.

To maintain these sources of support and attract new ones, Nochlezhka hires staff whose exclusive, full-time task is tending to current supporters and welcoming interested parties by sharing information, showing them around the shelter's facilities, explaining the organization’s achievements, and going through all the available routs to support the project. In addition, Nochlezhka organizes a party every year to celebrate the project’s birthday and takes this opportunity to invite all collaborators, thank them publicly (giving them publicity), and lay out the yearly achievements they made possible (harnessing their trust).
Nochlezhka's success has led the organization to ask itself how to further expand its impact, grow and support more people. So far, the project has pursued two main strategies:

• It has launched a research team aimed at refining its own working model. This helps Nochlezhka better share its experience with government shelters and other organizations through seminars, consultancies, and free customized manuals that may help other initiatives develop similar projects. In addition, in 2018 Nochlezhka launched an online system to assist colleagues from other organizations by registering and tracking cases, and by guiding them on how to support homeless and undocumented people in a comprehensive way. Nowadays, several organizations in St. Petersburg and other cities have reproduced some of Nochlezhka's initiatives, such as the Warm Tents.

• Nochlezhka opened new branches in several areas of St. Petersburg and, recently, one in Moscow, where the government estimates a minimum of 15,000 homeless people (although by other estimates the figure is much higher). This new project in Moscow faced some major obstacles because neighbors of the new shelter violently opposed the notion of having homeless people in their neighborhood. But, in 2019, the organization found a new location for its shelter and is trying again –only this time it is organizing public awareness campaigns to win the neighbor’s support with the help of a small staff and a considerable group of volunteers. Although several organizations offer humanitarian aid in Moscow already, Nochlezhka believes that its own distinctive feature –comprehensive, long-term care and accompaniment for the homeless and undocumented– is an important contribution that should be promoted. In addition, establishing a new branch in Moscow is a strategy to increase its leverage with decision-makers, gain more political and legal impact in the country's capital, and give more visibility to the issues it works with. This will make its work easier in the future, as it will help improve conditions for migrants without residence permits from the root.

title: Gemah Ripah Waste Bank · Indonesia
introduction:
info 2022

Over the last few decades, cities have grown a lot. In 1950, 30% of the world’s population lived in urban areas and today that figure is more than 50%. Moreover, city life has changed our consumption habits so much that today we produce 3 times more waste than we did back then!

What to do with so much waste? Evidently, we need to learn to produce less and to better manage the waste we generate because, although many innovations have been made to manage and reuse it, the change has been so fast and radical that at present we don’t have the capacity to achieve it effectively, and we are generating an enormous amount of pollution and affecting our health and that of the entire planet. Garbage in the streets produces bad odors and unpleasant environments. It pollutes the air and clogs the sewage. Garbage dumps pollute land and water sources and also generate methane gas, which is contributing to climate change.

In Indonesia, where an extra 6,500 tons of garbage is produced every year, the government has failed to establish an appropriately efficient system to manage it, despite many efforts to achieve it. Much of the garbage generated in people’s homes is not collected and landfills are constantly overloaded. Moreover, only less than 20% of waste is being recycled, and although there are centers that buy waste for recycling, they usually only buy a few types of waste (such as plastic and glass). To make matters worse, as in the rest of the world, either due to lack of disposal alternatives or awareness regarding the seriousness of the situation, many people maintain habits that do not contribute to solving the problem such as indiscriminate burning of waste, throwing it in the wrong places or not sorting it. And the efforts of the few people who sort their garbage are squandered when the public collection services, by not having an effective management system, mix it again with the rest of the waste they collect.

This has long been the case at the Piyungan landfill for final waste disposal  (TPA), which is usually the landfill that receives garbage from Bantul and other localities of the Indonesian province of Yogyakarta. The landfill is constantly overloaded with waste and has to close seasonally, which leaves local garbage collectors without alternatives for channeling waste, and thus stops garbage collection from households and public places.

With the Yogyakarta earthquake in 2006, the situation worsened because the dumpsters were ruined, people had to buy a lot of temporary utensils because their things had been destroyed and, with so much new waste, the collection system collapsed, causing garbage to accumulate in the houses and on the streets and many people started worrying about this problem.

 

 

How to reduce, make the most of and better manage waste?
short_description: The Gemah Ripah Waste Bank is an economically self-sufficient project invented by inhabitants of Bantul, Indonesia, to make it easier for their community to contribute to solving the waste problem (by helping to sort, collect, recycle and reuse it) and benefit economically by doing so. As of today, it has been replicated by thousands of communities across Indonesia.

paragraphs.body_html: In 2008, a resident and activist from the village of Bantul named Bambang Suwerda, who is also a professor at the Yogyakarta Health Polytechnic, decided to get together with a group of friends from his community to do something about it. Clearly, the public waste management services were not up to the task and the community had to help solve the problem one way or another. And the first step would have to be to talk to neighbors and local leaders about the situation in order to try to find solutions together. So, the team began to mobilize in nearby communities to talk to them about the importance of everyone changing their waste management habits (not throwing it in the street or sorting waste in our homes, for example) to avoid diseases such as dengue or respiratory infections, so that drainage systems aren’t clogged and cause floods, in order to reduce environmental pollution, etc.

Soon, the team realized that, although it was extremely important to keep working at making people aware of the problem so that they start being a responsible party in its solution, it was also crucial to create incentives and, above all, alternatives that would facilitate this change.

Why (they asked themselves) can’t the waste management system be as efficient as the banking system? After all, much of the waste can be reused or recycled. It can still be useful or even generate money if it is sold.
That’s it! What needed to be done was to learn from the experience of conventional money banks and replicate their model, but managing, instead of money, waste.

A few months later, they decided to create the Gemah Ripah Waste Bank (Bank Sampah Gemah Ripah) in Bantul, for which Bambang donated a property and legally formed an organization in order to launch the project. In addition, they managed to obtain a monetary donation from an electric power company to build a small house to accommodate the waste bank and, with financial support from the local government, they also built a warehouse. Later on, the bank partnered with companies willing to buy the waste it was to receive, hired people from the community to manage the facility (a cashier, an administrator and two other people to help organize the waste) and finally opened its doors to the public.

The Gemah Ripah Waste Bank became Indonesia’s first waste bank! Where villagers can bring their separated garbage for the bank staff to weigh and calculate its cash value based on market prices, write it on their bank card to be deposited into their savings account and hand them a receipt. The bank then resells that waste and with the money it receives, pays people when they want to use their savings. Yes, just like the banks we know, but with waste!

But, what is the difference between the waste bank and the centers that buy waste from scavengers? The first big difference is that these centers only accept a few types of waste (such as plastic, glass, etc.) while Gemah Ripah has been expanding the variety of materials that people can sell to them. As of today, it accepts 43 types of garbage: cooking oil, raincoats, shoes, lamps, newspapers, cans, notebooks, cement, steel, paper, cardboard, furniture, aluminum, iron, etc. Secondly, the bank allows people to save their money and has established agreements with several institutions and local businesses so that they can obtain benefits for doing so. Stores that sell basic products such as rice or sugar, for example, have agreed with the bank to give better prices to customers who pay with these savings, which benefits them because it gives them promotion. And local schools too! The bank has strongly encouraged schools to give discounts to people who pay with their savings at Gemah Ripah to motivate people to open their accounts in their children's names so that they can benefit from their participation in the bank and, in the process, become aware of the problem from a young age and familiarize themselves with the habit of sorting garbage and not throwing it in the wrong places. Furthermore, not only individuals, but also local institutions or businesses can open accounts in the waste bank to make the most of the waste they produce.

With strategies such as these, the bank has contributed to strengthening Bantul’s economy. Its model has facilitated (and also encouraged) not only scavengers to collect and sell the waste that they cannot sell in other centers in order to obtain more income, but also that any person within the community can profit from the waste from their homes that was previously useless (or even a burden) to generate economic resources or even mobilize outside their home to collect things that can be sold in the bank as a business opportunity.

In addition, it is creating sources of employment, not only for the people from the community who work there, but also for neighbors interested in opening local recycling enterprises or in producing and selling handicrafts or other merchandise making use of the garbage that the bank collects. At present, for example, the bank has an agreement with a pet kibble company (Royal Canin) that invites its customers to return them the used bags, so that local artisans associated with the bank can turn them into handbags with creative designs. Once transformed, Gemah Ripah sells these bags to Royal Canin for distribution among its customers, and with the money received pays the artisans and keeps a small percentage to fund the operation of the bank. Also, in order to support other artisans that make items on their own, it installed a shop window display in its premises so that people can see their products and buy them.

As is the case of any conventional bank, the first thing customers encounter when they enter the waste bank is a cashier who receives what they are going to deposit, and a banner with the price list at which each material is being purchased (prices change according to the market). Apart from that, it’s a little different. At the reception area, there is a scale to weigh the waste and a shop window display with the products made from recycled materials that are for sale. Passing through this room, you arrive to the back area of the bank, where there are two warehouses and a garden. In one warehouse, some of the waste (including unicel) is stored, reorganized and even recycled. In the other, the organic waste and the dry leaves that the local government gives to the bank are processed to generate compost. Most of this compost is sold to the government itself for use in gardens and other areas of Bantul, a mutually beneficial arrangement. Another part of the compost is sold to the bank’s clients or used for the orchard that Gemah Ripah has set up in the garden, so that visitors can see the benefits of using organic fertilizers. The bank is especially interested in children seeing these advantages because it tries to instill awareness from an early age concerning the waste problem, with hopes that in the future, they will be able to do things differently. That is why it encourages families to open their accounts in their children’s names and to get them involved in garbage sorting. In fact, the bank set up a small fish pond where children who help their families sort garbage can fish as a reward. In addition, Gema Ripah organizes activities with neighboring schools so that children can learn how to sort and reuse garbage by making handicrafts with it.

Gemah Ripah’s success has drawn so much attention that, for some time now, officials from other communities, leaders and other people have started visiting it to learn about recycling techniques or to draw from its experience and its work model to replicate it. Nowadays, the bank has so many visitors that it offers various packages that include guided tours of the bank, souvenirs, and consultancies or training sessions that can last hours or days. To cater to visitors’ needs, the bank has created a Whatsapp group with several of the town’s merchants in order to see who wants to meet their demands for drinks, food or even lodging. This is generating additional economic benefits for the community and is helping to bring it close and make it participate in the bank's project.

At first, Gemah Ripah started by doing the sales accounts by hand and people had to wait a while to receive their savings, since the bank had to sell the waste first in order to be able to pay them. Now, the bank already has the resources to establish different payment agreements with customers (it can pay them immediately if that’s their wish) and thanks to the development of specific software for this type of bank, it has increased its capacity to manage money and the bank’s overall operations. The software has a system that allows it to calculate the value of the waste received according to the updated market price and helps it record transactions on the computer (not only on the customers’ paper card) in order to maintain transparent accounting practices and to be able to plan its operations.

The waste bank is a project that makes it easier for the community to contribute to solving the waste problem (by helping to sort, collect, recycle and reuse it) and to benefit economically at the same time.

But it has also managed to be, in itself, a financially self-sufficient business. The bank buys garbage from people based on market prices and resells it at a slightly higher price in order to keep a commission that allows it to cover its operating costs (paying its staff, maintenance, transportation, etc.) without the need for ask for donations or financing (well, they are currently looking for support to expand their land and have greater capacity, so if you are interested in supporting them, you can contact them here). It also earns money from the visits and from the sale of products (handicrafts, compost, etc.). In addition, it receives support from many students; it installed a rainwater harvesting system that is used for the operation of the premises and it contracted a system so that people can make phone recharges with their savings (which gives it additional income).

For all this, the project has won numerous awards from both governments and companies throughout the country for its valuable proposal that is concrete, feasible, profitable and replicable to minimize the serious environmental and public health impact of waste.

As of today (2022), more than a thousand people from Bantul and other parts of Yogyakarta are associated with Gemah Ripah and already more than 11 thousand communities throughout Indonesia have been inspired by their model to open their own waste banks! Adapting, of course, the design of their premises and their rules according to their own context. In some places, for example, communities have agreed that the bank will deliver their savings only once the Ramadan celebrations begin.

Knowing that it is very important to keep waste banks close so that people are encouraged to participate in them, Gemah Ripah has tried to make it easier for anyone interested to replicate its model in other towns. It has systematized, for example, the bank’s infrastructure, organization and procedure requirements and created a guide so that people, managers of other waste banks, groups or communities can know, step by step, how to open a waste bank or how to manage it. In addition, it shares the software that it developed in order to manage this type of bank and has formed a network with other waste banks to organize training sessions that help them improve and give each other feedback.

title: Work in Art · Mexico
introduction:
info 2021

The Mayan Riviera in the state of Quintana Roo has become one of the most visited destinations in Mexico and the world, which is why thousands of people have moved to its beaches and cities seeking job opportunities in tourism (the population has multiplied almost 17 times in the last 45 years! ). But the enormous economic flow brought about by visitors has not benefitted everyone equally: today, more than 40% of the population lives in poverty, partly because many of the jobs are low-paying and partly because many cities have been growing at great speed and with poor oversight, which has led to an insufficiency of infrastructure and basic services for many inhabitants. Therefore, you can see a marked difference between the affluence of the resort districts in places like Cancun, Playa del Carmen and Tulum, and the destitution of the neighborhoods where people working in the tourism industry live.

 

How to improve conditions in marginalized neighborhoods?
short_description: Work in Art is a collective that works in Playa del Carmen and other parts of the Mexican Mayan Riviera recovering public sites ––particularly in marginalized neighborhoods–– through graffiti murals that aim to help everyone have a happy and dignified place to live in and enjoy, while also promoting urban artists, local businesses and tourism.
location_map_text: Playa del Carmen, Quintana Roo, Mexico

paragraphs.body_html: In 2013, several graffiti artists from Quintana Roo got together in Playa del Carmen to paint the walls of a school with the idea of making it a nicer, more pleasant space for the children. This was when they realized that, although there were many artists and graffiti artists like them in the area, there was no local group with a project for the city or the region as there are in other parts of the world. So they decided to form Work in Art, a collective of artists, designers, photographers and graffiti makers that since then dedicates to paint murals with optimistic and constructive messages on the walls of Playa del Carmen's streets, public spaces and neighborhoods, as well as in other communities nearby. From their perspective, the urban art of graffiti has proven to be a powerful tool for change that has helped many cities around the world to build their own identity, has given voice and recognition as artists to many young people, has brought art to the streets, as an activity has promoted dynamics of conviviality and joy (with rap, poetry, and so on) and, above all, has helped recover dull, neglected public spaces, rehabilitating and giving color to the places where people live, making them feel happier there and creating the conditions for people to make the most and take ownership of them.

Almost immediately, the group came up with the idea of organizing the first "Playa del Carmen paints itself in color" festival, which was going to paint murals in houses and businesses in the Colosio neighborhood (the non-touristy part of the city's main street known as 5th Avenue). The idea was to fix it up and make it more attractive for the inhabitants of this disadvantaged neighborhood and at the same time create a cultural corridor that would attract tourists and benefit local businesses.

The Work in Art team began this project by visiting neighbors' homes to ask them if they would like to have their outer walls painted. After getting permission to paint the walls, they put out a call for proposals and were able to attract more than 50 national and international artists to paint the murals, many of them graffiti artists they had worked with in the past. In order to welcome these artists and pay for their lodging, transportation, food and painting materials for the duration of the festival, the Collective's team reached out to their network of friends and acquaintances to get all sorts of support. Initially they encountered some resistance because this kind of events were not yet common in Playa del Carmen and graffiti was considered a form of vandalism by many, but enough people were motivated and supported them in many ways: the local government helped them with painting permits and other logistical matters, some restaurants donated food for the artists during the event, several hostels offered guest artists free lodging, paint stores provided materials and some photographers joined in documenting the process.

The murals turned out so beautiful and uplifted the neighborhood so much that other collectives started organizing interventions in the tourist-y areas of town and many businesses became enthusiastic and offered sponsorship for upcoming events.

So Work in Art decided to continue making interventions and murals in different parts of the city, especially in poor neighborhoods and neglected public spaces. For instance, one year Work in Art painted the under bridges at the entrance to Playa del Carmen hoping to create a new tourist route for visiting murals that would help the local economy. Another year the collective invited the neighborhood's children to participate in the painting of a public sports field. On another occasion it called for artists from the region to intervene in a sports field in Chetumal. It has also organized events to intervene the walls of low-income neighborhoods. And, from time to time, Work in Art accepts requests from hotels and other businesses to paint their walls and beautify them. In addition, on some occasions, the collective has used the murals to make a statement about an issue that is important to their community, such as the mural on the sea turtle created to raise awareness about its endangered status, or the "Homage to our heroes" mural on the nearby island of Cozumel, with which the collective sought to honor and highlight the health sector personnel who had been protecting the population during the Covid-19 pandemic.

According to Work in Art, there are different strands among the graffiti movement: some groups are anti-system anarchists who don't want any kind of support from companies or governments. Others want to help local artists make themselves known. In its case, the collective has decided on inviting artists who are already somewhat recognized so as to guarantee the quality of their murals and facilitate more opportunities to paint walls to continue its project for the region. That is why Work in Art is very careful when choosing artists to work with and why, as part of the selection process, it requests portfolios with photos of their murals to know how good they are and whether the type of themes they paint are in line with the purposes of the collective. Even though Work in Art does not restrict the murals' themes once it has chosen artists, it does make a pact with them so as to assure the people who lend their walls that there will be no offensive or pornographic content in the paintings.

Work in Art has not chosen to formally register as a civil organization and has preferred to continue organizing itself as a collective in an informal way because members feel that if they began to assign formal salaries to themselves and get involved with paperwork and money, the project would lose its essence and would no longer be an opportunity to freely do what they like to do. So, for the time being, they have no long-term plans, and each of them has their own work and devotes their free time to the project when they spontaneously decide to organize a festival or a specific intervention.
In addition to all this, what has allowed the project to be sustained and grow is that its working model benefits many people:

• Guest artists. Normally the agreement with the artists is that, although they are not paid for the murals, Work in Art covers their travel expenses to Playa del Carmen, their daily allowance and the materials they request for their work. This gives them the chance to travel, meet other artists and, above all, enables them to make themselves known, because they can put their name and contact information on their painting so other people can contact them to do more murals on a paid basis beyond the festival in question.

• Lesser known or emerging artists from Playa del Carmen and the region. Although Work In Art does not provide them with walls to paint at festivals (because if the mural’s quality does not meet expectations this could affect the work of others), it does give them the chance to meet more established artists and to learn from them by observing their work directly when they come visit.

• The communities. In addition to the impact of the murals in their city and neighborhoods, many communities have been able to enjoy graffiti workshops and mural painting activities that Work in Art puts together, mostly for children and usually with the involvement of guest artists who impart the workshop as a thank you.

• Local businesses. As festivals and other interventions have made murals very popular in Playa del Carmen, Work in Art has had little trouble getting support to organize and finance its interventions in the city. Normally the collective avoids asking for public funds because the group considers them to be too complicated. Instead, it has relied on the contributions of independent producers and, above all, of several local businesses. In exchange for funding, lodging or food for guest artists, Work in Art offers to paint murals on their facades, draw their logo on murals in other parts of the city, film short videos so they can promote themselves as socially responsible businesses, or mention them on their social media to promote them. As this has proven to be good publicity in the city, many companies are willing to support the collective when it organizes events. Some, such as paint manufacturers, even consider the support they give to Work in Art in their annual budgets and have gone so far as to ask them for exclusivity to ensure that competitors don't beat them to the punch. But Work in Art does not sign exclusivity contracts because it wants to preserve its freedom and prefers to choose its sources of support according to each project's needs.

• The government. Some local governments have supported Work in Art's efforts with funding or logistics (such as permits to intervene public spaces) because this is helping them rehabilitate many of the most disadvantaged neighborhoods in the region.

• Other organizations and collectives. Work in Art has invited other collectives and social organizations to collaborate and join forces to organize multidisciplinary meetings (with rap, poetry, theater, graffiti, among others), to intervene certain areas of the city, to organize workshops or to host artists.

Experience has taught Work in Art how to organize new events more readily. For instance, the collective has learned to prepare portfolios with its main ideas for an intervention, and to leverage the extensive network of contacts it has built to submit the portfolios directly to the people in charge in businesses or in government who might support the project.

In addition, over time, Work in Art has been gathering the gear purchased with festivals budget (such as scaffolding, materials and speakers), which has helped in becoming more independent because this type of equipment is usually the most difficult to procure.

The Work in Art project has been spreading throughout Playa del Carmen and some other places in the Mayan Riviera and is proving by example the transformative power of art and the importance of taking action to combat inequality and provide more favorable conditions for all the city's inhabitants.

title: Christmas Tree Forest · Mexico
introduction:
info 2016

The growth of cities –and of the agricultural or livestock activities needed to supply them– have been taking land from nature. About 1 million hectares of forest land are destroyed every year in Mexico alone! Deforestation not only robs many animals and plants of their homes, but also prevents water reabsorption into the soil and oxygen production. Clearly, many of the people and businesses that make a living from these activities have been unable, unwilling or unsure of how to exploit resources without abusing nature and putting it at risk.

 

 

How to harness natural resources without destroying them?
short_description: The Christmas Tree Forest produces and sells trees while offering tours and training to promote sustainable forest management.

paragraphs.body_html: In 1960, a group of people decided to buy 400 hectares of semi-deforested land in the Amecameca region, State of Mexico, to start a Christmas tree business. They designed a land management model that has inspired many other projects because of its success in rehabilitating the forest and even turning the property into a tree nursery that sells trees wholesale and retail to customers throughout the country and abroad. Their model has even enabled the project to give away more than 5 million trees for the reforestation of other areas of Mexico.

The Christmas Tree Forest (Bosque de los Árboles de Navidad), as the project was named, has achieved sustainable forest management because it only uses part of the land to plant Christmas trees (120 of its 400 hectares). The rest is either kept intact or reforested by the organization, which sells only 50,000 of the 350,000 trees it produces each year. In addition, the Forest plants many Viking trees because their trunks have the capacity to regenerate after being cut down –which means tree sales do not entail the destruction of the forest.

The project has also attained sustainable forest management because of its efforts to identify possible threats to the forest or to the project itself and its measures to prevent them. The team set firebreaks in the forest, for instance, and trained all its personnel to fight fires. It also developed mixed tree crops specifically designed to prevent soil erosion as well as to stop pests in one type of tree from propagating to all others. Furthermore, the project hired its own staff of experts (biologists, engineers and technicians) which means that any problem that arises can be immediately addressed. And, although security does not seem to be an issue in the region, the Forest has put together a team of foresters to guard against potential logging and tree theft.

Other preventive measures have to do with increasing the project's self-sufficiency: by conserving much of the forest, for instance, the project has plenty of dried leaves to use as fertilizer, which greatly reduces the need to outsource. Also, by developing mixed tree crops the project now has registered patents that yield some profits. In addition, the Christmas Tree Forest has designed a hydraulic engineering system to harvest and use rainwater which has achieved complete self-sufficiency in supplying toilets, drinking water, and irrigation for the entire property –despite Amecameca’s known water scarcity.

In order to sell its product, the Christmas Tree Forest has devised several strategies to make its business more attractive to different people. In 1999, for instance, the Forest decided to partner with the neighboring Hacienda Panoaya, a lodging space (hotel and campsites) that offers visits to the Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz Museum, the Volcanoes Museum, the English labyrinth, the neighboring petting-zoo, the zip-lines and other extreme sports facilities. Thanks to this partnership, the Hacienda now offers several of these services free of charge to the Forest’s clients and, in return, the Forest supplies the Hacienda’s guests with small trees and Christmas-tree coupons, and invites them to attend talks on sustainable forest management and tours of the tree nursery and the forest. In other words, the agreement allows both projects to offer a more comprehensive and attractive range of activities so that more people are encouraged to visit them in Amecameca.

The Forest has partnered with companies (such as Coca Cola, El Metro, Coppel, etc.) for the same purpose. In this case, the Christmas Tree Forest offers integration walks, retreats and talks to strengthen employee dynamics and, in exchange, gets paid a fee and is given the opportunity of propagating its work and raising awareness on the importance of conservation.

The project also organizes school fieldtrips on their premises which have secured the official backing of the Ministry of Public Education. These visits leverage the project's experience in a way that reinforces school curricula on subjects such as science, environmental education (garbage management, rainwater harvesting, etc.) and civics. Fees from the fieldtrips are an additional source of income for the Christmas Tree Forest, which welcomes about 20 schools a day! These fieldtrips are co-organized with Hacienda Panoaya and include environmental and cultural education as well as entertainment. To make them even more attractive, the trip includes Christmas tree coupons for students, a small tree from the nursery and a participation certificate.

Moreover, as part of its strategies to make the business more attractive to visitors, the project also collaborates with the local population. Each year during the high season the Forest encourages merchants to sell their products at its Christmas Bazaar, and to prepare food to sell at its Christmas Food Market. This arrangement does not involve rent fees and therefore does not bring in direct profits for the Forest, but it does carry benefits: the Forest ensures a diverse offer of food and products by selecting the merchants, which means customers and visitors have more incentives to spend the day at their premises eating local food and buying things at the bazaar. In addition, the local population appreciates this collaboration and gets involved with the project. For the Forest, this good relationship means the support of loggers, forest rangers, cleaners and guides, and for the locals, it means 70 permanent and about 400 temporary jobs each year. In addition, the Christmas Tree Forest can keep its facilities clean without spending money by welcoming local junk dealers to collect and use their garbage, and a similar win-win agreement has been reached with local shepherds, who graze their sheep on the Forest’s premises and, in doing so, cut the grass and fertilize the land.

This variety of collaborations enables the Christmas Tree Forest to sell more trees, raise awareness on sustainable natural resource management, and spread the word about its project. Even so, the Forest has decided to further expand its reach by offering free technical training courses on installing and maintaining tree nurseries, rainwater harvesting and other topics to farmers and to national and foreign organizations that visit the premises. All of this has earned the project recognition and awards both national and from various educational institutions, and has planted seeds in the minds of many visitors which will hopefully translate into more sustainable development practices.

title: Biomaya Movement · Mexico
introduction:
info 2021

Mexico’s Mayan Riviera is one of the world’s leading tourist destinations for many reasons, not least because of the incredible beauty of its white sandy beaches and its crystal-clear waters. Unfortunately, since 2011 these beaches have been suffering the inflow of massive amounts of sargassum, a type of seaweed that normally floats in the sea and serves as a refuge for many species of animals, but which has been reproducing in excess due to climate change and to agricultural and sewage waste. So much so that it now occupies an area of ocean measuring some 9,000 kilometers in length and each year, in the spring and summer seasons, it drifts in large quantities towards the coasts of the Mexican Caribbean.

Stagnant on the beaches, sargassum prevents coral reefs from getting the sunlight they need to survive, spoils the landscape, prevents people from swimming in the sea, and when it decomposes, releases toxic chemicals that harm animals and give off foul odors. In addition to the enormous environmental impact, all this has scared away many visitors and has dealt a heavy blow to the local economy which is heavily dependent on tourism (which yields more than 85% of its GDP!).

 

 

How to reduce the environmental and economic impact of sargassum?
short_description: Biomaya Movement is a company that sells soaps made from sargassum it collects from the beaches of the Mexican Caribbean. Its project helps clean the coast and reactivate tourism, which has been impacted by the excessive arrival of this type of seaweed in the region. It also provides jobs for homemakers from vulnerable communities.
location_map_text: Playa del Carmen, Quintana Roo, Mexico

paragraphs.body_html: As sargassum comes in greater quantities every year and everything suggests that the problem will get even worse, the government and the private sector have done everything to prevent its buildup on the coast: the Mexican Navy has sent ships to curb the arrival of the seaweed, and hotels and local authorities pay companies to collect it from the beaches. Besides, several businesspeople have been exploring ways to harness it and use it as raw material to make products such as fertilizers, building blocks, and sunscreens.

One such effort is the project launched by the Parker marriage. Since she is a cosmetologist, the first idea they set out to explore was making beauty products. After about two years of research, approaching scientists and other experts, and doing several tests in laboratories to learn about the seaweed's composition and its potential for use and treatment, in 2019 they finally found a formula to make safe high-quality hand and body soaps. So, once the product was ready, they got the endorsement of the health authorities and founded the company Biomaya Movement to be able to market it.

But as the name suggests, the project's objective from the onset was not only making a profit by selling sargassum products, but also creating a platform to join efforts to minimize the seaweed’s negative impact on the environment and on tourism, and to help improve the region's economy. Therefore, as well as designing a business model based on removing sargassum from the beaches and leveraging it as raw material, they decided to call on homemakers from rural communities to help with the manufacture of soaps (women who, although they need to earn an income, cannot usually work full time because they have to take care of their families). Also, they mobilized the community of Playa del Carmen and its surroundings to participate in their movement by selling their products, helping to clean the beaches, and other activities.

To get this dynamic started, as soon as Biomaya Movement established itself as a company, it organized a press conference in a well-known hotel and invited many important local actors (businessmen, NGOs, activists, biologists, hotel owners, media, and others), to make its project and proposal known and to try to establish collaborations. And the strategy worked, because when many businesses of all kinds saw its social and environmental cause, they decided to join the effort by selling the soaps in their establishments, which was a great start for Biomaya!

According to what Biomaya learned from experts, sargassum has many properties that can be beneficial to skin and the method for processing it is relatively simple. The problem is the high cost of paying, preparing and equipping personnel capable of collecting sargassum without taking sand from the beaches and of doing so safely (because if you don't harvest live algae, rotting sargassum can be toxic and dangerous). Then there are the costs of shipping the seaweed, financing a warehouse to store it (so that it lasts for the off-season), and cleaning and processing it to yield the extract. Because of all this, the company decided that its soaps would be aimed at a middle-class consumer profile in order to sell at a price that made the investment profitable. So, they designed glycerin bars mixed with sargassum extracts and different fragrances that promise to moisturize, cleanse and rejuvenate the appearance of skin. Furthermore, they came up with the idea of making the packaging with PET sheets they make from plastics and bottles they collect from the beach and send to be recycled and treated to comply with hygiene and quality standards.

Biomaya has decided to hire young people to collect sargassum on the beaches and to invite rural, mainly Mayan, homemakers to take part in the production of soap so as to contribute to their household economy and become more self-sufficient. Many of these women have lost their jobs due to the economic crisis in the region or are unable to hold a full-time job because they have to take care of their children and families.

Biomaya offers them a deal: the company gives them what they need to make the soaps (stove, gas, molds, plates, spoons, and so on) and holds workshops to teach them how to make 300 soaps in 3 hours. With this work model, they can make money from home, at whatever time suits them best and without having to neglect their children. They also have the option of selling the soaps on their own, paying Biomaya only the cost of the inputs. Either way, the company agrees to buy an established amount from them, which can increase if Biomaya manages to sell more soaps with the help of its distributors.

As many rural communities are wary of working with strangers because they have had many experiences of abuse, Biomaya collaborated with the civil organization Rotary Club to approach these families and invite them into the project. Also, Biomaya has recently been making efforts to approach homemakers from low-income neighborhoods in Playa del Carmen to offer them the same deal.

All these strategies have helped the company fulfill the social mission of its movement and attract clients and collaborators interested in supporting it. The Riviera Hospital, for instance, has helped them by offering doctor appointments and discounts on health services for the women who work with them.

Besides the Hospital, many people have joined the Biomaya Movement's call to participate in the project in various ways and thus contribute to cleaning the beaches of plastic and sargassum while also creating jobs.
Biomaya sees itself as an organization that promotes the sustainable development of the Mayan Riviera, and it has outlined a series of strategies to encourage the local community to join its project:

• First of all, it doesn't ask for economic support from the government because it doesn't want to be linked to any political party and lose empathy from people as a result. Rather, it supports its project with the sale of soaps.
• Besides, it calls on people to volunteer by cleaning up the beaches and collecting plastic bottles.

• To encourage businesses to sell its soaps, Biomaya designed stamps with its name and a "responsible business" banner that can be affixed to the entrances of stores. These stamps give publicity and legitimacy to the businesses because people can see them as part of this movement and know that buying from them contributes to Biomaya's social cause.

• It also created a WhatsApp group called "Environment" with public officials, businessmen, divers, biologists and all kinds of local people. On this group it promotes garbage collection campaigns to get volunteers and shares ideas on environmental initiatives for the region. The ties with all these actors have helped Biomaya a lot: businesses help spread the word about the project and its campaigns with customers, the Sargasso Monitoring Center in Cancun informs them which beaches have large amounts of seaweed so they can collect it, some companies have donated tools to clean the beaches, and more.

• Biomaya also designed a whole section on its website describing the many ways in which anyone interested can contribute: by spreading the word about the project, buying or selling its products, cleaning the beaches, and so on.

• And to further expand the reach of its initiative, Biomaya is contemplating the idea of creating a network among the various businesses involved in its movement for mutual support. Currently many of these businesses give discounts to customers who mention they are members of the Biomaya Movement (because this means the movement is advertising for them). But the idea that it is currently exploring is creating a membership that people can buy to get further discounts at collaborating businesses. This would help the businesses promote themselves and Biomaya pay the homemakers and sargassum collectors.

Biomaya's founders have designed a work plan that aims to lay the groundwork so that they, as general managers of the company, can soon leave the project running by itself and only be responsible for thinking about how to improve the model and make it grow, so they can focus on new projects.

That is why they have been building, little by little, a small core team of around 7 people with different responsibilities: managing the project, looking for better prices from suppliers, making it profitable, dealing with vendors and helping them solve their problems, promoting the project in social media and at other events (investing in advertising is what has brought them the most profit), and so on. This team works from the central office of Biomaya Movement in Playa del Carmen where the warehouse is and coordinates tasks such as the collection of sargassum and plastics and the search for communities that can support them with the production of soaps. Their salary varies according to the results they achieve in the tasks assigned to them, a strategy that Biomaya uses to motivate them and to ensure the efficiency of their work.

Aside from this core team, the project also involves the homemakers who produce the soaps (currently --2021-- around 15), the young people hired to collect the sargassum, the salespeople and the experts who continue to explore, with the help of laboratories and research centers, the possibilities for developing new sargassum-based products.

 

For the project to grow exponentially, Biomaya has designed a working model to expand its sales coverage (getting more vendors, representatives and regional partners to extend its presence in more and more places) and, at the same time, expand the number of sargassum-based products they can sell.

Vendors are people or businesses that, in exchange for a certain amount of money (Biomaya offers several packages), are given a specific quantity of soaps that they can sell for the price they choose. Regional representatives are people who, through their own initiative, look for markets in new areas and earn according to the number of customers they manage to secure. If after some time they show they have successfully positioned the soaps in a given region, the company makes them partners and gives them the license and exclusivity to operate the brand in that region with a certain degree of independence. When this is the case, the partners keep 5% of the profits from the sale of soaps as royalties and 25% from sales, and the other 70% must be sent to Biomaya's head office to pay homemakers, the young people who collect sargassum on the beaches, and cover other expenses. This model has allowed Biomaya to expand its presence not only in hotels and spas but in all types of businesses (shoe stores, universities, hospitals, and others) in 7 states of the country.

Because the initial investment was very substantial and the project only started recently, Biomaya Movement is just recovering from the costs of launching the project and setting up its location and operating equipment. Although it chose to produce soaps because they are inexpensive and everyone uses them, today (2021) its challenge is to sell many of these so that it can reinvest the profits in the new sargassum-based products it is exploring. In its view, these products will also bring great social benefits, not only because they will provide jobs for more people, but also because some of them are being designed to tackle local problems, such as waterproofing for houses (it rains a lot out there) and asphalt to fill potholes in communities and urban centers in need of it, for instance.

title: Library of Things and Services of the Old Quarter · Spain
introduction:
info 2021

How often do you use the hammer you have at home, or the crutches you bought that time you were injured? We spend a lot of money on products that we only need occasionally or items we simply discard once we use them. Worldwide, this and other forms of misuse of resources not only affect our personal finances but are also creating more than 2 billion tons of waste per year and causing serious environmental damage.

 

How can we make better use of the things we have to improve our finances and reduce our environmental impact?
short_description: The Library of Things and Services (Caixa d'Eines i Feines) of Barcelona's Old Quarter collects tools, wheelchairs, sewing machines and other objects that the people of the neighborhood no longer use or may need only occasionally and puts them at the service of everyone. With this initiative, things are used by more people and for longer, reducing waste and helping household economies. This project also provides workshops to promote the exchange of services among neighbors and the use of the library's items as a means to solve everyday needs.

paragraphs.body_html: For decades, many communities around the world have been creating libraries of objects to make better use of their things by sharing them and, in so doing, building alternative forms of solidarity economy and circular economy. Object libraries (or banks) lend out sewing machines, tools, toys, wheelchairs and other things that people only use temporarily or suddenly and which are typically donated by members of the neighborhood or community, so that people do not have to actually buy them and can instead use them only as needed. In this way, items are used by more people and for longer, reducing waste and helping household economies.

In 2015, a group of friends, some of them neighbors, learned about this alternative model of consumption and decided to open a local library of things and services for the community of Pou de la Figuera in Barcelona's Old Quarter, a neighborhood with many public housing units. To launch the project, the team began by researching similar initiatives and interviewing some of them ––then, having a better idea of how these initiatives work, the team formed the civil association CERCA (Comunitats, Eines i Recursos Casc Àntic) in order to raise the necessary resources to create the library. In 2020, the team managed to win a competitive government grant that provided their start-up funds on the condition that they cover at least 20% of the project's total budget with their own resources. The team leveraged the funding to hire a part-time staff member to help devise a strategy to raise resources to meet this commitment, manage the project, secure and set up a location in the middle of the neighborhood's main square so that it would be visible and easily accessible to neighbors, and serve users.

Because the funding was obtained at a time when the confinement measures to contain the Covid-19 crisis restricted the chances of approaching neighborhood residents to talk about the new project, the first thing the group did once the premises were secured was leverage its contacts with other local organizations to reach people through social media. Using an online form, the group asked residents what they would like the library to have and what tools or things they did not use or barely used they were willing to share with the community. While donations were the priority to optimize existing local resources, the team leveraged the funding to purchase things that people had suggested and that had not been secured through donations, as well as other things that they themselves identified might be of interest to the community while brainstorming amongst themselves.  Finally, in mid-2021, the Library of Things and Services (Caixa D'Eines i Feines in Catalan) opened its doors to the public.

In order to make a catalog of the items the library procured and to allow the public to book loans in advance, the Caixa D'Eines i Feines made use of an open-source software that is available for the management of this type of libraries called Lend Engine. Although this software has free versions, the Caixa opted for a low-cost version to store more data and serve more users.

The Caixa decided to ask users to become associates of the library by paying an annual membership fee and to charge for the loan of items, which would allow it to self-finance the project, pay its operating expenses (such as the software, rent and maintenance of the premises, the salary of the person in charge of managing the project, etc.), and meet the 20% contribution required by the government funding. But knowing that not all neighbors have the same economic capacity and so as not to leave anyone out, the team decided that the membership fee would only be 10 to 20 euros, depending on the user's capacity, and the fee for the loan of items would also be symbolic and definitely cheaper than elsewhere (1 to 5 euros per week depending on the case). In addition, the library chose to receive payments directly on the premises (rather than online) to give users the opportunity to expose their situation and, if necessary, to exempt them from paying. This flexibility shows that the library is betting on trust in its staff and users, and on their co-responsibility to take care of, return and pay for the things they borrow with full regard for their community and for this project that seeks to benefit it.

Another important objective of the Caixa has been to promote proximity and small-scale economy and to strengthen relationships and support among neighbors through the exchange of professional services among themselves. In other words, the Caixa wants to leverage the network of library associates to link those who are service providers or owners of small local businesses with other neighbors, with a view to enable exchanges, encourage the use of local services or products, identify common interests, or even establish agreements to work together.

In this respect, although their website catalog already allows members to register and publish their profiles with offers and requests (for cleaning services, therapies, private classes, etc.), the Caixa is only just taking its first steps to set up and consolidate this network of service exchanges. For instance, it is currently organizing various types of activities and workshops right in the middle of the neighborhood square so that neighbors who have not yet done so learn about the project and feel encouraged to participate. At the same time, registered members also get to know each other, share knowledge on how to best use the library's items to solve everyday problems, and share ideas on how to consolidate the service library.

The workshops that the Caixa provides are usually on topics relevant to the goal of extending the lifespan of objects and making people aware of the ways in which they can be better utilized.
