This is why the Caixa invites local organizations interested in making themselves known, as well as friends willing to support the project, to share their knowledge with neighbors by offering workshops on how to use free software such as Linux, how to repair their own bicycles, clothes, electrical appliances and other such items by leveraging objects available in the library such as sewing machines or tools. The workshops are free so that everyone can benefit from them, but voluntary fees are welcome to support workshop providers. The Caixa promotes them mainly on Facebook, which is its main means of contact with users, but the goal is that they can gradually be scheduled according to the demand of neighbors, as is done in the "suggested” groups of social media.

Despite the difficulties in obtaining funding and launching the project in the midst of the Covid-19 pandemic, the Caixa de Eines i Feines has managed to set up its premises, create a rich library of items at the service of its neighborhood, and associate more than 90 people in a very short time! The challenge it faces today is to consolidate and persist, mostly by getting members to become more involved with the project and actually start changing their habits of consumption, such as not purchasing things that can now be borrowed from the library.

title: Solidarity Economy Network XES · Spain
introduction:
info 2021

More than 600 million people in the world live on less than $1.90 USD a day and 70% of the population live in countries where inequality continues to grow. What also continues to grow are cities, consumption habits and unsustainable land use practices, all of which are risking the planet’s ability to give us what we need to survive.

 

How do we create an economy that benefits us all and does not destroy the planet?
short_description: The Solidarity Economy Network XES develops tools and activities to call for, promote, strengthen and articulate solidarity economy projects in Catalonia to create an economy that is fairer, more centered around people and more respectful towards nature.

paragraphs.body_html: The Solidarity Economy Network XES (Xarxa D'Economia Solidària XES) is a project of Catalan cooperatives that first got together during the Porto Alegre World Social Forum, an event that brought together more than 12,000 people from around the world to discuss alternative proposals to the current form of globalization and to the damage it is causing the planet and its people. Although the movement for a social solidarity economy has been around for several decades, the Catalan team that launched the XES decided that it was important to join forces and create a political project in their region that would contribute to the global struggle to replace the capitalist economy (which is aggressive with the planet, competitive and fosters inequalities) with one that is fairer, more solidarity-based, more focused on people and their quality of life, and more respectful towards nature.

For this reason, in 2002 XES was formally constituted as a civil organization and it started developing tools and activities to call for, promote, strengthen and articulate projects, businesses and people in Catalonia that align with the values of solidarity economy in their objectives as well as in their ways of producing, distributing or even consuming. Some of these tools and activities are:

• The Pam a Pam, which is an online map that marks the social and solidarity economy projects linked to the network within the region of Catalonia. This map makes the different projects known among members and among people interested in consuming services or products that favor a fairer economy. By using the map, users can find out about solidarity economy alternatives in their area, create lists of “favorites”, comment on them and so on. To define which people or local businesses can be part of this network, XES trains volunteers to interview projects and, based on 15 social and environmental criteria regarding the way they work, XES evaluates the extent to which each complies with the principles of solidarity economy. The Pam a Pam then serves not only to identify projects and give them visibility, but also to guide initiatives and people who are interested in transforming their ways of working and who may want to join the movement by learning how to better meet the interview criteria. Pam a Pam was developed by the organization SETEM and the XES with open source so that anyone can help improve it or even use it to drive their own project.

• The Social Balance. In addition to the Pam a Pam interview, a group of XES experts developed the Social Balance, a much more extensive online form in which organizations or individuals with a business or project must answer questions about the way they work and the type of contributions they are making. Based on indicators such as democracy, equality, environmental commitment, social commitment, labor quality and professional quality, these questions help evaluate whether projects are complying with the principles of social and solidarity economy, and to what extent. Those who pass the Social Balance not only become part of the XES network of partners (as with Pam a Pam) but also acquire the right to be registered in the directory of the XES Social Market and to participate in the Solidarity Economy Fair. Unlike the Pam a Pam map, the Social Market directory is a reference platform in the world of the social economy in Catalonia because it is well known that organizations, people and businesses registered here have the seal of approval of the Social Balance. This seal has a lot of legitimacy because the XES has spent years perfecting the survey so that it really serves to identify the level at which organizations comply with the principles of solidarity economy, which has gotten many authorities and donors to use it as a reference when deciding which projects to support with funding. In other words, the Social Balance is a tool with which XES helps organizations self-evaluate, monitor their progress (they can fill it out online for free once a year), position themselves to make themselves known through the Social Market directory and the Fair, and legitimize themselves in the eyes of donors when seeking support. In addition, XES offers specialized consulting services to other initiatives (at a cost) to identify strategies ––based on the Social Balance–– to improve their projects and strengthen them by linking them with other members of the network.

• The Solidarity Economy Fair. This is XES's main project –– it allocates at least one third of its budget to it. Each year, XES invites all the people and organizations that participate in its Social Market to take part in an event that allows them to meet, establish relationships of cooperation and present their projects to people interested in solving their daily needs by consuming from solidarity economy businesses that offer fair trade products or services, food, education, clean energy, etc. In the Fair XES showcases the solidarity economy alternatives available in the region of Catalonia and organizes debates, conferences and exhibitions. In addition, the XES leverages this event to present an annual report on the state of the local Social Market and on the progress and challenges of the sector so that all participants can better understand the scope of the project they are helping build.

• Courses and publications. In addition to these tools, XES also identifies the needs of its network partners as well as the services or experiences of other partners that may help meet them, either with training workshops, conferences, summer courses or through meetings. It also publishes books, manuals and other materials to strengthen members and broaden knowledge about the social and solidarity economy, and provides guidance on labor issues, feminism, ecology, and others.

The XES is a second-level association, which means that it is something like an umbrella organization that fulfills its objective of promoting solidarity economy by forming, coordinating and strengthening people or groups (whether formally constituted or not) that belong or want to belong to this movement. Its project is above all political, because its work seeks to strengthen the viable alternatives to capitalism that are being advanced and give them visibility among society and decision-makers so that they gradually replace current choices of consumption.

The XES organizes members into commissions and local networks. The commissions meet frequently to work on projects for the network and once a year send a representative to the XES General Assembly where the most important decisions of the organization are taken. All members can participate in this assembly, but only those who have paid the annual membership fee have the right to speak and vote. The Assembly democratically elects a 5-person Board of Directors which, together with a representative of each commission, will form the Permanent Commission that coordinates all areas of work.

The commissions are formed and disbanded according to the needs of the network. Some are thematic (such as Feminism or Ecology) and are responsible for mobilizing partners so that they can improve their practices by steering them towards the principles of solidarity economy. Others are executive (such as Pam a Pam or the Fair) and are responsible for promoting XES tools and projects to organize and strengthen the network of partners.

Local networks are teams that help Catalan initiatives interested in forming local groups and that want to adopt the XES name to gain legitimacy and visibility by leveraging the recognition that the organization has in the region (XES L'Hospitalet, XES Baix Llobregat, etc.). To take its name, the XES requires them to have a minimum of 3 members, pay their membership fee to the network, submit reports on their work and progress, use an image that is harmonious with that of the organization (its colors, logo, etc.) and use its tools (the Pam a Pam, the Social Balance, the Fair, etc.).

In addition, XES hires a part-time technical-administrative team of about 8 members (some of whom are part of one of the commissions) to manage and keep the network in motion, to follow up on the agreements of the assemblies and to seek funding. This team is very important for the XES because of the integration work it does for the network, since it is responsible for approaching the different members and commissions to learn about their interests and needs, for making proposals to them about objectives and ways of working that they may adopt so as to bring their projects into harmony with all others, and for taking their plans and budgets to the Permanent Commission and then to the General Assembly for approval.

The XES has been able to secure two annual public funds (from the government of Catalonia and the government of Barcelona) which account for half of its budget and which, because they are fixed, help it carry out its work with a certain measure of stability. In addition, the XES is supported by other sources of temporary funding, association fees, payments it receives for providing services (such as the consultancies it offers based on the Social Balance) and payments from some local governments that ask for its support in mapping solidarity economy initiatives in the region.

The XES has achieved great political impact because, through its tools and the social market it has formed, it has positioned itself as a point of reference that gives a voice to organizations in the social and solidarity economy sector in Catalonia and maintains a proactive discourse that guides interested parties on concrete and viable ways to counteract the current economic model. Today the network has more than 300 members and 15 local networks, and its Solidarity Economy Fairs have attracted more than 199 companies and 19,000 visitors in a single event.

title: GreenPrice Supermarket · China
introduction:
info 2017

In Hong Kong, about 3200 tons of food are wasted daily. From these, 29 tons are wasted due to a lack of clarity in product labeling.

Many people confuse the “use by” date (which states when a product is no longer safe to eat) with the “best before” date (which states when a food reaches its peak quality): When shoppers read the “best before” date, they often think that the products will expire soon and do not buy them.

Knowing that they will not sell, supermarkets return tons of products to suppliers when their best-before date is approaching, even if they are more than 6 months away from expiring. Since suppliers can no longer sell these products, they throw them away as soon as possible so as not to lose more money in storage. 150 million food items in good shape were thrown away in 2014 alone!

All this food, which could feed more than 40,000 families, is not only wasted: it also saturates city landfills and creates environmental pollution.

 

 

Is it possible to reduce food waste and the pollution it creates?
short_description: In Hong Kong, confusing food labeling causes tons of good food items to go to waste. GreenPrice resells these products at a discount and educates consumers about labeling as well as ethical and responsible consumption to reduce both waste and the pollution it results in.
external_link_text: GreenPrice Supermarket 绿惜超级市场

paragraphs.body_html: In 2016, business students at the University of Hong Kong created the GreenPrice Supermarket project (绿惜超级市场) with the aim of raising awareness around the misunderstanding of labeling and reducing waste.

GreenPrice buys products in good condition that suppliers are about to discard at a low price (or gets them as a concession or donation) and, after passing them through a strict quality control, resells them to the public much cheaper, at a price 30 to 40% below the market price. This adds one more step to the sales chain, which allows for products to be used instead of wasted.

Although the products GreenPrice resells depend on what is sourced from suppliers each week, they are usually processed foods and other types of goods such as cosmetics. This is why GreenPrice has identified the middle class as the target audience for its discount model, because neither the upper class nor the young people of Hong Kong seem to care too much about the price of these products, which are also not of particular interest to people of lesser means since they are not essential necessities.

Reselling the products is in itself an important strategy to avoid waste. But GreenPrice has understood the importance of supporting this strategy with campaigns to educate the population on labeling and raising awareness around the need for ethical and environmentally and socially responsible consumption. To this end, GreenPrice collaborates with universities and companies to develop, differentiate and systematize its model, and also provides educational courses and campaigns in schools, companies and community centers in and outside Hong Kong. In addition, it shares information through its Website, its Facebook page and its Instagram profile.
GreenPrice's scheme works because it benefits everyone involved:

• It benefits GreenPrice because it yields profits that ensure the continuation of the project. GreenPrice is registered as a company, but because it reinvests 70% of its profits back into the growth of its initiative, it can be considered a "social enterprise" even though Hong Kong does not yet have this legal category.
• It benefits consumers because it gives them access to food products at a better price while offering them a concrete way to have a positive impact on their community and the environment.

• It benefits suppliers because it saves them the costs of transporting, storing and disposing of products, minimizing their losses. In addition, many of them can register the products they contribute to GreenPrice as part of their Corporate Social Responsibility program. Plus, by selling to this new market, they reach a population of potential customers with their products.
• It benefits society by reducing food waste and its environmental impact, and by raising awareness in order to eliminate this problem at its roots in the long term.

GreenPrice sells its products at different points of purchase: in its own store, through its online supermarket (with home delivery), at fairs, in neighborhoods and universities, and at corporate and environmental events. By diversifying, the company not only reaches more customers with its products and its awareness campaign, but also reduces its dependence on a specific group of customers.

The initiative has had great success since its founding and continues to grow as it has pursued strategies to scale its model. In just one year, 2016-2017 it managed to attract significant investments (especially from the SIE Fund in 2016) which have been allocated to procure suppliers, diversify products and multiply physical stores. GreenPrice is also developing its loyalty program and expanding its means of distribution.

However, and although this may seem contradictory, GreenPrice's scaling model also includes an exit plan, because its long-term goal is precisely to eliminate the root of the problem of food waste due to labeling confusion: according to GreenPrice, what the government should do ––rather than launch the campaigns it is currently promoting to educate the population about product labeling–– is to altogether prohibit distributors from discarding products with an expiration date that is not yet reached. But while this actually happens and until the rules are changed, its plan is to help the government speed up the process of raising awareness to reduce waste. How? By running its own social awareness campaigns and selling products that have passed their best-before date at low cost in the hope that when people see that they do sell, they will start to change their own habits.  In other words, the organization knows that once its initiative succeeds it will have to disappear, because if the consumer education campaigns are successful, its business model will become irrelevant. GreenPrice's strategy, then, is to grow until that happens, making the most of the time it takes to solve the labeling problem.

title: Sungai Utik Longhouse · Indonesia
introduction:
info 2022

Forests are home to an infinity of living beings, they help absorb carbon and regulate the climate. But, since they are also home to important resources such as water, trees, and many plants and animals that can be used as food and medicine, we humans have already wiped out millions of hectares of them! For this reason, for several decades there has been an intense battle between those who seek to continue exploiting their resources without any type of control and those who try to protect them to stop their rapid destruction. A battle in which, by the way, the communities that have inhabited and preserved them for hundreds of years are rarely taken into account, which disregards their right to make decisions about how to manage them.

The same thing is happening in the region of West Kalimantan, in the Indonesian part of Borneo island, where since the 1960’s, the State has used communities’ territories to carry out its projects (or to hand them over to private capitals) using as an excuse that the national interest is more important, to the point of modifying the law to define their forests (the “customary forests”) as part of the “State forests”.

Since the early 1970s, the communities of the Dayak Iban ethnic group have seen the appearance of more and more companies and civil organizations, national and foreign, interested in their territories. Some trying to launch projects to exploit them, by cutting down trees or establishing mining and palm oil plantations, and others trying to protect them by designating conservation areas and national parks (because by 2010, more than 10 million hectares had already been lost!).

With few legal tools to defend their territories and many economic needs to sort out, several communities have had to adjust to the new laws that tell them how to manage their own lands in order to conserve them or, in other cases, they have decided to sell them, or to allow companies to cut down their trees in order to obtain revenue to survive. However, other communities have not felt comfortable with either option. On one hand, they are concerned that the new conservation laws will limit their ability to manage and preserve them as they have done until now, according to their traditional way of life. And, on the other hand, they are worried about making agreements with companies that could quickly run down their resources and end up dispossessing them of their territories.

 

 

How to take advantage of our forests without destroying them and without putting our way of life and our autonomy at risk?
short_description: The Sungai Utik community (in the Indonesian part of Borneo) has managed to protect its forest, its way of life and its autonomy by working together from its customary Longhouse to defend its territory and use it sustainably, guided by its values and customs, and collaborating with other organizations.

paragraphs.body_html: When, in the 1970s, different companies offered money to the Sungai Utik community of the Dayak Iban ethnic group, in exchange for using its land or cutting down its trees, it decided to refuse. Not because it didn’t have great economic needs, but because the community considered that it would be better to find another way to obtain income that didn’t put its autonomy at risk or destroy its forest, so that its grandchildren could also profit from it. After all, it had managed to preserve it for hundreds of years with the guidance of its traditional knowledge, laws and forms of organization. The forest is, for the members of this community, the home that gives them water, food and medicine. The place where the spirits of their ancestors live. The one that has provided them with resources to survive and that, therefore, has defined their culture and way of life.

But even with their refusal, some companies started to cut down the trees in their lands without their consent, because the State had given them permission to do so on the grounds that these lands didn’t have any formally recognized owners, and that by law, it had the right to concession them to private individuals.

Given this, the members of the community saw the need to stop the loggers from entering by defending themselves with machetes and, some time later, with the advice of non-governmental organizations, decided to start mobilizing through legal means to demand the right to their land and obtain the tools to protect it. So, besides sending some of its leaders to learn about land tenure laws in the country’s capital, Sungai Utik had to design a forest management plan that allow it to gain resources without destroying it and work with the neighboring community to make a formal map of its territory (which is officially a buffer zone between two national parks) to prove to the authorities that it is inhabited by indigenous communities with ancestral uses and customs. For this, they used a process known as participatory mapping, that means that both communities discussed and defined the names of the places, its limits, its resources, its forms of use and management, etc.

In 2012, the Alliance of Indigenous Peoples of the Archipelago (Aliansi Masyarakat Adat Nusantara, AMAN) managed to get the State to modify the law to distinguish “customary forests” from “State forests”. This way, the indigenous populations that managed to get the government to recognize them as customary communities (governed by their own traditional laws), could now demand the national government to recognize their right to manage their lands in accordance with their traditional way of life. Also, the communities could prevent the government from acting on their lands without their permission, as long as they effectively conserve them according to their own uses and customs.

Like other communities, Sungai Utik profited from this change to advance its legal fight for the recognition of its territory as “customary forest”, in order to protect it more securely. For its members, the fight was not about demanding their rights, but about “getting them back” and, thanks to the community’s unanimous decision to win this fight and to the support of various civil organizations, Sungai Utik overcame the innumerable obstacles that companies and interest groups promoted to hamper the process. In 2019, it managed to get the Kapuas Hulu Regency government to grant it recognition as a customary community (the first to obtain it in the Regency) and finally, in May 2020 it managed to get the national government of Indonesia to grant it the official right to use and manage its 9,480 hectares of customary forest under its customary laws.

Another strategy that helped a lot to obtain this official recognition was that Sungai Utik recorded videos and documentaries about its fight and mobilized to promote it in forums with other organizations to gain their support and put pressure on the government, by showing them that they weren’t alone. Mainly, it approached consolidated international organizations, not only because they better understand the importance of its demands, but also because they have resources, influence and legitimacy. When, for example, in 2019 the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) awarded Sungai Utik the Equatorial Prize that honors communities around the planet that show ways to fight poverty while preserving natural areas, it was more difficult for the national government to deny official recognition to a community that had received such a prestigious award.

The Sungai Utik community has around 280 members and most of them live in the Longhouse, a 214-meter-long wooden house in which several family houses are connected with a wide corridor and a terrace where the members of the community can gather, spend time together, make crafts or tattoos, and dry the grains of their crops. The rest live in small houses around the Longhouse.

Sungai Utik is a sub-village that is led in harmony between the official head of the village and the head of the customary Longhouse (as they also call their traditional form of community organization). The tribe organizes itself following its traditional laws, takes all the decisions jointly and in its frequent meetings it ensures that all its members participate (women, men, youth, elders and children) to make sure that all points of view are considered and that leaders comply with the agreements and decisions without being guided by personal interests. Thanks to this constant communication, it has been able to discuss a lot about what it wants as a community and has remained united in its fight.

During Sungai Utik’s assemblies, members talk about the future to which they aspire, design 5-year plans and, based on these, seek the support of other organizations (which they register in a directory of contacts) when they need to solve financing issues, obtain trainings, etc. When an external organization proposes a member of Sungai Utik to implement a program in the village, he or she first discusses it with the others and if they accept the proposal, they always make sure to negotiate the terms so that the community maintains control over the project in question. In other words, the Sungai Utik community is clear about the importance of its autonomy and defines its collaborations very carefully to keep control over its life.

Over time, Sungai Utik has managed to gain the support of many institutions and organizations both national and foreign. Some have helped it carry out the legal process for the recognition of its lands. Others to scientifically establish the value of these and of its traditional forms of forest management. Some more to prepare video-documentary materials to communicate its project. As most of the community is Catholic, currently (2022) the church is helping them build a new temple in the town. Probably, the closest organization is AMAN, which congregates indigenous groups from all over the Indonesian archipelago and is the one that got the government to recognize the right of communities to claim their customary forests. The current head of the Longhouse was one of the founding members of this association and currently another of the community leaders also participates in it. AMAN helped the Sungai Utik community obtain the recognition of its territory, is providing training to its young people so that they make healthy use of social media without questioning their identity and self-esteem, helps it design entrepreneurship programs so that members do not depend on formal jobs, links them with top-level brands abroad so they can sell their products, and puts them in contact with influencers to promote them.

Although the people of Sungai Utik can support any political party or figure they want, as a community it has decided not to support any political party and, in fact, avoids doing any type of deal with politicians, because it believes that its support is always accompanied by conditions or future payment expectations that can put their autonomy at risk. Because of this and its resistance to give up the use of its lands to the government and private companies, Sungai Utik has earned the animosity of several politicians and even the local government, which has on several occasions ignored it when it installs public services in the region (electric current, pipes, roads). For this reason, the community has had to install these services with its own money and manpower and, since then, has decided to address the national government directly, bypassing the local government, to request the support or the public budgets that they are entitled to, and to urge the local government to actually deliver them.

The Sungai Utik community sustains itself mainly with fishing and with its crops, mainly rice, which it also uses for its rituals and to sell abroad. It also hunts animals and keeps livestock for personal use (mainly pigs and chickens).

In order to carry out these activities without damaging the forest’s ability to regenerate itself, it uses three strategies that are based on its traditional values, knowledge and laws:

1. It divides the forest into 3 zones with different purposes and utilization levels. One is the production area, in which community members are allowed to practice farming, hunting, and collecting firewood, timber, and other resources (all within limits defined by customary law). Another is the reserve area, where they can grow medicinal plants or extract wood to build houses or boats for local use, only if the trees in the production area are not big enough yet, and with a limit of 15 trees per family to give the forest time to regenerate. Besides, for each tree felled, they must plant 2 or more new trees. The third is the protected area, which is where the rivers emerge. In this one, it is allowed to feed animals and breed fish, but it is not allowed to practice agriculture or cut down trees. This way, the water from the rivers is kept clean in the rest of the territory, which ensures supply for the community.

2. It uses a rotational cultivation system mainly for rice and rubber, but also for crops such as eggplant and cucumbers. The system consists in, after cultivating a piece of land in the production area for a while, letting it rest for several years, in order to keep the land fertile and give the vegetation time to regenerate. Meanwhile, it is burnt, and another piece of land starts to be used. The burning is done with strict monitoring and the ashes are used as fertilizer.
3. It practices agroforestry by intercropping crops with tradable fruit trees or pasture for livestock.

The Sungai Utik community has another strategy to preserve in the long term not only its forest, but also its traditional way of life: the education of its new generations. Children and young people are encouraged to participate in community rituals and assemblies (or, if they are living outside, to stay informed about what is happening in them) so that they are aware of what the community wants and needs and so that they support it any way they can, if they manage to establish contacts abroad. Besides, the local school teaches them about cultivation processes and the forest’s resources, and also familiarizes them with the traditional dances and the making of local handicrafts.

In 2020, seizing the opportunity that the community decided to isolate (close) itself to be protected from the COVID-19 pandemic, the people of Sungai Utik organized themselves to build a new traditional Longhouse with the guidance of their elders. This works as a House of Culture, in which they are organizing a library with some books in English and technology courses, so that young people can help the community to document and communicate abroad (mainly on social media) their history, their culture and their struggle from their point of view, without the need to rely on the support of external organizations that have their own language and vision regarding Sungai Utik. They are also organizing activities so that people with special knowledge or talents can share them with the rest of the community and so that senior adults can pass on traditional knowledge, experiences, techniques or values, so that they are not lost and reach the future generations (what is known as oral tradition). With the same objective, they are filming many of these encounters. They have documented, for example, the way some local instruments are played, and they also filmed the construction process of the new Longhouse, to leave a record in case in the future someone wants to build one in the traditional way. For all this, the House of Culture is also serving the community to display the culture of the Longhouses to its visitors.
Besides selling crops, Sungai Utik has adopted various strategies to earn money without destroying its forest:
• Renting the House of Culture to people from other communities who want to organize their meetings in the traditional Dayak Iban way (in a Longhouse).
• Selling some products made with local resources to prestigious international brands, such as body scrubs, mango jellies, oil or soaps.

• Exploring small-scale ecotourism. The forest inhabited by Sungai Utik is very attractive due to its enormous biodiversity and because it is home to species that are difficult to find in other regions of the world (several at risk of extinction, such as the helmeted hornbill or the Bornean clouded leopard). Also, its community is one of the few that still preserves the traditional way of life of the Dayak Iban. For this reason, in recent years, the community members have decided to explore the path of community tourism to spread their culture and thus preserve it. The agreement with the community is that each one participates according to what they know and like to do the most (hosting tourists, taking them for a walk on the river, translating, disseminating, etc.) and, if necessary, responsibilities are rotated so that everyone can benefit equally. The community only requires them to keep prices within an agreed range. Many, for example, obtain an extra income selling handicrafts that are normally used for self-consumption, such as textiles, baskets or wicker rugs, and others accommodate visitors in their homes. In this case, they are required to pay a small percentage of the profits to integrate them into a savings account that is used as an emergency fund for the community. For now, Sungai Utik is piloting this alternative with controlled tourism to get to know the experience and see if it can be done without altering local life too much. They are starting with friends and people recommended by friends, mainly from Malaysia. In the first place, because they are neighbors and have a lot of cultural affinity and also, because many are from the same tribe (which was divided when the border with Indonesia was defined) and they want to see how people continue to live there because they have lost their traditional community practices. In other words, the vision with this tourism program is to make Sungai Utik a sort of living demonstration village where people can know what the authentic Dayak Iban culture is like, how they get along as a community, what they eat, how they make their handicrafts, etc. For this reason, they are using social media a lot to spread their rituals and customs, and thus attract visitors and support from abroad (Instagram for the Indonesian population and Facebook for the one from Malaysia).

• Securing financing. In order to obtain funding, especially from international organizations, and thus avoid asking for governmental support, Sungai Utik had to form a non-governmental organization to be able to receive donations from abroad (as required by law) and a community organization to be able to implement them. Normally, the community starts the projects with its own resources because it has realized that showing that the idea is already started makes it easier for others to want to join and donate to be recognized as part of the process. This is what it did, for example, to get support to build the new Longhouse (the House of Culture): all together they cleared the land and laid the base of the house using resources from their forest or that they bought from local people. Later, they showed this work in their meetings and events outside the community to get different supports.

As the Sungai Utik project becomes more comprehensive and complex, the need to obtain resources and to have people from the community capable of managing and devoting time to the different programs grows (that is, the finances program, the House of Culture, the sale of products, the ecotourism initiative, etc.). To solve this, Sungai Utik is using its civic organization to hire (with pay) a small team of young people that it is training to learn how to run the project independently.

Defending their territory and their autonomy. Being guided by their values ​​and customs. Working together as a community. Exploring alternatives to meet their economic needs while conserving their forest and their culture. Seeking allies... With these strategies, Sungai Utik has shown the world how important it is to restore the communities the rights over their lands, in order to facilitate, with justice and support, that they can decide their ways of life and solve their economic needs without destroying their forests nor allowing anyone else to do so.

Today, Sungai Utik is supporting other Dayak Iban Longhouses so that they can achieve the recognition of their lands and continues to mobilize itself to pave the way for its independence and that of future generations.

title: CRISP Crisis Simulations for Peace · Germany
introduction:
info 2021

Climate change, inequality, wars… If humanity is to survive and improve its quality of life, solving the many problems we face will require everyone collaborating to change our way of thinking and acting. But many of these problems are so complex and have so many underlying causes and tangled interests that attempting to solve them can be very overwhelming and confusing, which has caused many people to lose motivation when getting involved in transforming their own realities, and has even led many others to confront each other and enter into conflict and war.

 

 

How to promote the peaceful construction of solutions to the problems facing humanity?
short_description: CRISP is an international organization based in Berlin that develops projects and role-playing simulation games so that communities living in post-war regions or undergoing transformation processes can reflect on these situations from the perspective of the different actors involved and regarding their different needs. These dynamics enable dialogue and promote civic education and citizen participation.

paragraphs.body_html: A few years ago, a group of students from Berlin discovered the use of simulation games for civic education. They first offered other students and then schools and organizations worldwide to use these games to help people who are experiencing complex social situations (in their family, community or country) to better understand them in order to take part in their solution.

Simulation games are interactive activities in which organizers propose a fictious or realistic and simplified version of those situations (with the same rules, demands, beliefs, etc., but on a small scale). Participants are supposed to get informed and prepare themselves to be able to "play the role" of one of the people involved while taking into account their concerns, reasons and ways of thinking, as well as the different aspects, interests and points of view that are at stake. By becoming familiar with these conditions during the game experience and by having to make decisions from the point of view of others, players learn to empathize with or at least better understand the people who are in that position in real life. These dynamics foster an environment of greater trust that creates better attitudes for dialogue by preventing the impulse to solve problems through violence. This has also proven useful for players to explore the various ways in which these same problems could be addressed in real life, to reflect on the role they have or could have in their own communities, and even to suggest how to solve conflicts or reach minimum agreements among themselves.

That is why the students, who had already been organizing international crisis simulation games with students for years, decided to make the most of their experience and started adapting these games and designing their own tools to help communities living in post-war regions or going through transition processes in different parts of the world to build bridges of dialogue and solve conflicts. In 2007, they formed the non-governmental organization Crisis Simulation for Peace - CRISP in order to promote this project.

Since then, CRISP partners with groups interested in promoting peace and transformation processes mainly in Europe, the Middle East, North and Sub-Saharan Africa, and Central Asia. These partnerships work to facilitate peaceful conflict transformation and promote civic education and citizen participation. Usually, the groups in question are civil society organizations and foundations that seek CRISP’s support in working with young people, decision makers, peace professionals or directly with groups in conflict, because although they may have the funding to do so, they lack the methods to do so. Sometimes these partners are companies, universities and local governments too. Often the collaboration is about helping them engage in dialogues and negotiations and sometimes it is about training non-formal educators or people who are involved in political decision making and social reconstruction processes in one way or another (such as peace builders). In other words, people who have a need for useful knowledge and methods that will enable them to appropriately address sensitive issues in their work.

With these partnerships, CRISP has designed learning tools and activities in several languages on all kinds of political and social issues (decision-making, negotiations, migration, climate, etc.). In Egypt, for instance, it organized a simulation game to promote the participation of youth and women in the transition process underway in the country as a result of the upcoming local council elections. In Kyrgyzstan, CRISP worked with activists interested in promoting peaceful dialogue in their country. In Jordan, it trained humanitarian workers to develop community projects. And in Eastern Europe and Germany it lead workshops to train conflict consultants and diplomats. In addition to these activities, CRISP works with partners to create materials to promote their projects, such as an audio walk with personal stories and different views on the events on Maidan in Ukraine in 2014 and a manual on dealing with sensitive topics of modern history in a school frame. It has also helped form networks to advance common initiatives, such as a network of organizations and individuals from Georgia, Azerbaijan and Armenia working to promote equitable conditions for women.

When CRISP launches a project with an organization, the first thing it does is talking to this new partner about the background situation, need for an intervention and the target groups. Then, as the case may be, CRISP shares materials about their experience in the context under discussion, get feedback on these issues from the organization in question and explain what to expect from working with CRISP. It also uses conflict analysis and needs assessment tools such as stakeholder maps and problem trees to help the organization describe in detail the conflicts or processes it wants to address and the learning objectives it hopes to achieve by collaborating with CRISP. Out of all of this, CRISP drafts a proposal of activities or courses of action that are realistically achievable.

In order for these activities to have the greatest possible long-term impact, CRISP analyzes ––together with the members of the organization–– what role they can and want to take in addressing the problems at hand (whether to work with the causes or with the consequences), what skills they can acquire to strengthen their capacity to fulfill this role, which actors can be invited to participate in order to increase reach (for instance, other professional organizations or local people with particular motivation or capacity to carry what was learned through the project beyond the duration of the activity), and how effects can be multiplied (creating structures, training trainers, publishing materials together so that the experience can inspire other projects, groups or decision-makers, etc.).

CRISP is careful to set clear, achievable and measurable goals and to emphasize the need to include as many participants as possible, especially disadvantaged or marginalized groups, to ensure that different interests are represented in a balanced way and that activities can address the root causes of problems. It also takes special care not to leave unfinished business after withdrawing from an activity that it will not be able to address any more, so as not to hinder the groups' own process.

Sometimes CRISP offers collaborators some of the options in its portfolio, that is, simulation games developed in the past and that it believes the organization can use for its own purposes. And sometimes CRISP suggests to co-design a new activity, tailor-made for the organization at hand.

In this latter case, with their advice, the organization seeking CRISP's support defines the duration of the activity (one day, one week, one summer), its objective (to make a decision, develop a policy, resolve a conflict), the learning methods (mapping of actors and conflict dynamics, experience-based learning) and the preferred formats to develop the project (simulation games with up to 40 participants, conferences, round tables, retreats, consultancies to design educational curricula, online workshops, and so on).

Once they agree on the activity that will be implemented, CRISP asks the organization if it has the financial resources to fund it. If it doesn’t, they come up in tandem with an action plan to get the funds, always trying to make sure that this does not cost the beneficiaries any money. CRISP also tries to allocate part of the funding to increase its own staff and that of the partner organization to build a stronger and more legitimate project.

In addition, CRISP plans, implements and evaluates the impact of all its activities and projects together with partners in order to receive their feedback at every stage of the process. This helps it evaluate whether values are proving to be compatible and to think about how to design better activities in the future.

CRISP is very concerned that its projects always respond to the expectations and needs of each case and that the participants in its activities follow through with what they have learned so that the activities have the greatest possible impact and really serve to promote peaceful and constructive transition processes. For this reason, from time to time CRISP organizes "vision meetings" with external facilitators to train its own team with conflict analysis tools, so that they can always understand the problems impartially and reflect on their role and legitimacy as an organization when intervening in other countries, on the lessons they have learned in their interventions and on the care they must take to ensure that their work does not cause any harm in the populations they engage with.

The great diversity of projects, games and activities that CRISP has organized has been possible because, although it is a small organization with a staff of approximately 12 people, its team is multidisciplinary (there are political scientists, educators, administrators, social workers, mediators, lawyers, ethnologists, etc.), and also because they all have diverse experiences and skillsets that allow it to meet and adapt to the varied needs of the groups it works with. Staff includes experts on different regions of the world, people with experience in the design and implementation of simulation games and other conflict transformation activities, project management, negotiation and cooperation.

CRISP organizes its collaborations with the support of an executive director, an accountant and several project coordinators. It also has a board of directors made up of people elected every two years by the organization's members. This board helps manage CRISP’s financial affairs, takes responsibility for its decisions and, together with the project coordinators, decides on action strategies and projects to be carried out. When the CRISP team is not enough to implement any of the projects fully, the organization hires external professionals on a temporary basis. Besides, every 3 months CRISP hires (with a very moderate financial support) an intern to work part time helping with administrative work, implementing activities with beneficiaries and obtaining donors, funding and partners. Also, because CRISP is part of the European Solidarity Corps Program, it invites two volunteers per year to help in its activities, which gives them the opportunity to become familiar with CRISP’s work and receive experience in conflict transformation.

In order to remain impartial in the selection of its projects, CRISP does not receive institutional funding, but obtains grants and donations for specific projects from agencies interested in supporting processes of transformation and conflict resolution (such as the German Foreign Affairs Office or the German Agency for International Cooperation, GIZ, OSCE, UN etc.). But because these funds are not enough to cover the full costs of activities and often the rules of these funds state that organizations cannot invest in specific forms of infrastructure, materials and other things that CRISP needs to carry out its projects, the organization is constantly promoting other strategies to diversify its sources of support. In addition to charging for its consulting services or portfolio materials to partners who can afford them, CRISP has registered as a charitable organization to attract donors interested in tax deductions for their contributions, it has created a membership system to receive support from individuals or organizations that want to promote its project without setting conditions, and invites people to offer free professional consulting, networking, promotion, and other services. CRISP believes it is very important to be transparent in the way it manages its resources so that collaborators have a sense of certainty and clarity that their contributions are being used appropriately and feel encouraged to continue offering their support. To this effect, CRISP publishes its finances, organization and decision-making on its website and in a newsletter. It has also signed the Transparent Civil Society Initiative promoted by Transparency International.

CRISP has detected that funding is often subject to trends, that is, that there are topics, regions or organizations that are given preference according to the political context of a given moment ("donor darlings" or preferred recipients, as CRISP calls them). Therefore, when it does not find options to fund projects that touch on sensitive issues or that are intended for regions that no one wants to fund, CRISP designs hybrid projects that take into account the interests of the current calls-for-proposals that happen to make room to also address the issues and populations CRISP wants to work with. So if, for instance, CRISP could not find funding for projects in Bosnia or for workshops on human rights somewhere else, the organization would look for calls that support projects to promote the participation of young people in social processes and, within those courses, it would then include as many Bosnian people as the granting scheme allows or raise the topic of human rights, while still meeting the donors’ objectives. It often means working more than listed in the contract, but CRISP sees it as an own contribution, which is so necessary to stay motivated and independent in the field of peacebuilding.

CRISP places great emphasis on ensuring that its projects have long-term impact and therefore stays in touch with the groups it has worked with as it continues to expand its collaborative networks. To date, it has worked with over 170 projects in collaboration with more than 50 partner organizations in 25 countries around the world.

Throughout all of this work, CRISP has helped create safe spaces for people around the world interested in solving their conflicts and transforming their societies to critically reflect, meet and work together. CRISP sees itself as an organization that adds to the transformative processes being carried out by other projects and groups without "Westplaining"–– an organization that is helping to create and empower a new generation of local actors with the knowledge and skills to work for change of their own choosing. With its simulation games and other activities, CRISP helps reflect on each person’s and organization’s role in these processes and builds the capacity of partners to better manage their resources and work so that they have a greater impact and do not inadvertently cause harm.

title: Clara · Spain
introduction:
info 2021

Because life expectancy at birth is 83 years in Spain (the third highest in the world!), this country has more and more seniors, many of whom need special care to survive.

 

Despite this fact, the resources allocated to this population by the State are insufficient, and more than 80% are used to purchase services from the private sector (at-home care, nursing homes, and so on) rather than to strengthen the public elderly care system.

 

The problem here is that the few companies solid enough to meet the demanding bidding requirements to offer these services have formed monopolies that prioritize their interests over the needs of the most vulnerable families. Most of the current supply of care, for instance, is for non-dependent seniors (retirement tourism, for instance) and many retirement homes are known for their poor conditions, standardized treatment of the elderly (with a fixed time for diaper changes, for instance) and some cases of abuse. In the absence of quality services that meet the needs of their elderly, many families who cannot care for them are forced to hire independent caregivers (usually migrant women who are employed irregularly) and to care for their relatives with little guidance and huge economic expenses that not all can afford.

On top of everything else, the difficulties that young people face today in terms of owning their own homes suggest that the conditions for the elderly in the future will be even more challenging.

 

 

How to improve the model of elderly care so that all seniors can live a dignified life?
short_description: Clara is an organization in Barcelona that works to improve elderly care to ensure the dignity, autonomy and well-being of seniors. To this end, it provides support for families, designs projects, gives workshops and advises public and private centers.

paragraphs.body_html: Worried about the inadequate treatment, isolation and neglect that more and more seniors face in Barcelona, in 2019 social worker Innan Urueta and therapist Cristina Nagore decided to create the organization Clara (Clara Ser Gran) to improve care for the elderly and create more favorable conditions for the seniors of the future by promoting solidarity economy values such as autonomy, equity and cooperation. With this project, they hoped to help replace the traditional care model with one that would put the elderly, with their specific needs, dignity and autonomy at the center and, above all, one that would take their input into account when designing strategies for their care.

Since then, Clara has three main ways of working:

 

  • It counsels and guides older adults and their families to create an "aging itinerary" which enables them either to plan their aging process so that it unfolds in accordance with their own choices and in the best possible circumstances, or to arrange care for the existing seniors in the family, making the best possible use of their social and material resources so they can remain at home and keep on taking part in household and community dynamics. Clara also works with families and seniors to help settle conflicts, make decisions and avoid the difficulties that often arise throughout the caregiving process, especially for those who depend on others for survival. To do this, Clara meets with the elderly and their families to help them design a plan according to their specific needs and outsource qualified personnel to attend to them (usually psychologists, physiotherapists and nurses who are trusted because Clara has worked with them in the past and is familiar with the quality of their work). The organization also helps its clients engage in social activities so that they remain motivated and active.

•  It helps design projects and provides consultancy. In order to benefit more seniors and fulfill its goal of improving the overall model of care, Clara decided to diversify its clients as much as possible. In addition to families, it began offering consulting services to both public and private nursing homes, day centers and care services. Clara guides them to improve the working conditions of staff (who usually work in very precarious circumstances) and trains them to provide quality care. It also counsels them on how to plan for services, spaces and activities that maximize the resources and opportunities of the seniors they work with (as well as their families’) so they may live their old age in a more dignified and autonomous way, in accordance with their own wishes, decisions and habits. For instance, Clara encourages care centers to collaborate with nearby organizations and businesses to design activities that help seniors stay involved in their community, engage with other generations, and maintain a relevant role that motivates them and prevents them from being isolated or discriminated against because of their age.

• It organizes workshops and spaces for reflection with students and people of all ages to think about the issue of old age as a process that we will all face, to question stereotypes about the elderly, and to raise awareness about the culture of care in Spain and the precarious situation in which most caregivers live. Clara organizes some of these workshops with local authorities to share its experiences and professional insights, to advocate and to promote its work.

Since the launch of the project, Clara's founders asked for support from a government business incubator called Barcelona Activa, which helped them connect with other actors and rent an inexpensive space in a gallery shared by several social projects, as well as providing them with training to launch their initiative. Although these trainings helped them boost their project, it was experience what taught them it was not a good idea to appoint themselves a salary when the project was just getting started and lacked enough funds. Experience has shown that, at least until the project takes off, they will have to work part-time at some other job to cover their personal living expenses and dedicate the remaining time to the Clara project. Also, they have learned that they will have to charge their work on an hourly basis for a while (which they figure out by keeping a "Time Tracker") and allocate at least 17% of the profits to incubate their initiative.

Today, Innan and a new person are Clara's partners, and they have a core team of professionals (psychologists, physiotherapists, nurses, among others) whom they subcontract when projects come up. That is to say that if a family asks for their help and is in need of, say, psychological support, the partners contact the psychologist in their team and pay for it themselves (because in the end Clara is the one offering the service and is ultimately responsible for it). Since these professionals are not partners but freelancers, Clara is looking for more people who are interested in becoming partners and who have ideas, projects, capital or clients ––people who are prepared to charge per project, at least for a while.

With the legal advice and training provided by Coopolis, Ateneu Cooperativo de Barcelona (a government agency in charge of promoting solidarity economy policies and organizations at the local level), Clara decided to legally register as a " work cooperative". This is because although the process is expensive (you must pay an accountant and a notary and you need to have seed capital), having a formal registration will enable the partners to, in the long run, earn enough money to live off of this business they are passionate about and even create jobs. In addition, Clara chose to register as a " work cooperative" instead of as a "company" or "for-profit cooperative" because being a non-profit entity would make it easier to access public grants for the Solidarity Economy sector. This would also give Clara more legitimacy in connecting with people in this particular community who, having a similar ideological approach, could support the project with resources, collaborations or ideas. This community has very few projects working with older adults, which would allow Clara to fill a niche and perhaps even get clients, both among the members of this sector (who tend to consume each other’s services and products) and among people who hire solidarity economy services because of their affinity with their work methods and principles.

In fact, one of the first things Clara did when it was set up was to become a member of the Federation of Worker Cooperatives of Catalonia, which functions as a professional association that provides them with consultancy services and has also helped them make themselves known and connect with other like-minded projects and people. It also takes part in the Solidarity Economy Fairs organized by the Solidarity Economy Network XES to promote its work.

The collaboration with Coopolis is also helping Clara get clients, as the institution has been coordinating a working group among care initiatives that is meeting frequently to identify who among the solidarity economy network, the government, and elsewhere might be interested in getting to know them, channeling beneficiaries to their projects, or recommending them.

Today, Clara subsists on the fees for its services (assistance to families, co-design of spaces, consultancies, talks and workshops to political actors, schools and others) and on the grants it gets by competing in public calls for proposals with projects developed in collaboration with other organizations. The intention is not to depend on public grants in the future because, although Clara's work profile makes them elegible, these are very labor-intensive, require a lot of management, take a long time and provide few resources. Clara's goal is to subsist on the services offered to private clients because these are paid on the spot and allow for a much freer approach to the project. And perhaps, if it can raise enough money, Clara might one day compete for government contracts, which normally only large companies have a chance at winning.

title: Songshan UNESCO Global Geopark · China
introduction:
info 2018

The Songshan Mountains in China are invaluable for their natural and cultural wealth. These beautiful mountains in Henan Province, are known to experts as a “geological encyclopedia”. The geological history of the earth can be readily deciphered on these mountains: 3.5 billion years of geological strata and three major tectonic movements are clearly visible in the unique profiles of its cliffs.

Here, the oldest astronomical observation platform in China can be found, as well as the largest and best maintained pagoda forest in the country. Its innumerable temples and monasteries, many of them recognized as World Heritage sites, have witnessed the development of Confucianism as well as the birth of Taoism and Zen Buddhism, with its Shaolin monks, whose philosophy and martial arts have impacted the cultural life of much of China and the world.

Therefore, the great challenge of the Chinese government has been to design policies that help reduce the poverty of its population without harming the geological and cultural wealth of the region.

 

How can poverty be alleviated while protecting nature and culture?
short_description: Songshan UNESCO Global Geopark protects and studies a beautiful geological area in whose mountains the history of the earth is written. It also safeguards a mosaic of Taoist, Buddhist and Confucianist cultures. The geopark brings tangible economic benefits to the local population, who has found in geological and cultural tourism an alternative to poverty and an opportunity to create and strengthen their cultural bonds with the world.

paragraphs.body_html: In 2001 the Chinese government created Songshan National Park, one of the country's first national parks, to research and protect this area and its cultures while promoting the development of local communities through tourism. By 2004, Songshan had succeeded in forging a model worthy of certification as a UNESCO Global Geopark.

But what is this UNESCO certification about?

UNESCO Global Geoparks are reserves that protect areas of geological and natural value while empowering local communities, supporting their development and promoting their cultural identity. To obtain this certification, the park must submit a comprehensive plan that includes research and education in geology and the environment; the economic and cultural development of local communities, empowerment of women, and cooperation with other parks in the Global Geoparks Network. As the UNESCO certification is not accompanied by funding, local and national governments are also required to guarantee sustained economic support.

Songshan UNESCO Global Geopark (嵩山世界地质公园) is perfect for implementing a successful model for conservation, research, cultural exchange and tourism. In addition to its geological and natural beauty, the geopark is home to the following attractions:

  • The Museum of Geology, that receives visits from students of all ages, the younger ones as part of programs for ecological awareness and the older ones as part of their university education, especially in Earth Sciences.
  • The Shaolin Temple, that is probably the most important attraction of the place, because of its shows and the training in martial arts and Buddhism that it offers to thousands of students from China and the rest of the world. As the cradle of kung-fu, the temple organizes an international martial arts festival every four years with parades and exhibitions, which attracts a large number of visitors.
  • The Zhongyue Taoist Temple, that is the best preserved architectural complex of this ancient culture, and is also host to several centuries-old trees.
  • The Confucian Songyuan Academy, that attracts, among others, students from all over the country who are looking for a source of inspiration and luck for their university entrance exams.

In addition, the park boasts a scenic cable car ride through the mountains, as well as the astronomical observatory, many temples and pagodas, and camping areas.
To receive the UNESCO certification, the geopark presented a detailed plan full of self-sustainability strategies, which it has so far implemented successfully:

• Mapping, planning and integral design of the project. The park authorities evaluated the local geological resources of potential tourist interest, as well as the human, aquifer, forest, environmental, artistic and cultural resources of the area. Once the resources were mapped, they designed an integral development model, giving equal value to the environmental, economic and social benefits of the park. They also used this information to design the infrastructure: transportation services and a sustainable supply of resources such as electricity, telecommunications, and water. This mapping also allowed them to detect the need for and facilitate the design of lookouts, the cable car and audio guides.

• Natural and cultural protection. Besides being a UNESCO Global Geopark, Songshan is also officially a Scenic Area and a Forest Park, which guarantees its protection under Chinese law. This has allowed the park authorities to regulate mining, close factories, and control the exploitation of natural resources within the reserve, and also to protect the cultural heritage of the villages, moderating their development. They are also working to restore the use of the land to the local communities, planning the growth of the surrounding urban areas, and creating laws for the protection and management of geological and natural relics.

• Education. Songshan Geopark has a plan for all levels of education. It created the Geology Museum, which receives school visits to educate students and visitors about geology and the environment. It also established partnerships with universities to contribute to university education and generate research projects in earth sciences. It also trains the local population on preventive measures for possible natural disasters that might happen in the region. But the geopark's educational project goes beyond the earth sciences, it also includes education about and dissemination of native cultures and their manifestations such as Kung-fu and Taoism.

• Improve the quality of life of the community. The geopark has allowed local communities to generate their own jobs by providing tourist services (accommodation, transport, food, guide, etc). Their activities are only sparsely regulated, and the prices of their services are not controlled. Local inhabitants have free access to the geopark (although limited in the case of the Shaolin Temple due to the large number of visitors). Plenty of resources have been allocated for the maintenance of traditional villages, so many villagers rent out their homes to visitors.

• Shared management and financing. Much of the success of the geopark is due to the extensive and consistent public funding it has received since its inception. And even so, the geopark has devised many ways not to depend 100% on this financing. Administration is shared between Defeng's government, the forest park's managers, the scenic area and the geopark. The government agency Hong Kong-China Songshan Travel Company is in charge of investing in everything related to tourism: cable cars, tickets, toilets, shops, etc. Part of the profit is kept by the company and part is distributed among the other sections of the geopark. Tickets for the Geology Museum and the astronomical observation platform are free of charge. The remaining sites charge a small fee for maintenance, as well as to limit the number of visitors and to control the ecological impact on the area. The project is also financially supported by taxes paid by the small businesses that live off of tourism revenue.

• Cooperation with other parks. Being part of the Global Geoparks Network has greatly benefited Songshan through its exchange with other geoparks in the network. For example, they have learned new ways of teaching children, and improved on them, creating special books and techniques. The cultural exchange and networking is especially valuable because China was closed to the outside world for a long time, and the international exposure granted by the UNESCO label attracts many more tourists. Through this network, they have also been able to scale up their model by guiding other parks through their validation processes and by sharing their experience.

In 2007 Songshan Geopark was recognized as one of the 248 most important and best maintained tourist attractions nationwide (according to the 5A certification of the Ministry of Tourism and Culture of China).

China is the country that has the most parks registered under the UNESCO certification (35 of its more than 240 national geoparks until 2017). This is due to the extensive efforts made by the State for the self-sustainable economic management of natural protected areas through a model like Songshan’s: long-term public investment to build the ecotourism infrastructure, private companies to take care of management, and local communities to offer tourist services and conservation.

title: Seoul Innovation Park · South Korea
introduction:
info 2022

In Korea, as in many countries, half of the population lives in the capital city, Seoul, because that’s where there are more opportunities to make money and more access to doctors, schools, etc. Cities make it easier to share resources and services, but they also demand a lot of work and creativity to ensure that people have a good quality of life: that they have access to food, are safe from danger, have access to water, etc.

 

 

How to facilitate constant creativity and innovation to address the many needs of the city?
short_description: The Seoul Innovation Park is a project launched by the Seoul Government in South Korea to motivate citizens to help it resolve the city's problems by building innovative solutions and collaborating. The Park offers citizens the use of its facilities and workshops, support from different government agencies, and the organization of bonding events and activities.

paragraphs.body_html: When in 2010 the Korean Center for Disease Control and Prevention (KCDC) left its 100,000 square meter facilities in Seoul to move to another province, an intense debate began about how to capitalize on such a huge area, since space in that mega city is highly coveted. Some thought it could be put to good use by developing real estate or commercial ventures, but fortunately, the idea that won was that of the well-known activist and then-mayor, Won-soon Park (who also created the Beautiful Stores): the Seoul government would give that area to the citizens so they could gather, socialize, and help explore and develop innovative proposals to address the city's problems—especially its lack of self-sufficiency in food and energy.
This gave birth to the Seoul Innovation Park (서울혁신파크), a project launched in 2015 to promote societal collaboration in solving the city's problems, utilizing various strategies such as:

1. It lends its facilities for people to gather

To facilitate people meeting, enjoying and working together, the Park has designed three types of spaces: 1. Those open to the public - outdoor areas, cafes, spaces that can be rented for meetings, and others that are free to use, such as rooftop terraces that people can book for events like weddings or meetings, etc. 2. Offices, conference and meeting rooms that the Park rents out to "residents" or "tenants", i.e., collectives and organizations that the Park selects (two per year) if they demonstrate in their application that they are not seeking to profit and have a project to address social needs related to the Park's priorities (Seoul's energy and food self-sufficiency) or sustainable development goals. Today, the Park houses projects related to education, environmental protection, energy, manufacturing, architecture, human rights, and many more topics. One of them, for example, is the Odyssey School, which teaches high school students about social change and innovation through practical experiences during one year, with the help of teachers who are or have been entrepreneurs, many of them residents of the same Park. 3. Workshops that offer facilities and machinery that citizens can use if they demonstrate their commitment to use them for social good instead of personal profit. Examples of such workshops include the carpentry workshop and the plastic recycling workshop. These workshops are staffed by professionals who provide courses, guide visitors, and organize tours for students to learn about innovative ways of using materials to prevent waste. Residents can also utilize these spaces and resources to fulfill their own project needs. To take advantage of all these spaces, the Park provides parking lots, ATMs, a post office, lactation rooms, etc. available to all.

1. Supports the work of innovators.

 

At its facilities, the Park has opened branches of several government agencies (such as the Seoul Social Housing Support Center, the Seoul Co-op Support Center, the Seoul Northwest District Working Mom Support Center, etc.) to serve as Support Entities for residents that assist them and promote multisectoral projects such as the Energy Transition initiative, in which they are exploring alternatives to reduce energy loss in old buildings, for example.

The Seoul government hires a private company to manage the Innovation Park and coordinate all this work. The Seoul Innovation Center, as this company is called, is responsible for managing the space, organizing activities and awareness campaigns with citizens (vegan fairs to raise environmental awareness with fun activities, for example), convening support offices, selecting residents, and coordinating collaborative projects to support them.

As a project of the city government, the financial sustainability and very existence of Seoul Innovation Park depend on the political will of the government officials in power at the time. Firstly, because the Park operates with a public budget assigned by the government and has no own resources, as the rents received from the cafeteria and residents for the use of the space, parking fees, etc., have to be returned to the authorities. Additionally, because if a party without affinity to its project or with other interests takes over the government, it could terminate the project and assign the space to someone else. For this reason, the Park community is exploring ways to demonstrate that innovation takes time and that the networks and initiatives that have emerged from this project so far are very valuable for the city.

title: Union of Tosepan Cooperatives · Mexico
introduction:
info 2022
