For hundreds of years, the rural and indigenous communities living in the mountains of northeastern Puebla, Mexico, have been confronted by people who want to take over their lands and exploit their natural resources. Early on it was the conquistadors, then the large landowners and more recently it has been governments and national and international companies looking to carry out projects that have little to do with local needs without even consulting the communities, such as large-scale hotels or big retailers like Walmart that jeopardize small, local businesses. These have also insisted on installing hydroelectric and mining projects that pollute local waters and land. On top of this, caciques and middlemen have long monopolized the export market for regional products, as well as political institutions and the sale of products within the communities. They pay producers a pittance and sell overpriced staple foods on the grounds that getting them to the highlands is too difficult.  To make matters worse, most official authorities have privileged these external interests and visions of development, ignoring the demands of local populations, repressing them when they protest and stripping them of their resources. This has increased their poverty (more than 60% of the population earns less than the minimum wage!) and pushed them to migrate in search of better opportunities.

 

 

How to meet the needs of rural and indigenous communities and promote the kind of development they want?
short_description: The Union of Tosepan Cooperatives comprises more than 400 cooperatives of rural and indigenous communities in the highlands of Puebla and Veracruz in Mexico, all working together to develop projects to improve each community's quality of life in a way that is comprehensive and in keeping with their own aspirations. These projects include establishing common cooperatives to supply themselves with basic products and to sell their crops without intermediaries; to save money and loan it among the communities themselves; to defend their territory against external mega-projects; to train themselves to be able to implement projects and to improve housing. They have also built health centers and an intercultural school.

paragraphs.body_html: In 1977, a group of around 700 small scale farmers from 5 communities organized to demand that sugar be supplied at affordable prices for their families. The few stores that sold sugar in their villages charged up to 6 times the official price, and sometimes only sold it on condition that other products were also purchased. Not getting a response from the sellers in the region, who did not want to lose their profits, the farmers got new suppliers in Mexico City and opened cooperative stores in their communities to be able to distribute the sugar. This organized action, which cut out the middlemen and gave them access to sugar at a much lower price, was so successful that they soon did the same with other staple goods and multiplied their cooperative stores, which by 1980 had spread to more than 30 communities. In this process, they got the support of agronomists that the government had originally sent to assist them in agricultural technologies. The model of these basic commodity stores worked so well that the federal government helped them replicate it in several nearby communities and, indeed, in different remote areas of the country. When the communities realized that the government wanted to take more and more control over the program and that the need for basic goods was relatively satisfied in their region, they preferred to move away from the grocery store project and instead focus on strengthening their own capacity to produce food to supply their families without relying on outside products so heavily, and to market it to other regions without having to go through middlemen who bought it from them on the spot, but at predatory prices.

Because getting credit and government support to do this was virtually impossible, in 1980 they decided to once again bet on the organization among communities and start their new project by legally registering their movement as the Regional Agricultural Cooperative Tosepan Titataniske ("Tosepan Titataniske" means "United We Shall Overcome" in Nahuat, the local language).

The communities of the Tosepan Cooperative started off by growing and marketing pepper but soon realized that to avoid depending too heavily on the fate of this crop (market prices, harvesting success, and so on), they would have to diversify their production. So they started growing, gathering and marketing coffee, oranges, zapote, mamey and other foods from small producers in the region, and managed to get better prices for them. They also encouraged backyard orchards for family use and, with the support of the government agronomists and other external and local advisors, they worked to improve farming techniques and to adapt and develop innovative ecological technologies for production (such as vermicomposting).

The Tosepan Titataniske Cooperative soon became a kind of parent cooperative that raises resources to help incubate other cooperatives and local projects to become profitable and economically self-sufficient. Having seen the merits of organizing to solve common problems, the communities soon came up with more and more projects to address the needs of the region. Thus, from the original cooperative sprang new cooperatives with projects aimed at solving different concrete needs.

In 1997, for instance, communities created the cooperative "Maseual Xicaualis" ("Indigenous Force" in Nahuat) to stockpile and transform their products, and to create links to be able to certify and market them abroad.

Also, because bank loans were almost completely unavailable for their communities, a year later 1,266 people from 41 different communities pooled together $636,000 pesos of their own money to create a "savings fund" that would allow them to meet family or community contingencies without going into debt (difficulties with crops, natural disasters, health problems, and so on). The cooperative they created to manage and foster this fund (called "Tosepan Tomin", "Everybody's Money" in Nahuat) looked for advice and training to learn how to manage the project and soon was able to also make loans, which attracted many new communities where the cooperative opened more and more branches. As this initiative grew, the banking authorities forced the cooperative to legally formalize its operations. Tosepan agreed because, although it was a complicated and time-consuming process, this would give its members greater certainty that the money they were investing was in good hands. The savings and loan fund was so successful that by 2018 it had $405 million pesos in savings, $385 million in loans and more than 36,000 members from 441 communities that until then didn’t get financial services. Although other private services are now lending to these populations, many people still prefer Tosepan because it does not charge them commissions, it offers them a higher interest rate and it has designed products that adequately respond to their needs and that seek to improve their quality of life and that of their communities, such as life insurance, remittance payments, and savings funds for children, retirees and festivities. It also offers credits that can be paid on dates set according to the economic capacity of each person and according to the objectives of the loan (for instance, the time it takes to harvest a given crop). Some of the loans are intended for production, for women, for emergencies, for health, or to build or rehabilitate houses. On rare occasions the cooperative seeks external financing to be able to offer loans such as the housing ones, but in reality its savings fund model has worked because of two main strategies: The first is to operate mainly with the members' savings, that is, with money from the communities themselves (members contribute at least $600 pesos to be able to join and use the cooperative's services and if they decide to leave they get their money back). The second strategy is to bet on trust, since the cooperative provides loans to people who other financial institutions reject because they lack economic backing. To guarantee repayment, the cooperative makes use of what they call a "solidarity credit" methodology: people who apply for a loan first have to ask permission from their community, and if the community approves and endorses them (because they know them personally and know their history), then the cooperative passes their application on to a credit committee for loan approval. If the person fails to repay, the cooperative may ask the community to talk to them and help them solve their problem, or to back them up by paying on their behalf to preserve the chance of getting future support. Such a situation will be avoided at all costs by the borrower so as to avoid getting in trouble with their community.

Because creating cooperatives such as these required a great deal of knowledge that had previously been foreign to the communities, in 2003 the Tosepan created a new cooperative in the town of Cuetzalan (the "Kaltaixpetaniloyan", "The house where the spirit opens" in Nahuat) to set up a training center that would prepare the cooperatives' members and managers to carry out their projects. Nowadays the cooperative also offers training at a cost to outside people, organizations or cooperatives interested in Tosepan's experience and uses the profits from these trainings to finance the training center's operations.

And in order to provide food and lodging for the cooperative members who attend these trainings or other Tosepan meetings, they opened the cooperative "Tosepan Kali" ("Our house" in Nahuat) the following year, through which they bought a plot of land and built a hotel. This same cooperative would soon have new tasks. First of all, welcoming tourists to cover the hotel's expenses (taking advantage of the fact that Cuetzalan is a very popular destination). Also, the hotel became something of a testing ground for the other cooperatives, where they explore new ideas and see what works and what doesn't, before scaling them up. As an example, they tested ecological technologies (solar panels, rainwater harvesting, and others) that would later be replicated in the sustainable housing program.  And cooperatives that sell products will sometimes first offer them to hotel guests to see how well they are received before promoting them elsewhere. Nowadays, the Tosepan Kali is also looking to promote ecotourism opportunities in the villages that are involved with Tosepan (with projects such as the "cinnamon route") and to help the communities host visitors.

As for the sustainable housing program, in 2006 the Tosepan decided to form a cooperative called "Tichanchiuaj" ("Together we build our houses" in Nahuat) to be able to get hold of and supply the communities with durable, well-priced and preferably locally manufactured construction materials to build and rehabilitate their houses. Another goal was also to help incorporate family orchards and green technologies (for the use and exploitation of solar energy and rainwater, recycling of agricultural waste, and so on) in order to make the best use of them.

In 2008, the communities decided to create the "Tosepan Ojtatsentekitinij" ("Together we work bamboo" in Nahuat) to produce and transform bamboo for different uses (such as homes in the housing program) and in 2009 the women of the region succeeded in launching their own cooperative (the "Tosepan Siuamej", "Women united" in Nahuat) to produce and market products that would not only give them some economic independence, but also ease their household chores giving them more time for themselves and their projects. They bought, for instance, machines to make tortillas, mills, and other items.

Because public health services (doctors and drugs) were insufficient, in 2009 the communities formed the cooperative "Tosepan Pajti" ("Health is life for all" in Nahuat). Through it, they have opened health centers in several communities where they perform clinical analyses, offer drugs at a low cost and provide medical assistance with the support of intern doctors who carry out their internships there thanks to agreements that the cooperative has signed with universities. Also, the cooperative trained a group of health promoters who have the task of approaching the communities, organizing hygiene campaigns and health days, giving workshops and making home visits, all with the intent of preventing illness rather than only treating it. These home visits are very important because promoters encourage each family to appoint their own health "guardian" to look out for situations that could be putting the health of family members at risk (such as poor hygiene habits, nutrition, garbage management, household upkeep, and others); the guardian then passes the report on to the promoters. Based on this information, the promoters provide support to families by leveraging resources from different Tosepan cooperatives to provide care in a comprehensive way by, for instance, offering health credits, medical care, economic support to improve housing conditions, and other services.
Some years later, in 2017, the cooperative "Pisilnekmej" ("small bees" in Nahuat) was also launched to produce and market honey.

To further consolidate the different cooperatives and support their work, Tosepan formed the civil association "Yeknemilis" ("Good Life" in Nahuat) in 2002, which is focused on providing them with technical assistance and running the Training Center. Also, with the same goal in mind, in 2012 it founded the radio station "Tosepan Limakxtux" ("Our Universe" in Nahuat) to broadcast the work being done among the communities. Since by law the Tosepan Savings Fund can only make loans to individuals and not to cooperatives, that same year it also created the "Tosepan Foundation". This Foundation would help secure financing and subsidies to help primarily those cooperatives that have difficulty making their own resources, such as the Health project. And it would also support the school that the communities in Cuetzalan opened in 2006 to promote the cooperative culture among the new generations and to combine formal education with agricultural and entrepreneurial activities so that children might consider the possibility of staying in their communities when they finish school instead of migrating, or returning to help improve them in the future. Nowadays, the school "Tosepan Kalnemachtiloyan" ("The school belongs to everyone" in Nahuat) serves around 100 children with the support of teachers who originally came to do their professional internships as teacher trainees and then decided to stay. Its system is accredited by the National Council for the Promotion of Education (CONAFE) and is similar to the Montessori system, teaching preschool through high school in the local language as well as in Spanish. The school also encourages cooperation between families so that children have a better diet, as parents have to take turns preparing nutritious meals and financing them.

Because diversifying the cooperatives has been aimed at addressing the different needs of the member communities in a comprehensive way (their health, economic needs, and so on), in 2007 the organization decided to become the Union of Tosepan Cooperatives (Unión de Cooperativas Tosepan), which would help the cooperatives coordinate, share their resources and support each other (the hotel would help the producers test their products, the marketing company would help sell them, the savings and loans fund would help build houses, the Tichanchiuaj cooperative would help get materials, and so on). Since then, the Union encourages the training of each of the cooperatives to improve the quality of their services and to ensure they are always relevant to local needs. To this end, the Union gives each of them a large measure of organizational and financial autonomy, and supports the training of their members so that they are less and less reliant on outside experts. It also seeks to ease their work by tackling many of the common obstacles.

To create better conditions for the cooperatives' work and for life in the communities in general, Tosepan frequently bids for contracts to build public works such as the school, and to rehabilitate and build roads, among others.

It also devotes a great deal of effort to encourage the communities to organize to defend their territory from growing delinquency, local abusive leaders, big enterprises and extractive projects such as mining, hydroelectric plants or fracking. To do so, it has used a host of different strategies. Among the most important ones is the involvement, together with other organizations and local authorities, in the creation of the Cuetzalan Integral Territorial Planning Committee (COTIC), an organization that aims to regulate the use of the territory, and in which the communities make up the majority and make decisions that authorities have to comply with. Together with COTIC, Tosepan helped draft a land-use plan, which is a legal instrument through which they jointly defined the permitted and non-permitted uses of their territory, setting limits to the mega-projects that would usually undertake activities without even consulting them. With this ordinance, the communities are better protected because they have more tools to fight back through institutional channels (placing legal safeguards, say) against companies or governments that launch projects without obeying their terms and conditions (because they would be incurring in an illegal act). Another similar strategy was put together with the Tiyat Tlali Council, another group they created to join forces with organizations from other parts of the highlands to defend the territory of more than 200 towns. Together they established local defense committees and declared their region "free of extractive projects" with the aim of setting a precedent in case companies or institutions have intentions of undertaking operations in their territory.

But besides all this, Tosepan has organized many activities to stop interventions that the communities consider detrimental to their lands, their economy or their health. To name a few, they have held sit-ins, marches, encampments, blockades, occupation of town halls, forums and informative caravans to warn the communities about the risks of entering into deals with the companies. Furthermore, since political parties normally back interests that are foreign to the communities, the Union of Cooperatives has also used the strategy of running independent candidates in local elections to defend its interests.

By 2022, the work of the Union and its cooperatives had attracted more than 40,000 members organized in 430 local cooperatives in the highlands of Puebla and the state of Veracruz. Local cooperatives are formed when they apply to join the Union of Cooperatives, jointly explore the options for linking its programs to the demands of their community, learn about its rules, and form a local board of directors, usually with people who are trusted by the community and whose social work is widely recognized.

Such widespread participation has been possible thanks to the Union's sophisticated organizational system: after meeting with community members to learn about their proposals and needs, each local cooperative appoints a delegate who has one vote in the General Assembly of Delegates, which meets once a month (on market days) in the town of Cuetzalan to make joint decisions (such as the creation of new cooperatives or the implementation of training courses in response to needs raised at the Assembly). This Assembly is the highest authority of the organization and it holds discussions on the suggestions and concerns of the sister cooperatives (the savings fund, the health cooperative, the women cooperative, and so on), as well as those of the civil associations, the school, and the various local cooperatives. On some occasions, the Assembly considers work proposals submitted to the Union of Cooperatives from outside groups, or invites local authorities and candidates to share their projects to see if Tosepan supports them or not.

Because the Union of Cooperatives has grown so much, assemblies are now held not only in Nahuat but also in Tutunaku and Spanish so that all attendees can participate. The Assembly has a Management Board and an Oversight Board (which monitors compliance with the agreements reached), which are democratically elected by all the members after following a long and careful validation process. The process involves, first of all, collectively outlining the regional development plan that everyone wants for the communities. Then, the communities nominate people they believe can carry out this plan. After taking a training course on the work of Tosepan, these community nominees then submit their proposals to the Assembly so that delegates can choose the most suitable people.

With the support of its Training Center, Tosepan has formed a group of people called "promoters" who are also nominated by the communities. Like the health promoters, these promoters must also speak the local language as well as Spanish, and are in charge of helping organize the communities, providing technical assistance to members, and linking them to services offered by the sister cooperatives (bringing them, for instance, the products of the savings fund with a device they call Tosepanmóvil, or handing out piggy banks to children so they can start their own savings fund). For this reason, promoters play a very important role in integrating the different projects of the Union of Cooperatives, grounding them in the communities and drawing new participants in.

The Union of Tosepan Cooperatives project has shown the enormous potential that organization among communities has to improve their quality of life and promote local development on their own terms. With this project, the communities in the northern highlands of Puebla and part of Veracruz have enabled thousands of families to solve many of their needs with their own resources and labor, access various products and services, sell their crops and products at a better price, make better use of their local resources and create jobs within the communities themselves (building houses, repairing roads, teaching courses, and so on).

The required use of local languages in all the services provided by the sister cooperatives, in assemblies and at school has not only helped reappraise and revitalize these languages, but has also brought information and attention to more people, since the majority of the local population is indigenous.

The training courses, the cooperatives and the school have all been preparing the new generations of cooperative members who will uphold and enhance the communities' project in the future. The outstanding processes of democratic participation of the population in the cooperatives' projects and the partnerships with universities, social organizations, independent experts and other communities have set the grounds for gradually solving many of the concrete needs that concern members, and for improving their quality of life in a comprehensive way, in keeping with their needs and aspirations, and with a focus on regional development, all of which are Tosepan's objectives.

Collective action has enabled Tosepan communities to protect their territory and jointly plan the path they want to follow. In this regard, in 2017 the Union of Cooperatives spent almost a year putting together a wide survey among all its thousands of members, community by community, to identify their vision and hopes for the next 40 years of the project and, from this, drew the main lines of action on which it is currently working (food sovereignty, protection of territory, autonomy to organize, decent housing, and so on).

title: Upsala Circus · Russia
introduction:
info 2019

As in many parts of the world, some children and teens in Russia are particularly vulnerable because they endure economic hardship, violence or disabilities –all of which may affect their quality of life and restrict their options for the future. And although we now understand how important play and creativity are for the physical and emotional development of children, spaces for recreation, growth and community are often out of reach for these very kids. In other words, the young, vulnerable people whose development could benefit the most from these activities often have the least access to them.

 

How to foster the wholesome development of children and a life free from poverty and violence for them?
short_description: Upsala Circus teaches circus skills to vulnerable children and teens, enriching their physical, intellectual and emotional development, and fostering opportunities for their future.

paragraphs.body_html: The young Russian and German artists who created Upsala Circus (упсала чирк) believed in the potential of the performing arts to improve people's lives, strengthen communities and foster solid support networks. They also knew that although theater and circus promote people's emotional development, they are not accessible to everyone. So, in 2000, they started working with homeless children in St. Petersburg by organizing workshops and putting together physical and artistic activities for kids.

When the state took it upon itself to build shelters, the number of homeless children decreased, and Upsala decided to focus its work on kids and teens facing poverty, violence and disability in general. The Upsala team was convinced that the performing arts –particularly the circus– are wonderful grounds on which to build communication skills, social tools and even physical competencies like aerial acrobatics, hip hop and break dancing, all of which are great means of channeling concerns and confusions. These sets of skills even give children and teens options to find employment later in life as circus performers, trainers, choreographers, professional artists, show directors, and so on.

The teaching philosophy that guides Upsala’s workshops and programs stresses values such as the desire to improve, acceptance of oneself and others, the ability to set things in motion, as well as health and safety. In fact, when it comes to evaluating how effective the programs are, Upsala uses these values as criteria to assesses its impact on the lives of kids.

Upsala Circus is registered in Russia as a non-commercial Charity Organization with 25 workers (designers, trainers, administrators and others). The Upsala team has created five distinct Programs that aim to be relevant to different groups of children and teens, each offering specific paths for development:

• The Circus Rebels. Upsala approaches schools attended by marginalized children to identify, in tandem with authorities and parents, who could most benefit from its project. Circus Rebels then offers professional training for young people in their area of choice: circus performers, choreographers, professional artists, teachers, trainers or show directors.

• The Pakitain. It is a creative center for children and teens with special needs (mostly Down syndrome and sometimes autism), which has been running since 2016 as an integrated complement to the Circus Rebels program. Kids learn choreography, break dancing and acrobatic skills, among others.

• The Professional Artists Program. After rigorous tests, some of the graduates of the Circus Rebels program join this professional circus team that performs in St. Petersburg and abroad. In other words, this is a source of employment for the "rebel" graduates of its training program when they come of age, should they choose circus as a livelihood.

• Street Art Festivals. Upsala organizes free outdoor festivals once a year and invites artists from other street circuses. This helps promote and shed light on their project, as well as reach communities that do not always have access to art and spectacle.
• Circus Teacher Training School. To scale the scope of its project up, Upsala imparts short courses once or twice a year to underground circus teachers and trainers.

To better serve the kids who participate in the programs, Upsala also helps their families with paperwork to qualify for some public services, by donating clothes and basic necessities, offering medical services, and more. Upsala also offers them personalized meetings to tackle specific problems such as their children's health, school performance, behavioral problems, moments of crisis, care for children with special needs and more.

Upsala’s awareness raising activities with the larger population help create a more supportive environment for the children in the programs. One example of this is the flea market put together with local kids to make them aware of the importance of supporting less fortunate children: participants sell second-hand items, food or artistic creations made by themselves, and donate 50% to the Upsala Circus project. Another example is their partaking, in 2018, in a meeting of teenage circus performers from Syria, Afghanistan, Russia and Germany who came together to talk about their lives and how they face the world's problems beyond any racial or socioeconomic differences. The meeting involved documentary theater, circus and art labs. In addition, Upsala organizes concerts and festivals and creates promotional videos and publications to disseminate its project, raise awareness of the issues it works on and gain more support (such as new volunteers, donors and collaborators).

To be able to offer training and activities for at-risk children and teens free of charge, Upsala has had to look for different sources of support. Some of its funds come from the ticket sales of its circus performances, and others from fees paid by the professionals who enroll on its Circus Teacher Training School. In addition, the project makes the most of its social awareness events (such as the flea market or its concerts and festivals) to raise new financial or in-kind support. And it also gets donations, but usually tries to get them from foundations and businesses rather than the government, since public funds often come with too many rules and restrictions.

Upsala sometimes offers some services in exchange for financial support, such as circus videos that companies and businesses can use in their publicity. In addition, Upsala raises funds from sponsors and business partners, and has teamed up with companies that write texts for and organize crowdfunding campaigns with no charge (or take a commission from the donations themselves). Both Upsala and these companies promote information about events through social media (Facebook, Instagram, Youtube) as well as other media to attract more collaboration.
Finally, Upsala raises a lot of its funds through donations via the online platform that its team designed for this purpose, or even by text message!

To maintain the support of its collaborators, Upsala goes to great lengths to convey transparency in the management of its resources and, to this end, publishes monthly graphs and diagrams that clearly show how every contribution has been put to use (payments to professionals and administrative personnel, support for kids and their families, maintenance, festivals and trips, stage design and rehearsals, etc.).

Two other important sources of support that account for the project’s success are, first, the volunteers who take part in the programs and, second, the donation of the property where the circus is located, contributed by a businessman back in 2002. Thanks to a crowdfunding campaign, the Upsala team gathered enough funds to build a tent and other facilities on the property, which has enabled their initiative of integration and social justice to develop and grow.

Nowadays, the Upsala team is attempting to scale their project up through their Circus Teacher Training School program. The idea is that graduates will take on and promote their new circus philosophy throughout Russia.

title: Cabins The Refuge · Mexico
introduction:
info 2016

The accelerated pace of city life and a lack of contact with nature have a negative effect on the health of many people. But despite this, 50% of the world’s population currently lives in urban areas. There are many reasons why this is the case, but it often has to do with having access to employment opportunities and services that allow people to support themselves economically.

 

 

How to create a healthier, financially sustainable way of life outside the city?
short_description: Cabins The Refuge is an alternative rural tourism project that uses means such as barter, ecological technologies and courses to sustain itself while promoting healthier life experiences and projects.

paragraphs.body_html: In 1999, a family from the Mexican city of Puebla decided to move to a beautiful mountain town called Zacatlan de las Manzanas to get away from city life and to create Cabins The Refuge (Cabañas El Refugio), an alternative rural tourism project that would allow them to subsist while promoting a better quality of life for themselves and for their visitors.

To start off the project, the family got support from their relatives to buy land and successfully participated in calls for proposals to get public funding. The issue with public funding, however, is that it is hard to get and, even though the resources themselves often take a long time to get delivered, results must be presented on a very strict schedule as a requirement for future support. So ––in order to deliver results on time and open the door to more funding in the future–– the family did not wait to actually receive the money they had secured and, instead, began to make the most of local resources to advance the project as much as possible while the public funding was in the pipeline: They learned about local bio-construction techniques and began to build a set of cabins with local materials (straw, earth, and so on) for visitors to lodge.

Once it got the funding, The Refuge took advantage of the fact that the money was non-refundable (which means that the project did not have to pay it back but only prove it had made good use of the funds) to bet on creative and risky ideas that would help the project become more self-sufficient in the future and depend less on external support: The Refuge got a wind generator and solar panels, for instance, to build a hybrid energy system in conjunction with the electric current installations of the Federal Electricity Commission (CFE in Spanish). The project’s vision was that ––because electricity is more stable than alternative energies–– the combination of these different sources would help avoid supply failures, since electricity would be available when the other energy sources were not working. And this idea would also help reduce expenses in electricity payments to the CFE, not only because of the energy that the wind generator and the solar cells would be supplying, but also because if this energy turned out to have surpluses, The Refuge could channel them to the electricity supplier and get deductions from future bills. Needless to say, these alternative energies would also entail a lower environmental impact, which was part of the project's intention.  In addition, The Refuge planted an orchard with apple trees and many other foods for its own consumption. This does not mean, however, that the project seeks to be 100% self-sustainable in terms of food, because The Refuge believes that part of its success depends on the support it gets from the local community, which its why it is important to not monopolize the economic opportunities of the area (a rural region with more than 50% of the population living in poverty and more than 15% in extreme poverty) and rather benefit the population by buying at least part of their inputs from them, and even inviting them to offer services or products to visitors (such as horseback riding, snacks, and others).

Once The Refuge’s family was fully established, they decided to create several attractions to harness more visitors, differentiate themselves from other lodging spaces in the region and fulfill their objective of creating a space for rest, entertainment and the promotion of healthier lifestyles. For instance, they got a hold of more government funding to buy a telescope and build an observatory. They also built a dining room, a temazcal, a small squash court and spaces to organize events. These event spaces have attracted visits from schools, companies with retreats, families celebrating functions such as weddings, and others, and have also proven very important to the mission of promoting practices and offering courses for human development and quality of life.

In this sense, a practice that has helped The Refuge to get hold of speakers or trainers is to accept barter proposals from visitors. In exchange for nights of lodging, for instance, the Refuge has been offered not only courses, but also publicity, solar panels, bottles of wine, and many types of work for the benefit of the place. These bartering practices  ––which the Refuge discusses with people directly to ensure they suit both parties–– have also helped to better fulfill the project’s mission of supporting visitors' personal projects: if a retiree, backpacker or thesis student, for instance, approaches The Refuge saying that he or she would like to spend a season in one of the forest cabins to develop a project or idea, The Refuge suggests helpful activities that they might want to do in exchange.

Initially, The Refuge built its premises making the most of local resources (earth, soil, etc.) and with the support of public funds and family loans. Today, its maintenance depends on several sources of support: first, the alternative energy sources and the orchard, which reduce expenses and provide energy and food. Second, the income it gets from cabin rentals and services offered (meals, temazcal, etc.), which The Refuge normally reinvests in the project. And finally, the inputs or services it agrees upon with some of the visitors in exchange for lodging, which help diversify the Refuge’s offer to other clients.

The lodge is in high season year-round ––there is no shortage of customers. This is due, among other things, to the fact that The Refuge is a different and attractive project, mainly for inhabitants of large cities nearby, such as Mexico City and Puebla. It also has to do with the fact that Zacatlan de las Manzanas has gained visibility since it was named "Pueblo Mágico" (Magical Village), a certification promoted by the Mexican Ministry of Tourism and government authorities at different levels to stimulate national tourism (and, with it, local development) by granting this title to places that still preserve a rich historical and cultural legacy. In addition, The Refuge has achieved a constant flow of visitors because it got itself listed on travel sites such as Trip Advisor and Facebook, which not only help promote the project amongst their huge number of users, but also make them feel more certain that visiting The Refuge will be worthwhile: these platforms allow users to rate their experiences in the businesses (with points, stars or comments) so that other people interested in visiting know what to expect. Positive comments from visitors have helped The Refuge create a kind of public reputation that has attracted more people. In any case, The Refuge is careful not to depend wholly on these platforms to get customers because this same evaluation system that serves well to promote, also has flaws that can be detrimental: if, for some reason, there is a disagreement with a visitor, for instance, the platforms are not able to judge who is right, the negative comments are never removed and when they are recorded they have the potential to have a long-term effect, even after the problem has been solved. Even so, the success The Refuge has had is also due to the fact that it makes the most of the feedback from visitors within these platforms, and also takes into account feedback from its own suggestion book, which is placed in the main room of the establishment to record the opinions of customers and improve.

title: Fortalece · Mexico
introduction:
info 2016

Getting funding for social or environmental development projects in Mexico is difficult because there is little public and private support and because many initiatives compete for it. In addition, there is a certain reluctance to support projects that are not considered feasible or are not seen as a priority, and there is distrust in the use that some organizations and donors make of funds (either because of their capacity to manage them or because of previous experiences of corruption).

In an attempt to address this, the government has created mechanisms to formalize social organizations themselves, as well as the processes for providing them with support. One such mechanism is the certification of organizations as authorized donors, which seeks to make investment in social projects more effective and make it easier for civil organizations to get financial support. But getting this certification is, itself, not easy: the procedure is very complex, time-consuming and tedious and, in addition, it requires compliance with certain requirements that are not available to all projects, such as being formally registered or contributing to solving problems that are in line with the State’s development agenda.

This and other norms for regularizing and granting support to civil society organizations demand standardized requirements, which place organizations in conditions of inequality because they favor initiatives with a higher degree of:

  • Structuring. The amount of organizational soundness required of initiatives tends to discourage projects with little experience.
  • Linkage with donors. This is a major problem because initiatives often arise from disadvantaged social sectors that do not have contact with the social sectors that have the economic capacity to donate.
  • Intellectual capital to gather information and successfully compete in calls for funds, especially international ones, which require knowledge of other languages, education, training and access to information resources that many initiatives do not have.
  • Economic capacity. Although most of the procedures are free of charge, preparing for them requires that initiatives have the capacity to cover expenses such as paying the public notary, or their transportation to administrative offices, which are usually in the capital city. Because many organizations seek certification or support precisely because they lack resources, meeting these expenses is, for many, almost impossible.

 

As a result, certification fails to benefit the initiatives that need it most and very few organizations successfully complete the process. And this happens time and again in their search for other public and private support.

 

 

Is it possible to create more equitable opportunities for social organizations to obtain support?
short_description: Fortalece promotes a more equitable access to financial support for civil organizations by offering legal and fiscal consultations, advising decision-makers and publishing materials to strengthen the sector.

paragraphs.body_html: Fortalece (Fortalece Legal) began in 2011 when lawyer Angeles Anaya saw the problem of inequality that exists among social organizations with regards to the capacity to get resources, and decided to help "satisfy the hunger for advice in the world of civil society organizations". For the lawyer, the distrust with regards to civil organizations implied by these complex regulations, as well as the difficulty of the procedures themselves, limit the number of donations, prevent innovations that give a real turn to the current system and accentuate inequality in terms of access to economic support. In light of this, she decided to teach a course called Legal and fiscal framework of philanthropy at the Universidad Iberoamericana in Mexico City, to address two problems at once, without the need for a large investment in paperwork and financial resources: on the one hand, to address the lack of professionals in the field by training tax lawyers, and on the other, to provide free advice to civil organizations with the support of students, who would gain experience by providing such consultancies to various initiatives for a whole semester.

Later, Fortalece decided to register as a civil association in order to dedicate itself more permanently to attacking the problem. Today it sustains itself by:

  • offering legal and tax advice to civil society organizations, which entails training them to seek support and helping them formalize and obtain certification as authorized donors.
  • publishing books on the subject and didactic materials to strengthen the sector.
  • providing consultancies to tax authorities (those in charge of allocating public support) with the intention of raising awareness amongst them on the particular needs of the most vulnerable development initiatives and advocating to improve conditions for social organizations.

Fortalece has managed to remain active, in part, because there are very few experts in the field, and the procedures and processes are still complex and not very transparent for applicants. This degree of specialization is one of its main distinguishing features and has allowed it to survive thanks to the fact that many clients recommend it.

title: Escuela Nueva · Colombia
introduction:
info 2013

As in many parts of the world, rural schools in Colombia receive less attention and resources than urban schools. In addition, the materials and knowledge that the students receive are often irrelevant to their context and community. By not learning what is required to live in the countryside, many of them end up migrating to the cities and leaving their villages behind, which reproduces the conditions of inequality that exist in the country.

 

 

Is it possible to build an education that is more relevant to the life of rural communities?
short_description: Escuela Nueva is a model of active education that has been replicated throughout Colombia and in many parts of the world to make the educational experience more relevant and of quality for rural communities.
external_link_text: Fundación Escuela Nueva Volvamos a la Gente

paragraphs.body_html: In the 1970s, a group of teachers developed a pedagogical model to offer relevant and quality education for rural Colombia and created the Escuela Nueva project (Fundación Escuela Nueva Volvamos a la Gente) to promote it.

From the beginning, the model was focused on rural schools, especially multi-grade schools, where a single teacher teaches several primary school grades simultaneously. This focus on schools that are most isolated and most in need is designed to reduce educational and economic inequalities between rural and urban Colombia. Although initial implementation costs are high, the costs of keeping the model running are not, making it viable for many rural schools with small budgets.

One of the factors that contribute to the model's sustainability is that it is systemic or, in other words, it does not focus on a single aspect of education but involves all the members of the educational community: students, teachers, administrators, families, and the community. Besides, it also encompasses curricular content, materials, and classroom activities, as well as training, follow-up, administration, decision-making dynamics, and school-community relations.

The Escuela Nueva model transforms many of the conventions of traditional schooling. Students advance at their own learning pace, and instead of passively receiving information, education is active, participatory, and collaborative. Because this system is centered on the experience of students, their context, and their community, more students decide to stay in school and complete their studies. In addition, the education on offer is intercultural, as it integrates universal and local knowledge and promotes ways of learning that are useful for each child and his or her community, creating a fertile ground for entrepreneurship. The objective is to stop migration to the cities from being the only option for students, and to provide opportunities for those who wish to stay in their hometowns and enrich their community.

Escuela Nueva not only employs various strategies to make its project itself more self-sustainable, but also offers comprehensive consulting packages to foster the self-sustainability of the schools interested in replicating its education model; these packages encompass the adaptation of learning materials to the local context, training of teachers and administrators, and the creation of pilot schools. In the adaptation process, Escuela Nueva encourages the participation of families, children, and teachers to take ownership of the project and to adapt it to their needs; it even has a parent government and a student government! Since everyone participates in the decision-making, they are motivated to become more deeply involved in the educational process, thus making it more effective. In addition, Escuela Nueva provides platforms (meetings, workshops) for the discussion and dissemination of innovations within the schools and with the community and once the model is up and running, Escuela Nueva also provides them with technical assistance and promotes learning communities with a network of schools participating in the project, which allows them to exchange ideas and to get feedback.

Escuela Nueva is registered as a social enterprise, which allows it to scale its educational model by selling consulting services and reinvesting its profits in the project without relying solely on donations.

These comprehensive consultancies represent Escuela Nueva's main source of income, but its sources of support also include donations from sponsors from different agencies, online donations, volunteers, and matching funds schemes with foundations.

Escuela Nueva is considered a high-impact social innovation model that improves the quality of education. This project has boosted rural education so successfully that in the 1980s and 1990s, the Colombian State adopted the model for all its rural schools. The program reached more than 20,000 rural schools in the country. As a result, in a 1998 UNESCO evaluation, Colombia was the only country where rural schools outperformed urban schools. It has also been selected as an example of successful reform by the World Bank and the United Nations. In schools where it has been implemented, dropout and grade repetition rates have decreased, and academic achievement has improved. Perhaps that is why schools in more than 17 countries, in addition to Colombia, have decided to adapt and replicate its model!

title: China Development Brief · China
introduction:
info 2019

In recent decades, countries around the world have seen the rise of grassroot projects and non-governmental organizations that aim to either complement, redirect or counterbalance their government’s development policies. In the specific case of China, enthusiasm grew in the aftermath of the 2008 Sichuan earthquake and the Beijing Olympics that same year. But this sector –known as the civil society– faces the same difficulties it has for decades, both in China and abroad: networking, organizing, growing and financing projects are not always easy tasks.

 

 

How to foster the development of civil society?
short_description: China Development Brief provides an online platform, events, training, and research to help strengthen civil society in China by enabling its actors to meet, convene, collaborate and share resources and proposals.

paragraphs.body_html: In 1996, Nick Young, from the British newspaper The Guardian, got a team together to print a periodic newsletter –which he called China Development Brief (中国发展简报) – with a view to circulate knowledge that might be useful to civil society’s growth in the Asian country. The newsletter included information on NGOs, resources that could be leveraged to support projects, scheduled events and meetings, and other pertinent information. Eventually, the group decided to create an online version of the newsletter to broaden the scope of their project and went on to translate the first English version into Chinese to reach even more people.

To date, the project continues to promote the exchange of information (research, experiences), resources (funding, opportunities) and meetings between organizations through different strategies: firstly, through its website, which publishes information relevant to civil society; secondly, by organizing events and forums; and thirdly, by putting together publications, workshops and training that enable the sector to grow and expand its scope.

Currently, non-governmental organizations, foundations, companies, individuals and research centers can go on the China Development Brief website to promote their projects and events, as well as to network and partner amongst themselves.

The site aims to keep content relevant and varied to spark the interest of individuals and organizations. Visitors can find out what's new in the field of China’s civil society through the "News" section, delve into topics relevant to the sector under "Articles" or "Publications", or connect with other organizations through the "Events" tab. And people can also find and reach other NGOs or charitable organizations through the site’s "Directory".

To put the directory together and make it as current and complete as possible, China Development Brief has been compiling a list of development projects for several years. Information is gathered through questionnaires filled in by the different organizations interested in participating that is then uploaded and periodically updated on the website by an editing team. In the case of the Chinese version, initiatives can register in the directory directly by filling in a form and choosing relevant tags. They are encouraged to state their objectives, major achievements, projects, donors and partners, distinctions, social media profiles, contact, legal profile, region, sector, year of launch, number of staff members in China, religious affiliations, mission, connections, location, and others.

China Development Brief organizes an annual forum and several workshops to strengthen the sector by developing new capacities. These activities serve to guide foreign NGOs that want to work in China –by helping them get acquainted with and navigate the legislation and characteristics of the local civil society–, to provide information for scholars who study China’s civil society, and to train Chinese initiatives in management, advocacy, funding, and more.

To broaden the scope of these efforts, the initiative also publishes books and ebooks based on its own research, sends a monthly e-newsletter to contributors, and opens channels of communication to share resources and information through its various networks, such as Twitter, Facebook, Linkedin, Sina Weibo and a Wechat group. In addition, China Development Brief has also published information of interest such as interviews with various civil society actors, salary reports in the sector and a Chinese-English dictionary of development terms.

The China Development Brief was originally registered as a company but decided to change its legal status to civil organization in 2017, under the official name of "Beijing E-share Civil Society Information Center". This decision was made because changes in China's Charity Law made the registration of non-governmental organizations easier ­–it used to be a very complicated procedure– and provided incentives that the organization could benefit from:  the government buys services from registered organizations as a way to support its own programs.

The organization's staff is small but answers to a Board of Directors composed of various leaders in the field, which helps ensure that the initiative remains relevant to different sectors and has ties to all of them. Internally, decisions are made by a senior management team, which includes the director, the executive director, the editors-in-chief of the English and Chinese versions of the site, and the accountant. Consensus from everyone in this team is sought for all major decisions –but when consensus is not achieved, a vote is taken. Ultimately, the legal representative has the final say.

To gradually fulfill its mission of promoting and strengthening citizen participation, the China Development Brief has decided to avoid addressing highly controversial issues that could be politically delicate.

China Development Brief’s main sources of funding are donations from international foundations because there are many foreign donors interested in investing on strengthening citizen participation in the solution of problems, rather than in the solution of problems themselves –the Chinese government, on the other hand, allocates few funds for the development of civil organizations because it prioritizes its own socio-environmental interventions.

In addition to donations, the China Development Brief is also supported by the proceeds from publication sales, the commissions it earns from posting job offers on its website, and the support of volunteers.

The efforts of China Development Brief not only enable civil society to consolidate its current work, but also to increase its reach over time, attract new actors and participants, gain traction with their individual projects, and grow on their own steam in the future.

title: MACIA Studio · Mexico
introduction:
info 2021

In large cities, access to green areas and public recreational spaces is crucial for everyone to have the opportunity to exercise and interact safely and healthily. But in metropolises like Mexico City, these spaces are insufficient and very unevenly distributed, making life experiences very different for each of its inhabitants.

 

How to expand opportunities so all the city’s inhabitants have access to quality public spaces for conviviality and recreation?
short_description: MACIA Studio promotes a more equitable access to green areas and public spaces in the city where children are taken into account and which are designed with the participation of users, through urban interventions, research, exhibitions, consultancies and workshops.

paragraphs.body_html: In 2019, Leticia Lozano and Mariana Ríos created the architecture firm MACIA Studio to promote safer and more inclusive public spaces of interaction and recreation for the inhabitants of Mexico City with, above all, a greater sensitivity to the needs of children. According to them, the urban environment has a very significant impact on children's health, behavior and development, which is why many of the city's problems are a consequence of inequitable access to these spaces for people in general as well as of the " adult-centric" vision that has prevailed in the design of urban policies and which has disregarded the specific needs and interests of children (who make up more than 26.7% of the population) depriving them of access to spaces to play and exercise and of opportunities to learn to channel their emotions and interact with their communities in a healthy and safe way.

That is why MACIA Studio is dedicated to promote the equitable access of children and adults to green and recreational areas through interventions in public spaces, workshops, publications, or consultancies  which foster new dynamics of interaction and new ways to make the most of and enjoy public space.

MACIA Studio has made great efforts to promote a culture of community participation and of placing communities themselves at the center of projects, which has been a key strategy to identify the various situations that affect and concern them and to design interventions that take them into account in an interdisciplinary manner that is more relevant to their specific context, so that people become involved with and take ownership of the projects. To expand access to play and spaces of conviviality, the Studio organizes meetings and workshops, for instance, to talk with the inhabitants of some of the city's neighborhoods about ways to reactivate underutilized public spaces in their neighborhoods. Sometimes these participatory dynamics have resulted in interventions to clean up and refurbish parks or natural areas that are neglected or abandoned, so that they are no longer dangerous zones that people avoid but safe and attractive spots for social interaction. In other occasions, they have served to design "urban toys", which are structures or artifacts that MACIA Studio builds in these spaces to invite play and new forms of interaction among community members. For instance, MACIA Studio created "Tamaulipas" in an abandoned park, a structure of 3 concrete circles, one on top of the other and with a hammock on the top one, right beneath the trees, which made the park attractive to many people and, as a result, turned it into a place for socializing.

MACIA Studio not only encourages the participation and interaction of the people who benefit from its projects, but also works to promote this type of practice among professionals who design urban planning initiatives. For instance, urban toys have not only served to recover specific public spaces, but also to illustrate the potential of this type of interventions. In other words, MACIA Studio has observed and evaluated the impact that its “urban toys” have had on communities and has documented the before and after of its intervention, the emergence of new dynamics, the time people spent in the location, the level of maintenance of the place, and so on. The Studio uses these results to raise awareness among local governments, companies or whoever their potential clients or new collaborators may be, about the importance of seeking feedback from beneficiaries to create conditions or incentives that really enable a new social dynamic and about the enormous potential of the type of interventions that its team has come up with thanks to these dynamics of participation.

Another instance of these dynamics came about when a government call came out to design play spaces for children; MACIA Studio organized a series of games so that the designers participating in the call could meet and interact with the children who would benefit from their projects and thus present proposals closer to their specific interests and needs.

MACIA Studio has also provided consultancies to other initiatives to encourage them to take potential beneficiaries into account in the design of their projects and foster results that are relevant to them. In 2019, for instance, MACIA Studio collaborated with the Universities of Exeter and Leeds who, through the Mobile Solutions to the Mexican Kidnapping Epidemic (MAKE) research project, were looking to develop a mobile application to help reduce the risk of kidnapping. MACIA Studio helped them by implementing participatory research workshops in all types of communities related to that problem (migrant homes, offices of civil organizations, elementary schools, universities, a state congressional hall, a federal psychosocial rehabilitation center, neighborhood committees, sports centers, etc. ), which allowed them to identify the points of view of victims, victims' relatives, civil associations, migrants' organizations, human rights activists, public officials, representatives of law enforcement institutions, creatives, political scientists and programmers, as well as to learn about the different practices that all these actors use on a daily basis to address the problem of kidnapping in Mexico.

Another strategy that MACIA Studio uses to guide the planning of spaces that are more sensitive to the perspectives and needs of children and their communities in different contexts and to promote its approach in more populations and in the long term is to train public servants with workshops, and to develop and publish research and manuals.

In addition to promoting its work approach among professionals dedicated to developing this type of projects, MACIA Studio has also organized activities in different parts of the world to raise awareness among society about the need to promote more equitable access to green and recreational areas while taking children into account, and about the importance of kids’ participation in the creation of these spaces.

In some of its projects, for instance, MACIA has installed exhibits that show the before and after of the spaces it has intervened with the participation of users, so that they realize their own potential to transform their communities.

The project also created a play workshop to raise awareness among a group of about 40 children about the inequalities in access to green areas in Mexico City and to motivate them to come up with solutions. Given that in this city the inhabitants of certain areas have access to an average of 6m2 of green areas per person, while others have access to approx. 40m2, the MACIA Studio team decided to use a version of the technique known as participatory mapping that uses graphic representations (maps, drawings, models) to make it easier for the beneficiaries to see the project ideas more clearly and share their points of view: In a park, they drew squares of various sizes, one inside the other, with yarn. The largest was about 40m2, the next was 24m2 and so on down to the smallest of 6m2. After telling the children about the inequality in the distribution of green areas in their city, they were invited to stand on the large square, where they were told to imagine standing on the area with the most access to green space. Next, they were asked to enter the 24m2 square, and so successively the children were placed inside the squares until they reached the smallest one. There, squeezed together, the MACIA Studio team explained that they were now in the area with the least access to green areas and asked them: "Did you know that depending on where you live in the city you have more or less access to green areas?” Based on this question, a reflection was encouraged among the participating children and then cardboard, leaves, wooden sticks and other materials were handed to them so that each could explain, through a model, their proposals to make access to green areas more equitable for all.

When the founders of MACIA Studio met and realized their common interest in promoting access to play and recreational areas for children and other populations in the city, they began to explore ways in which they could build a project together: the first thing they did was to discuss the work they had each done in the past in order to classify it into AXES or categories (research-action, publications, temporary interventions, products, and so on). This allowed them to identify the experience they had to offer services and the type of projects they were both interested in doing, as well as to define the "branding" or aspects that would make their initiative different from others, in order to communicate them to potential clients or collaborators, positioning themselves against other alternatives.

MACIA Studio was registered as a company in Mexico in order to financially support its initiative with funding from public calls for proposals and by selling projects to foundations, governments and universities. For these projects, MACIA designs specific solutions according to the needs of each one, and hires temporary collaborators or relies on volunteers to carry them out.

The Studio protects its different projects under a creative commons license to ensure that their authorship is known and to better promote the Studio itself, all while also allowing these projects to inspire others and reach more people (since others may take them on in accordance to MACIA Studio's principles while still attributing MACIA the creative ownership). Besides, MACIA Studio constantly explores new strategies to promote its project and reach more communities: spreading it among family and friends, participating in conventions and workshops of all kinds and taking advantage of social media such as Instagram or Twitter.

title: Mescladis · Spain
introduction:
info 2021

As an immigrant in Barcelona, getting a work permit is extremely difficult because applicants have to, first of all, prove at least 3 years of residence in the city without working! and second, they must participate in a series of courses (language, Catalan citizenship, etc.) that the government offers to “facilitate their incorporation into Catalan society“. In addition, applicants must have a formal full-time job offer for at least one year from a solid company that has not recorded a loss in its last accounting period. These complex and absurd requirements have forced thousands of people to struggle to survive with no documents, in permanent fear of being deported and with enormous difficulties in asserting their rights and finding paid activities that allow them to lead a dignified life.

 

 

How can we work with immigrants to help them get a dignified job?
short_description: Mescladis is a project that uses the profits from its restaurants to provide vocational training courses, internship opportunities and legal accompaniment to immigrants in Barcelona with the aim of expanding their chances to get a job and lead a dignified life. Mescladis also promotes social reflection on the problem of migration through artistic interventions and projects, cooking workshops and talks in educational centers.

paragraphs.body_html: One evening in Amsterdam, Martin Habiague spotted several children through a brightly lit window having fun in one of the workshops that the local cookie store put together for their enjoyment. An activity that, incidentally, has helped the store promote and sell its cookies, which in turn has enabled it to organize these activities at no charge to its community! Upon learning of this project, an idea came to Martín, who had been looking for ways to support vulnerable populations without having to worry about the means to do so. Eventually, in 2004, he decided to launch Mescladis.

The original idea was simple: opening an ice cream parlor and using the profits to organize activities for the neighborhood children. As it turned out, the project did not turn out to be an ice cream parlor and it did not turn out to be simple. Within a few years, the initiative that started as a small restaurant in a neighborhood of Barcelona became a series of restaurant-bars in the city, artistic interventions, school and community workshops, courses, accompaniment programs and, in short, a whole project to support young immigrants in Barcelona to enter the labor market financed with the profits, yes, from the restaurants themselves!

When Martín and a friend started Mescladis they were not at odds with the idea of creating a company to promote their social project in a profitable way. But they also knew that, if they wanted to gain the trust and support of organizations and individuals who are also working to create alternatives for a more ethical, solidarity-based economy, it would be important to leave no doubt as to the primary intention of the business they wanted to undertake ––which was supporting immigrant populations–– and perhaps the best option to do so was to insert themselves into the world of non-profit organizations. Since they did not meet the requirement of having at least 3 members to form a civil association, they had to go for the option of registering as a foundation (Fundació Mescladís), even though they did not really have much capital to start the project.

Once formally constituted, Mescladis began getting support from Barcelona Activa (a type of local government incubator) and formed a board of trustees with members from the world of solidarity economy organizations who, because they were well known in the field, helped them establish contacts and network. Because of this, as well as getting a loan from the bank, the team was able to approach people in this sector to ask for informal loans of around 100 euros, which they promised to repay with interest once the project was underway (interest that would certainly be lower than what the banks would have asked for). With the money raised, the organization set up an investment fund that enabled the launch of its project. The fundraising campaign with members of the solidarity economy sector also helped Mescladis make itself known in this community, present its project and get links, collaborations and even its first clients.

This is how Mescladis was born, an initiative that today has 3 restaurants in the city of Barcelona which have done very well because they attract many people not only with their food, their offer of fair-trade products, organic agriculture and locally sourced items, but also with the added incentive of supporting their project.

In one of these restaurants ––the restaurant-school–– the organization created the Cooking Opportunities Program to offer free training courses to young immigrants who already live in the city and who want to get a job or change their current one but cannot do so because they either have no experience or have not received the job offers required by the government to qualify for a work permit. In addition, the Mescladis team provides them with legal guidance to regularize their migratory situation, helps them with their immigration paperwork, provides them with courses in different areas of the restaurant industry (as cooks, waiters, and so on), gives them the chance to intern in the restaurant so the experience helps them find a job in the future and, at the end of the process, Mescladis provides its trainees with a certificate to help them find employment, either in one of its own branches or in other restaurants with which Mescladis collaborates (it usually manages to place at least a third of its graduates).

To accomplish all this, Mescladis takes great care to ensure that its restaurants do not make a loss, not only because a large part of the project is financed by their profits, but also to ensure that the government does not take away its right to offer contracts to immigrants. To this end, the restaurants have a very strict administration: they have clear internal rules about procedures and the responsibilities of each person and have installed mechanisms to avoid problems of trust, such as cash registers that ensure money does not have to pass through anyone's hands.

Mescladis has also worked hard to promote the recognition of its certificate among authorities and other restaurants, aiming to make it a guarantee of high-quality training. In fact, many restaurants that have attested to this quality will consistently offer jobs to Mescladis’ trainees.

Although Mescladis admits into its Program people who come to seek support directly, it selects most of its participants with the support of organizations such as the Refugee Commission of Catalonia, Caritas or second chance schools because besides sending them some of their beneficiaries, these organizations are willing to vouch for them if there is a problem. Also, these organizations support participants in other areas of their lives, which makes it easier for them to complete the Mescladis course successfully, even if enrolling prevents them from making an income for part of the year. In any case, Mescladis has identity quotas for the Program, which means that it makes sure that its participants are of different ages, origins, genders, and so on, to show that we can live together and to foster dynamics and bonds that do not normally arise among similar people.

In addition to the training program for immigrants, Mescladis devotes many efforts to raising awareness among the general population about immigrants' situations in order to promote a more empathetic, favorable and open environment for them. It frequently receives visits from NGOs, universities and students interested in understanding its project model. Besides, since 2014 Mescladis helps manage the building of the Casal del Barrio Pou de la Figuera where it has its branch Mescladis del Pou. This collaboration has been very important because it has served as a platform to organize various awareness-raising activities, since the Casales de Barrio are public spaces that yield their management to civil organizations in exchange for helping to strengthen relations of friendship and cooperation among neighbors.

The organization has also made collaborations with artists to document and share the stories and experiences of migrant people with photos, paintings and testimonies on various walls and steel rolling-doors on business fronts in the city, on restaurant tablecloths (so that customers get curious and learn about the project), in books, traveling exhibitions, documentaries, feature films and comics –– even on a Web platform called Ciudad Migrante where, as well as sharing photographs, they created a map that locates the organizations, services and resources that are available in Barcelona to support migrants (language courses, shelters, legal aid, etc.). Mescladis also uses all these materials to give talks in schools about the conditions in which this sector of the population lives, to encourage children to reflect on the problem and to get them to recognize the right of people to migrate. Sometimes the protagonists of these stories (from photos, comics, etc.) participate in these talks to share their experiences with the children.

Additionally, Mescladis organizes workshops for the students of its restaurant-school to show the residents of the neighborhood their different cuisines (Mexican, Japanese, Syrian, etc.) and stories of the places they come from. In this way, locals can travel around the world through flavors and the activity becomes a pretext to learn about the different ways of being and doing of others, fostering an atmosphere of empathy that encourages conviviality in the local community. Sometimes, these workshops are visited by tourists thanks to agreements that Mescladis has established with some local travel agencies. At other times, the workshops are also organized to help companies carry out group dynamics with their employees.

One of Mescladis' great achievements is managing to cover about 90% of its project needs with the profits from its restaurant-bars. The rest is covered by profits from catering services and events for companies, organizations and individuals; by fees paid by tourists and companies for cooking workshops; and by some grants from government institutions and other donors. The organization also receives support from volunteers to put together activities, workshops, artistic interventions and other tasks suggested by the volunteers themselves.

Thanks to all this, Mescladis has been able to train around 70 immigrants a year and has helped many of them secure work permits. Its experience has served to show authorities and other organizations that there is an alternative way to help regularize this sector of the population and improve their living conditions in Barcelona.

title: Furia Mexicana · Spain
introduction:
info 2021
