The conditions of inequality that women live under are devastating and it is estimated that it will take more than 100 years to bridge the gender gap between men and women in the world. Women own, for instance, less than 20% of the world’ s lands, they make up two thirds of the world’s illiterate population, and only 6 countries grant them the same labor rights as men.

On top of the lack of equal opportunities, one out of every three women in the world is a victim of physical or sexual violence at some point in her life. In Mexico alone, 4 out of 10 women have been victims of sexual violence and 9 women are murdered every day!

 

 

How can we build a more equitable world that is safer for women?
short_description: Furia Mexicana is a collective of Mexican women living in Barcelona which fosters solidarity among women and raises awareness to combat inequality and gender violence.

paragraphs.body_html: On March 8, 2020 thousands of people marched in various cities around the world to demand fairer and safer conditions for women, and a group of Mexican women living in Catalonia decided to join the march in Barcelona to denounce the thousands of femicides that occur in Mexico and are seldom punished.

At this event they got to know each other better and decided to form a feminist collective ("colectiva" as they call it in Spanish, using the feminine version of the noun) to give other movements fighting against gender violence in Mexico a voice and a presence in Catalonia. They also wanted to look out for and support one another, make friends, share their experiences of discrimination and mourning as migrants, and organize discussions on feminism, sexuality and sexist microaggressions.

This is how Furia Mexicana was born. The women decided to take this name because on the day of the march someone shouted “¡Furia Mexicanas!”, which is Spanish for “Mexicans, rage!" and they thought it perfectly captured their anger against sexist violence.

 

Building the project

The Covid-19 pandemic lockdowns started almost immediately after the march, so the new collective had to hold their first meetings online. In these sessions, the women decided to organize their project by forming commissions to coordinate the work and make joint decisions in assemblies that would be led by those who volunteered to take on the day's agenda. Knowing that not all the women in the collective have the same availability to attend meetings, the assemblies would be held only once a month, online and for two hours to enable everyone's involvement and so as not to leave anyone out. Also, everyone would have a voice regardless of their level of engagement with the project. They also decided that those interested in being part of the collective would have to fill out a form to describe themselves and their background, be based in Catalonia and be Mexican (although they have made a couple of exceptions). They also created a Drive (an Internet storage space) to share documents, books and other materials.

The commissions that Furia Mexicana has assembled are not fixed because the project has been adapting to the needs of the group, the interests of the members (who participate on a voluntary basis), and external events as they arise. In any case, there are two commissions that operate regularly: the Communication Commission and the "Artivism" Commission. The first is in charge of the internal and external communication of the project and its mission is to establish links with other feminist organizations. Thanks to these links, the collective has joined forces with other collectives to attend demonstrations or to support women facing difficulties. For instance, they once organized a clothing drive so that a young woman who was a victim of violence could leave her home and become independent. In fact, since then, the members of the collective have gathered things like toothbrushes, sanitary pads and clothes in a suitcase to have at hand in case another woman in similar circumstances needs their support in the future.

The "Artivism" Commission is responsible for organizing demonstrations, performances and other awareness-raising and advocacy activities to make the issues of concern to the group more visible. Once, for instance, they picked a wall in a busy public space to collectively paint a mural of racist phrases that local people have said to them and invited passers-by to share their experiences of discrimination by intervening the wall. On another occasion, this commission organized a fundraising campaign to support the Zapatista tour that traveled to Europe. And the commission has also helped organize demonstrations in front of the Mexican consulate to protest violence against women in this country.

As for the collective's objectives of self-care and reflection, organization has come about organically through social media. At first all the women shared a Whatsapp group chat, but when they realized that many were getting overwhelmed by the number of messages exchanged, they decided to make communication more efficient by creating thematic subgroups. That is, they opened different Whatsapp groups according to the interests and needs they could identify: one on feminist parenting for mothers, another to exchange services and products and share job opportunities... They also created an "announcements" group to publish only resolutions taken in other groups or commissions so that everyone, whether they take part in the groups or not, can find out what is happening in the collective in general, which helps foster cross-cutting collaboration and prevents efforts from being duplicated.

Another way of promoting self-care and reflection on issues important to the collective has been to leverage the amount and diversity of knowledge and experiences of the women who have joined the project (some 60 people, some of them artists, others caregivers, scientists, communicators, psychologists, teachers, researchers, etc.) to organize talks and other support activities among each other ––such as the women's circle once put together by a psychologist, or the dance workshop offered by a member who is a dancer.  Although their main interest is to work among and for women, on one occasion Furia Mexicana also organized a workshop to raise awareness among men on the problem of sexism.

As the pandemic lockdown measures were relaxed, the women of the collective began to meet in homes or open spaces again, but they decided to continue having online meetings to facilitate the attendance of those who live outside of Barcelona or have activities that prevent them from meeting in person.

Although Furia Mexicana uses almost no money for its activities, it created a "resistance fund" and appointed a treasurer to manage it. In the resistance fund, the collective gathers all the funds it raises to pay activity expenses (posters or loudspeakers for marches, for instance) or to support a comrade in need.

To raise funds to cover these types of expenses, Furia Mexicana took part in a solidarity economy fair organized by Coopolis (an organization that works to strengthen migrant collectives) selling cakes and objects donated by women of the collective. Members have also organized fundraisers among themselves and have given workshops or talks on the issues they work on in their group. Once, in fact, instead of charging for one of their talks, they offered it free of charge to a civic center in the city in exchange for the use of their space to hold one of the collective's meetings.

To date (2021) Furia Mexicana is not legally registered as an organization because the procedure is costly and doing it would entail a much more formal commitment ––which is only just being built into their project. But the idea is not ruled out for the future, because it seems to many members that registering could help them get resources more readily (by offering services or giving courses, for instance) and that it could even help the collective open up employment opportunities for some of its members eventually, which could give the project a significant boost.

title: Guadalajara Time Bank · Mexico
introduction:
info 2016

In this crazy world of ours, 10% of the population owns 86% of the wealth, while half of the population put together owns a mere 1% of it! Lack of money prevents many people (as well as organizations, governments and companies) from paying for products and services needed to survive.

 

 

How to meet our needs when money is scarce?
short_description: The Guadalajara Time Bank encourages its community to barter services using time as an alternative currency so that people can depend less on money and meet their needs through cooperation, solidarity and mutual trust.

paragraphs.body_html: Economic crises have led many communities around the globe to come up with new strategies to solve their needs without depending so heavily on money and, in this sense, complementary currencies have proven to be a very useful alternative. Complementary currencies are vouchers, coupons, points and other types of instruments that are used as money and only have value within the communities that agree to exchange them. Their purpose is not to completely replace official money, but rather to help people cover at least part of their expenses so that official money can be saved or used for other things. Actually, there are thousands of complementary currencies in many countries which may be made of paper, some other material or even come in a digital format ––but what they all have in common is that they seek to promote cooperation among the members of a community to meet their needs with mutual trust and support.

Time banks are a very interesting experiment in this regard; they have been spreading all over the world (there are more than a thousand!) and use nothing more and nothing less than time as currency! With time banks, you offer your time to support another person and calculate the hours it took to provide such service. The number of hours you walked their dogs, say, or the number of hours you spent caring for them when they were sick, and so on. This number of hours is then recorded (or "deposited") in your Time Bank account so you can use them to pay for a service from another Time Bank provider when you need to do so, just as you would with official money. In other words, time banks are a community initiative that offers an alternative way to exchange services without having to spend money. In many places, money is not enough for people to pay for all their expenses, so using time as currency allows them to exchange services and, therefore, use the little money they do have on other things.
In 2011, a group of people from Guadalajara, Mexico, decided to explore this proposal to support their community and opened their own local Time Bank.

To get the Time Bank started, the team chose a "time broker" or coordinator and, with his help, organized meetings with people interested in learning more about the project to properly explain the idea behind the time bank, and to give everyone a chance to get to know each other. People who chose to participate (which were called "time investors") were asked which services they would like to receive and which of their own skills or services they could offer to meet the needs of others (carpentry, English classes, etc.). Once both supply and demand had been mapped, the time broker set about inviting more time investors of various profiles to cover the different needs as thoroughly as possible, making it easier for the dynamics to really serve the participants by actually supporting their economies.

Once a minimum network of investors had been assembled, the time agent explained how the exchange dynamics would work and shared a set of guidelines with basic rules of coexistence and participation (such as letting people know in advanced if a service had to be cancelled, for instance) to ensure the proper functioning of the bank and the satisfaction of all members.

During the first few months, time investors had to send an e-mail to the time broker to let him know the type of service they needed; then, the broker ––who concentrated the information–– was in charge of finding another member of the network interested in offering such service. When the exchange was completed, both parties would write to the time broker to register the number of hours to be "deposited" on the accounts. It was soon discovered that there is a web platform with free software for managing time banks that works in a similar way to traditional banks and can be adapted by any local time bank. Services offered and requested can be listed on this platform, and investors can have and manage their own account, make transactions and register movements without the mediation of a time broker. In addition, members can rate their experiences with comments and stars for others to take as a reference. For the Guadalajara Time Bank team, this platform became an important source of support because it helped network members exchange classes, animal care, technical consultations, professional services, and so on, more efficiently and in a more streamlined fashion, while also letting the team see the exchange dynamics in a clearer and more transparent way, and even letting them note users' feedback to identify unmet needs or potential problems (such as members who might be causing conflict in the network). It also relieved the work of the time broker who, from then on, focused on organizing frequent meetings with members of the Bank's network to raise awareness of the importance of the project and share the needs identified in the process, while also helping everyone get to know each other better, begin to trust each other, and discuss new possibilities for collaboration.

Although the Guadalajara Time Bank is no longer in operation, it left an interesting and very important example of how projects or communities can use time as currency of exchange to cover at least part of their needs without the use of money.

title: Sustainable Healthy Nature ASRI · Indonesia
introduction:
info 2022

Tropical forests give us drinking water, capture carbon and help regulate the climate, and despite this, in just a few decades, we have already destroyed half of them, endangering our survival as humanity and that of many other species that live in them.

Indonesia, for example, has already lost 80% of its forests! Largely because the government has allowed private companies to displace the communities that inhabit them to cut them down or replace them with large plantations, mainly palm oil. And also, because when they don’t get these permits, either because of conservation laws or policies, what many companies do is offer farmers to buy their lands or pay them to cut down trees in areas where it is illegal, which many farmers agree to do because they need the money to survive.

 

How to stop the deterioration of tropical forests?
short_description: ASRI collaborates with communities in Indonesia to conserve their forests by addressing the needs that lead them to overexploit them with programs in health, reforestation, agriculture, education and entrepreneurship.

paragraphs.body_html: When in 1993, Kinari Webb (a biologist from the United States) traveled to West Kalimantan to study orangutans and realized the overwhelming ecological crisis that was taking place, she approached several local people to ask them why they were cutting down their forests or selling their lands to companies if this, in the long run, would mean that their resources would dry up or that they would be dispossessed of their lands (in addition to the enormous environmental impact). What many people answered her was that they did it because they needed to earn income to be able to support their families and pay their medical expenses, since the services available in the area were few and very basic and traveling to other nearby cities to seek medical attention was very expensive. Kinari asked them what they would ask in exchange for stop selling or cutting down their forests. The answer was very clear: an alternative that allowed them to generate income and have access to medical services.

Intrigued, Kinari did some further research into what was happening and realized that the forest’s health of and that of the people were intimately linked in a vicious circle: people were contributing to the destruction of the forests to get money to pay for their medical expenses and survive, but this deforestation was extinguishing their living environment and their resources, and was causing the spread of contagious diseases such as tuberculosis, dengue and malaria, which ironically was aggravating the health problems that people wanted to solve by cutting them down. Besides, many of them, no longer being able to cultivate their lands, were not eating fruits and vegetables since the ones that are sold in the area are very expensive (because they are imported from Java) and this was creating new health issues such as malnutrition and diarrhea. To complicate the situation even further, Kinari confirmed that in the province of West Kalimantan there were only 3 clinics and 1 doctor for every 60,000 inhabitants, which explained why people had to find resources to be able to travel to other cities to receive medical attention. She also found that governmental and civil society projects to protect the forest did not seem to be addressing the needs that were forcing people to collaborate with the companies that were destroying it.

Realizing this difficult situation, Kinari decided to return to the United States to study medicine so that she could come back to Borneo to do her bit. A few years later, in 2005, she decided it was time to act. She formed the organization Health in Harmony in the United States and, along with the ecologist Cam Webb, began to explore which part of Borneo was the most suitable to open a clinic from which they could build a project with the communities that were being affected by this dynamic. In the end, they decided on the village of Sukadana, near the Gunung Palung National Park in West Kalimantan, because they saw that more than 70% of the buffer zone had already been deforested there and that 33% of the families living in its surroundings were obtaining more than half of their income from logging.

When, in 2007, they learned that Indonesian law only allows foreign organizations to work with its population if they do it through local organizations, they decided to partner with Indonesian dentist Hotlin Ompusunggu to form an Indonesian non-governmental organization called Sustainable Healthy Nature (ASRI, by its Bahasa name Alam Sehat Lestari).

Once the organization was created, and convinced that the local people are the ones who know best the causes of their problems and the ways in which they can be solved, the first thing the ASRI team did was to put into practice what it now calls the “radical listening approach”, which is about not selling solutions to people nor imposing agendas on them (as many governments and organizations do), but rather talk with them about the problems that affect them and listen very carefully to their concerns, their needs, their diagnosis of these problems and their proposals to solve them, in order to help them carry out these proposals. Kinari learned the value of practicing radical listening when, in 2005, working as a volunteer doctor in Aceh, Indonesia to help victims of a hurricane, she realized that many humanitarian organizations were not listening to the people’s needs, because they were giving them rice when, in fact, they were asking them for help to clear their lands, so they could cultivate it themselves. For this reason, the ASRI team spent more than 400 hours during its first 2 years talking with all kinds of people from the community (in their homes and meetings) to have a thorough knowledge of their situation and ask them about their needs and proposals to preserve the forest. This is how they discovered that on average, people were earning about $13 USD per month and that their main demands were to have access to good and cheap medical services (or that could be paid for with means other than money) and to have training in other jobs that allowed them to earn an income in order to stop living from logging.

So, the first program that ASRI launched was the Clinic, because with it, the organization would not only offer health services at affordable prices, but it could also begin forming a space and a work team in order to create, little by little, programs that would solve in a comprehensive and simultaneous manner the different causes and consequences of deforestation that its team identified along with the community.

Kinari enlisted the support of her university classmates to raise funds to rent land and set up the Clinic and soon, with the support of nurse academy trainees from nearby schools, it began offering services such as immunizations, birth control, general medicine and dental and ophthalmologic care. In addition, the Clinic established agreements with universities in the United States so that their doctors could visit it to learn about tropical diseases in exchange for training local doctors. It also started coordinating a course for health workers in small towns to teach them how to supervise the treatment of tuberculosis patients, and it started giving scholarships to some local doctors, so they could be trained abroad and come back to help.

Years later, ASRI was able to buy its own land and build the Clinic that is still open today in Suakadana. At the request of the local population, it also created a Mobile Clinic that makes regular visits to the most remote communities to bring services closer to them. The Mobile Clinic is a team of about 3 people that goes by van from community to community with medicines, immunizations, ambulance equipment and equipment for dental procedures. Thanks to this outreach to the communities, ASRI has been able to diagnose and treat tons of people with diseases such as malaria, tuberculosis or epilepsy.

In the meetings that ASRI had with the communities, it understood that no matter how cheap its services are, there are many people who cannot afford them. That is why it decided to offer, as people themselves suggested, the possibility of paying with barter, so as not to exclude anyone: people can pay by working at the Clinic and each hour of work is given a price that is recorded so that they can exchange it for medical services when needed; people can also pay with handicrafts (baskets, bracelets, etc.) that the Clinic receives at pre-established prices and then resells them to cover its expenses; they can also pay with eggshells, manure or seedlings, which ASRI uses to help reforest the National Park and for its organic farming program (of which we will talk more later on).

For ASRI, accepting this last form of payment is also a strategy to encourage people to help restore the forest. In fact, with the same idea in mind, it also established a system of discounts for the communities neighboring the National Park, with which it gives them discounts on the Clinic’s services depending on how well their forest area is preserved. To assess this, ASRI takes into account the community’s proximity to the National Park and other indicators that it designed in collaboration with Park staff and with the communities themselves (such as whether they have left entrances for loggers, if there are traces of deforestation, etc.). On the basis of these indicators, each community is assigned a color that corresponds to a specific discount. The blue color, for example, gives a 50% discount to the communities that live far from the Park and have no deforestation indicators, while the green color gives a 70% discount to those that do not have deforestation indicators either, but live near the National Park. Many communities know that they cannot get the highest discount, because it is impossible for them to fully stop exploiting the forest’s resources, or to completely abandon their agricultural activities to comply a 100% with the indicators. And yet, this system has helped to significantly reduce logging in the region because, since the colors and their discounts are assigned to entire communities and not to each person, people who continue logging are pressured by their neighbors to stop doing so.

• Reforestation and deforestation monitoring

ASRI collaborates with the National Park authorities and neighboring communities to monitor deforestation by organizing follow-up meetings, conducting surveys and using satellite images. Also, it relies heavily on the forest guardians, which are people from the communities associated to the discount program that ASRI hires to watch the forest in their area and alert it if there is any risk of fire or any deforestation activity.

The forest guardians also let neighbors know about the programs that ASRI offers to support those who want to stop logging and they also help set up the nurseries where ASRI is cultivating seedlings of native species to help the National Park reforest its land. Many of these seedlings are planted by the guardians themselves, others are given by the National Park, and others come from the Clinic (which receives them as payment for its services). But, additionally, in order for the communities to benefit from the reforestation project, ASRI is inviting them to grow these seedlings and sell them to the organization so they can make extra money. In fact, ASRI is also buying to some women from nearby communities eco-bags made of bamboo straw that they make by hand and that are used to plant the seedlings with less environmental impact than plastic bags.

• Organic agriculture

Since the first meetings with ASRI, many communities expressed their interest in learning skills that would allow them to have a job other than logging. Particularly, they showed interest in organic agriculture, because the State had designated their lands as part of the National Park and was requiring them to use this type of agriculture that many knew nothing about, and that is why they were engaged in cutting down trees to survive. For this reason, ASRI enlisted the help of experts from Java and the National Park to offer trainings in organic farming so that communities can comply with the new rules and resume farming as a livelihood. Its trainings include more ecological farming techniques (for cultivation and for making fertilizers), business training, and advice on registering for a Ministry of Agriculture program that offers further training, certification, and links to markets. Once they obtain this government certification, the farmers in the program become independent from ASRI so that the organization can continue training other people.

ASRI also started the Family Orchard Program, with which it provides training to improve agricultural practices at home. Part of the manure that is used in this program comes from the payments that people make to the Clinic, another is bought from the farmers of the Organic Agriculture Program, and another is prepared by the ASRI staff itself, with the organic waste that they save from their daily meals.

Thanks to these programs, many people (including several forest guardians) have been able to start businesses selling organic food and even organic fertilizer to buyers that ASRI has helped them find (usually from abroad, where these types of products are in high demand).

• Voluntary chainsaw buyback

Realizing that it was not easy for many loggers to stop pursuing logging and undertake new activities, since 2016 ASRI started another program that offers them to buy their chainsaw in exchange for a commitment to use that money to invest in a new business. To facilitate this transition, ASRI works as an incubator that helps them develop their entrepreneurship: ASRI talks with them to see what new business they want and could start; helps them identify what they would need to launch it; links them with business consultants to receive training in home finance and business development and management; and supports them with a small economic incentive so that they can dedicate themselves to exploring their new project while they start to generate profits. Also, instead of paying them for the chainsaw in cash, it uses the money (about 4 million rupees or $270 USD) to help them buy the supplies they need to start their new business. If this is not enough, it lends them up to an additional 6 million rupees interest-free (about $400) for them to buy the missing in-kind inputs. ASRI gets these resources from donations and from what it earns from dismantling the saws and selling the knives. Entrepreneurs who ask for these additional loans agree to put a piggy bank in their house to save part of the profits from their business, a part for themselves and another to repay the loan to ASRI so that it can continue buying chainsaws from other people and thus support them in their ventures. Each month, the program coordinator visits their homes and collects both savings and once they finish paying off the loan, ASRI returns their personal savings. By 2022, they had already managed to get more than 229 people to exchange their chainsaws with this program.

• Goats for Widows

ASRI needed to obtain manure for its reforestation activities and for the organic farming workshops, because the one it obtained through the Clinic (when people used it to pay for their medical services) was not being enough. So, when a donor gave ASRI a goat, the organization came up with an idea to, on one hand, stock up on manure for these programs and, on the other hand, support single mothers (usually widows) who, having no way to generate income, were taking their children out of school to engage in logging, so they could support the family with money.

The idea was simple: ASRI gave the goat to a single mother from the community in exchange for her giving the organization her first female calf and selling her manure. Afterwards, ASRI gave this calf to another single mother, with whom it made the same agreement in order to continue with the same dynamic and, little by little, support more women. ASRI got a male to impregnate the female goats and the program coordinator, a woman from the community, visits the owners of the goats to see how their animals are doing and to offer them basic health care.

By obtaining the goats, which are normally expensive, many of these women have begun to generate income by selling the kids, manure or milk (some even tried to sell cheese) and this way, they have been able to send their children back to school. Today (2022), more than 200 women have participated in this program that ASRI named “Goats for Widows”.

ASRI has organized frequent talks in the 39 communities with which it collaborates on how to take care of personal health and that of the forest. It also organizes courses and activities for children (with the ASRI Kids Program) and teenagers (ASRI Teens), to take them to know the forest better, explore with them the relationship that exists between the forest’s health and that of people, teach them about recycling, show them how to identify local plants, etc. The courses are held twice a week after school hours at the Clinic facilities, and schools are invited to come and listen to them, which has also benefited many mothers who work and have nowhere to leave their children after they finish school. ASRI has also organized summer courses on which they do visits to organic farms, grow plants, prepare compost, learn how to eat well, etc. By working with the new generations, ASRI hopes to pave the way for easier forest conservation in the future.

To truly respond to the needs and concerns of local populations, ASRI not only designs its programs with them using radical listening. It has also formed a work team with all Indonesian people and is trying to integrate more and more people from the same communities to lead them.

While ASRI implements the project with this team, Health in Harmony, which is like its sister organization in the United States, is dedicated to promoting it abroad, obtaining funding for programs, helping ASRI professionalize its staff, and exploring ways to scale its working model to other regions of the world.

In any case, at present ASRI already supports itself mainly with funding that it obtains itself, and with the profits from the Clinic, which has become much more self-sufficient thanks to the entrepreneurship, organic farming and goat breeding programs, which have helped people earn money and be able to pay for their health services. To support its reforestation program, for example, the organization started a Trees’ Sponsors Program where people can donate ASRI money to watch the growth of a certain number of seeds and to plant them on their behalf. Also, ASRI opened a small store in the Clinic to generate additional income by selling products that can help reduce the use of plastic (such as thermos flasks, cloth diapers, reusable straws, bamboo toothbrushes, etc.) and also installed a system to collect rainwater and solar panels that provide 100% of the energy it needs to operate.

ASRI also receives the support of various types of volunteers: foreign doctors who do their medical residences or internships at the Clinic, people who visit it to support the project because they like what it is doing, and students from other professions who visit it to learn about its work model or to do social service.

To monitor its project, regularly assess how it is working and think of new ways to improve it, ASRI makes work plans every 5 years and, also, every morning it organizes brief all-staff meetings (of about 70 people) in which they discuss the activities planned for the day, in order to be coordinated and give each other feedback or advice if they are facing a specific problem. It also organizes frequent meetings with the communities (or participates in those that they carry out for different reasons) to keep an eye on their perception and concerns about the programs, receive their feedback and detect aspects that need to be modified. Furthermore, every 5 years or so it organizes a survey in the different communities with which it collaborates to measure the commitment rate that they have with its programs (with indicators to identify how many programs each person is benefiting from, who is participating, etc.).

The 2013 survey, for example, allowed ASRI to see that illegal loggers had been reduced by 89%, that 68% of those surveyed had started planting trees on their own, and that many felt better prepared to pursue other economic activities thanks to the organization’s programs. By 2019, ASRI managed to reforest more than 200 hectares with more than 200,000 trees, treated more than 30,000 patients and contributed to reduce the number of infant mortality cases in the region by 67%.

Today, many of the people who benefit from ASRI’s programs already have more resources to pay the Clinic when they get sick, and some even have access to a new public health insurance that covers many of these expenses. But the seedling payment method is still a great support for those who suffer from diseases that are not covered by this insurance, or simply do not have any insurance or enough money to pay for health services on their own.

Listening to the proposals of the communities involved in deforestation, ASRI has been able to design a comprehensive strategy to attack the different faces of the problem and build alternatives so that communities can subsist and meet their health needs without having to destroy the forest. Many of these alternatives, in fact, include activities that are rather helping recover the damaged forest and protect it, replacing the vicious circle with a virtuous one.

In 2014, at the request of some international organizations, ASRI and Health in Harmony began organizing radical listening meetings with communities from the Raja Ampat National Park, in Papua, to see the possibilities of replicating their model there, in order to protect both the forests and the marine habitat in the area. Today (2022), they have already finished the stage of radical listening and are in the process of analyzing the results. Furthermore, since 2018, ASRI has been scaling its project with communities surrounding the Bukit Baka Bukit Raya National Park, also in West Kalimantan province.

Outside of Indonesia, it is Health in Harmony that is scaling the work model that it piloted with ASRI. It is collaborating, for example, with local organizations from the Brazilian Amazon and Madagascar to promote conservation programs. In Madagascar, people have claimed they need health services and food security to be able to dedicate themselves to care for the forest instead of cutting it down.

Although it appears to be an organization dedicated to providing medical services, the main objective of Health-in-Harmony is the conservation of nature. That is why it is exploring places that share the problem of the degradation of natural areas to promote its radical listening model to design and implement, together with local communities, tailored programs that allow them not to have to choose between satisfying their needs and preserving their territories.

title: YOLK's Solar Cows · South Korea
introduction:
info 2022

In many rural regions, companies or governments do not provide electricity facilities because the population is so small it would be difficult to recoup such a large investment. As a result, people in these areas often have to rely on expensive and highly polluting sources of energy, such as kerosene lamps, and have to charge their devices and phones at stores that charge them for the service and make them waste a lot of time.

 

As many families cannot afford to send their children to school because they need their support to cover their expenses (taking care of livestock, farming, etc.), this situation further limits their opportunities to provide them with education.

 

How to give these families access to energy so they can afford to send their children to school?
short_description: In rural areas of the world where there is no electricity (and if there is, it is very expensive) and where sending children to school is a luxury many parents cannot afford, YOLK is installing solar-powered cow-shaped charging stations in schools and providing children with batteries to recharge while they attend classes, which they can then take home to charge their family's lamps or cell phones. This is helping to replace the use of kerosene lamps (which are highly polluting) and saving money for these families, allowing them to send their children to school. To achieve this, YOLK sells its services to development agencies and the corporate social responsibility departments of large corporations: In exchange for funding, YOLK establishes contacts with schools, installs solar cows, monitors their impact on communities, and provides follow-up support.

paragraphs.body_html: This is what Sen was wondering when she decided to dedicate herself to promoting access to solar energy worldwide and, when researching where was it most needed, she discovered that this was the situation for many people, especially in Africa, where 43% of the population lacks access to electricity.

The South Korean designer had recently formed the company YOLK (요크) in Seoul, South Korea, with which she had invented such thin portable solar panels that they were selling very well! But although she was making a lot of money with them, Sen soon began to feel dissatisfied with devoting her efforts to such a small market niche when she could instead be helping solar energy reach more people.

So, exploring ideas to achieve this, Sen first considered the option of starting to donate solar lamps or something similar, but then thought that donations do not last long because it is difficult to maintain them when needed. Instead, she would have to design a product or service that could be financed and maintained simply by being useful in solving people's problems. For example, inventing something that could help replace the vicious circle in which people, by not having access to electricity, use highly polluting energy sources, become impoverished, and cannot send their children to study, with a virtuous circle in which making access to solar energy easier, people reduce their environmental impact and, of course, their expenses, so that with fewer economic pressures, they can afford to send their children to school. This, Sen thought, would be a great contribution, because education is a valuable tool for life that gives one more options and freedom to choose. And that's how she came up with the idea of the solar cows!

The model would work as follows: YOLK would install charging stations in the shape of a cow with solar panels in schools in these regions, and each child would be given a lamp and a battery that they could recharge in the "udders" of the cow, as if they were milking it, while taking classes. This way, they could study for a few hours without harming their family, because at the end of the day they would bring the charged battery back home to cover their energy needs, either by using it for solar lamps and/or to charge their cell phones and other devices. YOLK would adjust the solar cows so that the battery charging was slow, thus encouraging children to stay in school for longer periods. And to incentivize parents to send their children to school every day, the batteries could only be charged enough to cover one day's energy needs: 3-4 cell phone charges, or about 6 hours of dim light or 3 hours of bright light, or one cell phone charge and two radio charges, etc. In addition, the batteries would have a special design that would only allow them to be recharged in the solar cows so that no one could take them away.

In 2018, YOLK contacted an NGO in Kenya to ask for their help in identifying a school in the region that might be interested in piloting (testing) this idea, and thus began collaborating with a small school in the village of Pokot, where they invested some of the profits they had earned from selling their solar panels to see if the solar cow model would work.

Very soon, after seeing that indeed several parents were sending their children to school with the incentive that they would return home with the lamp and the battery fully charged, YOLK decided to present this experience at a development conference that was held in Kenya to let people interested in these issues know about their proposal and perhaps even support it. And it worked! Many people were impressed by the success of their pilot experience and since then YOLK has been able to replicate this model in many other schools.

And YOLK has done this following a very interesting business model: instead of YOLK itself paying for installing and maintaining the solar cows, it sells its services to organizations dedicated to financing development projects (such as the Korea International Cooperation Agency, KOICA), or to companies that have Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) programs like LG. In exchange for their financing, YOLK establishes collaborations with schools in regions that are experiencing this problem, manufactures and installs the solar cows, trains school staff to use and maintain them properly, provides after-service maintenance, and reports to the funders the impact they are having in increasing children's attendance to class, as each battery has a code that allows it to automatically record when it is connected to the cow. This model works for funders, not only because by purchasing YOLK's services, their company or agency helps increase access to energy for many families, reduce their environmental impact, and facilitate children going to school. It also works for them because when YOLK recognizes their sponsorship by labeling the project as "funded by X" or "made in collaboration with X", they can promote themselves better and in some places even get tax benefits.

Over time, besides increasing children's attendance to school, solar cows have had other impacts on education. For example, some schools have been able to use digital screens to teach, which has been especially useful where there are not enough teachers. And during the Covid-19 pandemic, which prevented children from going to school for a long time, YOLK added a function to the solar lamps to listen to radio (mainly educational channels in the country) and an SD card slot that can be pre-loaded with educational programs for when there is no radio signal reception. Nowadays, this new model of lamps is also helping children to review their school learning at home.

To diversify its sources of support to sustain the project and not rely 100% on finding buyers for its services, YOLK sells other products (such as mini solar panels, solar lamps, etc.) on internet platforms such as Naver or Amazon where, to encourage people to buy, it shows them the social impact their purchase could have through small videos, photos, etc.

YOLK has also organized crowdfunding campaigns on internet sites such as Wadiz or Kickstarter. On these sites, people can present the project they have in mind and the amount of money they need to implement it. If, within an agreed-upon time, with the support of online investments from other people (friends, investors, philanthropists who fall in love with their idea and want to support it, etc.), they raise at least that amount of money, then they can keep it to finance their project, but if the total does not reach that sum, the money is returned to the investors. In 2021, YOLK organized a campaign that was so successful that it raised, with the support of more than 200 people, the amount of 47 million Korean won (about $35,000 USD).

Additionally, in Tanzania, YOLK was piloting a scheme to see if charging people to recharge their batteries would work. Since it didn't work well because the people using the solar cows have the lowest incomes, now (2022) they are exploring the possibility of charging a very modest fee to people and covering the rest of the expenses by obtaining subsidies.

Finally, YOLK is exploring another way to generate income to sustain its project... by commercializing coffee! This idea arose when, after installing a solar cow in a school in Ethiopia, YOLK learned that the coffee from that region is highly recognized for its quality, and that many of the producers are parents of the school's students. From there, the proposal emerged to function as a bridge for these families to sell their coffee to the Korean market, which pays a lot for these products. YOLK will be the intermediary, and thus, in addition to helping producers sell their coffee to more consumers, it will allocate part of the profits to the same school. The rest will be used to sustain and expand the solar cow project. To make this idea a reality, YOLK has already designed a brand for the coffee (called Allo Yolk) and has already begun to present it at fairs.

By 2022, YOLK was already working with 20 schools in Kenya, Tanzania, the Democratic Republic of Congo, and Ethiopia, which have reported that with solar cows, children are registering more in school, attending more, abandoning less, and also having, in many cases, better technologies to study, as the schools themselves are acquiring access to electricity. In turn, families are spending and polluting less because they are using fewer kerosene lamps. With its experience in these schools and the growth of its project, which has become increasingly integral, YOLK is proving that sometimes all it takes is to remove one obstacle for the situation to change completely and problems begin to solve themselves.
YOLK has won numerous awards for its innovation and impact, such as the Aidex2018 Aid Innovation Challenge, the iF Design Award for Social Impact, among others.

title: Spasibo! · Russia
introduction:
info 2019

 

Despite the fact that the textile industry is the second most polluting industry in the world, clothing production has doubled in recent years and the overall dynamics of consumption have been marked by enormous waste: people buy twice as much clothing, wear it for half the time they used to, and when they no longer want a garment, they burn it or throw it in landfills (more than 70% is wasted!) instead of recycling it (less than 1% of clothes are recycled) or donating it to people in need.

 

 

How to reduce textile industry waste?
short_description: Spasibo! is a thrift store in St. Petersburg, Russia, that collects, recycles, redistributes and sells second-hand clothing to reduce waste in the textile industry while using the proceeds to support various social projects.

paragraphs.body_html: Many companies and social organizations are devising alternative models of consumption that seek to be fairer and more environmentally friendly. One example of these are thrift stores, which have emerged in several countries since the 1970s with the proposal to collect and resell clothes in good condition that people no longer want or need, so as to give these items a new use instead of throwing them away.

In 2010, a group of young people in St. Petersburg, Russia, realized that the situation in their city was not very different from that of the rest of the world, since people gave away 5% of the clothes they no longer wanted to their friends, donated another 5% to people in need, and threw away the remaining 90%!. So, inspired by the proposal of thrift stores and the ideas of circular economy they decided to create their own version of the model and opened Spasibo! (спасибо!), a store aimed at recovering discarded clothes to make better use of them while supporting different social projects at the same time. This mean that part of the clothes they collected would be redistributed to social organizations that serve populations that could benefit from them. Another part would be recycled. And another portion would be sold in one of their thrift stores and part of the profits would be used for Spasibo’s own operations and another part to financially support different social projects (shelters, cooperatives, and so on).

Since Russia does not provide the legal status of a social enterprise, Spasibo! decided to launch its project by registering as a company because although its objective was to help solve social problems, it realized that by registering as a non-governmental organization it would not be able to yield the necessary profits to maintain its project in a sustainable manner ––much less to support other social initiatives, as it intended to do (charitable organizations can only obtain 30% of their resources from sales). So, by registering as a company, Spasibo! would not be able to obtain government support, but would have the opportunity to make a profit to finance its project in a free and cost-effective way as well as to support other social initiatives.

Once registered, Spasibo! placed 120 containers in different areas of the city, making sure to install them in places protected from the weather to ensure durability (shopping malls, offices, etc.) and launched 7 thrift stores throughout St. Petersburg to reach more people (nowadays, in 2021, there are 4 in operation). Spasibo! collects clothes from these bins, mends them and sells them at prices that are very competitive with the traditional market. While many customers visit their stores because of these prices and the type of clothes they sell (Spasibo! did a market study to create a brand according to local fashion), other people buy from them because they share the objective of their project and want to support it.
The clothes collected in the containers makes up about 80% of what Spasibo! offers in stores, and its sale yields profit that goes towards various purposes:
• A portion goes to buy the remaining 20% of the merchandise: very cheap clothes that Spasibo! looks for in other stores to resell at a slightly higher price.
• Another portion goes to cover operating expenses, the purchase of containers for clothing donations, equipment for stores, the installation of new branches and the development of the organization.

• A further portion is used to support other social organizations: in addition to helping them by giving them a space in their stores to sell their own products or souvenirs, Spasibo! supports them with financial assistance and clothing. Since Spasibo! realized that some of the recipient organizations were reselling clothes instead of using them for their beneficiaries, nowadays, Spasibo! carefully reviews the profile of the requesting organizations before making any donation and asks them to fill out a form to evaluate the veracity of their needs and their intentions in order to avoid repeating these past abusive experiences. In the case of financial assistance, Spasibo! carefully checks that the organizations being supported have a good reputation, have been in existence for at least three years and, above all, that their projects help solve problems at the root ––in other words, that they are building an alternative reality–- in order to ensure that the aid has the greatest possible impact.

• Nowadays the company also invests part of its profits in advertising because it has realized how important it is to attract new support and clients, and that the way it used to promote itself was not enough (at the beginning of the project, Spasibo! bet on public relations by attending festivals, conferences and television programs to achieve free promotion and attract donors).

• And, as well as investing its profits in these areas, Spasibo! also invests as much as it can in a stability fund, that is, a savings fund that allows it to meet the commitments it has made with other social initiatives and to cover operating expenses (especially paying employees) when sales are not going well, the market suffers setbacks or donations of clothes are insufficient.

Like any company, Spasibo! is legally required to be organized with a hierarchical structure and its CEO must take legal responsibility for the organization's decisions. But in its day-to-day work, the project’s board is organized with more of a cooperative management scheme in which its 10 members meet at least once a month to distribute the tasks of the project in commissions and make decisions democratically (such as which organizations to support for example) based on five-year plans and objectives that are defined among everyone.

Also, because Spasibo! is established as a company and makes a profit, it cannot work with volunteers, so it works with 80 employees (including the board of directors). For this same reason, Spasibo! tries to attract investors, although it does not close its doors to monetary donations. In fact, only once did it receive a donation that helped strengthen its financial self-sustainability: a man donated money to the project in exchange for a temporary share in the company. This money was invested in opening new stores and buying a recycling machine that not only has saved Spasibo! the money on outsourcing that service, but has also helped the project make an extra income. When the donation money was recovered, Spasibo! returned it to the donor, who was happy that the organization had made good use of his support.

As one of the first organizations to introduce the thrift store model in Russia, Spasibo! attracted the interest of many groups that wanted to replicate this initiative, so, eager to expand the scope of its project, Spasibo! initially spent a lot of time mentoring these organizations. But the project soon realized that only 10% of these organizations managed to survive and, moreover, that several of them had very different ethical principles from its own. So Spasibo! decided to change its strategy to make better use of its time and resources while continuing to support these organizations and started an incubator, that is, a project to help the development of initiatives interested in following this model with investment and training for a defined period. Unfortunately, the incubator model also failed, as only 2% of the supported organizations managed to launch their projects successfully, so Spasibo! decided to change its strategy again: on the one hand, it prepared online guidance materials so that organizations interested in replicating its initiative could continue to make the most of its experience and know-how. On the other hand, it began to explore a franchising model to further scale its project in a more effective and efficient way. To do so, Spasibo! hired a team of experts in this model to help systematize its franchise proposal, identifying its original or differentiating elements (what makes Spasibo! different from other thrift stores) in order to patent them. The team also helped design a 5-year plan with specific objectives to develop the franchises. Nowadays Spasibo! is working on this plan and as similar organizations are already well established in Moscow, it will most likely start by setting up the first franchises in cities such as Nizhny Nodgorov and Kazan.

title: Little Donkey Farm · China
introduction:
info 2017

In China, as in so many other countries, industrial agriculture has damaged the environment, the livelihood of small-scale farmers, and the health of consumers.

Many people no longer trust in the quality of the food produced by industrial agriculture. More people than ever want access to local, organic, ethically-sourced, high-quality food: the market for organic products grew from 0.36% in 2007 to 1.34% in 2013.

 

 

Is it even possible to recreate sustainable agriculture in a world with such high demand for food?
short_description: The Little Donkey Farm rents plots of land for city dwellers to grow food sustainably. It promotes research into new technologies and rescues traditional knowledge through partnerships with universities, promotes community building among farmers and customers, and offers visits, demonstrations, consulting, workshops and training.

paragraphs.body_html:
In 2008, pioneering researchers from Renmin University leased abandoned land tracts in rural Beijing to create the Little Donkey Farm (小毛驴市民农园), a sustainable agriculture project.

At the Little Donkey Farm, Beijing residents rent plots of land to cultivate food. They have a choice between three types of subscriptions.

1. Learn to cultivate the land and care for the animals themselves. The farm offers training, tools and organic products for food production.
  2. Leave the care of the plot of land and animals to the farm, whose staff takes care of everything.
  3. A combination of these two options, in which customers learn to grow food, but the farm takes care of the daily care of the land.

No matter which option they choose, they periodically receive fresh organic food from their plot, which they may harvest themselves or have it delivered at certain places around the city, or even at home.

This model is called Community-Supported Agriculture (CSA), and promotes local agriculture that strengthens the community and builds a co-responsible, reciprocal partnership between farmers and customers.

Besides the above, the Little Donkey Farm has also managed to build self-sustainability largely due to:

1.  The Farm has actively worked to rescue traditional expertise in agriculture and animal husbandry of local farmers, for whom the Little Donkey Farm is a source of employment.

2.  The Little Donkey Farm has fostered alliances with several universities, who use the plots to test their latest innovations, nurture new talent and train communities in the latest organic farming technologies. These universities also monitor and provide feedback to the farm, so that it is in a constant state of innovation.

3. This project has incorporated as a social enterprise operated by three institutions: The Centre for Development, Science and Technology in Guoren Municipality, Renmin University and the Government of Haidian District (where it is located). Its standing as a social enterprise has allowed the Farm to diversify its funding sources and subsist in a region where land rent is very expensive.

4. In addition to the payment of subscription fees, the project obtains additional income from operating a small restaurant and a shop where it sells its own products and those of other alternative projects, which provides mutual support with other local initiatives and makes the visit to the farm more attractive for families in Beijing. The Farm also offers school trips, demonstration gardens, local carpentry and craft workshops, as well as consulting and training to scale up its model by demonstrating the use of the latest technological innovations to students, entrepreneurs and government officials, and guiding them through how to develop and strengthen cooperative projects that provide integral services. Because of its social orientation, the Little Donkey Farm also receives donations from foundations and governments and is supported by the work of volunteers and interns. The purpose of this collaboration is threefold: it provides the farm with a workforce, trains students and youth in sustainable agriculture and promotes this alternative lifestyle in the urban population.

5. Popular social networks in China such as Wechat, Weibo and Taobao enhance the work of the Farm in many ways: They use these services for promotion and communication with their clients, but also to organize networks of both consumers and local alternative initiatives, to disseminate and receive feedback on their project, to sell their products online and to diversify payment methods to facilitate sales (through Alipay, for instance).

6. The Little Donkey Farm is successful partly because it benefits several actors. Researchers, students, farmers, volunteers and entrepreneurs learn from the model and its processes. Consumers have access to quality local products with memberships that fit their needs, a learning space and the community dynamics that are generated around the farm. And local communities benefit from the income from the land rent, employment on the farm, and the rescue of their traditional knowledge. The communities also receive training in which they learn innovative farming techniques, and how to package, certify and sell their products.

The Little Donkey Farm was the first to implement the Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) model in China. This model has been replicated in over 500 farms around the country. The Farm has become a leader in its field, proving once and again that urban life can be integrated with sustainable agriculture.

title: Livingseas Reforesting the Sea · Indonesia
introduction:
Info 2025

For millions of marine creatures, finding a home has become increasingly difficult.

 

Coral reefs, those vibrant underwater neighborhoods where fish raise their young and octopuses play hide-and-seek, are turning into white cemeteries. It’s as if entire villages were disappearing underwater. Climate change is warming the waters, while pollution from hotels dumping wastewater, boats dragging anchors, tourists wearing toxic sunscreens, factory waste, and some fishermen stunning fish with cyanide to capture them alive, poisons what little remains.

 

In Bali, where many communities depend on tourism seeking crystal-clear waters and colorful fish, this is not just an ecological problem: it is an economic and cultural crisis.

 

But fighting it is not easy. Some document the death of the corals to alert the world. Others are cleaning trash from the beaches so it doesn’t reach the sea or the reefs. Others are monitoring and studying the problem to find the best way to solve it. And still others are setting rules to at least curb harmful activities. Everyone is fighting from their own trench, because the emergency is today.

 

But the challenge is enormous and more hands, more ideas, more ways to act are needed.

 

How can we help combat the deterioration of marine ecosystems?

paragraphs.body_html:
The birth of LivingSeas is the story of a diver who decided to join this fight.

 

Leon Boey, a dive instructor from Singapore, had founded LivingSeas Asia in 2005 as just another tourism business. For years, he dedicated himself to taking visitors to admire the reefs and expanding his business by opening new branches in Indonesia. Over time, Leon witnessed how the places he knew were changing. The colors faded, the fish disappeared, and the corals were covered in a ghostly white.

 

Worried, he began to read about them, to learn on his own different ways to restore them, and to test and adjust them during his dives. He even traveled to Sulawesi to learn the techniques of a coral reforestation project and to share experiences with them.

When the 2020 pandemic brought tourism to a standstill, Leon was forced to explore alternative paths to avoid losing his business, and suddenly it hit him—of course! It was the perfect opportunity to make a radical shift for his dive shop and stop doing “business as usual”! He would transform it from a common entreprise into an active coral reef restoration movement!

 

He could perfectly leverage what he had learned running his dive agency to create and sell new experiences, but now for sustainable diving. And also educational programs, which would teach through practice, by restoring corals.

 

It was in fact a very good idea because everyone would win: the sea would be rehabilitated, visitors would enjoy diving and contributing at the same time, his business could continue despite the blow the pandemic was dealing to tourism, and the community would not only have new jobs but would protect the place that provides its livelihood.

 

Leon closed the other Livingseas branches and concentrated on the one in the port of Padang Bai, on an island called Bali, in Indonesia. His idea was not just to conserve what remained, but to rewind the damage: replant corals, revitalize the marine ecosystem, and, in the process, involve the local community and tourists in a model of responsible and purposeful ecotourism.

 

To achieve this, he had the brilliant idea of designing a roadmap, that is, the path he would follow to grow his project in stages, each with a specific strategic objective:

The first thing he decided to do was to ask his closest circle for support: the community of divers who already knew him and shared his interest in caring for the sea. Leon sent them a kind of newsletter explaining his plan and asking for donations, and the response was very positive.

 

The goal of this stage was to build a proof of concept: a model of what he wanted to do with the project that would demonstrate to those who had supported him that he could deliver on his promises and thus secure more support.

 

So he used the first funds to buy materials and to start forming a work team, organizing workshops and training for local youth, whom he paid for a year so they could effectively dedicate themselves to learning and practicing how to prepare the structures for planting the corals, how to install them under the sea, etc. For Leon, this part was crucial, first, because he would then have candidates to whom he could offer employment in his project, and second, because for many people in that community the coral crisis was still very abstract, and involving some in its restoration through different jobs (as divers, in administration, in the kitchen, etc.) would help them understand the scale of the problem and communicate it to their family, friends, etc.

 

While doing all this, Leon leveraged the trust he had with people from the local community to pull the initial "levers" and obtain the necessary permits.

 

Once he had them, he chose an area to start the reforestation and got to work. Months later, when the pandemic rules relaxed and tourism began to reactivate, he started offering visitors coral restoration dive trips.

With a concept that was starting to yield results and show the first signs of marine life returning, the next step was to talk about it.

 

For Leon, the best strategy to scale the project was not to start asking for support here and there, but to assemble an outreach team dedicated to raising awareness about the problem of the oceans and the solution that Livingseas was offering—because, in his own words, “you don’t push, you talk about it”. The team began to openly share their progress, achievements, and learnings through different channels (especially on social media), putting special effort into getting their message to people in related niches like the marine sector, ship interests, etc. This genuine form of communication began to organically attract more sponsors, volunteers, and allies interested in supporting.

With the project validated and making waves, the time came to seek growth actively and professionally.

 

Scale wasn't just important; it was everything. An entire ecosystem hinges on it; a small patch of new coral isn't enough to revive the complex web of life. This was made starkly clear when the sharks, key indicators of a healthy reef, didn't return until 2024.

 

That's why Leon mainly followed two strategies:

 

  • The first is that alongside his dive agency (registered as a for-profit company) he registered the Livingseas Foundation (Yayasan Lestari Biru Livingseas) — its non-profit arm — to be able to secure more funds.

 

    • Today, the dive agency uses its profits to pay its staff, who are responsible for both recreational diving and the conservation project. And the Foundation gets money to pay for project supplies like the iron structures where the corals are placed, the ties used to attach them, etc.

 

  • The second was to hire a specialized sales team of remote workers who typically work under a scheme of low base salary plus commission. This team is dedicated to generating leads, a digital marketing technique that involves focusing on identifying and attracting customers who might be interested in the products or services offered, in this case:

 

    • Travel Agencies — who can sell Livingseas's conservation dive experiences and keep a commission.

 

    • Corporations — that need to organize corporate social responsibility programs, workshops for their employees, etc.; and

 

    • Schools (especially universities and international baccalaureate, IB schools) — that often look for opportunities to organize workshops or field practices and to secure joint funds for collaborative research projects.

Although finding reliable colleagues who shared Livingseas’ way of working was not easy, Leon had finally managed to assemble a team that worked very well together. Some prepared the meals, others promoted the project on social media, or maintained the tanks, or brought corals to plant, etc.

 

With Lea, his conservation project coordinator, and Abe, the operations coordinator, he met every two weeks to plan and adjust strategies.

 

But he soon realized that growth brought new problems: contracts, payroll, taxes, and legal matters were becoming chaotic. If he wanted Livingseas to keep functioning without depending on him and even to be able to replicate itself in other places, he needed to better structure the organization and ensure everything was done legally, professionally, and with good conditions for the employees.

 

In other words, the organization had reached the point of needing to form a human resources department, a tax management department, a legal affairs department, etc., and that's why this stage was dedicated to preparing (or finding) the staff who would be in charge of them.

With the organization stabilized and functioning autonomously, Leon faces his most strategic challenge: ensuring the project transcends his leadership. His dream is no longer just to restore corals, but to create a replicable model that others can adopt in other regions.

 

To achieve this, Livingseas is following strategies such as:

 

  • promoting a simple, clear, easy-to-copy product, with tangible and specific objectives: coral reef restoration.

 

  • not patenting its techniques and instead actively promoting that its model be copied and scaled. Not only because they themselves learned from other projects (like the one in Sulawesi), but because for Leon, true success is not in being unique, but in inspiring a global marine restoration movement that is accessible.

 

  • seeking people who start to do what Leon does now, meaning they take on the different roles he has had to assume to set up the organization (conceiving it, organizing it, funding it, promoting it, etc.), and can even eventually take his place and lead Livingseas with his same vision.

 

  • leveraging networks and collaborations. Not precisely by "hunting" them, as many projects do, but by attracting them. By publicizing Livingseas's work and letting those who are truly interested approach. And then, seeing what they can offer the project and what they are looking for, to see if it's something that is needed or adds value or not.

Livingseas has built an ingenious and diverse funding model that allows it to be sustainable. Its income comes from several complementary sources:

 

The backbone is its dive agency, which offers purpose-driven experiences: conservation dives, educational workshops, and specialized tours. These services are sold not only to individual tourists but also through B2B partnerships with companies, universities, and travel agencies. The generated revenue covers basic operational costs and team salaries.

 

But planting corals requires more resources to pay for supplies like metal structures, special resin, and tools, so Livingseas uses its Foundation to secure additional support, such as:

 

  • The financial grants and professional support obtained by collaborating with universities on research projects, and organizing fellowship programs where participants secure their own funding while learning and contributing to the fieldwork.

 

  • Donations collected through its website.

 

  • Custom projects agreed upon with corporate sponsors: companies that ask "I give you x amount of money, what can you do with this?", and Livingseas offers them concrete options like funding 50 coral structures, paying the salary of a restoration diver for a month, or adopting a specific zone of the reef.

 

Furthermore, Livingseas is exploring new ideas to secure more support:

 

  • It is adapting its current office space to open a restaurant where tourists can learn while enjoying a meal, thanks to large screens showcasing the underwater restoration work.

 

  • It is collaborating with researchers to evaluate whether the project can participate in biodiversity credit markets.

 

  • And also, Leon is starting to organize the construction of an underwater Balinese house (known as Jineng) made of coral! a unique attraction that would radically differentiate his diving offering and draw in new visitors interested in regenerative tourism.

What Leon and his team have achieved is beautiful, inspiring, and exciting. Their efforts are visible underwater: where before there was only white and silence, colorful corals, fish of all kinds, and even sharks are now dancing again. This means the ecosystem is gradually recovering.

 

By May 2025, they had already managed to revitalize over 6000 m² of seabed in Bali, plant more than 300,000 coral fragments, and train and employ 24 local youth as marine restoration experts!!

 

Livingseas demonstrates that the problem is serious, but the solution is in our hands: getting organized and taking action works, EVERYTHING COUNTS!

title: IYouShe · China
introduction:
Info 2023

 

Ever noticed how, when big natural disasters strike, loads of people pitch in to help out their community voluntarily? That’s exactly what happened back in 2008 in the Chinese province of Sichuan. A massive earthquake hit, leaving over 80,000 people dead and wiping out the homes of more than 5 million. The government, organizations from all over China and beyond, and especially a lot of locals all came together to help transport the injured, get food, rebuild, and more.

 

It was so impactful to see all that could be achieved thanks to the spontaneous organization of society that many began to imagine how much more could be accomplished if people maintained this attitude of participation and solidarity even after the crisis, to address the issues in their neighborhoods.

 

How can we encourage people to work together and lend a hand in their communities on a regular basis?
short_description: IYouShe works with residents in the neighborhoods of the Chinese city of Chengdu to help them learn how to organize themselves and support each other to tackle their community issues, boost its resilience, and improve its living conditions autonomously. They do this by bringing them quality services from the government, organizations, and businesses, and by setting up activities to help them meet, socialize, and learn how to start projects together. They also make it easier for them to share their resources, with programs like the Community Storehouse and neighborhood gardens.
external_link_text: 成都市爱有戏社区发展中心

paragraphs.body_html: In 2009, Liu Fei (刘飞) and other activists from the city of Chengdu decided to create the organization IYouShe (Chinese: 成都市爱有戏社区发展中心) to improve living conditions in their city's neighborhoods and communities. They aimed to enhance their ability to prevent and cope with crises by bringing government, business, and social organization services closer to them and by encouraging neighbors to get to know each other, support one another, and learn to organize autonomously to solve their problems.

IYouShe works in different neighborhoods with projects that are tailor-made for each one. So, when IYouShe decides to start working in a neighborhood, the first thing they do is chat with the locals and check out what's going on in that community—like who needs what, which families or groups might need extra help, and stuff like that. Based on what they find out, IYouShe suggests action plans that can include its 'signature' programs (working models they've come up with and found success with in other places), or programs they design just for that neighborhood, usually using strategies like:

1 - It helps the government manage and improve its Social Service Stations.

 

In every town and neighborhood in China, local governments have been opening centers called Social Service Stations where they gather social workers, civil organizations, volunteers, businesses, and entrepreneurs to work together and close to the residents, to address their needs as comprehensively and efficiently as possible. For example, a Social Service Station might include government social workers, a company offering elder care services, an NGO working with people with disabilities, and so on.

One way IYouShe supports neighborhoods in Chengdu is by helping the government improve the services it offers through these Stations, by:

    • Gathering information about residents, their needs, and demands so the government can design and monitor programs to address them — using surveys and interviews.
    • Training and professionalizing social workers or organizations operating there so they can offer better services to residents — providing workshops and the opportunity to put what they've learned into practice in one of the neighborhoods where IYouShe works.
