    • Also proposing or implementing programs or services to complement those already offered at these Stations — giving, for example, counseling to local schools to support students with special needs and their families, family planning and sexual education courses, etc.

2 - Sets up its own Social Service Stations.

 

In addition to supporting local governments in improving their Social Service Stations, IYouShe is collaborating with them to open and manage Stations using its own working model. With this model, besides bringing together social workers, civil organizations, and businesses for the residents, IYouShe also encourages residents to get involved and find ways to self-organize, support each other, and create conditions to address community issues as they arise.

To open one of these stations, for example, the government lent IYouShe a vacant plot of land in a neighborhood in Chengdu for free for 5 years. The agreement was that IYouShe would use its own ideas and resources to build a project there that could offer services and activities benefiting the residents and help improve their community dynamics. These services and activities could be offered directly or with the support of other organizations, and each year, at least 50 of them would have to be offered for free to the neighborhood residents.

IYouShe cleaned and fixed up the place, then met with the neighbors to ask them what they needed and what kind of activities or services they'd like to have in that space. Based on that, they reached out to organizations and businesses that could meet those needs and invited them to set up shop for free on the land to offer their services to the neighbors. They'd only have to cover operating expenses like water or electricity, and give a small percentage of their profits to IYouShe, which IYouShe would use to fund its own work.

Today, at this Station, there's an organization that runs workshops for people with disabilities in the neighborhood. They teach them how to make baskets and help them sell them on online selling platforms like Taobao — which is like the Chinese Amazon — so they can earn a living. IYouShe supports this project by making deals with the platforms to help promote these baskets and encourage people to buy them. For instance, IYouShe suggests to the platforms that they encourage people to buy by offering to donate 1 yuan to the project for every yuan the customer spends. Selling platforms like Taobao can do this because they have a Foundation.

There's also an organization that supports the elderly in the neighborhood. They opened an online store with products the elderly often need, offer home services, help diagnose and guide them when they feel unwell, and offer courses to help them be more self-sufficient. For example, they give a workshop on how to manage money now that they're retired. They also organize activities with other people in the neighborhood so they can socialize with them and not feel isolated. They give workshops for their families, caregivers, and other volunteer neighbors to experience and understand what they're going through so they can take better care of them. In one of these workshops, for instance, they put weights on the participants' arms so they can feel the mobility difficulties many elderly people experience and empathize with them. They also teach them what kind of adaptations they need to make in the house to better care for them (in bathrooms, beds, clothes, food, etc.).

Another organization opened an entertainment and culture room where calligraphy and painting courses are offered. Another one provides psychological care to neighbors. And since one of the biggest concerns expressed by young people in that neighborhood is not having a place to leave their young children when they go to work, another one opened a childcare center that also offers courses to parents on how to take care of them.

Clearly, what makes this work model special is that instead of setting up many offices with services that people may or may not want or need, it designs services based on the specific needs expressed by the residents themselves (who are the beneficiaries) in each neighborhood.

Another Station created by IYouShe is the one in the railroad workers' neighborhood, where the local government lent them a huge warehouse at the neighborhood entrance to work in. IYouShe renovated this space with huge glass walls where today, with the collaboration of entrepreneurs, volunteers, organizations, and the residents themselves, it offers a library, a tea house that aims to bring neighbors together and share their stories (Sichuanese people love to gather and drink tea), and a space where crafts are taught that can be sold so that participating residents can generate some income.

And since one of the biggest concerns expressed by that community is the lack of employment opportunities for young people, they also created a Vocational Station to incubate entrepreneurs: an area within the station that is lent to a different team of young people each year for them to try launching a business from there, testing their idea with the neighbors. For example, one team adapted the space to open a store selling ready-to-go drinks (tea, coffee, juices, etc.). Initially, IYouShe didn't charge entrepreneurs for using this space, but soon realized that without pressure, young people became overconfident and their businesses didn't really thrive. So now they make an agreement with them where they do charge, and quite a bit, but if they manage to make the business prosper by the end of the year, they refund that money.

Another interesting project within that station is the Charity Shop, which (like the Beautiful Stores) sells second-hand clothing and other items that are in good condition and obtained through donations to give them a second life and reduce waste. Some of these donations come from people who no longer need them, while others come, for example, from companies that give what they couldn't sell. Since they are donations, the store can also sell the products at affordable prices to make them accessible to more people. And to better leverage its capacity to contribute to the community with its project, the store employs many people with disabilities.

IYouShe considers itself an organization that contributes to the government's social development efforts because it helps train its public servants, explores ideas to enhance its services, and, due to its closeness and experience with the communities, provides feedback that it uses to improve.

3 - It helps neighborhoods organize and train themselves to become more independent and resilient.

 

IYouShe's involvement in neighborhoods or communities rarely stops at addressing the interests and needs of the people in the community or training those who provide these services. IYouShe also helps these communities learn to organize and assist each other so that eventually they can solve their problems on their own.

Meetings with Agreements

 

One method it uses to promote community participation and organization is organizing meetings with neighbors to discuss their personal needs, identify common concerns, and make suggestions together to address them. In these meetings, neighbors have to negotiate their priorities and come to agreements on actions they can take together. Additionally, they must commit not to have new meetings until these actions are fulfilled — a rule that IYouShe has set so that neighbors have confidence that these meetings truly have an impact and increase their interest in carrying them out. On some occasions, IYouShe also provides small financial support so that neighbors can implement these solutions and gradually build their community's autonomy.

Trainings to Organize

 

Additionally, IYouShe offers workshops where it teaches neighborhood residents different methods and rules so they can effectively discuss ideas to jointly address community issues that concern them and negotiate conflicting positions. It also organizes courses where, with the support of people from the same community or professionals, it teaches specific ways they can organize and plan actions to solve their problems themselves: how to conduct meetings, how to bring their demands to the government, how to cooperate with other organizations, how to organize votes to choose their representatives, and even how to create a formal organization and seek funds to sustain it — sometimes offering financial support to help them successfully go through this process. IYouShe collaborates with universities to prepare some of the materials used for these workshops.

4- Promotes Mutual Aid

 

Of course, not everyone is naturally interested in what happens to their neighbors, let alone willing to participate in the activities proposed by IYouShe to solve their neighborhood's problems. For IYouShe, this has a lot to do with the fact that people in city neighborhoods don't even know each other. That's why the solution they've focused on is creating opportunities for neighbors to meet, socialize, and start building relationships naturally.

Spaces and Activities of Common Interest

 

One strategy it uses to create these opportunities is setting up spaces like ping pong courts and organizing recreational activities like dance classes. It has also promoted community gardens: IYouShe invites neighbors to allocate some common space in their neighborhoods to plant ornamental, edible, and medicinal plants, and teaches them how to set up the gardens, produce compost to maintain them, cook their food, and organize to manage them. The gardens have proven to be a very effective excuse for several neighbors to get to know each other and socialize because they beautify their neighborhoods, save them some money on food and medicine, and allow them to have contact with nature. Some communities even use them to organize visits for local school children so they can learn about plants, animals, etc.

This strategy of creating spaces and activities for residents in the neighborhood to get to know each other and socialize has yielded very clear results in communities like the railroad workers, for example, where neighbors have started to self-organize spontaneously by creating different self-managed groups to share interests, solve problems, and support each other: there's a group that organizes field trips, book clubs, etc. Today, more than 50 local groups post a sign with their proposal and contact information on the Station's bulletin board so that anyone interested can join them.

Art and Culture

 

Another strategy is arts and culture programs. For IYouShe, if you want a community to function as such and its members to organize and support each other, it's necessary for it to have an identity that makes its members feel like part of a group with something in common. Therefore, if a community lacks that identity, it's necessary to build it.

To achieve this, it's betting on art and culture. Through its Art and Social Innovation Lab, IYouShe has been collaborating with artists from across the country to organize interventions, exhibitions, and activities aimed at helping the residents of the neighborhoods where it works get to know each other and understand themselves as a community.

In Supo neighborhood (苏坡), for instance, IYouShe managed to get the local government to lend them a disused space on the ground floor of a busy street building for showcasing exhibitions. In the summer of 2023, artists Chen Jianing (陈嘉宁) and Bai Haiyang (柏海洋) used that space as a base to engage deeply with various people from the neighborhood. Jianing, for instance, had a brilliant idea to connect with the locals and make them feel comfortable: instead of renting an apartment in the neighborhood to live and sleep during his artistic stay, he set up a small room inside the mini exhibition space. To furnish it, he asked his parents to send traditional food from his hometown (in Guangdong) that he offered to neighbors who stopped by the exhibition space in exchange for furniture they no longer used or could lend him. This gave him an excuse to chat with them, get to know their homes, etc. Upon learning that despite being a very old neighborhood, part of it would soon be demolished due to new development plans in the area, Jianing and Haiyang decided to capture the essence of their community before it disappeared with the changes. Haiyang did this by collecting very symbolic and interesting belongings from the neighbors (diaries, keys, tickets, photos, etc.) and putting together an exhibition with them. And Chen Jianing created a beautiful book with stories and photographs of the local night market and its characters.

Community Warehouse (义仓 Yicang)

 

But the most representative program that IYouShe uses to promote mutual aid in the communities it works with, and which has therefore become one of its "signature" programs (meaning it tries to implement it in all communities), is the Community Warehouse (义仓 Yicang). A "Warehouse" inspired by the granaries that many ancient Chinese villages organized with small contributions from community members to support the most in need and to face periods of crisis.

In many of the neighborhoods where IYouShe works today, it designates a common area within the community (like a community center, for example) to gather donations for people or families in need and forms a local committee to manage them. This committee includes community members and donors and is supervised by IYouShe. To obtain these donations, it publishes a list of items that community members have expressed they need, along with other everyday items that it knows will be needed sooner or later, categorized into second-hand items, non-perishable foods (like oil, rice, etc.), hygiene or household cleaning items, and time. People interested in contributing to the Community warehouse can only donate items listed, and their donations must be approved by the warehouse managers, who check that they're in good condition and meet the needs (if not, they're not accepted). Sometimes IYouShe actively seeks out individuals or companies (sponsors) that it believes can contribute specific items that a neighbor in need has requested. Sometimes it also asks community members who are well-known to make contributions to encourage others to do the same.

IYouShe has software that helps manage the Community warehouses transparently:

Whenever someone contributes something, it's assigned a code, and if it's a physical item, a QR code sticker is placed on it for identification and is logged in a collection list, which includes who, when, and what was donated, who received it, and when it was redistributed to a neighbor. This list is posted on a webpage or in a neighborhood spot so everyone can see their contributions were recorded and what happened to them. It also allows recipients who want to reciprocate to do so by offering their time, services, or even products voluntarily. To encourage large companies to continue making frequent donations to the Community warehouse, notifications are sent informing them about what's happening with their donations, when and who receives them. This helps them be aware of their impact and motivates them to keep supporting. Sometimes the Community warehouses share donated products among themselves.

But the Warehouse is more than just a storage space for donations; it's a program, a channel that makes it easier for people who want to support voluntarily. It also aims to better utilize the community's resources. For instance, individuals who want to sponsor specific people, children, or families can sign contracts with the Warehouse. This commitment ensures that their support is distributed in a scheduled and transparent manner. For example, someone who wants to support a child can channel their financial aid through the Warehouse to pay for the child's education until the child reaches university. The contract can be ended before the agreed-upon date if necessary.

To spread the word and inspire people's solidarity, the Community Warehouses use some sub-programs. With one called "A Spoonful of Rice" they encourage families in the neighborhood to ask 10 neighbors to donate a spoonful of rice for the community. With the Theater program, volunteers put on shows to entertain and socialize people, combating isolation and loneliness, especially among the elderly. Additionally, they organize bazaars where free medical consultations are offered, and neighbors can sell items or services to generate income for themselves or support other vulnerable people in their neighborhood. All these sub-programs not only encourage socializing and a spirit of helping among neighbors but also help identify leaders who can assist in organizing other activities that IYouShe implements in the communities.

The Warehouse idea has been so successful that since 2013, it has been replicated in over 2500 communities across 98 cities in 32 provinces of the country, with the participation of more than 5 million people and 3,000 organizations! Because of this, IYouShe has created a Warehouse Network that provides training through a website, guide materials, and meetings so they can implement their model effectively, adapting it to their local conditions, of course.

Although IYouShe began its project with a small team that had little experience in social development issues, it has invested a lot in training and regularly updating its own staff. As its project has grown, it has been able to form a multidisciplinary team of around 178 employees, including social workers, sociologists, anthropologists, artists, psychologists, administrators, and more. This diverse team allows it to work with communities in a comprehensive way.

IYouShe started as a non-profit civil organization and, with the support of the local government, also set up a kind of social enterprise. This enterprise is used to manage the Stations in neighborhoods and offer them cheap public services. Most of its financial resources come from payments it receives from the government for these services. In other words, through its social enterprise, IYouShe asks the government for support with spaces, permits, and funding to operate stations in different communities, like the one for the railway workers mentioned earlier. This setup gives IYouShe more autonomy to choose and design its projects because the government only requires it to contribute to meeting the needs of the communities and promote their self-organization.

Additionally, to avoid relying 100% on funding from a single "client," IYouShe sells its services to foundations like Alibaba (in exchange for giving them recognition as a sponsor). It also charges a fee to residents for certain services, activities, or workshops offered in the community through the social enterprise platform. Furthermore, it makes agreements with social organizations (entrepreneurship workshops, charity shops, etc.) operating in the stations to donate part of their profits to the community fund. Sometimes, it also arranges matching donations with large companies, like the ones it secures with online sales platforms for the basket workshop for people with disabilities we talked about earlier.

To sustain its projects, IYouShe actively seeks support from volunteers within the neighborhoods to organize its various activities and frequently receives help from volunteers from other places (including international volunteers) who want to support these communities. In fact, the assistance from these volunteers and the broad support received from the government since its inception have been crucial for the organization's strengthening. By partnering with the government to promote community organization as a strategy to improve city conditions, the government has shown particular interest in supporting it with resources, spaces, training, etc.

Thanks to all these projects, IYouShe has become one of the top 100 most recognized social organizations in China. Now, besides running its own projects, it hosts regular events and activities where its more experienced community organizations share their know-how with communities in other parts of the country that are just starting out.

title: Barefoot College Solar Night Schools · India
introduction:
info 2012

Because education can truly provide opportunities for a better quality of life, India has opened many public schools in recent decades. But more than 60% of children –particularly girls– who live in the poorest rural areas of the country have not been able to make use of them. One of the reasons is that schools usually operate during the day, precisely when families need their kids’ help to do household chores and perform other activities that are crucial for their livelihoods, such as tending to animals and crops, or collecting water from wells. In addition, often the eldest sons must leave their studies and migrate to the city to support the family economically, and many girls get married and leave their parents at a very young age. Making education effectively accessible to these communities has been a challenge.

 

 

How to give these children a chance to study without risking their families’ survival?
short_description: Barefoot College's Solar Night Schools provide many children in India with access to education by addressing the various barriers that prevent them from attending regular public schools, as well and by catering to their specific needs and those of their families.

paragraphs.body_html: In 1975, an organization called the Barefoot College which worked with these populations in the Rajasthan desert became aware of the situation children of the region were facing. So it worked with the communities to open night schools that would enable families to actually send their kids to school without having to go without their much needed help for economic activities and household chores.

Unlike regular schools, the Barefoot College night schools have constantly adapted their model to better meet the economic and cultural realities of children to ensure kids can not only attend classes but actually make the most of them, for the benefit of themselves and their communities. To accomplish this, Barefoot college has deployed four main strategies:

  1. The school timetable and calendar cater to the children’s needs.
  2. The schools are supported by a whole network of development programs that help meet the various needs of students and their families so kids can make the most of the school experience.
  3. Schools are organized and run with a great deal of local participation.
  4. The curriculum abides by an intercultural education model meant to both expand opportunities for children and also yield benefits to communities.

The first thing night schools do to ensure that children can actually attend classes is that timetables are tailored to their needs: they begin at 6 pm and finish at approximately 10 pm, which allows children to finish helping their families first before going to school. In addition, attendance is flexible at specific periods of the year, such as during planting and harvesting seasons, or when students have to migrate seasonally to areas where animals can graze.

Second, Barefoot College reinforces its work with several of its other development programs in the region to ensure that children can actually go to school and make the most of their education. In this way, schools operate under what is known as an "integrated service delivery model” that meets the different needs of students or their families:

Because there is no electricity grid in these areas, the solar energy program enables communities to make solar lamps themselves so that classes can take place at night (hence the program’s name: Solar Night Schools). And because this is a desert and children must usually spend part of their day collecting water from the well, schools have also installed rainwater harvesting tanks so that children can study and still return home with water without having to choose one activity over the other for lack of time. Besides, teachers are taught to identify possible health concerns in children in a timely manner by the health program. And the carpentry workshop that works with people with disabilities supplies the schools with toys and didactic materials.

This integration of different programs and services into the schools also makes some vocational education possible, which means that children can join one of the different Barefoot College initiatives once they graduate instead of being forced to migrate to find jobs –perhaps as technicians in the solar energy program, for instance, or as teachers in the schools.

The third strategy that Barefoot College has deployed to make schools more relevant to the context and needs of children and their communities is to create different participation mechanisms and dynamics that ensure local stewardship of the project at all stages.

Every couple of years, for instance, students from all night schools cast a vote to elect a Children's Parliament that represents them before the communities and their authorities, voices their concerns and views as direct beneficiaries of the schools, and sometimes also monitors the work of teachers, the availability of drinking water, the functioning of solar lamps, or the arrival of educational materials. In this way, children are taught to be proactive in solving their own problems from a young age, and the schools are guaranteed a constant flow of feedback and assessment.

In addition, there is an Education Committee in every community, which is managed by the communities themselves on a voluntary basis and is responsible for organizing the schools’ tasks, managing the funds they receive from Barefoot College and coordinating community participation. This helps best leverage local contributions in terms of space, work, materials, and so on, and better address any needs that may arise according to the priorities and interests of the communities themselves.

What these Education Committees and the Children’s Parliament help accomplish is decentralizing school management and involving families with the project –thus increasing their confidence in the long-term benefits of the initiative and encouraging them to send their children to school. The annual celebration of the Balmela Festival – which thanks the communities for their contributions and keeps them up to date with the schools' progress– also reinforces this purpose of community involvement.

According to Barefoot College, "literacy" is what is acquired in school, while "education" is what is gained from family, traditions, culture, environment and personal experiences. And both are crucial to individual and communal growth –which is why the night schools have sought a balance between imparting local as well as universal knowledge, between teaching general literacy and providing learning at the family and community level. And this is also the reason why, in addition to attracting kids to school and making it more relevant to them and their communities, night schools seek to help them eventually join or re-enter regular public schools.

To accomplish this, solar night schools abide by an Intercultural Education model in which official curricula are supplemented with local knowledge, resources and skills. This means that schools regularly invite community members to talk to kids about important topics to local life, use local languages, offer vocational education, organize trips to local institutions such as the post office or the police station to see how they work, create their own learning materials, organize festivals and Children's Parliament meetings to keep the community involved, and so on. And, in addition, night schools offer special 10-month courses to prepare children who are ready to join public schools.

Teachers are usually community members themselves who have been trained with an intensive ten-day program that is later reinforced by monthly meetings in which problems are addressed and teaching skills and methods improved. In addition, non-caste or "lower" caste teachers are encouraged to participate so that children and their families respect and recognize them as their equals because of the awareness they gain of their role in their community and their lives.

Barefoot College covers the schools' fixed expenses with donations and grants –water tank set up, or solar lamp manufacturing, for instance. But other expenses –such as teachers' salaries, facility repair, special activities such as children's parliament meetings and training workshops– are paid for with the interests yielded by a capital fund that the organization set up a few years back by investing some donations. Sometimes the interests are not enough to cover these expenses and the organization must either use the fund's capital –putting the survival of the program at risk– or get new funding, which is not easy because resources for educational projects are increasingly difficult to get a hold of, particularly since the 2008 financial crisis. For this reason, Barefoot College is doing everything in its power to diversify its sources of support to be able to sustain its capital fund and to maintain the necessary independence and autonomy that keep the project’s decision making and model relevant to the communities.

In this sense, Barefoot College has had two interesting accomplishments. The first is that by formally integrating its various programs, the organization has been able to leverage the materials, personnel and even financial resources allotted to each program for the benefit of all other programs too (and this is important because some fields attract more support than others). Thus, any contribution to Barefoot College in general also supports the Night Schools in particular. The second is that the organization has managed to cover almost all the needs of the project with voluntary contributions from the communities themselves: more than 5000 honorary members support the work of the organization by providing school facilities, helping to manage them through local Education Committees, teaching the children, and others. This is distinctive because development projects are frequently organized from far away, in headquarters removed from the actual sites and people they are meant for.

The night schools’ long-term impact has been broad: many of the graduates now have children enrolled in the schools themselves, and cycles in which generation after generation reached adulthood without knowing how to read or write are being broken. In addition, many of the students want to become teachers, which broadens their options for their own future and, of course, that of the schools!

The project has been so successful since its launch in 1975 that it has spread to eleven states in the country and has opened more than 225 schools for the benefit of more than 75,000 children who could not otherwise join formal educational programs due to the precarious economic conditions of their families and communities.

In addition, since 1988, Barefoot College has replicated its model in some day schools that run independently but collaborate with the organization to serve children who, for various reasons related to marginalization, have been unable to enroll in other public or private schools. And Barefoot College has also worked with local authorities to implement parts of its model in public schools to attract children who have dropped out of education.

title: Lake Apompal Ecotourism · Mexico
introduction:
info 2018

The Los Tuxtlas region in the Mexican jungle of Veracruz is renowned for its beauty, cultural richness and abundance of natural resources. However, as these resources were being overexploited, the Mexican government created the Los Tuxtlas Biosphere Reserve, which imposed restrictions on land use to conserve them. Although these restrictions have helped care for the ecosystem, they have also pushed many of the local inhabitants to migrate, as they have limited their possibilities to graze cattle, grow large crops or cut down trees, that is, to use their land to make a living.

 

 

Is it possible to live off the jungle’s resources without destroying it?
short_description: Lake Apompal Ecotourism is part of a community-based ecotourism project organized by communities in the jungle of Veracruz, Mexico, to solve their economic needs by taking advantage of the natural resources of their jungle lands without destroying them.

paragraphs.body_html: In 1997, several communities in the region organized to promote a community-based ecotourism project that would allow them to continue using their land to survive. Families from the Miguel Hidalgo community founded the Lake Apompal Ecotourism cooperative and, in alliance with the communities of Las Margaritas and Adolfo Lopez Mateos, who also created their own community enterprises, formed the Network of Community-based Ecotourism of Los Tuxtlas (Red de Ecoturismo Comunitario de Los Tuxtlas, S.C.).

The cooperatives began by identifying which local resources, both natural and cultural, might be used to attract tourism (waterfalls, exotic animals in the area, traditional dishes, and so on). They also conducted environmental impact assessments to find out how many visitors could be received at any one time without affecting nature. Afterwards, they organized themselves into commissions to distribute responsibilities among the participating members so that all the needs of the ecotourism project would be covered: tour guides, food, security, entertainment, management, etc.

The legal registration of the network allowed the communities to participate in state and federal government programs as well as in those of various institutions such as Semarnat (Ministry of the Environment and Natural Resources) and CONABIO (National Commission for the Knowledge and Use of Biodiversity), designed to promote these types of initiatives. With support from these programs, the communities received funding that enabled them, among other things, to build the first cabins for visitors. These programs also enabled them to participate in activities that helped them promote their initiative, such as visits to similar projects around the country organized to foster exchange, collaboration and feedback among community-based ecotourism initiatives; tourism fairs designed to promote the projects; and training for the community commissions on topics such as cooking, tourism, languages, hiking, project management, entrepreneurship, customer service, conflict resolution, acupuncture and first aid.

Lake Apompal Ecotourism also teamed up with the other communities in the Network to support each other, either by promoting their respective products (vanilla, honey, etc.) or services (such as food and lodging) with their clients, or by leveraging the attractiveness of each community to attract more visitors, offering them a more complete and varied experience. Together, the communities designed tours and activities such as visits to the volcano, hiking, bird watching, “son jarocho” music events, horseback riding, bonfires, walks to explore the reserve's core, boat rides with a visit to the archeological site of Las Margaritas, and so on.

Besides seeking local collaborations, the project also reached out to researchers and professionals to explore its development possibilities and design action plans to become increasingly self-sustaining. Many of these have joined "Friends of the Network of Community-based Ecotourism of Los Tuxtlas”, a group of people who met during their visits to the communities and now support their initiative by inviting people over and spreading the word through a Facebook page and other social media.

The project also collaborates with several national universities such as UNAM, UAM-Azcapozalco, Universidad Veracruzana, as well as some foreign ones, which send students to earn social service credits in the communities. These students have helped in different tasks, such as giving language classes, working on the bioconstructions for lodging, designing interpretive trails, putting together a book of local recipes, creating and translating a website for the project to better promote it, designing its logo, and others. In return, the communities offer them lodging and only charge them for food.

Today, the initiative subsists thanks to all these collaborations (with universities, students, other cooperatives in the network, the government, experts and friends), to the income from tourism and to the voluntary contributions of the communities themselves, who in addition to their work, also lend their land and materials to the project.

The community-based ecotourism initiative that the Network of Community-based Ecotourism of Los Tuxtlas has come up with to enable an alternative livelihood for its communities has also had an impact outside the communities themselves: the project took part, for instance, in the drafting of the national ecotourism sustainability standard NMX-AA-133-SCFI-2006 SEMARNAT on "certified ecotourism" and also won an honorable mention at the national level as part of the 2008 Nature Conservation Recognition of the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (SEMARNAT).

Unfortunately, a few years ago, there were increasing complaints about some authorities misusing public funds earmarked for these types of projects and support began to wane. This caused some of the Network's cooperatives to abandon the project when they lost hope that this could become a real economic alternative for their communities. But Lake Apompal Ecotourism has persisted, convinced that ecotourism requires a much larger time investment than farming before yielding profit, and that it remains a good alternative to conserve their rainforest so that future generations ––both from within and outside their community–– can enjoy it. From their perspective, the project has matured a lot and has been gaining experience with training and collaborations, and what is needed now is to look for new ways of adapting their model of community-based ecotourism to ensure its survival.

One of the adaptations they are currently trying out is to diversify, looking for collaborations with new communities, particularly larger, more remote and more touristy ones, such as Catemaco or Tlacotalpan. With these upcoming collaborations, they hope to attract more tourists, offer more varied experiences, receive more support and increase their income so they can actually turn community-based ecotourism into a profitable economic alternative that does not endanger their beautiful and frail land.

title: BlueGreen Mexico · Mexico
introduction:
info 2021

Because of its beautiful Caribbean beaches, cenotes, pyramids, cultural heritage and natural wonders, Quintana Roo has become Mexico’s top tourist destination and one of the most visited places in the world. This has attracted hundreds of thousands of people who move here seeking job opportunities in tourism, which is now the state’s main economic activity (making more than 85% of its GDP). The irony is that, despite the enormous economic flow produced by this sector, more than 40% of the population continues to live in poverty! Among other reasons, this is because the jobs created tend to be precarious and are increasingly low-paying. Another reason is that many cities have been growing at great speed and with poor oversight, which has led to an insufficiency of infrastructure and basic services for some inhabitants.

To further complicate the situation, during the past decade the beaches have been getting massive amounts of sargassum, which affects marine fauna and deters tourism. Sargassum is a seaweed that usually floats about at sea and provides shelter to many animals, but agricultural waste, changes in water temperature and other factors have caused it to reproduce in excess. Its growth now prevents sunlight from reaching coral reefs and harms animals with the toxic substances released as it decomposes. The stagnation of sargassum on the beaches also affects tourists by making it impossible to swim in the ocean and because of the insufferable smell of rot. The economic impact of the drop in tourism in the region has been such that the Mexican navy has installed barriers at sea to stop sargassum from getting to the coast (these have already collected more than 10,000 tons!) and local governments and hotels are spending large amounts of money to clean the beaches and stop the economic crisis that the uncontrolled shoring of seaweed is causing in the region.

 

In the face of this economic and ecological crisis, how can we help?
short_description: BlueGreen is a plant nursery in Puerto Morelos, Mexico, that uses its earnings to support its community by donating parkland, holding fundraisers to benefit vulnerable groups, and giving houses to families in need. These houses are built with sargassum-made building blocks that BlueGreen invented to harness this seaweed that invades beaches, harms animals and hampers tourism (the main source of income for the region). Also, BlueGreen hires people with psychological disorders or addictions to give them an opportunity at rehabilitation.

paragraphs.body_html: According to Omar Vázquez, we all have a responsibility to do our bit to improve the conditions of the places we live in. This is why, since he launched his BlueGreen plant nursery business in Puerto Morelos in 2013 (BlueGreen México), he has been using it as a platform to make all kinds of contributions to his community, including parkland and sargassum houses!

Omar opened the plant nursery with a $1,500 pesos investment (about USD $75) by selling a few plants, but soon the business grew, and he started selling grass, vertical gardens, flowers, fruit trees, palms, composts and other items, as well as offering gardening services.

As soon as his business started growing, Omar decided to leverage part of his profits to help make his city cleaner and more livable. He began by donating plants and manpower to condition and beautify public spaces that are important to people with greenery and gardens, such as the sports center, the retirement home, the medical dispensary, some schools, and parks. On some of these occasions the government provided logistical support and some businesses have also joined efforts by contributing with things such as lunches for BlueGreen's workers.

BlueGreen has also gifted gardens to low-income families, toys to children in nearby rural communities, fruit from the plant nursery to the elderly, and even placed a speed bump near a local school because parents were concerned about the risk to their children when they left school. On top of all this, BlueGreen organized a competition to give away vegetable boxes and a workshop to teach Puerto Morelos residents how to make vegetable gardens at home.

BlueGreen has also encouraged people to join its efforts to improve the city and support vulnerable groups. Once, for instance, when a local family's home burned down, it held a plant sale with discounts and made people aware that all proceeds would be given to the family on everyone's behalf. Or in 2017, as a way to support the victims of the terrible earthquake in the states of Oaxaca and Chiapas (Mexico), it put a drive together and called on its community to donate food in exchange for plants and raffle tickets to win a whole garden for their home. Besides, BlueGreen announced that all the proceeds from sales at the market that day were to be destined to this cause.

Additionally, since 2014, BlueGreen has been organizing yearly environmental and health walks. The walks are another excuse to mobilize local residents to support each other and improve their city. Each year they are held for a different cause: once to support a girl, another time to plant palm trees in public spaces, and so on. Sometimes BlueGreen leverages these walks to invite experts to talk to people about topics of common interest such as the environment, food or health.

Ever since sargassum began to invade the beach of Puerto Morelos, BlueGreen decided to turn the problem into something positive by including beach cleaning as part of its services and leveraging the gathered seaweed to make compost and biofertilizers for its plants. But what really revolutionized the project was seeking the help of expert biologists to devise "Sarga Blocks": building blocks similar to adobe blocks but made of sargassum and other organic material that BlueGreen itself prepares, and which are thermal, odorless, non-toxic and cost a third less than conventional partition walls. After patenting the invention, BlueGreen has developed further versions of these blocks to fine-tune them. The latest version has a design with holes that simplify assembly and save construction costs, and also contains a small percentage of plastic waste that BlueGreen also gathers from beaches. According to the company, a house built with Sarga Block with a bedroom, living room, dining room, kitchen and bathroom, requires an average of 20 tons of sargassum and, with proper maintenance, can last up to 120 years.

Sarga Blocks have become a success in Puerto Morelos and in many other places in Mexico and abroad that also suffer from sargassum invasion, because by leveraging the seaweed that washes ashore, they reduce the environmental impact and cost of importing raw material from elsewhere, help reduce the amount of sargassum on the beaches and offer an affordable way to tackle the housing problem in the region. But Sarga Blocks also became famous because, very much in line with its way of working, BlueGreen set about using the Sarga Blocks to build and donate housing for people who are homeless or have been affected by hurricanes in various corners of the region. By 2020 the company had already donated 13 "Angelita Houses" (as Omar named them in honor of his mother) as well as an office space for the DIF (a public agency in charge of providing psychological support to low-income families that Omar wanted to thank for supporting him in the past). The house donations have been made spontaneously, sometimes because BlueGreen directly approaches people who seem to need them, sometimes because friendly organizations suggest families who could benefit, and sometimes because people in need approach the organization to ask for its support.

To further increase the impact of the project, BlueGreen hires people whose psychological conditions or substance abuse problems make it difficult for them to find a job. These people help the project collect sargassum from the beaches, manufacture the blocks and build the houses on either an hourly or a per-project basis, which helps them rehabilitate by providing them with an opportunity to earn some income and rebuild their lives.

The advantages of Sarga Block have caught the eye of increasingly large clients (hotels and even a residential developer), which enabled BlueGreen to buy its first machine to stop making the blocks by hand and increase its production. Nowadays it has a first factory in Majahual and makes between 30,000 and 60,000 blocks per month.

But in addition, its work model has caught the attention of many people because it has shown that harmful potential resources, such as sargassum and plastic, can be leveraged to minimize their environmental impact. The project has also proven that with community solidarity and participation, job opportunities for vulnerable groups can be expanded and the living conditions of people at large can be improved.

For this reason, these days students from several schools visit BlueGreen to learn from its experience, and the project is being documented by important media outlets, by the UN, and even by Netflix, which is making a documentary about its project.

To top it all off, in recent years officials from 12 of the 22 countries that share the sargassum problem (mainly from Africa and the Caribbean) have approached BlueGreen to hold talks and provide consultancy on its work model and on the Sarga Blocks to help in the design of social housing plans. The company has also collaborated with businesspeople interested in using its blocks to develop ecological housing plans, has accepted invitations to take part in sustainable material fairs in Europe to publicize its proposal and has received innovation awards, such as the one given by the OPPO company.

All this success has made BlueGreen more ambitious in its social and environmental mission, as it is not only preparing new products to leverage the sargassum (tiles, pots, and others) but is expanding its capacity to be able to donate 4 houses per month!

title: La Flor Agroecological Farm · Costa Rica
introduction:
info 2018

The need to supply a rapidly growing world population (which increased by 30% between 1990 and 2020) has led to the use of industrialized agricultural practices that have contributed to the destruction of ecosystems and to the loss of biodiversity. Besides, large concentrations of people in urban areas (now home to more than 50% of the population) and the stress that often comes with the modern way of life, have led to negative effects on the health and well-being of many people.

 

Is it possible to develop a less invasive, healthier way of life for ourselves as well as for the planet?
short_description: La Flor Agroecological Farm promotes sustainable agriculture and environmental education with volunteer programs, workshops, school visits and collaborative activities with local communities. It also offers a space for those seeking an alternative way of life who are interested in living and working on the farm and contributing to the formation of civic awareness regarding sustainability.

paragraphs.body_html: Twenty years ago, German Briggitte Draabe decided to contribute in her own little way and explore a concrete alternative to this problem by buying 10 hectares of land in the locality of La Flor in the mountains of Costa Rica, aiming to 1) reforest and share a space of conserved nature, 2) work hand in hand with local communities to build an alternative, sustainable agricultural model, and 3) promote environmental, social and intercultural education amongst neighbors, students and local and foreign visitors.

From the onset, the Farm (Finca Agroecológica La Flor) sought to invite neighboring communities to participate in the project so as to design and implement a more just and ecological model of agriculture, taking into account their points of view and needs. However, the initial response from the neighboring communities was not very favorable because they did not understand why people from outside the community were asking for their voluntary participation in the development of a project that was alien to them, so the Farm's team decided to come up with new ways to approach them: they created employment opportunities that were attractive due to the lack of jobs in the region and began to build cabins on their land to receive tourists, students and volunteers. In exchange for lodging, food, training and experience in techniques and models for sustainable agricultural development, the volunteers not only offer their support for the maintenance of the farm (they clean roads, work in the orchard, recover the forest, build cabins, take care of the animals, improve the means of dissemination of the project such as social media, and so on). Some also organize activities to benefit the local communities, such as cleaning the river or teaching courses that are free for the communities and at a cost for visitors to the farm (in sustainable agriculture techniques, Spanish as a second language for foreigners, yoga, medicinal plants, dance, etc.). In addition to these activities, The Farm launched other dynamics to attract its neighbors. It organized coffee sessions with the elderly, for instance, and, in collaboration with the Costa Rican Ministry of Environment and Energy, began to offer training courses on the use and exploitation of local medicinal plants and the creation of worm farms, among others. Besides promoting environmental education for both visitors and local communities, these programs helped improve the Farm's own space and develop its ecological agriculture model, which now includes farm animals, vegetable gardens that use nature-friendly technologies and fertilizers, a garden with medicinal plants and a seed bank.

In order to get donations and funding to build its project, in 1998 the farm initially established itself as a non-profit organization called Association for the Development of Environmental and Human Consciousness (ASODECAH in Spanish). But because this kind of support was hard to get, the organization decided to change its financial sustainability strategy and diversify its sources of support:

First, it looked for ways to make better use of local resources to save some expenses (learning to make bio-constructions for huts and using animal manure to grow crops for the gardens, for instance) and to get new income by producing and selling farm products (milk, eggs, and so on).

In addition, it started offering 4-week sustainable development courses, created a Spanish language program for foreigners, invited organizations and companies to hold retreats at the farm, encouraged schools and tourists to visit, and redoubled its efforts to increase the visibility of the project and attract more visitors by including it in web platforms for lodging  (such as Airbnb).

The volunteer program also became an important source of support. In addition to their work, volunteers help the farm attract Costa Ricans from other cities who are unfamiliar with the concept of these kinds of farms.

Today, the profits generated by the courses (which are shared between the teachers and the organization), the sales of farm products, the fees contributed by the volunteers, and the payment of tourists' living expenses have helped keep the project afloat.

Over time, the Farm has been adapting to its participants and has made the most of their ideas and knowledge in order to build a model capable of showing that taking on lifestyles that are more friendly towards people and nature is actually possible. The project is currently going through a transition period because its leaders and founders have been increasingly yielding control over to a team of young people who were once volunteers at the Farm. This new work team is renovating the Farm’s facilities and coming up with new ways of managing and promoting the project. Their focus is multidisciplinary and a lot more inclined towards civical-ecological practices that are fostered through arts, sports, self-care and ecoturism (trailing, thermal waters, botanical garden, relaxation activities, and others). This new strategy, which seeks to bring more visitors to the farm, is also betting on the creation of an ecovillage which would open its doors to more people invested in spending a period of time at the Farm while experimenting on and working towards an alternative, less invasive, healthier lifestyle.

title: Friends of Calakmul · Mexico
introduction:
info 2021

Mexico loses more than 1 million hectares of trees and vegetation per year, –it is one of the most severely deforested countries in the world! The conservation and management of its natural resources have not been well balanced with the economic needs of the country and its inhabitants. Over the years, the Mexican government has taken some measures to redress this problem by enabling the communities that live in natural areas to benefit economically from their lands without overexploiting forest resources and destroying the habitat of endangered species. Natural Protected Areas (NPAs), for instance, are a mechanism for landowners to manage nature in a more sustainable manner: agriculture and cattle farming are prohibited in the most vulnerable areas (the core NPA zones), but in the “less vulnerable” areas (the buffer zones), land-owning communities are granted permits to make a moderate and controlled use of resources, which is defined and monitored by means of environmental management plans. However, forests offer very important environmental services to alleviate the devastating effects of climate change (they capture water and CO2 emissions, for instance, and provide shelter to plants, animals and entire ecosystems), and these modest mechanisms are proving insufficient to protect them. Finding alternatives that further limit their use but still allow communities to sustainably live off the land remains a challenge.

 

 

How can rainforests be effectively protected when landowning communities depend on their resources for survival?
short_description: Friends of Calakmul offers payments to communities in southeastern Mexico so that they can earn a living by caring for the jungle instead of by exploiting it.

paragraphs.body_html: More than 20 years ago, a group of environmentalists put together a proposal to protect between 40,000 and 60,000 hectares of rainforest in a National Protected Area known as the Calakmul Biosphere Reserve in the state of Campeche, Mexico. The group realized that many of the region’s small-scale landowners live off payments from logging companies that buy their exploitation permits –issued by the government under the NPA model– or even buy their land itself to log it. As these environmentalists saw it, the land exploitation permits were not really helping the urgent task of forest conservation. But how to convince the communities to stop using their lands or selling their permits when they rely on this for their livelihood? So the group came up with what was then a very novel strategy: they would offer financial compensation to the communities in exchange for them to relinquish their rights of exploitation and commit to keeping their lands intact. This sum of money would have to be at least equivalent to what the landowners would otherwise make from using the permits themselves or from selling them to the logging companies. The exchange would enable both the community’s survival and the forests’ conservation. And, in order to raise the necessary funding to meet these payments, the environmentalists formed the civil association Friends of Calakmul (Amigos de Calakmul).

Friends of Calakmul negotiates agreements with the rainforest’s small-scale landowners –land that is usually communally owned– who take on the commitment of preserving the ecosystem and guaranteeing its environmental services. In other words, the communities receive annual payments and, in exchange, look after protected areas: they ensure that fire prevention lines are clean and that roads are accessible, they monitor that no logging, hunting or extraction of species takes place, they document and photograph illegal activities and notify the organization and the authorities when pertinent, and so on. The payments compensate the communities for the lost income from economic exploitation, which means that people can still live off the land, but now their revenue comes from caring for it rather than from exploiting or selling it!

So long as Friends of Calakmul complies with the payments, the agreement with the landowning communities is permanent. For this reason, the organization designed a comprehensive strategy that includes several financing mechanisms that enable it to fulfill its side of the deal. To begin with, in order to raise public funds and donations, Friends of Calakmul got registered as a non-profit civil association. This facilitated an important international contribution. And what the organization decided to do with this money was very profitable: instead of using it to make the community payments directly, the team decided to invest it in a capital fund that would yield interests. The fund was left in charge of the organization "Mexican Fund for the Conservation of Nature” (Fondo Mexicano para la Conservación de la Naturaleza) and, given the size of the sum, the yielded interests have been enough to cover the payments to the communities without having to reach for the actual investment.

The capital fund strategy has greatly reduced the organization’s need to seek annual funds and has made it less dependent on external sources of income. But over time, Friends of Calakmul has acknowledged a need to increase the fund's capital and seek other financing mechanisms to keep on offering attractive financial compensations to the small-scale landowners. After all, the needs of these communities have continued to grow, the instability of the financial market keeps interest rates fluctuating, and, in addition, Friends of Calakmul wants to expand the conservation project’s scope by attracting new communities.

For this reason, Friends of Calakmul sought an agreement with the Mexican government's National Forestry Commission (CONAFOR in Spanish) to complement its financing strategy with a mechanism known as matching funds or concurrent funds. The way these funds work in principle is that each payment the organization makes to communities in exchange for overseeing forest conservation is "matched" by CONAFOR. That is, CONAFOR gives the organization an equivalent amount of money on the condition that the community effectively demonstrates they fulfilled their commitment to preserve the rainforest.

To get additional funding, Friends of Calakmul is also building a scheme to partake in the carbon credit market, an international instrument that calculates (and rewards!) greenhouse gas emissions that have been averted or offset. How it works is that carbon credits are issued for every ton of carbon dioxide (CO2) that is altogether avoided or that has been subtracted from the atmosphere –thanks to the use of renewable energy, efficient use of electricity, reforestation, avoided deforestation, cleaning of rivers and lakes, and so on. These carbon credits, which are equivalent to Carbon Emission Certificates (CERs), can then be bought and exchanged for money at a price established by the rules of the international market. The carbon credits market is one of the recognized international mechanisms that incentivize different people and institutions to voluntarily reduce their environmental footprint and take responsibility for the problem of climate change: if a company produces emissions, it can “offset” them by buying CERs from people or institutions who effectively reduce emissions through a reforestation program, for instance, or through a renewable energy program. To partake in the market, Friends of Calakmul has partnered with Terra Global Capital, a consulting organization from the United States that specializes in acting as an intermediary and which helps by finding companies that emit greenhouse gases and are interested in buying carbon credits on the international market to offset them.  As the Calakmul communities neutralize emissions by maintaining the environmental services of the rainforest, they can get CERs and then sell them to these companies.

To add this carbon market scheme (and any other scheme that helps pay the communities) to its wider financing strategy, Friends of Calakmul is currently about to transfer its capital fund to a trust fund. This is a legal contract that helps guarantee the honest and efficient use of financial resources for their intended purpose, under the supervision and responsibility of a neutral third-party, usually a bank. This type of trust entails the creation of a Technical Committee comprised of financial contributors, beneficiaries (the communities) and project operators (Friends of Calakmul and the intermediary company). Each party can negotiate their points of view and responsibilities, reach compromises, and agree on the amount of support on offer and on the use of the funds. Then, the bank is made responsible for overseeing the efficient management of the fund, as intended by the contract. This trust-building strategy is important because donors, foundations, governments, NGOs and the communities themselves tend to be very fearful of the types of corrupt practices that are frequent in the development field: often, money does not reach its destination and remains in the hands of intermediaries. With the trust fund, money does not have to pass through the hands of the organization, but goes directly to the Trust, which ensures transparency in its management and gives a sense of certainty to everyone involved. In addition, this gives the project credibility, which often results in more donations.

Friends of Calakmul also relies on different collaborations with universities or other initiatives to offer temporary training programs for the communities that aim to improve their living conditions and provide them with relevant tools for their conservation task. Among others, these include workshops for families or for school children to make fertilizers with local resources, and training on the creation of family gardens.

The organization also partners with scientists whose research serves to evaluate the progress of the conservation efforts. These scientists help Friends of Calakmul better achieve its objectives because they monitor the Reserve's biodiversity, the population of different species (such as the jaguar) and help show donors that the rainforest has been effectively preserved (this used to be done with resource sampling but is now accomplished with overflights and satellite images).

Friends of Calakmul works in a comprehensive way: it secures economic resources to address the socio-economic needs of the rainforest’s communities and comes up with new ways for them to make a living while looking after nature. The project has proven to be very effective in terms of economic self-sufficiency (it has never missed the annual payments) and has also managed to effectively apply this new scheme to thousands of hectares of rainforest. Now, Friends of Calakmul is looking to expand into the Quintana Roo rainforest (also in southeastern Mexico) to cover a total of more than 300,000 hectares, which means that more ecosystems and more communities will benefit.

title: Allmende-Kontor Community Garden · Germany
introduction:
info 2021

In Berlin, as in many other large cities in Germany and around the world, the need to ensure housing for a steadily growing population (50,000 new inhabitants per year!) has spurred enormous real estate development which, to the regret of many citizens, has gradually invaded the public spaces and green areas where people used to gather, organize community projects and be in contact with nature. 

 

How can we recover public spaces and green areas so that people can interact and organize?
short_description: ALLMENDE-KONTOR is a public community garden in Berlin, Germany that offers a meeting space for people interested in growing their own food, enjoying nature in the city and collaborating with different people to build cultural, social or political projects. It also supports other community gardens to promote the participation of Berliners in the urban design of their city.

paragraphs.body_html: A possible solution that has taken off all over the world and has a long history in Berlin is the creation of community gardens made by citizens to guarantee public spaces where the community can self-organize to produce its own food, maintain green areas in the city and, in some cases, address neighborhood problems or promote different types of political or social projects.

Many of these spaces have been recovered after long struggles by activists or neighbors, as happened with the Tempelhof airport land that fell into disuse in 2008 after the construction of the Brandenburg International Airport. When this happened, there were many clashes between those who wanted to use the land for private or commercial purposes and those who wanted to keep it as a public and natural space for the enjoyment of all Berliners. The latter mobilized en masse (with demonstrations, road shows, picnics, and so on) until they got the government to agree to keep the land as a public park.

The Allmende-Kontor Community Garden (Gemeinschaftsgarten Allmende-Kontor) project began in 2011, when a group of activists who participated in these mobilizations succeeded in getting the government to rent them 5000 square meters within the new park land at a symbolic price of €1 per square meter per year to create a community vegetable garden that would be self-managed and serve as a space of leisure and conviviality for all Berliners. As the group did not have a legal status at the beginning, they received support from the organization Workstation Ideenwerkstatt eV to make the necessary arrangements to set up the garden, until they decided to form their own organization in 2014 and legally registered as a civil association to facilitate the growth and management of their project.

At first, the Allmende-Kontor team received a lot of help from other community gardens and volunteers to build the first orchard containers for people to grow their own food and also to start organizing events and workshops in the new "Town Square," a space they designed for the fellowship and organization of the project members. Many of these workshops were an opportunity for the project members to get guidance and training on how to manage the garden and to promote the project and attract more people. In a short while, they planted more than 90 trees in the park and installed around 300 orchard containers, many of which are managed in teams and a few of which are managed by everyone, such as the bee garden, the box with dyeing plants and the compost box.

Today, in addition to offering a space open to the public for planting the vegetable gardens, Allmende-Kontor promotes more environmentally friendly agricultural practices through workshops and tours for schools, members of other gardens and the public at large. It also organizes cultural and educational events such as concerts, film screenings, lectures and sporting events. Above all, Allmende-Kontor fosters a community culture that promotes the right of everyone to participate in the urban design of their city and works on a political project in conjunction with Berlin's more than 200 community gardens to reclaim and preserve green public spaces for the benefit of the population.

As one of the main objectives of the project is to achieve a self-organizing garden community, the Allmende-Kontor team has sought to facilitate the participation of all its members under the same values and terms. For instance, the team created a manifesto in collaboration with other projects to set out the goals and priorities of the community gardens. And within Allmende-Kontor, it drafted rules detailing all the various roles and responsibilities. In addition, it periodically organizes workshops to train participating gardeners (in methods of irrigation, use of seeds, and so on) and opened a Nextcloud account (an internet data storage server) with the information from the workshops so that members can access it whenever they need it. It also created a mailing list to be able to send messages to the entire community simultaneously and publishes an online calendar and a monthly newsletter so that everyone is up-to-date on the activities that others are doing and can better organize themselves accordingly.

Allmende-Kondor has tried to organize the gardening community into color-coded neighborhoods: the orchard containers are numbered and assigned to one of 9 neighborhoods (red, yellow, orange, green, pink, etc.) and each neighborhood must elect a representative who will work with other neighborhoods to coordinate the distribution of activities of common interest such as water, garbage management, and others. But since not all gardeners participate with the same regularity, this scheme does not work as precisely in practice, which is why the project improvises and continues to explore other ways to keep the garden organized and functioning.

In addition to the internal meetings of each color-coded neighborhood, the gardeners generally meet once a week to make decisions about the project and to socialize; once a month to pick up the garbage from the park; from time to time to exchange experiences and knowledge with other community gardens or experts and to support each other (with plant exchanges, for example); and once a year to discuss and approve applications from newcomers and to redistribute orchard containers that are not being well utilized.

To cover the costs of building and maintaining the garden (tools, infrastructure, repairs, administration, etc.) Allmende-Kontor is financed by the proceeds from workshops, visits, events and from the donations it gets a hold of. It also charges a fee of between €30 and €60 euros for the use of each orchard container and requires that at least one of the people who manage it has a membership in the project (which costs around €12 per year). The payment of these fees is only to support the operation of the project because the land rental contract is only temporary and both the containers and everything on the land are public property.

Allmende-Kontor is convinced that community gardens are urban spaces that help improve the nutrition and quality of life of city dwellers and allow them to take part in defining what they want and expect from their city. For this reason, it devotes a large part of its efforts to raising public awareness of the importance of initiatives like its own. It participates in forums, discussion tables and other outreach activities, such as the "Day of the Sheep" in which it invites shepherds to bring their flocks to spend time with children and other visitors and show them how the sheep keep the place pruned without scaring away the local birds as machinery does. Sometimes it organizes political and cultural events, such as concerts, open-air film screenings, and so forth. It also invites schools, other gardens and the general public to participate in composting activities, take guided tours of the garden, and attend summer camps or workshops organized by some of the garden teams (on healthy eating or permaculture, for instance). It also published a book with recommendations for urban agriculture, invented a board game that reproduces the dynamics of the garden, and collaborated in the publication of a map of all the community gardens and urban agriculture projects in the city so that people can learn about them and visit them.

In addition to raising awareness among the general population about the importance of promoting the creation of new gardens and protecting existing ones, Allmende-Kontor provides training to other gardens and does a lot of advocacy work. It has teamed up, for instance, with other gardens in the city to participate in conferences (on solidarity economy, alternative agriculture, etc.), organize meetings, and meet with government authorities to share their proposals for urban policy and the maintenance of green spaces in Berlin.

Allmende-Kontor has shown that public spaces can be secured and self-organized with the participation of citizens. The size of its plot, its location and the large number of participants (it currently has around 500 gardeners) have made it an emblematic project within the movement of more than 200 community gardens in the city.

title: Yu Demonstration Village · China
introduction:
Info 2023

 

Picture this: You’ve been through tough times of war and hunger, but you’ve managed to pull yourself out of poverty and become one of the wealthiest people in your country. Then, suddenly, someone makes you see that you need to change the way you’re doing things because what’s allowing you to grow is also causing significant harm to your health.

Now, imagine this: You’re inspired to make that change, and you do it so well that you become the go-to example for many others who, like you, want to better their lives in a balanced manner!

That’s exactly what happened to the small village of Yu (in Chinese: 余村),  in Zhejiang province, eastern China, which has become a model village for sustainable rural development across the whole country.

 

Like many other rural towns in China, for decades Yu saw immense wealth through bold ventures into large-scale manufacturing, chemical plants, and mining. But over the past 20 years, it’s had to drastically change its development model because the cost was becoming too high—destroying the countryside, polluting its rivers and forests, causing severe health issues among its population—and the authorities decided to step in.

In 2003, China embarked on a major reform where towns like Yu had to, one way or another, figure out how to create a new model of economic growth that’s more eco-friendly. As part of this, Zhejiang province launched a program to revitalize 10,000 of its villages and use 1,000 of them as models to pilot ideas for achieving that transformation (a strategy commonly used in China: testing out ideas or policy proposals in specific communities, and if they work, scaling them to other regions).

To successfully coordinate this ambitious project, the province didn’t just assemble a multi-sectoral task force consisting of significant government ministries (Ecology, Justice, Education, Statistics, Energy, Finance, Human Resources, Food and Materials, Natural Resources, the Women’s Federation, etc.). It has also been coordinating the efforts between Party members, authorities at all levels, and representatives from the participating villages.

 

The residents of Yu, one of the villages selected for these pilot ‘experiments,‘ began having extensive discussions on how to meet the mandate of creating a new, more sustainable development model.

 

How to create a new economy that thrives without destroying our region?
short_description: Yu is recognized in China as a model village for the nationwide sustainable rural development project. By coming together as a community, clearly defining its priorities, and crafting long-term plans, the village has dramatically shifted its development model to restore the natural landscape of its region and build a more eco-friendly economy. It has achieved this mainly by betting on rural tourism, collaborating with entrepreneurs, and selling agricultural products such as tea and bamboo.
location_map_text: Yu Village, Anji County, Zhejiang Province, China

paragraphs.body_html:
Indeed, most of their mountains were already gone, their waters were dirty, and the air was heavily polluted. Something had to be done—and fast!

 

1. They put a stop to the destruction.

 

First and foremost, in just 3 years, the residents of Yu took the bold step to shut down three limestone quarries and the cement factory that had brought them so much wealth. And naturally, since the economic impact of closing these industries was significant and immediate, they began to focus all their energy on adapting their region to transform it into a rural ecotourism destination, creating jobs to replace the old ones.

2. They restored the landscape and the natural environment.

 

The people in Yu identified different elements of their region that could be utilized to attract tourism and make money—'ecological assets' like their bamboo forests, landscapes, etc. The village representative committee started by cleaning up the rivers: They assigned someone to conduct daily inspections, drafted several laws to prohibit the discharge of kitchen and bathroom water and the dumping of garbage into them, and formulated a plan for wastewater treatment.
