They also banned unauthorized construction along the riverbanks. They encouraged the community to pick up trash and called on professionals to clean up the waters. All of this, along with the closure of factories and mines, allowed the forest to quickly recover and become a more attractive spot for tourism, and also very important for China and the world, because today it captures large amounts of carbon emissions!

3. They beautified the village, making it more livable and visitor-friendly.

 

To spruce up their village and make it more livable and welcoming to visitors, the community built a canal to bring water down from the dam, installed sanitary latrines in every house in the village, and created a system capable of centrally treating all their waste. They also developed a new waste collection and management system, built a parking lot at the entrance of the village to keep pollution emissions under control inside, set up a tourist center, public restrooms, and more.

The village erected fire prevention infrastructure, established exercise tracks, restored homes and other sites that could be appealing for their cultural or historical value, and collaborated with university designers to build modern facilities inspired by local culture to enhance the landscape —such as a series of rest pavilions designed with Tsinghua University. Furthermore, they built an auditorium, a library, and an exhibition hall to share their project's story with visitors!

Besides, they repurposed some vacant houses to create spaces for community gatherings, where activities for neighbors of all ages are organized, offering training courses in various skills, childcare services, and more.

4. They created job alternatives.

 

To make up for the income they used to earn from working in factories, mines, or the cement plant, many people spruced up their homes to accommodate city tourists interested in spending time in nature (accommodations known as 农家乐 in China). Others opened restaurants and businesses for these visitors. All this preparation, besides creating a new source of income for local people, has provided jobs for many people from other regions.

5. They attract people who can contribute to the project.

 

Another really cool move the Yu community made to liven up village life and make it more appealing to tourists from different places was creating the Global Partners Program. This aims to bring together folks from the community who had migrated to cities for work and other people from the country and around the world interested in living in the countryside to start up creative and innovative businesses in Yu that not only make them money but also contribute to the community's project.

With the Program, folks interested can pitch their project to the community for evaluation to see if it aligns with its interests. They need to show what they want to do and how it will benefit the village. For that, they need to present their business plan, market study, projections, etc. The community assesses whether the idea is feasible, whether it competes with businesses or projects that locals could do—hostels, cafes, etc.—, the profile of the person proposing the project, etc., and takes about 2 or 3 months to respond. Interested parties should tell the village of Yu what they need to implement their business or project, and the village will respond with what it can offer to support them, often at no cost (infrastructure, unused land, etc.—All of Yu's land belongs to the whole community). But of course, it will also set requirements, such as the minimum number of customers they must achieve, the amount of money they must earn, etc.

Based on this, they'll agree on the percentage of profits the partner will have to hand over to the community each year (in addition to the taxes they normally have to pay to the government, like any business), so that the community can invest it in the village project. This percentage will range from a minimum amount (which the partner will have to pay even if their business doesn't thrive) to a maximum (in case the partner does really well). The agreement is for 5 years: if the partner's project works out, it can be renewed; if not, it's terminated.

This way, the Program allows the community to benefit from the investment and projects that partners bring to improve the village, which complement those of the local people, help make the place more attractive for the tourism project, and promote it, while also bringing economic benefits through the profit-sharing agreement.

One of the partners, for instance, opened a coffee shop inspired by classic Chinese comics. Another developed a project to grow organic produce for home delivery to urban consumers. Others are collaborating with the community, inviting city tourists to go mushroom and bamboo shoot picking — a unique countryside experience that many are willing to pay for, and which enables farmers to earn more from these products than if they were to collect and sell them independently at low market prices.

Other partners were loaned the land where the cement factory used to be to set up a bar, which is now serving as a hangout spot for tourists in the afternoons and has become a communal space for returnees, new partners, and the local community. The bar hosts concerts, movie screenings, corporate events, and music classes for kids, many of which are offered for free to the locals.

These same partners have also fixed up other plots of land amidst the beautiful forest landscape to organize music and sports events, company or organization meetings, and camps. The community can use these spaces and facilities to organize their own activities twice a month, as they not only loaned the land to the partners but also supported them with infrastructure like electricity, roads, public bathrooms, etc.

So, they've had each other's backs! The partners bring in projects that the villagers wouldn't otherwise pursue, draw in visitors, share their profits, and sometimes offer them jobs for some extra income — like preparing food for events. And the community, on their end, loans them the space to do so and helps them set it up.

To help the partners who come to Yu get to know each other, hang out, build community, collaborate, share ideas and resources, and have a space to incubate and develop projects that benefit the village, make it more attractive, and provide more income-generating options, the community built the "Global Partners Co-Creation Space of Yu Village", a spacious and modern building with offices, exhibition hall, reading room, conference room, etc.

6. They boost Art and Culture.

 

To create more incentives for people to want to visit or spend time in Yu, they've also formed a team to promote cultural activities and develop movies, stories, and other art forms to reclaim the area's history and share it with visitors. With some of the partners, for instance, they've already organized movie screenings, concerts, etc.

7. They developed industrial projects with a greener approach.

 

To create even more income sources for its people, the community has also invested in industrial projects with a greener focus. For example, they built a farm where visitors can pick fruits all year round, receive agricultural science training, and enjoy guided tours. They also partnered with Anji Yucun Qingyutang Agricultural Technology to construct facilities where, alongside local farmers and using cutting-edge technology, they can raise large quantities of high-quality fish through eco-friendly processes.

To construct and drive this transformation project in a coordinated, planned, and autonomous manner, the village has revamped its governance system to enable full community participation and ensure adherence to laws throughout the process.

Yu holds elections so the community can choose its representatives: They set up a committee to organize the election, post the list of candidates in public places, and later publish the results so people can ensure that the process was legal.

Also, to ensure villagers have a say in both the overall village development project and everyday matters like waste management, authorities arrange meetings to gather their opinions along with those of the village elders. These opinions are then presented to the local Party members' assembly for review and suggestions, and subsequently taken to the People's Congress to make decisions.
To carry out these decisions and manage the village, Yu designed teams responsible for different tasks — like the sanitation system management team, for instance.

And to oversee this work and ensure things are being done as agreed, the village established a sophisticated monitoring system that includes:

  1. Legal consultants who review decisions to ensure they comply with the law.
  2. Professional supervision from the People's Affairs Supervision Committee, which handles general community matters and must review and sign off on any village income or financial statement. They also need to approve payments exceeding 5000 yuan (approx. $700 USD) before they're made.
  3. Oversight from the villagers themselves, firstly because expenses are printed and displayed in public places (such as authorities' salaries, payments for works, food expenses, etc.). And also, because the village created a television platform called "People's Communication" that informs about community-related issues.
Also, to handle any conflicts that may arise among villagers and prevent them from escalating, the village set up a Mediation Office and a local Circuit Court (a local courthouse).

For all these reasons, the village of Yu was recognized in 2015 as a Demonstration Village of Democracy and Rule of Law at the national level, which means that today it serves as a model for many villages across the country, learning from its experience to strengthen their own governance and autonomy.

The success of Yu in becoming a demonstration village for China's transition to a greener economy is thanks to its own efforts, the resources it has gained from tourism activities, and the ideas, investments, and money generated by Global Partners.

But it's also thanks to significant measures taken since the beginning of the reform at a national level (in China), in the province (Zhejiang), and in the county (Anji) where Yu is located. These measures have greatly helped it in developing its project to become an attractive destination for rural ecotourism.

 

At the national level, companies that adopted more environmentally friendly practices started to be compensated, reforms were made to the Environmental Protection Law, inspections were initiated, and new environmental protection taxes were collected.

In addition, Zhejiang province rolled out another program known as the 'Double Eight Strategy' with which the government identified the strengths of the province and devised actions to bolster them (strengths in its economic structure, geography, industry, natural resources, culture, etc.). For instance, it coordinated urban and rural areas to improve the roads connecting them, making it easier for city dwellers to travel less than two hours to visit rural villages.

The province relocated its industrial parks.

Modernized factories by charging higher electricity rates to inefficient companies, while providing incentives to those adopting pollution control measures.

Additionally, efforts were made to clean up the area, primarily by promoting cooperation among all villages. For instance, they established the 'river chief system', appointing around 60,000 individuals ('river chiefs') responsible for managing the drainage basin, protecting rivers, preventing and controlling pollution, and restoring them.

It also improved healthcare services, water supply, waste management, and started regulating pesticide use to promote more eco-friendly agriculture, etc.

All of this made the province a national benchmark for other provinces also seeking to create a less environmentally destructive rural development model.

Moreover, Anji County (where Yu is located) has won significant awards for its concrete proposals to make Zhejiang a more eco-friendly province: the recognition as a National Ecological County, the China National Environmental and Habitat Award, the UN-Habitat Scroll of Honor, etc. These awards have greatly helped promote the region and attract all kinds of tourism to places like Yu. This includes 'red tourism', which refers to people from socialist-leaning areas who are interested in visiting places with interesting implementations of socialist ideas.

One of these concrete proposals was to create and strengthen the Anji brand, not just for being a beautiful region where you can enjoy nature, but also for its wild products such as white tea and bamboo, which is biodegradable and can replace materials like plastic or wood. These products are now widely recognized and well sold throughout the country, serving as an additional attraction for visitors and a source of income for local farmers.

Another significant source of support for Yu village's project was the recognition from China's president, which, in turn, attracted media attention and garnered widespread coverage. In 2005, Xi Jinping, who at the time was the Secretary of the Provincial Committee of the Communist Party in Zhejiang, visited Yu to inspect its progress in the project of renovating 10,000 villages and creating 1,000 demonstrative villages. Upon seeing what the Yu community had achieved in such a short time, he was extremely impressed, dubbed it a "model village", and urged the rest of the province to take note and learn from its transformation efforts.

It was precisely during that visit that Xi delivered his Two Mountains Theory, which a few years later (2017) would be enshrined in the Communist Party constitution as a guiding principle for modernizing rural development across China and making it more ecological.

Xi, after commending the Yu community for having the courage to close their quarries and factory, said: "Green waters and green mountains are as good as mountains of gold and silver". In other words, by taking care of nature (its waters and mountains), it can bring economic benefits to those who live in it.

Thanks to Yu's long-term planning for a more environmentally friendly economy, it has earned recognition from the Chinese Ministry of Culture and Tourism as a Key Rural Tourism Village and the "World's Best" title from the United Nations World Tourism Organization. This accolade has also allowed it to host the Second International Congress on Rural Tourism and has drawn officials from villages across the country who visit constantly to learn from its experience.

In 2018, Yu achieved certification as a National Scenic Area at the 4A level, and today it's focusing its efforts on reaching the 5A category, which is the highest in China and serves as a reference for millions of tourists in the country when choosing their travel destinations.

 

Because of this, Yu now faces the enormous challenge of preparing to accommodate an increasing number of tourists. This includes enhancing its infrastructure, managing resources like water more effectively, and refining its organizational structures. And also, the challenge of becoming able to meet the growing demand for its products, such as tea and bamboo, without compromising the care of its natural surroundings or jeopardizing its food sovereignty.

title: Universal Basic Income (Lab2050) · South Korea
introduction:
info 2022

Nowadays, even in the wealthiest countries there is a lot of inequality and unemployment, and some people are already wondering how the situation will be in a few years if technology continues to replace many activities that humans have traditionally done.

For example, in South Korea, 10% of the population holds half of the country’s wealth, 1 in 10 adults under 30 are unemployed, and it is estimated that by 2024, 15% of jobs will already be automated.

How to prepare for a future with so much inequality and fewer and fewer jobs?
short_description: The Lab2050 is a think tank in South Korea dedicated to proposing evidence-based public policies to address future challenges through conducting research and social experiments. Today, they are promoting the creation of a Universal Basic Income as a strategy to tackle inequality and the increasing unemployment due to automation in their country.

paragraphs.body_html: For Lab2050, an idea that would be well worth trying is to create a Universal Basic Income, that is, a sum of money given to every citizen at regular intervals on an individual basis, regardless of their economic status, employment situation, etc.

Lab2050 is a think tank that a group of journalists, economists, and other professionals created in 2017 to explore the challenges that the near future brings to Korea and ways in which they can be addressed to achieve a society with less inequality and more freedom for people. In other words, it is a "policy laboratory" where they focus on exploring possible paths and solutions to the country's problems and obtaining evidence to propose solid ideas to society and the policymakers who will make decisions in the future.

For example, to promote its Universal Basic Income proposal, Lab2050 has sought evidence:

 

 

  1. Exploring the experience of others — The idea of Universal Basic Income is not new and in recent years several countries have been conducting pilots of different sizes and durations to understand what is needed to implement it, what kind of response people have when it is given, what impact it has on the economy, etc. That's why Lab2050 has been organizing workshops, study groups, and conferences to invite people who have been involved in these experiments in one way or another (politicians, entrepreneurs, academics, etc.) to share their experience and the pros and cons they have seen in implementing Universal Basic Income, as well as the responses they have found to questions that may concern Korean society such as: Why should we work to have the government give part of our taxes to the rich or to people who do not need it? How will so much money be paid? What will happen if people, having their lives solved, no longer want to work? etc. By exploring experiences, Lab2050 has found several arguments to promote its proposal to implement Universal Basic Income in Korea, such as: a) That selecting beneficiaries and administering aid currently given to vulnerable groups - such as student scholarships, support for the unemployed, etc. - is expensive, time-consuming, prone to corruption, and sometimes so complex that it does not benefit those who need it most. Therefore, creating an alternative system that uses these same resources to support the entire population instead of specific groups could be more efficient and cheaper. b) That the budget to finance it could also be obtained by establishing special taxes that help achieve other important objectives for the country - such as taxing polluting companies to encourage them to improve their practices, for example. c) That people would hardly want to stop working just because they receive the Universal Basic Income, because the amount they would receive would only serve to survive and, above all, to have a minimal economic security to make decisions in their life with more freedom and not just out of necessity - because it is a constant, stable, and secure income. d) That it can help resist and overcome social or economic crises - Unconditional support that several countries gave to their entire population during the Covid-19 pandemic not only allowed many families to survive but also helped keep the economy active, with money circulating, etc.

1. Preparing surveys and simulations: In addition to reviewing how others have fared with Universal Basic Income, Lab2050 has been using surveys and conducting simulations to explore how well it could be received in Korea, how it could be implemented, and what results it could have. For example, they created an interactive questionnaire to raise awareness about Universal Basic Income and to better understand people's stance on this proposal. In the "Universal Basic Income Calculator", as they called this online tool, people can understand what it entails, what options there are for implementing it, what consequences would result from making one decision or another, etc. Based on their responses to questions like "Are you in favor of abolishing the employment policy and providing a basic income with these resources?" and "What kind of basic income do you want?", the questionnaire shows them the possible scenarios and consequences of their decision. Lab2050 has also conducted surveys among citizens to learn about their habits and, based on them, has designed simulations of the different scenarios that could arise if a Universal Basic Income were established. These simulations have shown that implementing it would be useful for distributing wealth more equitably and that while the top 20-30% would lose part of their income, the rest would benefit, increasing consumption and stimulating the economy.

1. Implementing Social Experiments: All these findings have motivated the Lab2050 team to go further and test the evidence they have been accumulating. Today (2023), they are collaborating with the government of the Gyeonggi Province, where a quarter of South Koreans reside, to implement one of the most ambitious pilot experiments with Universal Basic Income. Since 2022 and until 2027, the government has been providing monthly support of 150,000 won (around $110 USD) to about 3,500 people, with the only condition being that they are residents of the area. The money is provided in the form of vouchers that can only be used to consume at local small businesses (to support the local economy) and for a limited time (so that people do not accumulate them and they continue to benefit others). Before launching the experiment, Lab2050 organized meetings with residents to explain the project and get their views on the problems that they believe can be solved with Universal Basic Income. Once underway, they established a research team to observe the behavior of two groups of people (one of "treatment" and one of "comparison") in different areas of the province with different economic activities to compare their experiences. They are also conducting interviews to monitor whether this income improves their quality of life at both the individual and community levels. Although the Gyeonggi pilot is still in its early stages and there is no way to draw conclusions yet, the team is convinced that the results of this social experiment will help them to continue thinking about the future of South Korea and anticipate its problems.

Lab2050 knows that there are many urgent issues that need to be addressed in the present, and if they want to attract people interested in financing their projects, which are aimed at preparing for the future, they need to be creative in demonstrating the value they bring to society. That's why Lab2050 bets on the strategy of obtaining evidence to build its proposals, since it provides confidence and protects its reputation, and, above all, it allows them to offer solid arguments to society and policymakers to discuss and make political and economic decisions for their own benefit.

title: Beautiful Stores · South Korea
introduction:
info 2022

In South Korea, just like anywhere else, lots of folks worry about inequality, poverty, and how we’re trashing the planet at breakneck speed. But many of them don’t have a clue about how they can make a difference.

How can we make it easier for people to contribute to creating a better world?
short_description: In South Korea, the Beautiful Stores sell second-hand items and products that their team designs using materials that factories would otherwise waste, so that they can be used for longer before being discarded. They also resell environmentally-friendly items that are made with good working conditions, as well as those made by small producers or vulnerable groups. This way, the Beautiful Stores provide people with opportunities to make a difference by producing, buying, sharing their unused items, or volunteering. Additionally, a portion of their profits goes towards supporting community organizations and social entrepreneurs. To reduce and offset their own environmental impact, they have implemented various strategies such as using recycled paper and supporting tree-planting organizations.

paragraphs.body_html: About 20 years ago, convinced that the world needs everyone's participation to fight poverty and stop the destruction of the planet, and that all small actions count because "great rivers are made up of little drops of water" the Beautiful Foundation began exploring the idea of opening "charity shops" in Korea, like those that already existed in other countries.

Charity shops collect used clothing that people no longer want or need, and resell it so that others can further use it for a while instead of buying new clothes (which is one of the most polluting activities that exist!). Moreover, although the working models may vary, almost all charity shops allocate a portion of their earnings from the sale of these clothes to support different social causes (see for example Spasibo!). Therefore, this type of shops provide people with the opportunity to contribute in their own small way, either by donating what they no longer need for the shop to sell, or by purchasing and using the products sold by them.

After exploring for a while whether this idea of buying second-hand goods would be accepted by the Korean market, in 2002, the Foundation decided to create a whole chain of stores called "Beautiful Store" (in Korean 아름다운가게), and in just 5 years they had opened about 100!

Starting from the basic model of charity shops, Beautiful Stores have been building a very ambitious project to facilitate, in every possible way, that their spaces serve to promote behaviors that help build a world that is fairer and less abusive towards nature. Nowadays they do this by:"

SELLING RECYCLED PRODUCTS. They sell gently used, affordable second-hand products that they obtain through donations at their stores, by offering pick-up service for large donations and for companies that give them unsold stock products (such as jars, utensils, etc.), and by organizing collection drives with some schools. This way, they help prevent these products from going to waste and encourage people to buy fewer new items.

SELLING UPCYCLED PRODUCTS. The Beautiful Stores have also hired a team of designers to start their own commercial brand, "Eco Party Mearry", with which they sell handbags, dolls, cushions, and other items that they create from donated items that they are unable to sell or from scraps of fabric and other production remnants that they obtain through B2B agreements with factories (a process known as "upcycling"). As of 2022, the Beautiful Stores have created more than 10,000 upcycled products, using around 3 tons of leather, old clothes, etc. that would have otherwise been directly discarded each year.

RESELLING PRODUCTS "OF PUBLIC INTEREST". The Beautiful Stores also resell "fair trade" products that they buy from companies that specialize in importing this type of merchandise (that is made by small artisans or vulnerable groups, in a way that doesn't harm the environment and with good working conditions for the workers, etc.). They do this to take advantage of the reach of their stores to promote and introduce these products to potential buyers, thereby helping the groups that produce them, supporting certain social or environmental causes and promoting ethical and environmentally friendly ways of producing, transporting, etc. This way, they offer their customers a direct opportunity to have an impact through their purchases. Some of these products have sold so well in their stores that they were able to become independent and create their own brand, and still, Beautiful Stores continues to sell their products to support them.

PRODUCING AND SELLING THEIR OWN PUBLIC INTEREST PRODUCTS. In recent years, Beautiful Stores have been producing their own merchandise to support different groups and causes through their sales. For example, they have partnered with farmers from the Korean island of Jeju to produce bottled tangerine juice, and with the Filipino cooperative of small producers "Laua-an" to make muscovado sugar and organize support programs with their community.

SUPPORTING SOCIAL CAUSES WITH PROFITS. Besides helping all these groups, causes, and production methods by selling products, the stores donate more than 10% of the profits from those sales to support local community-grassroot projects or entrepreneurs who are driving interesting initiatives in different parts of the world (called Beautiful Fellows). The Fellows receive monthly maintenance support for 3 years so they can focus on developing and driving their projects, and they are then invited to meetings with other current and former fellows to continue making connections and supporting each other. To choose them, the stores periodically open calls for interested parties to present their ideas and work proposals, and show that they meet criteria such as: a) being founders of organizations that already have at least two members and three years of operation; b) having a strong social mission and leadership capacity; and c) "demonstrating" that their work model can actually solve problems. One of the fellows they have supported, for example, is a young man who created a business that trains his fellow orphans in the orphanage where he grew up to design and sell vertical gardens. In 2016 alone, the Beautiful Stores donated around $40 million dollars to these types of projects and people.

INFORMING. Stores are training their staff and providing informative brochures for customers to educate them about the enormous amount of waste in the industry, and to inform them about recycling, upcycling, and other alternatives. Sometimes, they even send their team to local schools to talk to children about the products they consume, their impact on the environment, and the working conditions of the people who make them. They want to make sure the kids get the message that ethical consumption is super important, starting from when they're young.

As a company, Beautiful Store divides its team into two sections. The first one is in charge of the administrative work and decides where to spend the money (i.e. which ethical products to buy and resell, who they will provide financial support to, etc.). The second section is responsible for "making" the money by, for example, running the stores.

Amazingly, aware of how its own existence contributes to pollution, the Beautiful Store came up with a "Roadmap to Zero CO2 emissions" on which, after analyzing its carbon footprint from electricity usage, transportation for collection, and other factors it decided to design a strategy to gradually reduce these emissions to zero. Part of the strategy involves changing its habits to use resources more efficiently, like improving water management in stores and using recycled paper for informational pamphlets. However, as its stores still contribute to pollution, another part of the strategy has been to provide financial support to local organizations that can help offset its impact, such as groups that plant trees. Thanks to these strategies, the Beautiful Store has managed to reduce its CO2 emissions by a quarter!

Basically, the Beautiful Store funds its project mainly through profits from sales in its physical stores, online and on TV. It also receives some monetary donations, which can be made in-store, online, or by phone at 1577-1113.

Besides that, Beautiful Store has also created a volunteer activities program where people who want to support their project can help out for around 4 hours a week. Volunteers can work in the stores, receive donations, create upcycled products, and more.

With over 100 stores in South Korea, the Beautiful Store has been able to channel millions of dollars to support different projects, groups, and more ethical and ecological ways of producing. It has also prevented the waste of tons of products and avoided the production of many others. Moreover, the project has achieved its ultimate goal: its stores have become a place where people can easily and directly support different social and environmental causes by either producing, donating (work, things, money), or buying their recycled, upcycled, or public interest products.

title: C3 Center for Complexity Sciences · Mexico
introduction:
info 2015-16

Ever since the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) was founded over one hundred years ago, its aim has been to address national problems through scientific research, teaching and by disseminating knowledge. But over time, the university has arranged itself along increasingly specialized scientific fields, all of which are separated by facilities, rules, funding, disciplinary languages and evaluation criteria. This has made it difficult for the university’s vast community to collaborate amongst itself or with other sectors of the population to address national problems with comprehensive, transdisciplinary and more inclusive perspectives.

 

How to best tackle problems that entail a wide array of disciplines and visions?
short_description: The Center for Complexity Sciences (C3) aims to pave the way for the National Autonomous University of Mexico to better address issues of national relevance that must be tackled from many angles and through a variety of disciplines. To achieve this, the C3 facilitates meetings and collaboration among faculty members, and between the university and other sectors of society.

paragraphs.body_html: In 2008, a group of UNAM researchers decided to come up with a project within the institution that would allow any member of the university –regardless of their field of knowledge or the faculty or institute they belong to– to work collaboratively with experts from other disciplines or from other sectors of society. The team realized that achieving this goal would entail encouraging discussions, providing physical spaces and even developing new working methods. Thus, the Center for Complexity Sciences (C3) (Centro de Ciencias de la Complejidad) was born with the purpose of building bridges between members of the large university community at UNAM –40,000 academics and 360,000 students distributed in more than 60 departments, schools and institutes– all while leveraging everyone’s knowledge and experience. The overarching mission would be to tackle the country’s most pressing problems (such as climate change or diabetes mellitus, for instance) with comprehensive analyses and interventions that address a variety of causes and angles.

The C3's general proposal needed, first and foremost, to allocate a physical meeting space within the university for those interested in addressing common problems from various disciplines or sectors. A building was devoted to this purpose, wherein offices have no fixed users and auditoriums are available to members from across the university.

In addition, C3 realized that differences in concepts, approaches and working methods also lead to a lack of communication between specialists. Therefore, the Center suggested the use of a "common language": the analytical and research tools provided by the complexity paradigm or complexity sciences. This particular toolkit is useful when identifying and exploring problems at different scales (global or local, for example) and trough different spheres (social, economic, etc.), all while considering the relationships between each of these aspects.

In addition to providing a physical space and a theoretical proposal, the C3 has been exploring different work models, always pondering which ones serve its objectives best.

To foster collaboration, for instance, the Center has:

• Arranged focus meetings that address specific problems and explore the possibility of launching tailored projects;
  • Offered its facilities for meetings amongst members of the university, or between them and authorities, companies, civil associations, the general public, and so on;
  • Organized seminars, courses and symposiums –both in-person and online to extend their impact– dedicated to developing the approach and methodologies of complexity or addressing topics of interdisciplinary interest.

Other work models the C3 has explored have to do with the way the Center is organized. After all, if the Center wants to yield a different outcome than the rest of the University, it must innovate in this respect too. So:

• The C3 has chosen a group of problem-based lines of research, which serve as non-disciplinary axes for the Center's work and lay out the themes that interested parties can become involved with. These lines of research also serve to organize the Center’s projects, meetings, courses, seminars and other activities: the "Complexity and Health" Program, for instance, attracts biologists, physicians, physicists, etc.

• The Center has chosen a flexible administrative structure so that projects can be as comprehensive and adaptable as possible, and thus relevant to more people. Instead of being divided by institutes and departments devoted to specific subjects or disciplines like the rest of the university (Biology department, Ecology department, etc.), the C3 has functional departments that serve members of all disciplines, such as the Teaching department, the Research department, the Communication department, and so on.

• To further ensure its flexibility, the C3 formed an Internal Council that meets periodically to, among other tasks, manage the different departments, and choose –and sometimes modify– the main lines of research.

• Unlike other university departments that also promote multi or interdisciplinary studies, the C3 decided not to hire academic staff, and only open some technical-administrative positions to staff areas of the project such as the communication or budget management units, for instance. This is intended to encourage any member of the university –and not only a group of fixed faculty members– to launch their own projects or participate in some of the ongoing ones, taking advantage of stays, sabbatical leaves, post-doctorates, events, etc. offered by the C3, but without becoming a permanent part of its faculty. This model has allowed the C3 to achieve good results in research, training and dissemination of knowledge without having to invest a lot of resources in salaries and benefits, all while helping the university better leverage the funds allocated to faculty payments. The measure has also helped in creating and adapting work teams with the needs of specific projects in mind. And it has helped disseminate the Center’s working methods, because when researchers get back to their respective institutes and departments, they take what they have learnt with them, increasing the project’s reach.

The C3 has faced some obstacles. Many of them have had to do with the bureaucracy of a university the size of UNAM, and others have to do with the fact that research and academic work has been done in a certain way for many years and change doesn’t always come easy.

One of these obstacles, for instance, has to do with the funding for academic work –such as grants or project money– which is often distributed according to fields of knowledge: $50 are specifically allocated to genetics research, say, and $45 specifically allotted to sociological research. But what happens with a problem like diabetes, which is neither strictly genetic nor sociological? The answer is that funding is not always easy to come by.

Also, because the C3’s bet is to have no permanent faculty, researchers who participate cannot always devote enough time to the development of the Center's project at large, or to all its various activities. Furthermore, academic performance evaluations usually have more traditional criteria and less conventional projects may not always be considered as favorably (publications are valued more highly than other types of activities, for instance).

Another recurrent problem has had to do with internal communication: it has not been easy to "translate" the concepts and methodologies of each discipline to work collectively.

However, as these obstacles are precisely the reasons why the C3 came up with its project in the first place, the Center understands that facilitating a space for collaboration is not enough, but that it must keep on identifying and removing obstacles along the way, and above all, exploring models, incentives and means so that university members can actually take on these new dynamics that the C3 is promoting.

title: Habitat for Humanity Hong Kong · China
introduction:
info 2020

There are enormous problems related to lack of housing or to the poor conditions of the places in which millions of people live and, given the accelerated rates of urbanization that several countries are experiencing, these will become even more complicated with time. In 2020, more than 1.2 billion people in the world lived in substandard housing and it is expected that some 3 billion people will require new homes by 2030! In Hong Kong, the waiting list for public housing can take up to several years and more than 200,000 people live in residences known for their very limited space.

 

 

How to ensure that all people have access to decent housing?
short_description: Habitat for Humanity Hong Kong works by promoting dignified, safe, and affordable housing for vulnerable groups in Hong Kong and Southeast Asia: it coordinates support networks to build and refurbish homes, schools, and shelters; assists communities affected by natural disasters; and raises awareness among the population and decision-makers about the poor housing conditions faced by many people in the region.
external_link_text: Habitat for Humanity Hong Kong  香港仁人家园

paragraphs.body_html: In 2004, Habitat for Humanity, which is an organization that works to promote better housing for all in more than 70 countries around the world, decided to open a branch office in Hong Kong to serve the Asia-Pacific region. Habitat for Humanity believes that decent, safe, and affordable housing is an important tool for poverty reduction because it can be used as a foundation for a healthier, more financially stable, and more self-sufficient life. This is why the organization supports vulnerable groups by promoting different projects to build, intervene, or refurbish schools, shelters, and homes; to assist populations affected by natural disasters; to raise awareness of the housing issues in the region and, also, to influence public policy.

Habitat for Humanity Hong Kong (仁人家园) has several programs that seek to solve the housing problems of traditionally marginalized groups. Some of these programs seek to address short-term needs and are permanent, such as the Home Works program, which helps build, clean or repair homes, retirement homes, and schools for low-income families, single parents, the elderly, and people with disabilities. Another example is the School Works program, that aims to paint and repair schools in underserved areas with the help of students and other volunteers, because it believes that schools are a second home for children and that, therefore, decent and pleasant learning environments must be guaranteed.

There are other programs with a more intermittent timeline, such as the Rural House Reconstruction Project, which supports rural families to build houses with subsidies, volunteer labor, and technical training for beneficiary families and for construction workers so that they can both supervise and ensure the quality of construction. Another example of one such program is the Women Build Program, which consists of month-long campaigns in which, in collaboration with other local organizations, volunteers, women and girls in vulnerable conditions (pregnant teens, migrant workers, and elderly women), intervenes in the homes or shelters of the latter with the intention of empowering them by means of ensuring more dignified housing conditions for them.

Programs focused on addressing crises caused by natural disasters or other emergencies (relief actions for hurricanes, earthquakes, floods, etc.) operate with different time projections: Some are preventive and are dedicated to building more adaptive and resilient housing in regions that are particularly vulnerable to natural disasters, while others are dedicated to give immediate relief to populations in emergency conditions by delivering temporary housing schemes or hygiene kits to affected families, for instance, as was the case with the floods in Kerala, India, in 2018, in which the organization supported more than 5,000 families that were affected by the disaster. Some others are dedicated to helping with housing recovery with medium-term projections, such as the 3-year program that the organization agreed upon along with local partners in the Sichuan province of China in response to the 2008 earthquake, which heavily affected the area. In addition, there are the programs focused on disaster relief with a long-term vision that promote not only the reconstruction of the homes of affected families, but also the conditions for them to rebuild in a better way, so as to avoid potential incidents caused by other natural disasters in the future. In the case of Kerala, for example, once the flood crisis was over, an entire community development plan was designed to meet these objectives.

Habitat also devotes a great deal of effort to raising awareness and sensitizing populations and governments in the region about the need to guarantee decent, safe, and affordable housing for all, as well as to take preventive measures to avoid future disasters due to lack of optimal housing conditions. To this end, it participates in fundraising races or marathons and organizes forums and other events that bring together global experts; it also organizes photographic exhibitions (such as the one called "From Ruins to Recovery: Habitat for Humanity Hong Kong's Disaster Response Exhibition"). These activities encourage the public to become familiar with the housing problems experienced by some of their fellow citizens or people in other parts of the region, while also helping to showcase the organization’s work and the potential impact their participation would have if they chose to support it, either via funds or volunteer work.

In this regard, Habitat makes a special effort to reach out to young people, whom it believes are the ones who can most easily empathize with the housing problem that so many people face and help them scale their project. In the school program mentioned above, for instance, Habitat has organized the painting of murals with images of different types of housing in the region to stimulate conversations and debates about the problems of urbanization, housing and inequality among students. It has also organized workshops for university students to learn how Habitat works and how to build houses that are resistant to natural disasters. Habitat also relies heavily on university volunteers to raise awareness in their communities about the housing problem, as they help by organizing expert forums or creating newsletters, brochures and other media to give visibility to the issue. That is why every year Habitat organizes campaigns such as the Habitat Young Leaders Build (HYLB) in which, with the support of celebrities who participate as Ambassadors for its cause, the organization prepares different activities at construction sites or on social networks to attract and motivate more young people, familiarize them with the problems in their community and in the region, and show them that there are specific skills they can learn and concrete things they can do to help: such as volunteering, taking the lead in making interventions, or becoming influencers and motivating their friends. Needless to say, the ambassadors' involvement not only serves as an incentive for other young people, but it also helps to promote the project and the causes it works with, attracting additional sources of support. In 2019, Emily Lam Ho's participation, for example, was featured in various media such as Tatler, East Week, Sing Tao Daily, and We People magazine.

Knowing that achieving major policy changes to improve housing conditions is a lengthy process in Hong Kong, Habitat works on several fronts to influence public policy on issues of financial inclusion, entrepreneurship, and housing markets. In addition to monitoring policies on the subject, it promotes microfinance for the real estate sector or petitions directed towards legislators and housing regulators. In 2020, for example, with the intention of influencing the planning of residences known as Subdivided Units (SDUs) in Hong Kong, Habitat undertook a campaign to identify the interests, needs and views of local organizations, social workers, landlords, developers, and potential future inhabitants, and formulated a minimum housing charter proposal based on them with recommendations for basic standards in order to ensure decent and quality conditions in SDUs. In addition, Habitat also relies on university volunteers to influence public policy, as they help by organizing outreach events, conducting surveys, identifying needs, and participating in recognized social awareness events such as World Housing Day.

Since its staff at the local level is very small, Habitat invests much of its efforts in creating, coordinating, and facilitating the work of a broad support network that allows it to implement and promote its various projects, benefit more people, ensure a certain stability for its programs, and plan long-term actions. This support network includes, among others:

• Volunteers.

Much of Habitat for Humanity Hong Kong's achievements can be attributed to the enormous efforts it has devoted to convening and coordinating a large network of volunteers who, in 2019 alone totaled 2,032 people who supported its projects with 11,946 hours of work in training, rescue, prevention, repair, or construction. Sometimes these collaborators also give money, either via their own contributions, by collecting funds, paying fees for participating as volunteers in programs such as the Global Village (which promotes the flow of volunteers throughout the Asia Pacific region to participate in the different projects of the organization), or with the contributions that they continue to send after participating in these programs. Habitat has been able to attract large numbers of volunteers because, despite being a Christian organization, it invites all people, regardless of their faith, to collaborate in a cause that benefits all types of communities. This is also possible because it has facilitated many schemes to attract their participation: in addition to campaigns on social media and calls for participation on its website, Habitat promotes the formation of groups of volunteers organized in "chapters" (local teams) that help create and coordinate programs, sometimes provide their own funds, organize fundraisings, call out for more volunteers, or do awareness-raising work amongst the population and decision-makers.

• Non-governmental organizations. NGOs help Habitat identify beneficiaries in the regions where it wants to work in and to implement programs in training, rescue, prevention, repair, or construction of housing in collaboration with volunteers, contractors, and beneficiary populations.

• Habitat for Humanity International. Although Habitat Hong Kong has its own board of directors, in being part of the global Habitat for Humanity network it receives oversight and logistical support from an international board of directors and the regional headquarters in Manila, as well as some financial support.
• Ambassadors. Celebrities sympathetic to Habitat's cause who voluntarily help motivate people to support and give visibility to its work and the housing problem.

• Schools and Universities. They help to recruit volunteers, give them a space to organize their chapters and collect funds, make donations, lend them their facilities, and collaborate in the organization of events, workshops, exhibitions, and other means to give visibility to their project.

• Beneficiary families. Of course, the collaboration of the beneficiary families with mortgage payments and with their own participation in the training, construction, and monitoring of its programs is a very important support for Habitat because it allows for more relevant interventions in the contexts of these populations, making them more likely to be sustained over time. For this reason, Habitat frequently organizes different community engagement dynamics to ensure that these families contribute to the design of programs or interventions.

• Donors. In order to have a reserve of resources (a savings fund) that allows it to react in time in case of natural disasters, Habitat has taken advantage of the worldwide recognition of Hong Kong's banking institutions (for their effectiveness and the importance of their geostrategic location) to promote itself as a recognized and reliable organization that is responsible for raising funds and coordinating efforts to respond to emergency situations caused by natural disasters in the region. This has allowed Habitat to form a network of donors that includes the Hong Kong government, Christian associations that support it by affinity of beliefs, individuals, corporations, companies or foundations. The latter, in addition to giving direct donations, support them in other ways, such as, for instance, organizing fundraising races, or activities to get support from their employees. In addition, through its Web Platform, Habitat encourages and facilitates donations by providing options for donations to be tax-deductible, one-time or regular, or to be made for specific purposes (a family, a Christmas gift, a school in another country, etc.). The site also offers a tool (developed by giviki.com) with which interested individuals or institutions can help by organizing fundraising campaigns on the Internet (crowdfunding). Although the largest portion of the financial resources that reach the organization come from the support of local corporations (38% of income in 2019), the most constant are the contributions of individuals who, attracted by volunteers at street fundraisers, are encouraged to register to give monthly contributions, because even if they only represent about 22% of the organization's income, because of their regularity they are key to the stability of its programs.

This great diversity of support, which allows it to ensure a certain consistency for its programs and even to project long-term actions, has been achieved thanks to several planning strategies, resource management, and a careful approach to its partners: For example, to give certainty to donors and volunteers and thus attract their participation, the organization takes advantage of its international experience in immediate relief in emergency situations, the credibility of Hong Kong's banking and administrative systems, as well as its strategic location in the Asia Pacific region. In addition, the organization is adept at systematizing and publicizing its work model on its platform, social media (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube), events, or campaigns, which gives clarity to potential collaborators on the ways in which they could support and on their potential impact. A similar effect is achieved with the publication of its results, because when donors or volunteers get to know the number of hours worked on, families served, schools or retirement homes repaired, etc., they can check the reach that their support has had or could potentially have. Besides, the organization is very careful to always thank and give publicity space to its collaborators in its platform and reports, which serves as an advertisement opportunity for many of them.

Habitat for Humanity Hong Kong is an organization that has had a very high impact and outreach. In 2018-2019 alone it helped more than 6,650 people in Hong Kong, 2,322 in mainland China, and, globally (as part of the international organization), more than 7 million people. All of this in large part thanks to an important work encouraging and coordinating efforts to improve housing conditions in the region.

title: APOPO · Cambodia
introduction:
Info 2024

 

Imagine living with the fear that every step you take could be your last.

 

As unbelievable as it seems due to how little is reported on this issue, this is the daily reality for 600 million people in over 60 countries, where large areas are still infested with landmines and other unexploded ordnance left behind from past wars. Some of these explosives were buried decades ago, yet they still pose a deadly threat today.

 

Unexploded bombs, grenades, mortars, and dangerous cluster munitions that open up and scatter smaller bombs everywhere, like a deadly rain of explosives, causing massive harm. People live under this constant threat. Landmines explode with the slightest touch, while anti-vehicle mines can destroy trucks or tanks.

 

The impact on communities is devastating. Landmines don’t just kill and injure indiscriminately—they also severely hinder economic development. They block access to essential roads and resources like water, preventing people from using fertile lands for farming or raising livestock. Many cannot rebuild their lives, return home, or develop their communities. Worst of all, 80% of the victims are civilians, and half of them are children!.

 

Solving this problem is incredibly difficult. First, because removing these explosives is so dangerous, the process is slow and costly. Removing a single landmine can cost up to $1,000, an enormous expense for countries whose economies are already devastated by war.

 

Additionally, the funding for mine clearance is decreasing. While 164 countries have signed treaties like the Ottawa Convention to stop the use of landmines, major powers like the United States, China, and India have not. Why? Some countries argue that mines are necessary for border defense or to protect strategic zones in the event of armed conflicts. But money is also a factor: these countries still produce, store, or sell landmines, which remains a profitable business. This makes it extremely difficult for the world to work together to eliminate this danger.

 

In Cambodia alone, during the Vietnam War, the U.S. dropped more than 26 million explosive submunitions, and these, along with landmines and other explosives placed by all the warring groups over three decades of conflict, have made the country one of the most dangerous places in the world for its people.

 

So even though the war ended in the ’90s, the impact is still devastating. It affects the country’s economy, which largely depends on rice cultivation and needs those territories. And it particularly impacts rural communities. In provinces like Preah Vihear, where 65% of the population lives in extreme poverty and depends on agriculture to survive, people have no choice but to risk using these mine-contaminated lands to grow crops.

 

Since 1979, over 64,000 people have been victims of these explosives, leaving Cambodia with more than 29,000 deaths and the highest per capita proportion of amputees in the world.

 

Although the Cambodian government has been reluctant to sign the Cluster Munitions Convention because it fears vulnerability against neighboring countries, it did sign the Ottawa Treaty and committed to clearing all landmines in its territory by 2025.

 

That’s why, since the ’90s, with help from various international organizations and foreign governments, Cambodia has cleared over 2 million explosives and cleaned more than 1 billion square meters of land.

 

However, the work is slow and expensive, and in 2023, the country reported that it suspected 435 km² of its territory might still be contaminated with landmines, unexploded ordnance (UXO), or other remnants of war (ERW).

 

 

How can we help speed up the cleanup process, make it safer, more affordable, and more efficient?
short_description: APOPO is an organization that trains African giant pouched rats to detect landmines faster and more cost-effectively than traditional methods. With operations in 8 countries, they have helped free vast areas from the damage caused by these explosives to communities and economies. Their model combines scientific research, education, and local partnerships, showing that simple innovations can solve complex problems. Today, beyond landmine clearance, they are exploring many other uses for their rats, such as helping detect tuberculosis!

paragraphs.body_html:
Saving lives by making the process faster, safer, cheaper, and more efficient.

 

It all began with Bart Weetjens, a Belgian engineer who, as a child, had an unusual fascination with rats. One day, while looking into the devastating problem of landmines in Africa, Bart remembered an article about rodents trained to detect explosives in labs. The connection was instant: if rats could smell explosives, why not use them to clear minefields?

 

Bart sought the support of Ron Verhagen, a professor from the University of Antwerp who was an expert on rats. He recommended exploring his idea with the African giant pouched rat.

 

In 1997, with modest funding from the Belgian government to develop his proposal, Bart founded APOPO (short for Anti-Persoonsmijnen Ontmijnende Product Ontwikkeling, or "Anti-Personnel Landmine Removal Product Development"), a nonprofit that, by 2017, became a global humanitarian NGO registered in Belgium.

 

APOPO combines low-cost innovation, scientific research, and local collaboration to accelerate landmine and explosive removal in 7 countries.

The Innovation

 

The early years of this project were a battle against disbelief. With limited funding, Bart set up a small training center in Tanzania, strategically chosen because:

 

  • It’s the natural habitat of the African giant rats.
  • Sokoine Agricultural University provided technical support and land to build APOPO’s training headquarters.
  • The climate was similar to other mined areas, allowing better testing.

 

There, the rats learned the basics: smell TNT, scratch the ground, and get a reward—a piece of banana! Challenges arose: some rats preferred napping to working, while others got distracted by new smells. But over time, the team perfected the method until it worked in controlled conditions. However, the real challenge lay outside, in the minefields where theory meets reality.

 

In 2003, armed with data and trained rats, Bart presented a risky proposal to the Mozambican government: “Let me show you that these rats can find mines without dying in the process, and at a fraction of the cost.” The challenge was enormous: mines buried for over 20 years, land compacted by intense sun, and war debris everywhere…

 

But the HeroRATs succeeded:

  • They found all the mines in the test zones.
  • Ignored 99% of the scrap metal that confuses metal detectors.
  • Worked much faster than conventional methods—while a human team with metal detectors can take up to 4 days to scan 400 square meters of mined land (especially in areas filled with war scrap that causes false alarms), a single HeroRAT can cover the same area in just 20 minutes. The secret? These rats are trained to ignore metal and focus solely on the smell of explosives.

1. Mine Action Program

 

Since APOPO’s arrival in Cambodia in 2014, it hasn’t operated in isolation but as a strategic ally to the Cambodian government and other national and international organizations dedicated to mine clearance. They collaborate in a well-structured way: APOPO operates under the supervision of the Cambodian Mine Action and Victim Assistance Authority (CMAA) and works closely with the Cambodian Mine Action Center (CMAC), the state agency for mine clearance. This strategic trio divides responsibilities with precision: the CMAA sets cleanup priorities based on population density, agricultural potential, and recent incidents; CMAC provides personnel and logistical infrastructure to remove mines and explosives; while APOPO provides its innovative army of rats and detection dogs, accelerating the process exponentially.

 

Before starting operations, the HeroRATs had to prove their effectiveness through rigorous tests under the International Mine Action Standards (IMAS), achieving 100% accuracy, which ultimately convinced the most skeptical authorities. APOPO didn’t just replicate its African model in Cambodia; they trained their rats to detect artisanal mines, especially common in Cambodia, and to work on flood-prone soils, a unique challenge in the region. In fact, their low-cost technology approach has been especially valuable: unlike expensive drones or scanners, rats are relatively easy to breed and train locally, creating employment opportunities for communities.

 

 

The Landmine Clearance Method

 

APOPO’s land clearance method is brilliant because it integrates traditional methods (humans with metal detectors) with animal innovation:

 

The operation starts with the HeroDOGs, primarily Belgian Shepherds that have been part of APOPO’s program since 2017 when the organization established its Canine Training Center in Kampong Chhnang—the first specialized center for technical inspection dogs (TSD) in Southeast Asia. These dogs play a crucial role in precisely delineating the boundaries of mined areas.

 

Once the area is marked, the HeroRATs take over. Equipped with harnesses and guided by two humans, these extraordinary rats methodically scan every inch of the marked dangerous area. When they detect TNT, they stop and scratch the ground. This advantage is key in Cambodia, where conventional metal detectors are constantly fooled by the metal debris left by decades of war (bullets, bomb fragments, and other military scraps). The rats, however, ignore all metal and only detect the smell of explosives.

 

In the final phase, human teams from CMAC verify each signal marked by the rats and safely remove the explosives. Specialized machines clear the vegetation for the next day and manual deminers create safe paths for the work teams.

 

The result of this integrated system is overwhelming: a process that’s not only safer, but very fast and cost-effective!

 

 

The Rigorous Training of HeroRATs and HeroDOGs

 

The process of turning African giant rats into expert landmine detectors is as meticulous as it is fascinating. It all begins when the young rats are just four weeks old: first, they undergo a period of socialization, where they get used to human contact and different environments. By the time they reach ten weeks, they start their training with the "click-reward" method: they learn that when they smell TNT and hear a click, they will receive a treat (banana-avocado smoothie). The training intensifies in progressive stages, from recognizing the scent on a small table to searching for real landmines buried in APOPO’s training minefield. To graduate, each rat must find all the mines in a 400 m² area with no more than one mistake, demonstrating 100% accuracy under international standards. What's amazing is that, despite their size, these rats cannot set off the mines: their weight (a maximum of 1.5 kg) is not enough to trigger explosions, making them perfect allies for this dangerous work. Each HeroRAT works for about 4-5 years before retiring to a well-deserved "retirement" with continued care.

 

In the case of HeroDOGs, the training combines discipline and play. These Belgian Malinois, selected for their exceptional sense of smell and stamina, begin their training as puppies at the Kampong Chhnang center. The first thing they learn is to associate the scent of explosives with their favorite Kong toy. Gradually, the training becomes more complex: they must search in straight lines, signal explosives without touching them, simply sitting 1 meter before the detected item and pointing their nose at it.

 

The most difficult test comes in training fields, where dogs show that they can work among rusted bullets, old cans, and other war remnants without getting distracted. A certified HeroDOG can inspect up to 1,500 square meters in a single day—equivalent to four football fields—with flawless precision. And like the rats, these dogs enjoy a dignified retirement after 5-6 years of service, spending their last years playing and receiving care from their handlers.

 

Together, HeroRATs and HeroDOGs form a perfect team that complements each other to make human and machine efforts more efficient: while rats are unbeatable in open terrain, dogs conquer dense vegetation areas where rats can't operate.

2. Educational Program

 

APOPO knows that clearing a minefield can take months or even years. But children still need to go to school, farmers must work their lands, and families live their daily lives surrounded by hidden dangers. This is why their mine risk educational program is as vital as their demining work.

 

The strategy is simple yet powerful:

 

  • Train entire communities to identify and report mines.

 

  • Turn victims into educators who share lessons learned through pain.

 

  • Use visual materials so even a young child can understand the danger.

 

  • And to ensure the world doesn't forget about this invisible problem, in 2017, they opened their Visitor Center in Siem Reap. There, visitors can see safe demonstrations of the rats' work and learn more about why this battle against mines is far from over.

3. Victim Assistance Program

 

In rural Cambodia, where rehabilitation centers are hours away, APOPO acts as the vital link connecting landmine victims with the help they need. While organizations like Humanity & Inclusion and the government provide free medical services—prosthetics, physical therapy, and psychological support—many survivors can't access them due to logistical barriers. This is where APOPO comes in: with their adapted vehicle, their team travels to remote districts like Preah Vihear to identify victims, assess their needs, and transport them to Humanity & Inclusion centers.

 

They do all this while collaborating with a network of 25 survivor groups who, in addition to conducting professional surveys to document specific victim needs—from prosthetics to psychological support—offer emotional companionship. These groups also generate data that Humanity & Inclusion and the government use to take action. The model is clear: APOPO doesn't replace rehabilitation services; it ensures that those who need them can access them. Since 2021, 172 victims have been assisted through this bridge, with 51 receiving specialized treatments.

Since arriving in 2015, APOPO has radically transformed the landmine situation in Cambodia. Here are some key achievements:

 

  • Land Cleared: to date, HeroDogs, HeroRATs, and their teams had helped clear over 65 million square meters of contaminated land, which has allowed entire communities to regain land for agriculture-, schools, and vital infrastructure.

 

  • Mines Eliminated: More than 7,800 landmines and 43,000 explosive remnants of war (unexploded bombs, small arms and ammunition, etc.) have been detected and destroyed, drastically reducing the risk to the local population.

 

  • Lives Saved: According to data from the CMAA, annual landmine casualties in Cambodia have fallen by 72% since 2014, partly thanks to the accelerated work of APOPO and its partners.

 

  • Local Economy: The organization generates local jobs—8 out of every 10 workers are Cambodians—by training rat handlers and specialized technicians. Additionally, it boosts the economy by purchasing supplies from over 30 local vendors, from rat food to work materials. But the most visible change is in the land: fields that were once deadly traps are now cultivable land where families grow rice and other food crops.

APOPO Expands Worldwide

 

APOPO has expanded its impact, now working in seven countries in addition to Cambodia. Each country faces its own challenges, but the organization has adapted without losing its essence. Their success relies on two key strategies: generating trust through scientific evidence and adapting to local realities.

 

It’s crucial for APOPO to generate scientific trust because governments wouldn’t allow them to work in their countries without clear proof that their methods really work. Demining is costly and dangerous, so governments need to be sure that APOPO's methods are effective before letting them work. That's why the organization not only works in the field but also documents everything they do, including errors and improvements. They publish research and detailed reports on their tests to ensure their methods are reliable and trusted. Furthermore, part of their strategy is to meet all international safety and efficacy standards, which allows them not only to work with governments but also to advise and help others replicate their methods in different contexts. For example, in Mozambique, they had to demonstrate for four years that their rats detected 100% of the mines in test areas before being granted permission to continue working. This scientific transparency, along with compliance with international standards, helps gain the trust of authorities and local communities, and encourages others to follow the same path to apply these methods successfully in other regions.

 

At the same time, APOPO adapts to the conditions of each country to remain effective. In each place, they adjust their approach according to the needs of the terrain and the culture. In Ukraine, for instance, due to extreme cold, they use dogs instead of rats for mine detection. In Cambodia, they trained rats to detect plastic mines, which are more common in that country. In Senegal, they've focused more on agricultural land, as requested by local communities. Additionally, in each country, they train local teams, which not only facilitates learning but also ensures the long-term sustainability of operations.

 

 

A Commitment to Research and Development

 

To expand their impact not only in other regions but also in other areas, APOPO’s research and development center in Tanzania has the goal of training animals for new applications. One of their most significant achievements has been training rats to detect tuberculosis in heat-inactivated human sputum samples. This breakthrough is now being used in several African countries, such as Tanzania and Ethiopia, where rats help detect the disease in regions with limited resources to perform fast tests. Thanks to this animal-based technology, APOPO has helped detect over 32,000 tuberculosis cases that might otherwise have gone unnoticed. The rats are trained to identify suspect samples, which are then verified by humans to confirm the results. This method has already proven effective and promises to improve early detection of tuberculosis in countries with limited healthcare systems.

 

Currently, APOPO is exploring other innovative applications for their rats. Among these, rescue and search operations stand out, where rats could play a crucial role in natural disasters. Thanks to their compact size, agility, and exceptional sense of smell, the trained rats could overcome the limitations of current technologies in rescue operations, such as penetrating rubble, navigating difficult terrain, and locating survivors in real-time. Equipped with technology such as chips that allow humans to track their location and miniature cameras that transmit what they are seeing, the rats could revolutionize how searches for trapped people are conducted.

 

APOPO is also exploring the use of rats to detect soil contaminants or ecological irregularities, by identifing levels of petroleum hydrocarbons in contaminated soils, which is crucial for environmental remediation.

 

In addition, APOPO is venturing into detecting wildlife smuggling by training rats to detect products from endangered species, such as pangolin scales and elephant ivory. Using real containers and specialized equipment, the rats are trained to inspect these containers using their sense of smell without opening them, making the detection of smuggling more efficient and less invasive than traditional methods. Operational trials are currently being conducted at key ports to assess their effectiveness in real-world conditions.

 

Admirably, to offset the carbon emissions of all of these activities, APOPO launched HeroTREEs, a program by which it is promoting Syntropic Agroforestry as a highly effective method, partnering with community-based organizations to establish demonstration plots and provide hands-on training. Through sustainable, organic farming practices in the Uluguru Mountains, farmers improve soil and water quality, boost food security, reduce poverty, and protect biodiversity.

International Offices: APOPO has an international structure, with registered charities in Switzerland, the United States and the United Kingdom. These offices are crucial for fundraising, forming strategic alliances, and global communication. APOPO’s training and innovation center is in Tanzania (the main headquarters), and APOPO has Mine Action programs in Cambodia, Azerbaijan, Ukraine, and Angola. It also has tuberculosis detection clinics in Tanzania and Ethiopia.

 

At the top of APOPO's structure is the International Board of Directors, an entity responsible for overseeing the organization's global mission and ensuring compliance with the highest ethical standards. This board is made up of experts in key areas such as humanitarian mine action, animal welfare, and sustainable development, who guide the operations and growth of APOPO.

 

Operational Departments: Below the board, the organization is divided into three key departments, each with specialized areas that work together to achieve its objectives:

 

  • The Mine Action department, which runs the Demining, Risk Education, and Victim Assistance.
  • The Tuberculosis detection department that is committed to fighting tuberculosis with low cost, efficient methods using trained rats. Currently, it is screening more samples, bridging diagnostic gaps and reaching more communities in need.
  • The Innovation and Research department, responsible for the Innovation Center in Tanzania. — When pilot projects from this center are validated, they become independent departments within the organization.

 

What truly distinguishes APOPO is its highly specialized technical operations while maintaining flexibility to innovate and adapt to new needs. In other words, its working model is hybrid: On the one hand, there is a technical verticality that allows each department to delve deeply into its specialization, ensuring a high level of professionalism. On the other hand, APOPO fosters a collaborative horizontal structure, ensuring that the learnings from each country are shared and adapted to other contexts.

APOPO doesn't rely on just one type of income but combines several sources to continue its vital work. Here’s how they do it:

 

1. Money from people like you (40%)

  • You can adopt a hero rat for €12 per month or a hero dog for €19, and you’ll receive regular emails, a welcome pack, and a certificate.
