  • They also accept one-time or monthly donations through their website.
  • In 2022, they organized events like marathons and bake sales, and online campaigns raising over €1.4 million.

 

2. Money from governments and organizations (35%)

  • They receive financial support from various governments, totaling nearly €3 million in 2022.
  • They won the prestigious Skoll Award, which is like the "Oscar" for social projects.

 

3. Innovative fundraising ideas (25%)

  • They took over a café in Cambodia (Sister Srey) and use its profits to support mine clearance.
  • They offer educational tours at their visitor center, which welcomes thousands of people in 2022.
  • They use impact bonds (or Development Impact Bonds, DIBs), an innovative way to finance projects that seek measurable results, where everyone involved benefits if the project succeeds. In these bonds, private investors, such as companies or funds, provide initial funding for specific projects, such as turning mined land into agricultural land. APOPO, together with local partners like NGOs, executes the work on the ground. The core principle is that if measurable results are achieved, like clearing a specific number of hectares for cultivation, governments or funding entities reimburse the invested money, plus a moderate interest. However, there is a risk involved. If the goals are not met, the investors bear the loss as they don’t recover their full investment.

 

To have more sources of support and thereby more impact, APOPO has built a network of strategic alliances: foundations like Skoll and governments such as Belgium’s offer funding for operations; universities like Antwerp contribute with scientific research; local NGOs like Cordaid facilitate fieldwork; and media outlets amplify their message. Each partner adds something unique — money, knowledge, infrastructure, or visibility — creating an ecosystem where everyone wins: companies improve their corporate social responsibility, governments get cost-efficient solutions, and APOPO expands its ability to save lives.

 

Moreover, APOPO has understood that to attract new partners, donors, and volunteers, it needs to make its work as well-known as possible, which is why it has made a strong commitment to strategic communication. One emblematic example is Magawa, their star rat, who, after winning the PDSA Gold medal, became a media sensation, going viral around the world.

 

But they don’t stop at viral stories: the organization maintains a constant commitment to transparency and access to information, offering a comprehensive resource bank for journalists and content creators on its website.

 

APOPO manages its funds strategically, optimizing each resource to maximize its social impact: it allocates 92% directly to field operations, keeping administrative costs minimal (8%); generates its own revenue through its Sister Srey café and educational tours; establishes partnerships with companies and universities to reduce technology and research expenses; and uses impact bonds where investors take on risks, ensuring that funds are only released when concrete goals are met.

APOPO's impact is not limited to Cambodia. Today, its reach has crossed borders, with operations in 8 countries, including Angola, Azerbaijan, Ukraine, Senegal, and Zimbabwe. In Tanzania, 104 HeroRATs are actively training and working, and globally, more than 162,924 explosives have been cleared.

 

This innovative approach has been widely recognized, winning international awards such as the Skoll Award in 2009 for its contribution to social innovation, and receiving support from renowned figures like Princess Astrid of Belgium, who serves as honorary president. Its model has been globally certified as a benchmark in animal-assisted demining.

 

The legacy of APOPO continues to grow. From its laboratories in Tanzania to the mined fields of three continents, the organization demonstrates how applied science can translate into freedom and security for the most vulnerable communities. While Cambodia remains its most emblematic case, APOPO’s model is replicated and adapted where it’s needed most, bringing hope and peace to those who need it most.

title: Peepeno'ob Network · Mexico
introduction:
info 2021

In Yucatan, Mexico, women are paid less than men for their work (when they are paid at all!), many are abused by their partners and as a group, women have less property to their name than men do.

 

On top of this, Indigenous Mayan women encounter additional difficulties in asserting their rights and having access to justice due to a lack of culturally sensitive services and information in their language.

 

How to create more equitable conditions for Mayan women?
short_description: The Peepeno'ob Network is a collective of indigenous Mayan women from the Mexican state of Yucatan that combats the violence and racist practices that indigenous women face, the public service discrimination they are subject to, and the lack of information about sexual and reproductive rights in their language. To this end, they carry out research, create outreach materials and work directly with women and authorities.

paragraphs.body_html: When a group of Mayan women from the state of Yucatan in Mexico met at an indigenous women's event on maternal health in 2012, they began to talk about their identity as Mayan women and, above all, about the difficulties they face in asserting their rights. They soon realized that they had similar concerns and that organizing would be crucial to address them.

As a result, they began to meet frequently to reflect on these issues and to take part in activities held by some of the local feminist collectives. Through trial and error, these experiences helped them identify the issues they were interested in working on as a group and prompted them to form their own initiative, the Peepeo'ob Network (Red Péepeno'ob). They chose this name for the collective because "péepeno'ob" in Mayan means "butterfly", an animal that for them brings about metamorphosis and change. And that was what the collective was after: creating a collaborative network with other Mayan women to raise awareness of and fight against the racist practices they face, against the discrimination in public services, against violence towards women, and against the lack of information on sexual and reproductive rights in their language.

Since then, the collective has been working to develop information and resources to address these issues with Mayan women in the region and to transform the way in which authorities guarantee their rights.
One of the main strategies of the Peepeno'ob Network to promote conditions of equity for Mayan women has been to share information on their rights with them.

The Network began, for instance, to give talks on local radio "XEPET, The Voice of Mayans" to leverage the station’s reach in several indigenous communities. In addition, it joined the "Living our Rights as a Community" Campaign, a project of like-minded collectives with which it collaborated to create a booklet on the sexual rights of teenagers and young people. They also produced podcasts, that is, recordings of short stories in a radio drama format (with characters, problems, and so on). The Peepeno'ob Network produced some on sex education and the right to confidentiality, and also collaborated in the Campaign by translating into Yucatecan Maya the audios created by indigenous collectives from other regions of the country that addressed issues of discrimination, violence and the right to equal opportunities. As the Mayan language is rarely written and is more often spoken, producing podcasts and making them available on sites such as Youtube and Spotify would enable them to reach Mayan women more effectively.

These two experiences encouraged the Network to launch a project of its own: the " Booklet of Mayan Indigenous Women's Rights", a short book in which they listed national and international laws they felt were relevant to Mayan women. This booklet, together with the podcasts, has been used to organize discussion and learning activities with young women and health promoters in the communities where the Network's participants live.

Besides preparing materials and activities for reflection and learning, the collective realized that it was important to do something to improve the way the State does its job with regards to these issues. From their perspective, the State is the one with the capacity, the budget and the obligation to guarantee the rights of indigenous women and, because it is doing a poor job, it is important to put pressure on it and help it divulge the issues of rights among the people, that is, socialize these rights in order to prevent more women from growing up with this information vacuum in their lives, as they did.

This is why the Network joined the initiative "What is Public is Ours" which was launched by the feminist organization Simone de Beauvoir Leadership Institute, a project that encourages indigenous women and youths to leverage the government's transparency and accountability tools to conduct research and monitor sexual and reproductive health services, so as to have solid information that will help them demand the changes they deem necessary from the authorities. With this collaboration, the Network began to research laws and statistics and realized that often the problem isn't the laws themselves, but the fact that they are not being enforced or are being poorly enforced. So the Network started interviewing women in the region to learn about their experiences as well as people who train public servants in the health sector, to understand how they interpret and implement laws and why their good intent might be getting lost.

All this information encouraged the Network to meet with decision-makers and share its views on why this way of working was not adequate. In fact, the authorities themselves began to invite the women to institutional events so they could share their findings and suggestions as beneficiaries of laws with more people.

The Network has placed great emphasis on accountability in the enforcement of Mexican Official Norm 046, which is a national piece of legislation that establishes the criteria for the prevention of and attention to domestic and sexual violence, as well as violence against women. The collective is pushing for this law to be effectively implemented and for it to be improved and distributed in a language that is accessible to all and with an intercultural perspective, that is, relevant to the specific needs of Mayan populations. To help authorities in this regard, they drew up a road map called "What to do in case of domestic or sexual violence" printed as a poster that explains the law in simple terms and which the collective is using to better disseminate it.

To date (2022), the Network has chosen to continue organizing "informally" and not officially register their collective as a civil organization because the procedures are so complicated and there are so few public resources for projects such as theirs that they feel would not be worth it. In any case, they know that if they ever get any public resources, they can ask other civil organizations for support to receive funds in their name.

What members do to pay for project expenses such as the printing of materials (the booklet or the road map) or travel costs for their meetings or events, is use their own money or, when possible, the Network's savings fund. In this fund, the collective pools the scholarships that some of its members get and the payments that the local government health sector gives them whenever they give workshops at their behest on the booklet or on sexual and reproductive rights.

The Simone de Beauvoir Leadership Institute has been a partner organization to the Network which has offered up its spaces for them to meet and has invited them to work on important projects such as " What is Public is Ours", which has helped the group increase its capacity for political advocacy. Also, meeting other indigenous women's collectives from all over the country in some events and collaborating with them has allowed the organization to share thoughts and participate in projects such as the Campaign, where it created materials that are helping its mission to divulge women's rights so women can exercise and demand them.

All these experiences have helped the collective gradually systematize its ideas and consolidate its project's identity and proposal. Although today the Peepeno'ob Network is a small group of women mainly from the state of Yucatan, it is seeking to broaden its scope to work with Mayan women from all over the Mexican peninsula.

title: Beijing On Action · China
introduction:
info 2017

In China, the lack of good job opportunities in rural areas has led more than 280 million people to migrate to the cities. To reduce this migration, the government has made access to basic services more difficult for those who do not hold an official residence permit from the city they have settled in (known as hukou), which is very difficult to obtain. This policy complicates the experience of the migrant population and makes them vulnerable to labor abuses, discrimination and difficulties in accessing justice, health and education services.

 

How to improve the quality of life of vulnerable migrant populations and protect their rights?
short_description: Beijing On Action helps migrant workers in Chinese cities solve labor and health problems, defend their rights and improve their overall quality of life with the support of a network of ex-migrant volunteers who assist each other and organize among themselves.
external_link_text: 北京在行动国际文化中心

paragraphs.body_html: In 2006, a group of migrants in Beijing got together to set up the non-governmental organization Beijing On Action (北京在行动国际文化中心) and created a toll-free hotline to help other migrants improve their quality of life in the city and defend their rights. Through this line, callers can ask for support in addressing urgent matters: getting a job, resolving legal disputes at work, dealing with health problems, or defending their social and political rights. This advice is offered by a team of 10 hired staff who coordinates the support of more than 300 ex-migrant volunteers.

Once migrants come into contact with On Action, they are invited to join the volunteer network. Through this network they help migrants in need of support, and also collaborate with each other, donate ítems amongst themselves (guitars, bicycles, etc.), and organize through the Beijing On Action website and through Chinese internet platforms such as QQ, Weibo and Wechat.

Upon contacting the organization, migrants receive comprehensive care thanks to the fact that the volunteers in the network have very diverse cultural and professional profiles (lawyers, doctors, sociologists, social workers). In addition to receiving support for their immediate needs, migrants can also participate in activities to adapt to and improve their living conditions in the city they are settling in. These include psychological care, loans of books from the mobile library, recreational activities (such as badminton, ping pong and karaoke), cultural activities (theater, healthcare and computer courses) and getting involved in work that benefits their new community (planting trees, donating blood, etc.). They also have access to employment counseling, which ranges from CV drafting to learning how to organize at work to achieve the benefits they are entitled to through collective bargaining. To date, more than 14,000 migrants have participated in these activities.

In addition to the contributions of its network of volunteers, Beijing On Action has been able to harness other sources of support to keep its project afloat. Its main source of funding comes from foundations and foreign embassies. Besides, the project collaborates with universities, hospitals, unions, foundations and government agencies, both national and international, that contribute with funding, courses or training. All these partnerships, which are coordinated by a department exclusively responsible for Beijing On Action's relations abroad, enable the initiative to work on a project-by-project basis and ensure that its services are free of charge.

To improve the conditions of migrants in the long term, the organization also works to raise awareness among the population about the migrants’ situation through public performances, activities of social benefit such as the ones mentioned before (blood donations and others), the dissemination of research on the subject, and training in Corporate Social Responsibility for companies, governments and organizations to improve their labor practices. In these trainings, companies are advised to promote the organization of their employees, establish an internal toll-free hotline for them, promote respect for their labor rights, and so forth. Although these practices improve the image and legal compliance of all companies, most of the organizations that come to Beijing On Action for this advice are foreign.

To sustain the trust and solidarity of its collaborators, Beijing On Action pays great attention to accountability and transparency in the management of its resources. To this end, it ensures that its board of directors is monitored by a board of external supervisors that is equivalent in rank. Besides, it publishes its activities and decisions on its website and social media, which also helps the project disseminate and get feedback on its work.

Beijing On Action's comprehensive model has already benefited more than 34,000 migrants and has shown how the conditions that make them vulnerable can be transformed while the root causes of their migration are resolved.

title: Nested Market · China
introduction:
info 2017

As in many parts of the world, the food industry in China is controlled by many intermediary actors (large companies, financial speculators, traders, and others) who set the market’s rules, rhythms, modes of production and prices, giving priority to large-scale production in the shortest time possible. This has led to unsustainable land exploitation –––which has caused serious food security problems–– and has also left small rural producers with an unfair and insufficient profit margin. As a result, the younger generations have been forced to leave the countryside and migrate to the cities in search of better work alternatives, often leaving their elderly parents and sometimes even their children behind. China’s rural areas, then, are full of elderly people who subsist on their own personal food production (known as subsistence economy) and are supported by the income that their children send from the cities.

 

 

How to combat the poverty of small rural producers?
short_description: Nested Market is an alternative market that links rural communities around Beijing, China, with city dwellers so that they can strengthen their economy by selling the remnants of their personal food production, without the middleman.

paragraphs.body_html: Over the last few years, a growing social movement has sought to create an alternative food system with fairer and more ecologically friendly processes that yield healthier products for the population at large. Many of the proposals within this movement are aimed at "localizing" agricultural activity, that is, they focus on local agricultural producers in order to break with the vices of mass production, such as its power relations and the dependence it fosters. One of these proposals is the Nested Market (巢状市场), an alternative market launched in 2010 by a group of researchers from the College of Humanities and Development Studies (COHD) of the China Agricultural University (CAU) so that elderly farmers in the small villages of Sanggang and Baoshi (very near the city of Beijing, China) could earn an extra income by selling the remaining products of their personal food production directly to consumers in the city of Beijing: eggs, chicken and fruits, for instance, which are products that do not require any special intervention and would often go to waste because producers could not sell them within their own communities since their neighbors produce these same things too.

The COHD researchers ––who had already spent years involved in action-research projects with these populations and had been taking their students along for teaching purposes–– considered that a direct link, without intermediaries, between rural producers and city consumers would have advantages on both ends. For rural producers, this would mean more benefits and a greater control over the process of their economic activity than by participating in the food macro-industry; they would also have greater opportunities to advocate for specific cultivation methods, quantities, rhythms and prices, among others. For consumers, this would give them a chance to support a vulnerable sector of the population, and would also mean healthier food (because local agriculture, although not 100% organic, uses less chemical fertilizers than industrial agriculture) at a price that falls somewhere between industrial and organic food.

The team began to promote this project by distributing pamphlets in different neighborhoods of the capital city to get potential buying partners and to set up a direct exchange network between farmers and consumers in the city. However, this strategy did not work because, without any personal connection with the project members, the city dwellers in question were not particularly interested in supporting their project. The researchers then sought the support of their closest and most direct acquaintances, such as colleagues, students, friends and even family members, and with their help they gradually consolidated a network of consumers (of friends and friends-of-friends) committed to supporting the project and providing their feedback, which has allowed the initiative to take on its own pace of growth.

With the support of a group of volunteers, the Nested Market designed a web platform for producers to present their products and for consumers to place orders and make payments. Besides, it also created an account on Wechat (a sort of fusion between Whatsapp and Facebook widely used in China) so that producers and consumers on the network could begin to meet, connect and organize directly. In this app, each farmer has a profile and an assigned group of families (of sometimes up to 150 people) with which they agree on the delivery point for their products in the city. To strengthen the relationship and, above all, to foster trust within this subgroup of consumers, producers seek to meet their special requests and share information regarding their freshest seasonal products, their promotions, and some personal information such as pictures or stories about their homes, families or difficulties. In addition, both on the app and on the website, the Nested Market posts information about food safety, the agricultural production process of their food, and even recipes to cook with. Having the project’s administration operate through the web platform and the Wechat group favors efficient and transparent project management because every step of the process is published online and therefore subject to scrutiny. And since consumers can evaluate the producers, it also promotes open feedback from users, which favors the upkeep of quality standards in terms of the market itself and of its products.

In addition to creating this community of exchange, the COHD team spent 3 years helping the communities of the Nested Market to organize and train themselves. In tandem with the researchers, the communities elect local leaders to help manage the project (usually 3, to have a counterbalance in case of disputes). These leaders are responsible for consulting with villagers about what products they want to sell, advertising to consumers, placing orders, overseeing the selection and packaging of products, and shipping them to the city. They are also in charge of managing resources: they allocate 10% of the profits to solve logistical issues (such as renting a car to transport the goods), 80% to pay the farmers, and around 3% to collect their respective commissions. All this comes with a commitment to keep in close contact with the researchers.

In addition, to strengthen the new market, the Nested Market’s team has done a good deal of research aimed at recovering traditional agricultural technologies; has purchased packaging machines, refrigerators, etc., to ensure the preservation of the products during transportation; and has organized visits to other markets in Beijing for the participating producers to learn what kind of issues they have to take into account in order to better meet the specific demands of consumers in the city (who have a different food culture).

To evaluate the progress of the project and adapt it when unforeseen events arise, the COHD research team makes frequent monitoring and follow-up visits to the communities, talks with them about their experiences in the processes of selection, review and packaging of the products, and monitors the feedback from users through the website and the App.

The Nested Market model consists, then, of helping form and organize the network of producers and consumers, and to help build capacities amongst communities and their leaders, so that they can become independent as soon as possible.

In order to pay for this organization and training work, the COHD team seeks funding from foundations (such as Bread for the World in Germany) and is supported by students and volunteers ––who are generally part of the circle of consumers–– who have helped with the creation of the web platform for free, offer delivery points to receive and distribute products in the city, assist with other logistics services, and make donations of clothes, toys, and other goods.

The Nested Market model seeks to counter poverty in rural areas and has the potential to reverse, at least in part, the migration trend. Although currently its main objective is to serve the elderly in specific towns, in the future these efforts could have an impact on young people as well, who may lose interest in migrating to the cities if they find decent opportunities to improve their quality of life within their own communities.

Today, the farmers in these villages arrange sales independently with consumers in Beijing through the web platform and Wechat (without intermediation from the researchers and without their subsidy). For the Nested Market team, thanks to the creation of communities "with borders" ––that is, communities where producers and consumers know each other–– bonds of friendship, trust and collaboration have emerged between rural villagers and urban consumers, which have sown the conditions for the implementation of other development initiatives, including some that are trying to promote the protection of native species, the recognition of local culture, environmental protection, and others.

title: Pujula Living Mayan Village · Mexico
introduction:
info 2021

Although the Mayan culture continues to have a very strong presence in both Mexico and Central America, it has been undergoing a rapid process of transformation in recent years, as more and more Mayan people are born in cities or leave their communities to move to large tourist centers to work with the millions of people who visit the region attracted by its renowned natural wonders, cuisine and archaeological sites. In light of this, much of the knowledge and customs of the countryside are no longer useful or relevant to the new generations, and although more than 60% of people identify as Mayan in places like Yucatán, for instance, only half speak the language because Spanish is now the most widely used.

 

 

How to rescue the valuable knowledge and customs of the Mayan culture that are being so quickly lost?
short_description: Pujula Living Mayan Village is a project undertaken by a Mayan community in Yucatan, Mexico, that documents and disseminates its culture's valuable knowledge and traditions which are rapidly being lost due to transformations in the region (particularly as a result of tourism)­­, to recover them and give them continuity. To this end, it has created a living demonstration village that offers workshops and visits for both Mayan communities and tourists.

paragraphs.body_html: When his parents' generation began to pass away, Sixto Mazon realized that his culture has many values, knowledge and practices that the younger generations are no longer really familiar with, which means that an enormous heritage, which will be impossible to recover later on, is being let go of. That is why Sixto decided to do what he could to recover, disseminate and give continuity to this knowledge before it vanishes for good.

And so in 2006 he and his family created Pujula Living Mayan Village (Pujulá Aldea Maya Viva), a project in which they interview Mayan people in the area (elders, artisans, craftsmen, and so on) to document their ways of seeing the world and their traditional techniques for cooking, building, healing, and other practices. In addition, to revive and disseminate these knowledge and values, Pujula is building a living Mayan demonstration village, filming videos and conducting workshops for the Mayan communities themselves as well as for tourists.

The members of Pujula know that, despite being born and raised within the Mayan culture, both themselves and the new generations do not fully know or understand traditional knowledge and values. That is to say that they either did not learn them at all, or they learned distorted versions of them, because the changes taking place in the region have been so rapid that many of these practices have fallen out of use within a single generation!

Therefore, in order to document as much knowledge and values as possible before they are forever lost, Pujula has been interviewing and filming mainly elders over the age of 80. In these interviews, Pujula asks open questions about the way the interviewees used to live, the name of some of the local plants, the techniques they used to make things, and so on. Sometimes the Pujula team also goes to them with questions about knowledge or practices that they themselves remember from their childhood and consider worth recovering, so as to verify if their own recollections are authentic or if they have been distorted with the passage of time or confused with new interpretations, especially those developed for tourism. For instance, when members of Pujula recalled living in very cool, hurricane-resistant “palapas” (houses made of palm) when they were children, they decided to find out how these palapas were built back then. And to do this they not only interviewed the elders, but also looked for people throughout the region who could replicate them.

The same happened with hammocks made of henequen (an agave plant), which was very popular in the past but has now been replaced with nylon and other materials. Pujula got hold of one of these hammocks as a sample and looked for people who knew how to make them. Not finding anyone, Pujula worked with artisans to find out how they were made using reverse technology, which means undoing and redoing the hammock until the original technique was deciphered.

These three research techniques (interviews with elders, the search for local experts and reverse technology) are the ones Pujula most uses to recover the knowledge and techniques that it regards as valuable to its culture and in danger of disappearing. And so, in order to carry out this research, the project has been compiling a list of people who could have important knowledge, who could provide guidance, or who could contribute in some other way.

To share the knowledge, values and techniques that its project recovers with Mayan communities and people from all over the world, Pujula has focused on two strategies: 1. Documenting a legacy that can be shared through videos and 2. Building a living demonstration Mayan village.

The videos are made with the support of a team of volunteers who help Pujula shoot the interviews and post them on social media platforms such as Facebook. Most of these videos are mini-clips that explain very specific topics: how to prepare Mayan chalk, what traditional dress is like and so on. Besides, Pujula has sought support from other organizations to make more extensive documentaries that would capture the results of his research. Some time ago a team from the National Autonomous University of Yucatan helped Pujula make a short film and, in the near future, a team from UNESCO will be working with them on a new documentary.

Another key element in the project is the demonstration village, where Pujula is attempting to recreate, on a 3-hectare plot of land purchased in Kaua, Yucatan, the type of place where members of its community were raised. In other words, the project wants to create a kind of living museum-village where both local communities and outside visitors can experience and learn about Mayan culture. That is why, with the support of some experts, it has designed a plan to split the land with such subprojects as:

• A space to keep Melipona bees. Nowadays, their honey is highly valued because they are endangered.
  • A space to grow henequen to make everyday objects.
  • A botanical center to grow plants used for traditional local medicine (they are looking for shamans, healers, curanderos and other people who know about herbology for this portion of the project).
  • A maternity center to deliver babies traditionally.
  • A space for planting kanches, a form of Mayan family orchard protected from animals because it is planted on raised beds, with onions, radish, chili, lettuce, tomatoes, and so on. This space seeks to show, especially to younger generations, that traditional agricultural practices are less harmful than many of today's practices that use herbicides.
  • An ethnographic museum to exhibit and sell the utensils that the Mayans used to use in their day-to-day life and that Pujula has recovered: bags, sandals, water jugs, hammocks, and other items.
  • A space with a traditional Mayan kitchen (with metate mortar and other traditional utensils).
  • A resting area, an ice cream shop and a restaurant to welcome visitors and introduce them to typical Mayan dishes.

Pujula has been gradually developing these subprojects on its land and already welcomes tourists and shows them its research findings, prepares traditional dishes with the support of people from the local communities, and organizes activities such as shamanic cleansings or workshops on various craft techniques such as hammock weaving, kitchen-utensil preparation, or the production of orchards. When Pujula built one of the traditional houses in the village, it organized a whole event so that anyone who was interested could come and witness the construction process and learn about its history, techniques and, while they were at it, stay for lunch. Pujula has designed several packages for visitors to participate in these types of activities and events, to get to know the village, have a meal and even camp there. Its expectation is that these community tours will bring economic benefits to the locals involved in its tour-related activities and their families but, above all, that they will provide the resources needed to fulfill the main objective of its project, which is to recover local culture.

The Mayan village of Pujula not only seeks to disseminate Mayan culture among tourists, but also to spread rescued knowledge, values and techniques among the Mayan communities themselves so these may live on. That is why Pujula has tried to position the village as a meeting place for people from nearby communities. And to achieve this, it has organized workshops and training in music, dance, hammock-making, basket-weaving, kitchen tool-crafting, and other such activities, with the intention that people learn about and value these aspects of their own culture which are being recovered ––perhaps even harnessing them to produce craftwork of their own to earn an income.

As Pujula has a special interest in rekindling the new generations' love for their culture and language, it sometimes organizes these workshops in collaboration with local schools. In 2021, for instance, it held a workshop on making straw baskets for students from the University of Tihosuco in Quintana Roo. In addition, it is registering the project under the government program " Youth Building the Future", which provides scholarships to young people who want to get work experience as interns in an organization or business. The hope is to attract young people to train them in different profitable activities that will earn them an income in the future while helping Pujula further develop the village.

One of these activities is being organized in collaboration with a small team of entrepreneurs from central Mexico who are renting part of Pujula’s land to plant habanero chiles and market them. What they are looking for is to involve young people from the program and others hired by the entrepreneurs through their own resources to learn and help them grow the chiles. The intention is that they will eventually be ready to replicate what they have learned in their own homes and make a profit by selling chiles to buyers that the group has already secured in places like Mexico City.

Pujula also started collaborating with other organizations to bring experts to the village for workshops on topics relevant to the challenges facing local communities today, such as health, alcoholism and domestic violence. Since the workshops were well received and attracted more than 45 families, they were held regularly until at least the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Although the Pujula project began in 2006, and the land and the project mostly belong to Sixto and his family, in 2010 they decided to register it as a civil association with 6 other people so as to get resources more readily. Thanks to this, the organization has been able to receive financial support from universities and foundations that have helped further the village's construction and pay for some expenses, such as the trainings organized for the communities.

Also, a few years later Pujula decided to join local networks that seek to strengthen community tourism, such as the Community Council of Alternative Tourism of Yucatan (COTACY), the network of Mayan cooperatives of the state of Yucatan Co'ox Mayab and the Peninsular Alliance, where community enterprises from all over the peninsula join and organize. Collaboration with these networks has helped it secure economic support and receive training, awards and certifications (one in sanitary safety measures, for instance) that give potential tourists certainty and prepare Pujula for hosting them. This has also helped the project leverage these networks' reach to make itself known at tourism fairs, events and through the digital media that these associations use to disseminate information.

To date, Pujula has been able to materialize its project thanks to the different kinds of support it gets by collaborating with these networks; the participation of volunteers; the fees paid by tourists for workshops, food, tours and the purchase of products; the payment of the land leased for the habanero chiles; the financing provided by universities and foundations; and of course, the investment of time and money made by Sixto's family to buy the land and develop the project to give back such an important legacy to their community.

title: Tumin · Mexico
introduction:
info 2013

Money is a tool invented by mankind to facilitate the exchange of products and services between people. But, when the money in circulation is insufficient or poorly distributed, this exchange becomes difficult because there are fewer jobs and less capacity to buy or pay for the goods and services needed to survive. In communities such as Espinal, in the jungle of Veracruz, Mexico, the lack of official money (the Mexican peso) has generated much poverty and violence and has forced many of its inhabitants to migrate to the cities or to the United States to find better opportunities.

 

How to strengthen the local economy when money is so scarce?
short_description: The Tumin is an alternative and complementary currency invented by the inhabitants of Espinal in Mexico to reduce their dependence on the little official money that reaches their community and to strengthen their economy by supporting one another.
external_link_text: Mercado Alternativo y Economía Solidaria (El Túmin)

paragraphs.body_html: In 2010, a group of teachers met with several people from Espinal and proposed to organize a project with the community that would strengthen the local economy. The initiative was to create and promote an alternative currency to complement the Mexican peso (the official currency).

Complementary currencies are vouchers, coupons, points, or other types of instruments that are used as money and only have value within the communities that agree to use them as a means of exchange. There are thousands of complementary currencies around the world and these can be made of paper or some other material, or can even take digital form.

Inspired by the Tláloc Multitrueque Network project––which is another complementary alternative currency used in the Central Valley of Mexico––the teachers of Espinal addressed their community and proposed the creation of their own local currency to help reestablish the exchange of products and services, which were not circulating not because of lack of interest but due to the lack of official money to exchange them. Therefore, the project (known as Tumin (El Tumin [www.tumin.org]) but formally called "Alternative Market and Solidarity Economy"), proposed the creation of an alternative currency, which would serve to reduce the community's dependence on the availability of official money to address their local needs.

To begin the project, the teachers met with different members of the community to discuss and evaluate, in tandem, what type of services or products each could offer. In other words, they began by mapping and creating a directory of the people interested in participating in the dynamic, as well as of the products and services each could offer in order to set up an exchange network. This allowed everyone to identify what was at hand and what was lacking, according to the interests and needs of the network of participants. Based on this information, they then looked out to find new participants who could provide what was needed or encouraged existing members to produce it. Any member of the community had the opportunity to join the project and was encouraged to do so, because this would make up for a greater diversity of products and services available, and the dynamics of exchange would work better.

The team designed and printed small bills called Tumin and gave all partners (i.e., community members who were enthusiastic in participating in the project) 500 free Tumin each (equivalent to $500 Mexican pesos, about $23 USD) to start spending at any one of the participating businesses. In exchange, the partners agreed to accept Tumin as payment for their own products and services, or to cover at least a percentage of their cost. In other words, the Tumin was not intended to completely replace the Mexican peso, but to encourage people to pay at least part of their expenses with the new alternative currency so they could save or use official money for other things. In order to prevent members from accumulating Tumin ––and to prevent the halt of its circulation, which is what tends to happen with official money–– the bills were printed with an expiration date. This measure ensured that the Tumin were used only for the exchange of goods and prevented people from enriching themselves or accumulating the currency.

The next step of the project was to organize the partners into commissions for education, communication, banking, etc. These commissions would help encourage the participation of the network’s members and fairly distribute the responsibilities that came along with the coordination of the various aspects of the project that were necessary to get it off the ground and to promote it. In order to take their different interests into account in a comprehensive manner and to ensure that all could be represented and benefited, it was decided that the commissions would rotate, that is, members would be in charge of one commission and then move to another one from time to time, so that they could learn about the needs of each area and contribute their ideas or point out problems, thus enriching the project and guaranteeing its transparency.

Today, the Tumin project has managed to survive thanks to the fact that it has gradually helped to promote the use, production, and exchange of local products. Undoubtedly, this has been possible, to a large extent, thanks to the voluntary contributions of the members of the network. The community, for example, contributes by encouraging the participation of new members or by lending a space for assemblies and hosting the House of Tumin, which is the place from which the project is coordinated and where members can buy and sell some of their products. Members also contribute resources for staff salaries and 5% of what they sell inside the House of Tumin for administrative expenses.

In part, the project has achieved its purpose of helping to solve the problems of the Espinal community by making better use of its local resources and promoting cooperation and solidarity among its inhabitants. Firstly, because the community is very divided by social, ethnic, and class barriers, and the Tumin has given them a project, a tool, and a concrete opportunity to get to know each other and show solidarity. Secondly, because the exchange network has helped, to a greater or lesser extent, to reduce the community's dependence on official money. In other words, thanks to Tumin, the real wealth of the population has increased without the need to acquire more official money because it is now possible to access the products and services offered in the Tumin network using fewer Mexican pesos.

title: The Bamboo School · Thailand
introduction:
Info 2024

 

In rural communities in Thailand, as in many countries, it is not always easy to find well-paid jobs or access to basic services such as healthcare and education. That is why many young people decide to migrate, overcrowding the cities and leaving their impoverished communities behind.

How can we break this cycle and create better opportunities in rural communities?
external_link_text: โรงเรียนไม้ไผ่เมชัย

paragraphs.body_html:
Mechai Viravaidya saw something clear: traditional education was not serving rural communities in Thailand, and most young people who went to the cities seeking a better future ended up trapped in the cycle of poverty.

 

It was time to stop talking about the need for change and start demonstrating how to do it with actions.

 

How? By transforming education, adapting it to the real needs of rural communities: If what young people learn is directly connected to their environment and their realities, they won’t have no choice but to go to the city to build a better future.

 

With this vision, in 2009 Mechai founded the Bamboo School (in Thai: โรงเรียนบambooเมชัย) and in English officially The Mechai Pattana School) in a poor rural area of Buriram province, Thailand, almost on the border with Cambodia.

 

His goal was not just to create another school where traditional academic knowledge was taught, but also to offer practical tools that students could directly apply to their surroundings. This way, education would become a driver of social and economic change, helping young people to at least have a realistic option to stay and build the future they wanted within their own communities.

Today, three key strategies define the unique educational model proposed by the Bamboo School:

 

1. Improving the community’s conditions

 

The school is not just a place to study, but a learning center for everyone in the community. It’s not just about educating children but improving everyone’s life through projects that directly involve them.

 

  • They opened a Learning Center for All: The SDG Community Center is a space where the elders can participate in social and recreational activities to stay active and connected with the community. It is also a place where workshops are organized for all age groups on various topics (agriculture, gender, etc.).

 

  • Only accepts payment through social service: At Bamboo School, tuition is not paid with money but with action. Instead of fees, both students and parents must contribute 800 hours of community service per year (400 hours each) and plant 800 trees.

 

  • Creates specific projects to support the community: The school organizes several projects through which students and their families can do their community service, such as:

 

    • Gardens for the elderly: A project promoted by the Bamboo School together with a community center and several local temples. With the support of monks, they are teaching elderly people from various communities how to grow vegetables using modern farming techniques. The idea is to help them improve their nutrition, generate income by selling their products at local markets, and, most importantly, prevent isolation by keeping them active and involved in the community. Students help with tasks like installing the gardens and water tanks. Within this project, elderly people are also taught how to use raised beds, specifically designed so they can work without bending over, making it easier for them to grow their own food and generate extra income. These raised beds require less space and are ideal for growing simple and profitable crops.

 

    • Agriculture adapted for people with disabilities: Some students designed semi-raised beds that people with disabilities can reach from their wheelchairs, enabling them to have their own home gardens and generate income independently.

 

    • Food delivery by drones: During the pandemic, the school delivered food to the elderly and healthcare workers using drones! This project was not only innovative but also brought a lot of joy and connection among the most vulnerable members of the community.

 

    • Swimming lessons for children: Students teach local children to swim, preparing them for floods, which are becoming more common due to climate change. With projects like this, the school anticipates the needs of the community and responds with practical solutions.

2. Forming Whole and Empathetic People

 

The purpose of this school is not just to teach math or history but to form people who truly care about others, who are empathetic, and who also know how to think outside the box to solve real problems. Therefore, students not only learn from books but also from life itself, the people around them, and the challenges they face daily.

 

  • Active Participation in Decisions: Every morning, students gather after breakfast to participate in the daily management of the school and its activities. They are also given a voice in key decisions, such as hiring teachers and admitting new students. How? By helping them organize through a student government, which they elect by vote. Regularly, this government meets with authorities and teachers to discuss these matters, present proposals, debate, and defend ideas, always aiming to reach a consensus that benefits the community. While they don’t always have the final word, their opinions are heard and taken into account, teaching them negotiation skills and teamwork.

 

  • Core Values: Live to Understand

 

    • Empathy: Empathy is one of the core foundations of the education at this school. Students not only learn to talk about empathy but experience it firsthand through immersive experiences and exercises designed to broaden their worldview: For example, to understand the daily challenges of people with disabilities, students spend an entire day each month in a wheelchair. They also skip dinner once a month to reflect on hunger and inequality and become aware of the realities of those who don’t have access to adequate food, developing a sense of solidarity. They also meet with deaf people, teach them the agricultural techniques used at the school, while learning sign language from them. This exercise helps them connect with people from a different reality and promotes social inclusion.

 

    • Discipline with purpose – Conscious use of technology: From grades 7 to 10, students are only allowed to use their cell phones for one hour per week to teach them to use technology responsibly and reduce dependency. In Exchange for using them, students must write three letters to family members or leaders, which are corrected by 11th-grade students. The goal of this exercise is to develop their writing skills and learn to think reflectively and value personal interaction.

3. Developing Skills for Entrepreneurship and Self-Sufficiency

 

In many rural areas, students have limited job opportunities nearby, so they are forced to migrate to cities in search of work to support their families, sometimes even before graduating. To transform this reality, the Bamboo School teaches its students how to create their own job opportunities within their communities so they can improve their living conditions without having to leave their homes or loved ones.

 

How do they achieve this?

 

  • Developing skills to start and manage businesses: Students are not only taught technical business knowledge but also given the opportunity to practice what they’ve learned through real projects carried out within the school’s facilities.

 

    • A key example is the agricultural project, which includes a lab for seed cultivation and gardens where they produce local food like mushrooms, lettuce, and other vegetables using small spaces, little water, minimal effort, and high-profit margins. Students learn the whole process, from production to sales in the community.

 

    • Another project is the printing workshop, where students learn to make t-shirts and other items by dyeing and stamping leaves and flowers. The school even secured a contract with IKEA to sell these products in their stores, giving them access to a much larger market.

 

  • Offering microcredits to graduated students: The school obtains resources to offer loans to graduates so they can start their own businesses in their villages and contribute to the development of their communities without the need to migrate.

 

  • Arranging internships and work experiences: The school makes agreements with companies of all types for students to do internships during their vacations. This allows them to gain practical experience, learn new skills, and earn income, which they will reinvest in their projects.

To offer an alternative educational option for students from marginalized communities, Mechai opened the Bamboo School in Buriram, one of the most impoverished rural regions in northeastern Thailand.

 

The school, which does not charge tuition, mainly accommodates students from low-income families but accepts anyone who meets the admission requirements, regardless of their economic status or social background. Students are selected through a lottery and an interview to ensure the process is fair and not discriminatory based on origin, social class, or background.

 

To reduce operating costs, the school not only implemented a solar energy system and rainwater collection system but also built its facilities with bamboo, a local material that is not only economical but also helps keep spaces cool, reducing expenses on air conditioning and other infrastructure.

The Bamboo School is one of the many development projects driven by the Mechai Foundation, which works to promote sustainability and well-being in communities across Thailand.

 

The Foundation also runs community centers that organize activities to improve rural community conditions, many of which are supported by the school’s students through their community service hours.

 

Additionally, these centers are helping the Bamboo School replicate its educational model in other schools that have shown interest both in Thailand and abroad.

 

To offer free education to its students, the Bamboo School has sought different sources of support, including:

 

  • Donations that the Mechai Foundation helps secure.

 

  • Two restaurants in Bangkok opened by its founder Mechai Viravaidya (“Cabbages & Condoms” and “Birds & Bees”) to fund many of its social projects, including the school, with their profits.

 

  • The social work of the students, which helps the school gain something very valuable: social capital. By benefiting the community, the school establishes a strong bond with the people, creating a broad support base, facilitating community participation, and ensuring the school can count on their support when needed.

 

  • The sale of products from the school: Many of the food items produced by students in the school’s gardens are sold in local markets, and the school keeps a small percentage of the profits. Others are used in the school’s cafeteria to feed students, allowing the school to reduce many expenses.

To ensure its educational proposal has more impact and can transform many places, the Bamboo School welcomes visitors from all over the world who want to learn about its approach, assigning them a group of students and teachers to show them the school and explain how the model works.

 

When it comes to schools intending to replicate their ideas, the school offers to send its own staff to these schools for direct training. Thanks to this strategy, many institutions in Thailand and neighboring countries have begun implementing Bamboo School’s educational model. For example, the Thailand Small Community Schools Association (ACST) has requested the school’s collaboration to implement its approach in small rural schools through the creation of learning and community development centers. Additionally, the school signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Cambodia’s Ministry of Education to replicate its educational model in 20 schools across that country.

title: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley · USA
introduction:
info 2021

It is well known that access to a good nutrition is fundamental to good physical and emotional wellbeing, and yet, like many other countries, the United States is experiencing a very shameful situation: while much of the food it produces each year for its own consumption is wasted (about 40%!), many of its inhabitants are at risk of going hungry! In California’s Silicon Valley, the situation is not much different. Its technological innovation has brought a lot of wealth to a part of its population that earns very good salaries, but this has increased the cost of living in the area, especially because of housing prices, which has caused the rest of the inhabitants who do not earn such a good salary (who are at least 1 in 4 people) not to be able to cover the costs of adequate food and live at risk of hunger.

 

 

How to ensure that all people have access to healthy food?
short_description: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley works to ensure that everyone in San Mateo and Santa Clara counties in California, USA, has access to healthy food. To accomplish it, Second Harvest distributes food in collaboration with other organizations, facilitates people's access to public support, advocates for the right to healthy food, educates the population, and helps to take advantage of food that local businesses would otherwise waste.
location_map_text: Santa Clara and San Mateo counties, Sillicon Valley, California, USA

paragraphs.body_html: Because this problem is not new, as early as 1974 an organization called Economic and Social Opportunities decided to open a food bank in Santa Clara County, California, to ensure that all people in the region could meet such a basic need as healthy food, without having to choose between nutrition and paying their bills. Within a few years, this food bank was established as a non-profit organization and joined the network of local food banks now known as Feeding America, as a strategy to receive advice that would help it grow and to leverage the network's legitimacy to more easily gain partnerships and support. In order to belong to this network, the organization had to pay a membership fee and comply with a series of requirements and trainings (on which kind of organizations to collaborate with, on how to handle and document food donations, on food safety, audits, and so on). In 2019 the organization decided to merge with the San Mateo County food bank and changed its name to Second Harvest of Silicon Valley.

Second Harvest of Silicon Valley is currently working to complement and, at the same time, improve state programs and policies to expand access to healthy food in the region. To achieve this, they have deployed at least four main strategies, the first two focused on addressing the problem now, and the last two aimed at solving the problem in the long term:

1. Expanding access to healthy food.  Second Harvest helps people take advantage of government food assistance programs such as the CalFresh Program, where the State provides low-income families with cards to buy the food they need and want from nearly every store and market in the region. It has also opened more than 100 food distribution centers with the support of a large number of well-organized volunteers. Besides, it has also formed a network of more than 300 local community partners that work with vulnerable populations (religious organizations, schools, nursing homes, community centers, shelters, and so on) and help Second Harvest get food to beneficiaries at one of their 900 distribution centers. Through collaboration with school districts, for instance, Second Harvest provides free or very low-cost meals to students throughout the year (whether school is in session or not).

To facilitate access to this aid and to reach the various populations that could benefit from its support, Second Harvest has created many information and guidance resources that try to be as varied and accessible as possible. It created, for instance, an area within the organization called Food Connection in charge of assisting those interested in receiving support, identifying their needs, and channeling them to the type of help that could be offered to them. Besides, Second Harvest also built a website with very complete and useful information, such as a map with all the locations of the distribution centers and a form so that people can request access to the Calfresh Program online. It also created an SMS text messaging system that tells you where to find distribution centers when you send "GETFOOD" and, in collaboration with the United Way Bay Area organization, provides a toll-free hotline with a multilingual staff that guarantees confidentiality to users and is available 24/7.

2. Educating on nutrition.  Second Harvest is aware that often poor nutrition is due not only to a lack of food, but also to a lack of knowledge about how to best consume it. This is why the organization created a Nutrition Center to educate its community with online resources (nutritious recipes, videos that show how to prepare them, and so forth), and with workshops on nutrition and food safety. And to make these resources and trainings relevant to the different people in its community, Second Harvest often develops them in different languages, for different cultures (recipes for Mexican enchiladas or Asian egg custard, say) and with sensitivity to different local needs (with considerations for diabetics, for example).

3. Influencing local culture and policy-making.  Although U.S. law does not allow charitable organizations like Second Harvest to devote more than 25% of their budget to political activism, the organization has tried to raise awareness among the local population and to advocate for policy-making against hunger at the local, state and national levels, in order to transform the conditions that are depriving so many people of access to healthy food, which the organization considers to be a human right. Thus, together with its community partners and activists, Second Harvest has invited legislators and decision makers to meetings (summits, thematic breakfasts, etc.) to share its experience, its achievements with the community partner collaboration scheme, and its suggestions and priorities to improve the effectiveness of public food access programs.  Second Harvest has also partnered with local governments both to gain their financial support and to guide them. To raise awareness among the local population, the organization disseminates information on its website about the most relevant policies under discussion, about its principles, about its recommendations for changing federal programs, and so on. It has also appointed a spokesperson with a direct telephone number to advise the media interested in publicizing its project or the problem of hunger.

4. Improving food usage in the region. Silicon Valley is an area that, despite having so many food access problems, also has terrible food waste. That is why Second Harvest has decided to buy only 25% of the food it distributes and take advantage of what is already in circulation instead: The other 50% of the food it distributes comes from private or government donations, and if these are fruits or vegetables that are damaged, for instance, it cuts off the bad parts. The remaining 25% is obtained by establishing agreements with stores so that, instead of throwing away leftover food or food that is about to expire, they donate it to the organization. In fact, when a law meant to force local establishments to donate at least 40% of their leftover food was first discussed in 2021, Second Harvest worked to establish itself as an organization certified to receive (and, of course, redistribute) these kinds of donations.

Second Harvest is a huge organization governed by a Board of Directors, the Chief Executive Officer (CEO), the Director of Philanthropy, the Director of Operations, the Vice President of Strategy and Promotion, the Vice President of Human Resources, and the Vice President of Programs and Services. Because it has a large number of employees (about 300), it has been able to form highly specialized teams that help organize its various activities and address the concerns of its many supporters and volunteers. For instance, one team is in charge of operations such as food packaging and delivery, and another is in charge of fundraising. Food Connection team members, who are responsible for outreach, are like social workers who identify potential beneficiaries and engage them with the project. Some, in fact, belong to partner agencies and support Second Harvest by channeling their own beneficiaries to one of its programs.

Most of Second Harvest's food distribution programs are fairly stable, meaning that they have not changed much since the organization's beginnings. But to keep adapting its project to the needs it is encountering and to develop better solutions, Second Harvest formed the Client Innovation Program, which is a department within the organization that uses surveys and focus groups to gather feedback from users on how the programs are working and explore ideas for improving their reach, relevance and quality. Shortly before the onset of the COVID 19 pandemic, for instance, the team launched a pilot project to see if food could be distributed through farmers' markets instead of delivering pre-filled food bags (a project that unfortunately did not work because of the health risks of the pandemic).

Second Harvest has devised many varied strategies to make it easier for all kinds of people to contribute to its project in the way that best suits them (with money, in-kind, labor, food, influence, expertise, leadership, transportation, and so forth) and in this way expand and diversify its sources of support to meet the demand for food in its community, without relying too heavily on any one of these sources in particular. Today, its main sources of support are collaborations, voluntary contributions and financial income.

1. Partnerships

Collaborations with other projects are very important to Second Harvest because these allow the organization to leverage their resources to address more situations or needs related to beneficiaries' food problems. It collaborates with companies related to the food industry (producers, food transportation companies, restaurants, schools, stores, and so on), for instance, to receive leftover food or food that would have been thrown away because its expiration date is approaching. In turn, these companies benefit because they can save storage or disposal costs, deduct taxes, and promote themselves as socially responsible companies. Besides, Second Harvest has agreed with local authorities that people who must perform court-ordered community service hours can do so by supporting the food bank. It has also helped local businesses organize volunteer activities and set up mechanisms to match employee donations to Second Harvest, which helps companies improve teambuilding and create an environment of innovation and productivity.

In some cases, collaborations also serve to fund Second Harvest’s project. In addition to matching employee donations, many local businesses organize fundraising competitions with other companies in exchange for advertising their brands on Second Harvest's facilities or trucks, for instance. And several local stores and online platforms attract customers by offering them the opportunity to shop "for a cause" (like Nextdoor for example) and share a portion of their profits with Second Harvest (10% of a product or 1% of their total sales, for instance) if customers show or register a certain code at the time of purchase.

Besides, partnerships help Second Harvest reach more people. The network it has formed with around 300 local organizations that serve different populations in the Silicon Valley area, for instance, helps a great deal in distributing food and reaching more beneficiaries. The arrangement is that these organizations help Second Harvest identify people in their communities who can benefit from food support, and Second Harvest gives them free food to distribute. It also guides them in registering their beneficiaries with public food programs ––such as Calfresh–– and shares some of the volunteers it gets for its own projects with them. In this way Second Harvest increases the reach of its project, while facilitating the work of these organizations in feeding their beneficiaries.

1. Voluntary Contributions

Voluntary contributions are another very important source of support for Second Harvest, since they enable the organization to achieve many of its goals without spending money. In 2020 alone, volunteers contributed more than 250,000 hours of service, which, according to Second Harvest, is equivalent to the work of 123 full-time employees. This tally of volunteer support is useful to show potential volunteers the importance of their involvement.

To recruit volunteers, Second Harvest advertises in the press, makes deals with companies to invite their employees to partake in exchange for various benefits, and publicizes opportunities on its social media and website. The latter shows which areas are most in need of support, features a calendar with dates and different options for participation (so that prospective volunteers choose whether they want to get involved individually or in teams, on a one-time basis or if they want to register as recurring volunteers, if they want to help with administrative work in their offices, to organize food in the warehouses or to distribute it, and so on). In other words, Second Harvest offers a variety of options to make it easier for interested parties to engage with the project.  It even gives them the option of creating a personalized page to organize the activities they may want to take part in and to make the most of the resources that Second Harvest can provide them with for this purpose.

For those who hold influence within their community and want to take advantage of it to promote the fight against hunger, the organization offers the support of its staff to deliver the message. Second Harvest also provides them with resources (recipes, videos, etc.) and special training to help them become Health Ambassadors if they so wish, giving talks on good eating practices in the community or at distribution centers. Second Harvest also offers training (with certification) for those who want to participate as Promoters by approaching communities to identify and channel individuals or families who could benefit from the organization's support.

Volunteers can also choose to contribute by organizing fundraising campaigns (virtual food drives) and, to this end, Second Harvest offers a platform and a toolkit to create and conduct customized campaigns,  which includes resources such as: a checklist to guide the organization of their campaign; facts and figures to raise awareness and ask for support; a FAQs section, a specialized email and phone line to solve queries and provide guidance; customizable wallpapers to use in Zoom conferences; customizable photos, logos and formats for posters and emails to promote their campaign; hashtags and opportunities to promote them on the organization's social media pages; and more. It also offers them an extensive and very creative list of tips and suggestions for organizing campaigns in different contexts (in companies, schools, churches, with family or friends, and so on), such as: organizing challenges where someone pledges to do something funny if a certain amount of money is raised for the campaign; offering donors to match their donations to motivate them (putting a dollar for every dollar they contribute, say); organizing events (trivia, movie nights) or contests (best chef, for instance) with participation fees that can be donated; putting a little box of fines for those who arrive late or commit some other fault and having the proceeds go to the campaign; allowing people to work from home for a period of time if in return the worker donates the money saved on gasoline; leveraging the campaigns to raise awareness on the importance of nutrition and on the food shortages that other members of the community go through by organizing concerts or conferences (perhaps with speakers that Second Harvest provides); agreeing with peers at work, school or church to occasionally replace a coffee or a meal with a donation to the campaign, or having contributions to Second Harvest presented on birthdays or anniversaries instead of gifts, and more.

To facilitate other types of voluntary contributions, such as in-kind donations, Second Harvest has created a special email and phone line to inform and assist those who are interested in donating space, vehicles, or other items.

1. Income

    Financial contributions are, of course, an indispensable source of support for Second Harvest, which is why, along with the resources to help volunteers organize fundraising campaigns previously mentioned, the organization has worked hard to create all kinds of strategies to help raise money. In this regard, over the years, the organization has realized that selecting a good (and capable) team dedicated to raising funds is critical. With the help of this team, Second Harvest has devised different ways to encourage and facilitate donations by creating, for instance, an email and a hotline to solve doubts and designing a web page that features several ways to support, such as:

    • a catalog with the different fundraising campaigns to participate in.
    • an online marketplace called "Virtual Barrel" that helps people visualize what their support will be used for because it shows images and prices of products (such as cans of tuna, chicken, and so on) that people can "buy online" to support the food bank, although the organization actually combines these donations with its general budget to ensure that the benefit reaches the different needs of the project.
    • a list of companies that participate in the Matching Gift Program by multiplying the value of each donation their employees make to Second Harvest. This means that, before making a donation, people can check if their company is part of this program and decide if it would be better for them to make a donation through their employers instead of doing it directly so that their support is greater and has more impact.
    • a section that allows you to make direct donations to the organization with different options: one-time or recurring (monthly) donation; with or without an acknowledgement of the donor; to make them in tribute, memory, celebration or recognition of someone; and others.
    • announcements regarding temporary donation matching campaigns with slogans such as "Your donation will be matched at $1 for $1 until May 31".
    • online tools and free advice (either one-on-one or during scheduled annual donation seminars) to inform the various ways in which one can contribute to Second Harvest by making long-term financial or estate plans: with estates, wills, living trusts (which may be revocable), with charitable gifts of stock or through retirement accounts (many of which are tax-deductible), etc.

Both securing new supporters and maintaining the support of existing ones is difficult. For this reason, Second Harvest tries to be as transparent and clear as possible when communicating how it collects and manages support, as well as the impact the organization is making to solve the problem of hunger in the community. Besides sharing its experiences on different social networks such as Faceboook, Instagram, Youtube, Linkedin and Twitter; Second Harvest publishes information on its website about its operations and finances: its annual activity reports; audits and evaluations by specialized agencies; its policies -conflicts of interest, privacy, etc.; and graphs and data on how the organization manages the support it gets. Second Harvest has also assigned a controller and a staff specifically devoted to addressing doubts about the organization's finances, dealing with complaints of abuse or corruption through an e-mail and a hotline, and providing specialized attention to any interested party.

Second Harvest also takes care of its collaborators by spending great efforts to thank them publicly, to inform them about its progress, to link them with decision-makers and other stakeholders, and to keep them close by and happy to have supported the organization. It frequently puts together conferences and events (such as the Make Hunger History Awards) to celebrate their efforts and help them get to know each other and disseminate their work while promoting themselves to people, companies, organizations and authorities linked to these types of projects.
