Second Harvest also uses its website to thank and recognize donors for their generosity by giving them different types of recognition according to their contribution: corporate donors are classified in the Premier, Diamond, Platinum or Gold categories; and major donors are classified in the Groundbreaker, Rainmaker, Harvester and Cultivator "circles of support". This portfolio with different categories of recognition, depending on the amount contributed, is a kind of agreement that Second Harvest offers donors to encourage their contributions in exchange for a series of benefits, such as tax deductibility (because Second Harvest is officially registered as a charity), advertising of its logos on the food distribution trucks for a certain period of time, and so on.

title: Mae Tao Clinic · Thailand
introduction:
Info 2024

 

 

War is one of the greatest horrors a society can endure. Its consequences are felt not only on the battlefields but also in the lives of thousands of people who have nothing to do with the confrontations and still lose their loved ones and are stripped of their homes and access to the most basic needs: food, water, health, education…

 

The people of Myanmar (formerly Burma) have had to live in this situation for decades! After independence in 1948, the new Myanmar government, dominated by the Bamar ethnic majority, made agreements with several minorities, such as the Karen, Shan, and Kachin, to give them more autonomy, allow them to self-govern, and control their resources. Unfortunately, many of these promises were not fulfilled, leading to uprisings and violent conflicts in some regions. To make matters worse, in 1962, the military took power in a coup, and under the new military junta, the country’s control was even more centralized. This triggered a series of clashes between the government and different ethnic groups, which in 1988 joined forces with students, monks, and activists to demand more democracy in a movement that was brutally attacked by the military junta, leaving thousands dead and forcing many to flee to neighboring countries.

 

Among them was Cynthia Maung, a Karen ethnic doctor who, while escaping, witnessed the difficult situation of refugees, students, and pro-democracy activists who had settled on one side or another of the Thai border. The situation was a humanitarian crisis: Despite being safe from direct violence, they had no papers, no rights, no food, no resources, and of course, no access to essential services like health.

 

 

How to support the population displaced by war?
external_link_text: แม่ตาวคลินิก
location_map_text: မယ်တော်ဆေးခန်း

paragraphs.body_html:
Cynthia decided to act in response to this desperate situation, and in 1989, she managed to get a very humble house lent to her in the village of Mae Sot (on the Thai side of the border), where, along with a few other students, she set up a small clinic to help her Burmese compatriots fleeing the war.

 

Although at first, she was the only one with medical training, and the clinic only had a few medical instruments Cynthia had managed to bring from Myanmar, its creation was so urgent that it not only prospered but still operates today, helping the victims of the terrible civil war that tragically continues in Myanmar.

Today, the Mae Tao Clinic (in Thai: แม่ตาวคลินิก and in Burmese: မယ်တော်ဆေးခန်း), treats not only refugee students and those fleeing the war, regardless of ethnicity, political condition, religion, etc., but also Burmese people crossing the border to visit it because in their regions there is no access to medical services, or when they do exist, they are either very expensive or of poor quality.

 

It also assists those who cannot go to clinics in Myanmar due to security concerns or political or religious reasons, as well as displaced people. And especially in recent years, it has helped many Burmese migrating to that area of Thailand to work and find a better quality of life but who, due to not having papers, have no access to many services in the country, such as health or education.

Clearly, in order to attend to and be useful to these different groups of Burmese people and help create a different future for them, the clinic has had to expand its facilities, prepare more staff, and most importantly, constantly adapt its services.

 

Today, the clinic defines its working model as “an umbrella social services network for refugees, migrant workers, and other displaced Burmese” which primarily includes three areas: Basic healthcare, education and vocational training, and Child protection and education.

1. Basic Healthcare

 

Mae Tao Clinic has a clear goal: to offer free and quality medical services to the population of Myanmar, especially to those who need it the most, without turning anyone away.

 

That is why it provides free consultations and medications to treat individuals with different diseases, or, for example, landmine victims who come from war zones, offering them physiotherapy and prosthetic services, helping them regain mobility and reintegrate into everyday life.

 

In fact, lately, there has been an increasing number of pregnant women seeking help with childbirth. This may be due to the high maternal mortality rates in the conflict zones of Myanmar. However, it is also very likely because they are trying to ensure a better future for their children in Thailand, because although Thailand has not signed the 1951 Refugee Convention and does not grant legal refugee status, all children born on Thai soil are at least given a birth certificate. For many Burmese, this document is a legal recognition that could help them obtain other types of residence permits in the future or open more doors.

 

Many times, people arrive at the clinic with severe cases that exceed its capacity. To help them, the clinic has established a referral system, meaning it collaborates with health centers, Thai public hospitals, and other humanitarian organizations to refer (send them) these patients, covering half of their costs.

 

By leveraging these same collaborations, the clinic also helps to monitor and treat patients with infectious diseases such as HIV, malaria, or tuberculosis.

2. Education and Vocational Training

 

Mae Tao Clinic has another clear objective: to provide the Burmese population with increasing access to better medical care. Therefore, instead of only focusing on treating patients at the border, the clinic also focuses on a strategy that ensures this is possible in the long term: training and educating.

 

How? Well, from several fronts at once:

 

  • On one hand, by educating patients: The clinic not only treats them and provides instructions on how to take care of themselves but also ensures that they truly understand their condition and treatment. Why? Because many of them, when they return home, will share what they’ve learned with their families and communities, multiplying the impact of knowledge. Additionally, this helps with prevention and lays the groundwork for healthier communities in the long term: when people know how to care for their health, they can prevent their conditions from worsening or even from emerging. For this reason, the clinic also holds workshops in migrant schools, teaching children and youth about hygiene, dental care, and disease prevention.

 

  • The clinic also keeps its staff constantly trained: In order to improve care continuously, the clinic’s team receives ongoing training through seminars, surgery training, maternal and child health courses, emergency care, and more.

 

  • It also trains more health professionals in Myanmar: Doctors, nurses, and health technicians from Myanmar are trained at the clinic and then take this knowledge back to their communities, where there is little or no access to medical services.

 

  • Additionally, it is part of a larger effort to transform the healthcare system in Myanmar: The Clinic participates in the Health Systems Strengthening (HSS) project, promoted by a network of community and ethnic organizations that aim to improve access to health in the country’s most vulnerable areas. They do this in two ways: first, by training health workers who operate in rural clinics where access to doctors is almost nonexistent. And second, by pushing for these services to be officially recognized by the Myanmar government, in order to create a more decentralized health system, where communities have control over their own healthcare and become part of a future federal healthcare system.

 

Thanks to this strategy, Mae Tao Clinic not only provides medical care today but is also helping to build a stronger healthcare system for the future.

3. Child Protection and Education

 

War not only leaves physical wounds, but it also breaks families and leaves many children in extremely vulnerable situations. In the case of Myanmar, thousands of minors have lost their parents, been abandoned, or simply cannot live with their families due to poverty, violence, or displacement. For these children, Mae Tao Clinic not only provides medical care but also a safe place to grow, learn, and dream of a better future.

 

The clinic's child protection program actually began as a practical response to an immediate need of its staff: in 1995, doctors and workers at the clinic, who had nowhere to leave their children while treating patients, decided to create a small daycare to take care of them. But of course, their work with refugees made them realize that many other children also needed help. Children whose mothers had died during childbirth or who had been abandoned because poverty prevented their families from caring for them, for example. That’s how, little by little, they began to admit more children with these situations, expanding the daycare into a larger program.

 

 

From a Daycare to a Comprehensive School

 

As the children grew, so did the program. In 1997, for example, they created the Child Development Center (CDC), a small primary school with only five teachers. And in 2005, they opened the secondary school so students could continue their education. By 2009, the CDC had its first graduating class of 12th grade, and that same year, a new building was opened to house all the students, from primary to secondary school, in one place.

 

Today, at the CDC, students can obtain internationally recognized certifications, such as the GED (equivalent to a high school diploma in the United States). This allows them to apply to universities, get better-paid jobs, and in some cases, even obtain scholarships to study abroad.

 

 

A Safe Refuge for the Most Vulnerable

 

Another need identified by the clinic was to offer safe shelters for abandoned or orphaned children, or, for example, for those who could not live with their families because their parents worked in precarious conditions that didn’t allow them to care for them. Many of these minors were living through very hard situations and needed help. That’s why the clinic began collaborating with local community organizations to form shelters, where children receive food, shelter, health guidance, and, above all, much love. They also work to find permanent homes for abandoned children, ensuring they have a stable future. By 2017, the clinic and its allies were already providing shelter, education, and support to children in 35 shelters in both Thailand and eastern Myanmar.

 

 

Working as a Team with the Community

 

The clinic knows it can’t do everything alone. That’s why it collaborates with other local organizations to ensure children can get everything they need: from food and clothing to emotional support.

 

Additionally, it organizes workshops and activities so families and communities can get involved in the children’s care, manage resources, and improve the programs, creating a support network that benefits everyone. This approach strengthens the clinic's capacity to care for more children.

Amid the constant flow of patients and limited resources, Mae Tao Clinic has managed to organize itself in a way that has allowed it to continue functioning against all odds. In 2016, they moved to new facilities and have gradually perfected an organizational model that combines flexibility with strength:

 

Mae Tao Clinic operates as an independent, non-profit community organization, a status that allows it to remain focused on the Burmese communities without depending on political or commercial interests.

 

The ethnic diversity of its medical team—composed primarily of professionals from the Karen and Bamar ethnicities, but also from other Burmese minorities—is a key part of its model. Their linguistic and cultural plurality allows patients from all ethnic groups to receive care in their native language and within a familiar cultural framework.

 

The organization is overseen by a Board of Directors, and to ensure that every decision made at the clinic adheres to the highest ethical standards, external auditors are allowed to attend and participate in key meetings.

 

The clinic has a remarkable ability to transform challenges into concrete improvements. A clear example of this is the evolution of its hygiene protocols: in 2006, during a routine evaluation, the medical staff identified that sterilization methods varied between departments, posing a significant risk of infections. Instead of ignoring the problem or applying temporary solutions, they formed a specialized working group that spent months analyzing each area. This meticulous process paid off in 2008 with the creation of the Infection Prevention Unit (IPU), which established standardized procedures for the entire clinic. But they didn’t stop there: a decade later, in 2018, they built a dedicated physical space exclusively for this work, designed specifically to optimize the flow of materials from their entry (in contaminated state) to their exit (completely sterilized). Each improvement arose from identifying specific flaws and developing tailored responses.

 

To maintain the quality of the clinic’s services, they interview patients each year to evaluate the treatments they received. Additionally, they maintain an ongoing training program to ensure that their staff—many of whom were trained at the clinic—is always up to date on the best medical practices.

Mae Tao Clinic has managed to stay operational for over three decades thanks to its ability to weave a diverse network of supports that complement each other: resources, knowledge, and strategic allies that have allowed it not only to survive but to expand and improve its services over time:

 

  • On one hand, it takes advantage of the expertise of international volunteers to gain specialized knowledge and create permanent local capacity—such as the Australian physiotherapist who trained the rehabilitation staff in 2014 or the Canadian doctor who founded the acupuncture department.

 

  • Furthermore, the clinic has formed key alliances to offer services it couldn’t provide on its own: For example, it collaborates with the Suwannimit Foundation to resolve legal procedures and access medications and supplies from the Thai healthcare system. It also works with the Burma Child Medical Fund, which helps cover the costs of sending patients to Mae Sot hospitals through the referral system. These collaborations address concrete needs: permits, specialists, equipment, and funding for severe cases. This ensures that patients receive complete care, even when some treatments are carried out outside the clinic.

 

  • Mae Tao Clinic has created multiple mechanisms for people to support it:

 

    • A donation system where one can choose exactly how to help, from $3 for a pair of glasses to $715 to train a healthcare worker

 

    • Creative campaigns, such as their annual raffle or sales of crafts made by refugees.

 

    • The publication of a detailed list of priority medical supplies so that those who prefer to donate items can check which ones the clinic needs most.

 

    • And for the most committed, step-by-step guides to organizing fundraising events. — The clinic has received extraordinary support, such as a donor who biked 2,000 km to raise funds.

 

To make the most of its limited resources, the clinic implemented a computerized management system that allows it to control its inventory in real-time, schedule purchases in advance to avoid costly last-minute expenses, and distribute medical supplies according to the specific needs of each area. This intelligent system, in operation since 2008, has significantly reduced material waste and optimized the use of every cent.

Over more than three decades, Mae Tao Clinic has built a network of medical care and community support that transcends borders and adverse circumstances. What began as a modest health shelter in a borrowed house has evolved into a comprehensive healthcare system that serves more than 100,000 patients each year — half Burmese migrants in Thailand, and the other half people who cross from Myanmar specifically seeking medical care that is denied to them in their country due to conflict or poverty.

 

Each year, the Clinic addresses medical conditions ranging from acute to chronic. But the true impact goes beyond consultations: the clinic has trained more than 3,000 healthcare workers who today are the only available medical providers in many remote communities in Myanmar.

 

In a context of forced migration and displacement, Mae Tao Clinic has understood that health cannot be separated from the overall well-being of individuals. That is why its work extends to building strong community networks that especially protect the most vulnerable. Thousands of children have found not only medical care here but also a home, education at the CDC school, and the possibility of dreaming of a different future.

 

This care model, which combines direct medical services with professional training, child protection, and community development, demonstrates that even in the most adverse circumstances, it is possible to build alternatives based on human dignity.

 

The story of Dr. Cynthia Maung and her team reminds us that true medicine does not only heal bodies but restores the social fabric and plants hope where there was once only desolation.

title: Farmers' Villages · Indonesia
introduction:
info 2022

There are more and more people in the world and more food is needed to satisfy us all. Despite this, working as a farmer is becoming less and less profitable, which is why many people are preferring to migrate to the cities instead of dedicating themselves to cultivating the fields, although it is also difficult to find well-paid jobs there.

The same thing happens in Indonesia. Even though the demand for food is growing at around 4% per year, there are fewer and fewer people that want to engage in agriculture. The few farmers who own their lands do not earn enough from their crops, since they don’t normally have direct contact with consumers and they need to sell them through intermediaries who keep a large part of the profits. In addition, they must compete with the prices of big agroindustrial corporations that have greater production capacity, and who monopolize the seeds and the market. And for those farmers who do not own their own lands the situation is even worse, because they must work other people’s fields, earning wages that do not allow them to meet their health, food and education needs. For the same reason, today only half of the rural population in Indonesia is dedicated to agriculture, and young people are increasingly losing interest in dedicating themselves to this work.

 

 

How to make farmers be able to live well from their work?
short_description: The Farmers’ Villages are a project from the Islamic organization Dompet Dhuafa and the farmers’ cooperative Agronative in Indonesia that enables farming to become a profitable and independent way of life by training farmers, linking them to markets and helping them to start their own agribusinesses. It also offers training sessions to officials, students and other people interested in learning about its work model or about modern organic farming techniques.

paragraphs.body_html: In order to create an alternative that allows people to live from agriculture and not have to migrate from their communities to survive, Dompet Dhuafa and a group of farmers from the Cibodas village in the West Java province of Indonesia, decided to create a Farmers’ Village (Desa Tani) to professionalize farmers in horticultural techniques (to produce food in orchards) and offer them tutoring so that they can start their own agribusinesses in an independent way.

Dompet Dhuafa (which in Indonesian means “poor people’s wallet”) is a philanthropic Islamic organization that since 1993 helps the Muslim community in many parts of the world to channel their donations to programs for combating poverty. Many kinds of charitable deeds are encouraged in Islam. One of them is Zakat, which is something like a moral obligation that encourages people who have their basic needs covered to donate a small percentage of their income to causes that benefit disadvantaged people (2.5% is what’s commonly accepted). In Indonesia, where there is a lot of poverty to fight, many Muslims (who represent about 90% of the population) usually give their donations to social organizations or programs that have been designed by the government to channel them to the people most in need, but the creators of Dompet Dhuafa realized that many people were losing the will to make these donations due to the lack of transparency with which they were handled as well as the lack of results. That is why they decided to create an organization with which they have since developed economic, health and education programs, that, due to their effectiveness, transparency and emphasis on empowering people, encourage the Muslim community to recover its will to contribute to the fight against poverty by giving them the certainty that their contributions are well spent.

Dompet Dhuafa is always looking for its projects to eventually be able to operate self-sufficiently. For this reason, since they started the Villages' project along with the Cibodas' farmers in 2018, they have spent a lot of time designing together a model that over time, allows the program firstly to be self-financing and secondly to be able to function without the support of the organization.

In 2018, they used a 1.2-hectare piece of land of one of the Cibodas’ farmers to start preparing the Village and by 2019, they managed to launch the program with 12 farmers who decided to participate.

The Village invites people from the area that are interested in starting an agribusiness to sign a 15-month contract (preferably poor or single mothers, who are the ones who need it most). In the contract, the Village commits itself to lending them a piece of land, tools and materials to produce, train them in modern horticultural and agribusiness techniques and link them with buyers. With the Village’s team mentorship, the farmers grow their own foods, learn how to package them, and start selling them to buyers that the Village helps them find. When the Village helps them sell their products, it adds a percentage (a maximum of 30%) to their price, which the Village keeps and invests in the project’s growth.

Once they begin to generate profits, the farmers give the Village periodically “voluntary savings” as well as “mandatory savings”. The mandatory ones are to return back, little by little the investment made in them by the Village (an economic value is given to the loan of the land, the equipment and the mentorship), so that the Village can continue supporting new farmers as the first ones become independent. Voluntary savings are, as their name says, optional, but the Village strongly suggests the farmers to do save money, in case they need to use it in an emergency, to cover other important needs that may arise and, above all, so that they can acquire or rent their own lands once they finish their contract with the Village, in order to continue their agribusiness independently. With these strategies, the Farmers' Village is trying to create self-sustainability in its community.

The farmer and the Village can renew the contract for one more period or terminate it before the agreed 15 months if there isn’t a good understanding between them. And if the farmer doesn’t manage to make his business prosper to generate profits, he is not forced to pay the expense that was made on him, but the situation is evaluated to determine if it is convenient for both of them to continue with the 15-month contract. In the opposite case, in which the farmer feels that he is ready to work his own land independently before the end of the 15 months, he can also terminate the contract without any problem.

To increase the farmers’ capacity to build a profitable and independent life alternative, the training sessions include land management (forms of planting, agricultural techniques, fertilization, etc.) and production and marketing processes. They teach, for example, modern cultivation techniques that help maximize land use, so that farmers get higher benefits for their work. One of them, for example, is the use of Smart Green Houses that they installed with the support of the insurance company Prudential Syariah. These houses have plastic walls that let in light to help keep the orchard’s temperature warm, which allows them to produce, according to Dompet Dhuafa, the equivalent or more than what would be produced in a 1,000 m2 of traditional open land cultivation but in a much smaller space. For the same reason, they are especially beneficial for farmers who do not own lands and have to rent them to someone else to be able to cultivate.
The Village has also set up a packing house (where produce is cleaned and packed for sale) and has established links with markets and logistics companies to help farmers distribute their produce.

The Cibodas Village started working very well: when comparing the survey that the team conducted at the beginning of the project with another they conducted in 2020 to assess its evolution, the results showed that the farmers had increased their income by 50%! Seeing this enormous success, the team decided to capitalize the profits obtained from the project to benefit more farmers by renting new lands (from the government, because it is cheaper) to open new Farmers’ Villages in nearby towns. By 2022, they already had new Farmers’ Villages in 4 parcels with a total of 2.8 hectares and 57 beneficiaries in nearby communities such as Suntenjaya, Cibodas and Lembang.

The success of the program also began to attract external visitors interested in its work model to empower farmers and its cultivation techniques, especially university students (from fields such as agronomy) and public officials working in agriculture and social development programs. For this reason, the Village began offering tailor-made training sessions for visitors for one day or up to 6 months that include visits to the nurseries, recreational activities, agriculture education and food. As of today, the Village charges for these trainings (with prices that vary according to the economic capacity of visitors) and invests those revenues in its project. Furthermore, the visits benefit the local community, since they provide the opportunity to offer visitors lodging services, food, etc.

The project’s growth made them realize that they not only had to expand their area of work, but also to institutionalize the project, in order to allow the local farmers to manage it independently and let Dompet Dhuafa focus on scaling the Villages’ proposal to other areas of the country.

With this in mind, in 2021 they decided to form the Agronative Producers Cooperative (Koperasi Produsen Agronative Pratama Indonesia) which has since worked hard to become an organization with which farmers manage the project in a way that is innovative, professional and independent to promote their agribusiness, and also one that serves as an inspiration for farmers from other places.

Agronative has its headquarters in the original Village, Cibodas, which now serves as an operations center (in which the members of the cooperative organize themselves) and as a demonstration space for those interested in learning about the project or wanting to collaborate with it. It is the cooperative that is now in charge of managing the program: it maintains the Villages in order, looks for markets, complies with what is agreed in the contracts with the farmers, takes care of the visits and manages the money. Dompet Dhuafa supports it by helping consolidate its organization and find markets and trainers. Farmers who finish the program and become independent can decide if they want to remain part of the cooperative and if they want to maintain the market networks they created with its support.

When the team realized that both the training with farmers and the education for external visitors’ projects were working very well, it decided to scale up the project so that it could benefit many more people. To achieve this, it got the government to lend them 10 hectares of land near Cibodas and is negotiating for it to charge them only taxes (without paying rent), since the cooperative is helping promote rural development. On these 10 hectares, Dompet Dhuafa and the cooperative are preparing a giant Village that will work as an educational-demonstrative center allowing to support many more farmers and that, with the infrastructure that they are already building, it will soon be able to receive up to 1,000 visitors at a time, who will be offered activities, visits and workshops! To this end, they are already establishing agreements with various educational and governmental institutions so that groups of students, interns and officials be sent to them. They are also obtaining financing to build a classroom, guest houses, a cafeteria, a viewpoint, a camping area, a farm that will also be educational, intelligent green houses, etc. The agreement between Agronative and Dompet Dhuafa is that the latter puts 30% of the investment and the cooperative has to get the rest. As the Islamic culture does not allow requesting loans with interest to avoid usury, what they have done is obtain donations from private institutions. To date (2022), they have already managed to raise more than 85% of the budget that they calculated would be necessary to install this macro Village.

The Farmers’ Villages sustain themselves with the commissions that they add to the price of the products sold by the farmers in the program; with the mandatory savings’ payments that the farmers give them back once they begin to generate profits in order to repay the investment made in them, and with the visiting fees. In addition, the Villages have received support from many organizations that have donated funding and infrastructure (smart green houses, for example) such as Bazma Pertamina, Prudential Syariah, Muslim Family Citybank and PT Audy Mandiri Indonesia. They also receive help from students who do internships in them. Some, for example, have helped them design more finished products (such as tomato chips) so that farmers can sell their crops at a higher price and have trained farmers’ families to be the ones to transform the crops so that the communities that house the Village receive more economic benefits.

All this income allows the project to pay its operating expenses (staff salary, payments to experts for training sessions, services, infrastructure, materials, maintenance, promotion, etc.), rent new lands and support more beneficiaries and visitors. The team hopes that, with the construction of the new Edu-agro-tourism Village, it will be able to have more income that will allow the project to keep improving and escalating.

To maintain the support of its donors and for them to create a bond of friendship with its beneficiaries, the Villages organize visits for them to learn about the project, share a moment with the farmers, take their families to spend the day and learn to harvest vegetables to take home.

The Farming Villages have benefited not only the local farmers who participate in the program and the visitors of their educational agro-tourism courses; they are also benefiting other villagers who are hired by the farmers participating in the program to help them with the planting; the families who are providing lodging or food to the visitors; and those who are helping to prepare finished products to increase the value of the crops of the program’s farmers. Many of the beneficiaries are people who previously only found temporary jobs or farmers who have been displaced from their lands by the State, either to establish conservation areas or to concession them to private companies to be converted into great scale crops.

With this initiative, they are demonstrating that agriculture can be an alternative way of life if people are supported, so that they can dedicate themselves to this activity in a profitable way and build a more independent and better-quality life for themselves and their communities. With the Farming Villages, Agronative and Dompet Dhuafa are helping increase the self-sustainability of many rural populations and are empowering more and more people to do the same in their own communities.

title: Ollin Kaos · Spain
introduction:
info 2021

Barcelona is a beautiful city on the shores of the Mediterranean Sea where people of more than 100 nationalities live together. According to some studies, it is one of the cities with the best living conditions in Spain and the one with the best reputation  in the country in terms of its administration, environment and economy.

 

Unfortunately, these advantages are not distributed evenly. Immigrants (who are 3 times more at risk of poverty than locals) as well as many citizens in general have difficulties leveraging the city’s prosperity and enjoying a good standard of living because of the high cost of goods and housing, and the precarious employment conditions many people are subject to.

 

 

How to create a better quality of life in the city?
short_description: The members of the Ollin Kaos collective have managed to build a healthier way of life and work freely in what they most enjoy by promoting dynamics in which they and the members of their community support one another and exchange knowledge and experiences through creative arts, self-care and self-management activities.

paragraphs.body_html: In 2014, after years of taking part in various collectives, Susana and Dickens decided to create their own project in Barcelona aimed at resisting against ––and building an alternative to–– the traditional system of life that pushes people to work in demanding low-paid jobs, feeding themselves with poor quality food and living in constant stress. This is how Ollin Kaos was born, a collective that promotes a gathering space and activities for neighbors, artists, collectives as well as migrants and locals to meet, integrate, support one another and exchange knowledge and experiences. Through the arts, creativity and self-care, the collective promotes communitarian dynamics that seek to improve the quality of life of all those who are willing to take part in the project.

Since its creation, more than 300 people have become members of Ollin Kaos and, although the number of active members varies according to the season, it normally attracts a large group of people who participate in one of its two main initiatives: the workshops and activities, and its gastronomic proposal.

The workshops and activities

Since they started the collective, Susana and Dickens decided to register as a non-profit cultural association to acquire a legal standing that would make it easier for them to lease a venue to organize events, since rents in Barcelona are very high and the process to apply for the free spaces provided by the city council for this type of projects (civic centers, for instance) is very complicated and has many rules.

Thanks to this, Ollin Kaos has been able to rent a venue to organize its activities. In this space Dickens set up a workshop to build traditional musical instruments and Susana, who is a dancer, built a practice room with a hardwood floor and some mirrors. The space frequently houses workshops, concerts, presentations and various activities of gastro-performance, contemporary dance, Mexica dance, Mexican son jarocho and other musical styles from countries such as Brazil, Colombia and Italy.

Some of these activities are offered directly by Susana or by Dickens in exchange for a modest participation fee and on the condition that participants become members of the collective. Others are offered by members of Ollin Kaos or other groups, such as the collective Artefactos Mexicanos, for instance, which sometimes organizes dinners along with film screenings to promote reflection on different themes. The deal is that, in exchange for a 10 euro fee, Ollin Kaos allows them to use the space to organize their activities or give courses, and they can in turn earn revenue with "reverse box office", that is, with the voluntary contribution of participants. Occasionally, as a way of earning funds, Ollin Kaos holds these workshops in other spaces and for other organizations that ask them to do so.

With these strategies, Ollin Kaos has succeeded in maintaining the venue, while leveraging the diversity of experiences of the collective's members to offer a variety of workshops and presentations that help them meet the objective of their project: to strengthen community ties and improve the physical and emotional well-being of the participants in a comprehensive way by addressing issues of self-care, health, social problems, history, and many more. In addition, the workshop facilitators also benefit from the opportunity to showcase their work and earn an income from the participants' contributions.

The food

Ollin Kaos' other main proposal is gastronomy. For the collective, food is a great excuse to get to know other cultures, share with others and nourish the body. That is why Ollin Kaos created a community canteen with one long table where every Thursday (twice daily) the collective shares creative, handmade, healthy and organic dishes from around the world, especially from Mexico because that is where Susana is from. The organizers let members know what the menu will be through a WhatsApp group chat so they can confirm their attendance and let them know if they are bringing guests, who are charged a slightly higher fee than members. These meals have enabled members of the collective to learn about the different dishes and their origins, and have given everyone a chance to get to know each other and socialize on a regular basis.

Besides, the food program is growing thanks to the fact that one of the members gave Ollin Kaos a part of her plot of land on the outskirts of Barcelona to plant a “milpa” (a vegetable garden with corn, beans, squash and chili) which they are using to learn about the land and the history of this Mexican agro-system in order to spread this knowledge with the members of the collective and other people from outside by organizing visits, workshops and other activities related to the preparation process and the healthy consumption of food.

Ollin Kaos makes decisions for the collective in assemblies with its members, but on a day-to-day basis, the project is coordinated by Susana and Dickens with the help of 1 or 2 interns they invite every quarter to help them carry out some tasks to keep the project afloat (cleaning, administrative, etc.) in exchange for food and free admission to the workshops.

Operating expenses such as water, electricity, rent or ingredients are generally covered by the workshop fees paid by organizers, the contributions from participants in the courses or activities, income from the canteen and the membership fee payments (which has a cost of 10 euros). Besides, Ollin Kaos frequently uses bartering to expand the possibilities of the project ––they sometimes exchange workshops for food, for instance. Also, since the vegetable garden has begun to bear fruit, they hope it will soon be able to supply part of the food used in the canteen and the other culinary activities.

Today, Susana and Dickens have managed to build an alternative way of life that allows them to work freely in what they love and make a living from it, and they have also managed to create a community of friends to whom they have provided, as well as meals and workshops, many opportunities to make their work known, explore their creative abilities and collaborate with one another.

title: ChildFund International
introduction:
info 2013

Early development has a great impact on everyone’s life. Our life-long health, our ability to learn and develop new skills, our opportunities in life, and perhaps even the amount of money we get to make have a lot to do with the care we received as kids, with the environment in which we grow up and even with what we ate in our early years. Yet one in five children around the world lives in extreme poverty. Often, families do not have the means to guarantee such basic things as proper nutrition, let alone an education and opportunities for the future. And more often than not, this is a cycle that repeats itself from generation to generation.

 

 

How to help all children have a chance to be happy and grow up healthy?

paragraphs.body_html: Seventy-five years ago, ChildFund International realized that breaking the cycle of poverty and improving the future of children would entail intervening in their early development and fostering the conditions for their comprehensive upbringing. So the organization decided to focus its work on making sure that the first, most formative years of life actually favored learning, health and development. And ChildFund also realized that, to achieve this goal, its work could not be restricted to just the children but should address their broader environment as well: their family, school and community.

Today, ChildFund has increased its reach to the point of working in 31 different countries. And because the organization understands that problems and circumstances are different in each country –indeed, in each village– ChildFund partners and collaborates with local organizations, businesses or governments to identify key problems and come up with coordinated solutions. In many cases, ChildFund even helps create these organizations within communities from scratch and helps build them up until they can take over the projects.

What makes ChildFund different is that, rather than having standardized programs, it tailors its interventions to the specific context of each locality. To achieve this, ChildFund partners with local organizations (NGOs, parents' committees, and so on) to identify what issues affecting the community also have an impact on children's development. Then, the project and organizations work in tandem to come up with programs to solve these matters in a comprehensive way –that is, for the benefit of entire families and communities, as well as for the children themselves. And when ChilFund wants to support a population in which there are no organizations to partner and work with, it collaborates with the communities to create them.

An important part of ChildFund's work is ensuring that these local organizations have the autonomy to make whatever decisions best suit their local contexts so that, little by little, they can become independent of ChildFund’s support. To achieve this, the project guides them in the process of registering as independent civil organizations, and works with them to design a plan that includes economic support, capacity building programs (training to obtain funds, manage programs, establish cooperatives, increase social participation, and others) and an "exit" date after 10 or 20 years, by which time the organizations will have to operate autonomously, as ChildFund's sponsorship and support will be withdrawn. Because ChildFund's ultimate goal is to build capacity at the local level to manage these projects, the organization evaluates whether or not the programs are working by regularly assessing how self-sufficient these organizations have become.

In some cases, this scheme of creating and strengthening organizations at the local level also entails getting businesses to sponsor the formation of local cooperative stores: members of the co-op will supply products to the businesses at fair prices, and commit to a series of responsibilities, such as enrolling their kids in school. The agreement also stipulates that the co-ops' profits will be reinvested in the cooperative itself to cover its running costs and pay its salaries, as well as in the community at large (say, through one of the programs run by NGOs operating in that same region). With this scheme, companies benefit from tax deductions, comply with their Social Responsibility programs, promote themselves and secure suppliers by buying products from the community. The co-op members, for their part, benefit from the investment in their community, which improves their general living conditions, and from the stimulation of the local economy through these employment opportunities. Co-ops also adjust to a given "exit plan" (i.e., the cooperative must be run entirely by the local community within a given period).

To promote these types of projects, ChildFund reinvests a large portion of its resources in fundraising staff, campaigns, and other strategies to get even more contributions. An instance of this is how ChildFund will sometimes encourage companies to sponsor a program by offering to "match" their donations, which means that, for every x amount of money that the company or its employees contribute, ChildFund will invest the same amount. But ChildFund tries to diversify its support as much as possible so as not to depend too much on the criteria or conditions of any one of these companies in particular –or indeed of any of its funding sources– because the project wants to guarantee its freedom to adapt its programs to the needs of different contexts. So in addition to securing corporate sponsorships, the organization also encourages individuals to make online donations through its website or to sponsor a specific child and support his or her education and development –however, ChildFund will put these contributions together to support not only the sponsored children (and their different needs such as nutrition, books, school supplies, etc.) but also their communities at large (with clean drinking water and medical providers, for instance).

ChildFund has come to realize that, in order to attract and maintain the support of collaborators and donors, transparency with regards to fund management is key, as is the efficient use of resources to convey trustworthiness. For this reason, the organization has made great efforts to systematize all the programs’ processes and results, and has established a telephone hotline to share information, answer any questions, and help donors and child sponsors feel connected with the children who benefit from their contributions – which helps maintain their support.

Another strategy that ChildFund frequently deploys to convey its trustworthiness to companies and organizations is managing their contributions through trust funds, which are legal contracts that oblige an intermediary (usually a bank) to supervise the handling of the money. Through this mechanism, all the parties involved negotiate and sign a very clear agreement on how much money will be donated and how it will be spent, and then the bank ensures that the terms of the agreement are complied with. This helps donors trust the proper handling of the funds because there is a legal contract that specifies exactly how money –which is never directly in the hands of the organization– will be spent.

ChildFund is a very large organization that works in many places around the globe, with specific interventions that depend on the partnerships in each location and within each context. But in general, its work promotes the development not only of children but also of their families and communities, which is why ChildFund encourages people to organize and take ownership of the projects until they eventually become wholly independent, both from ChildFund's help and from the companies that get involved with and support the programs. In other words, the community sponsorship programs are aimed at a specific objective: to guarantee the self-sustainability of the community within an agreed period so that ChildFund can redirect its efforts to support new communities and, thus, become relevant to more and more people.

title: Ory Lab and its DAWN | Avatar Robot Café ver.β · Japan
introduction:
Info 2025

 

For millions of people, leaving home is not an option.

 

Some because of accidents, others because of illnesses, mental health issues, or simply because the body can’t keep up anymore.

 

They live shut in at home or in the hospital, some unable even to get out of bed. Largely because the outside world has few options for people with mobility difficulties or who fall outside the average, in general.

 

Living in that isolation is not easy. Although technology has worked miracles, it still fails at the essential: It lets you “attend” a work meeting, but not grab a coffee afterward with colleagues. It lets you see your friends’ faces on a screen, but not find out anything about what’s happening behind it. It keeps you informed, but it doesn’t make you truly feel part of what’s going on out there.

 

Since he was a teenager, a Japanese guy named Kentaro Yoshifuji understood this very well.

 

When he was in junior high, his body seemed to betray him. He was the sickly kid in class, the one who missed so many lessons that, little by little, he stopped being part of the conversations. For three long years, while his classmates grew up, made plans, and had fun, he watched the world from a window, trapped in a cycle of relapses and isolation that made him feel very lonely and, because of that, depressed. The worst part wasn’t being absent, but how, upon returning, he discovered that the world had kept going without him. They had been passing him the notes, but he had missed the debates with the teacher. They had called him on the phone to say hello, but he had missed all those spontaneous moments where friendships are made.

 

That’s when he realized that a fundamental limitation of technology was that it connected, but didn’t include. It helped you be present, but not belong.

 

So when Kentaro’s health improved and he entered vocational school (and later university) to study artificial intelligence and robotics, he became obsessed with a question that would be the seed of an incredible project that would soon change his life — and that of many, many people!:

How can we improve technology to enable isolated people live their lives out there and stop feeling lonely?

paragraphs.body_html:
Kentaro came up with an idea to solve the problem in a way no one else had tried: If people had difficulties going out and interacting in the world, he would create robotic bodies that would allow them to live in it: avatar robots!

 

It wasn’t about bigger screens or sharper video calls. Nor about making robots with their image, or that thought for themselves using artificial intelligence.

 

His vision was more ambitious: Robots that would become physical extensions of people, directly controlled by them. That would become each of them. Literally, like an avatar. That rather than simulating their humanity, would carry it. That would allow them to have a physical presence in real life, not just in the digital world. Robots with which they could interact more fully, move as they wished, greet, work — be more independent!

The first he created was OriHime. A small 20 cm robot that, although it seemed simple, was revolutionary. With just a tablet, a person can bring it to life remotely by turning its head to look around, raising its arms to wave, or even expressing basic emotions like joy or nodding. A true avatar: it allows you to be physically present and interact in faraway places, whether in a café, a family gathering, or even at work.

 

Over time, Kentaro developed an even more advanced robot, which he called OriHime-D. A robot 120 cm tall that not only conveys presence, but can move freely — forward, backward, turning — and even hold things with its arms. It has a 360° camera, microphone, and speaker to see, hear, and speak from wherever it is, and it’s controlled over the internet with a simple screen with buttons. Thanks to its 14 motors it can approach people, nod its head, wave its hands, or carry light objects. It’s like controlling a full body at a distance, breaking the barriers of physical isolation.

 

Most incredible of all, for people with extreme cases like ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis) — a terrible disease that can make you lose mobility to the point of being unable to move anything in your body except your eyes — Kentaro developed OriHime-Eye, a robot that can be controlled using only your eyes! He leveraged a technology that some already used to communicate with their caregivers — a screen with a virtual keyboard that detects which letter you’re looking at so you can type without using your hands — and gave it a revolutionary twist: he connected it to a full robot that obeys your eyes! The robot can vocalize in real time what you type with your gaze, using speech synthesis. It helps you express your emotions, because it has an independent motor system that lets you show gestures like nodding, shaking your head, or raising your arms to greet. In models coupled to the OriHime-D (the mobile robot), you can even take the robot to the desired place (a living room, a restaurant) and control its movement remotely — and thus “visit” places in real time or “attend” events, family gatherings, weddings!

 

Kentaro’s true innovation was not only technical, but one of perspective. He didn’t just want to live his life working, practicing one of the common professions. He wanted to devote himself to building a bridge so that those trapped by illness, distance, or disability would not only observe the world, but could live in it: work, converse, celebrate, create memories, connect and communicate with others, interact, move autonomously, communicate emotions, take on different roles, feel useful and relevant among them, and, very importantly, find new paths for their lives by meeting new people, collaborating with others, generating income, and hearing new ideas.

 

That’s why, as Kentaro himself says, he invented his own profession: that of robot communicator! And to perfect it, he ran several experiments to better understand how human communication works: Despite considering himself very antisocial, for example, at university he moved into the campus dorms to be able to interact more with his classmates. He later worked as a camp leader at children’s camps, where he learned to work as a team and to speak in public convincingly. Later he approached a pantomime club, and the staff and patients of the Japanese ALS Association, with whom he understood that beyond words, communication requires gestures, physical presence, and spontaneity. Thanks to all those efforts, today every detail of his robots — from the angle of their head tilt to their numerous pre-programmed movements — is designed to replicate natural interactions.

By renting them

 

Ory Lab’s avatar robots are the materialization of a powerful idea: that no one should be left out of life just because their body can’t keep pace — a situation that, for different reasons, any of us may go through at some point in our lives.

 

Having invented such gems, the new challenge was to find ways for them to be accessible for people in isolation and for those who can open opportunities for them to use them.

 

That’s why, since Kentaro founded Ory Lab (オリィ研究所) in 2012, he and his team not only develop the robots but seek agreements with different companies to rent them in order to hire this type of worker (selling them is not so easy because manufacturing the robots is still very expensive).

 

Today Ory Lab has more than 300 robots rented, and the challenge is to reduce the rental cost, which currently ranges between $280 and $340 USD per month per robot, so that this technology becomes even more accessible to everyone.

 

In fact, the idea is to get them as accesible as possible to people who suffer from different types of isolation and could benefit from them: those who need to work while raising children, for example. Or those who want to spend time with family who live very far away. Or students who cannot attend classes when they are ill. Or people with physical disabilities…

 

 

By creating a platform to train them and showcasing them: A Café staffed by robots!

 

Ory Lab needed a space where it could test and improve the avatar robots, showcasing them to the public in real life. And the pilots (the people who operate them) needed a place to learn how to use them and receive honest feedback. That is, it wasn’t enough for them to exist in laboratories; a space was needed where they could function in an everyday environment.

 

And so, the Ory Lab team came up with a practical solution: to open a Café where people in isolation could work alongside a conventional staff of waiters, cooks, etc., operating the robots remotely! But not as a controlled experiment, rather as a real business, where in addition to opening job opportunities for them, each cup of coffee served would test both the technology and their ability to integrate into the labor world using the robots.

 

In 2018, they decided to test the idea by opening a small pilot Café in the city of Tokyo, to explore what it was like to work with robots, what was needed, whether it worked, how it felt.

 

To attract people in conditions of isolation willing to participate as pilots for the robots, they made a call through social networks, as they knew it is the place that most of them use to socialize and communicate with the world. And of course, the response was great! Ten people quickly came forward to take part in this adventure.

 

The first days were a constant learning process for everyone. The pilots, from their homes or hospitals, discovered how to overcome their nerves and move through a physical space via their robotic avatars, while the on-site café team — waiters, baristas, and cooks — learned to work with their robot coworkers. The customers who arrived, attracted by the novelty, unknowingly became a fundamental part of the experiment, giving spontaneous feedback with their reactions and comments.

 

Ory Lab ran 3 pilot Café experiments before opening the current one. In each, they addressed the challenges as they encountered them. When they noticed, for example, that it took the robots a long time to move between tables and that this made customers bored from waiting so long, they tried calling more pilots and exploring other possible workflows. In the end they decided to divide tasks among robots: some would focus on transporting food to tables, and others on chatting with customers to take their orders and entertain them while their food arrived, etc. This distribution wasn’t in the original plan — it arose from observing what worked during actual service.

 

After those first attempts, they had to pause testing for a while due to the pandemic, but in 2021 they started a new pilot with a coffeeshop called Avatar Robot Café DAWN ver.β (分身ロボットカフェ DAWN ver.β), which is the current one.

 

To help promote that people living in isolation have more and better conditions to be able to socialize in the world outside their homes, Ory Lab took every measure they could think of so that the Café itself would be as accessible as possible for everyone: it doesn’t have a single step, the space is designed so that wheelchairs can move easily, each table has outlets for medical equipment, and the bathrooms have care beds. In addition, the menu has options for those who have difficulty eating, and special cutlery or food grinding equipment is loaned to those who need it. In other words, every element of the café — from the height of the tables to the texture of the floors — was designed so that no one has to ask for “special accommodations,” because everything, from the outset, is made for everyone.

 

 

By scaling their project

 

Ory Lab has done so well with its project that today it is exploring different ways to scale it slowly but decisively:

 

  • It has, for example, increased the number of pilots. Today, 30 conventional employees work alongside 100 remote pilots! The pilots work on an outsourcing basis with flexible schedules that adapt to their needs: some connect a few hours a day, others on certain days of the week, rotating according to their capacities. Some pilots even operate different robots in different shifts.

 

  • It uses the Café as a laboratory to experiment with its robots, improve them, and continue developing new ones. When they learned, for example, that Mika and Sae (two of their pilots with ALS) had been baristas, they took advantage of their enormous experience and set out to create a barista robot in collaboration with Kawada Industries. Now they prepare coffee from home — grinding beans, adjusting the machine, and even making latte art… all through their robotic avatar!

 

  • Despite the success their Café has had, Ory Lab is not really considering the option of scaling its project by opening new cafés by itself or selling franchises to an investor. First, because their team feels they still have a lot to experiment with to improve the robots and expand the opportunities for them to be adopted in different contexts. But also, because setting up such a café costs a fortune and needs a lot of support. That’s why their current bet is to collaborate with governments, as they are doing with Denmark, where they have already opened their second Avatar Robot Café, with pilots from Tokyo helping, thanks to the automatic translator built into the robots.

 

  • And not only that! Ory Lab is already organizing tourist walks with robots as guides. At the Café in Tokyo, people can rent a backpack with an OriHime robot integrated at shoulder height that, operated by one of the pilots from home or hospital, tells stories and fun facts about the nearby neighborhoods while you walk. The tours last 1.5 hours and for now are a project in an experimental phase.

In 2009, when Kentaro realized that his university labs were too focused on publishing for the sake of publishing, he decided instead to improvise his own workshop to build robots at his home.

 

And to make the most of his resources to develop them:

 

  • he reduced his personal expenses as much as possible (he ate once a day!),

 

  • he designed each robot with interchangeable parts (so he wouldn’t have to redo everything every time a problem arose), and

 

  • he selected inexpensive materials, such as balsa wood and basic 3D printers. Sometimes he even recycled robot parts he found in university dumpsters.

Thanks to this, Kentaro was able to start building robot prototypes with his own resources which, although low-cost and very austere, allowed him to achieve two key advances:

 

  • First, he gained access to hospitals. At first doctors doubted his proposal, but seeing that Kentaro already had prototypes available and ready to be tested, they were encouraged to try them with their patients. Thus, with feedback from real users he was able to keep perfecting them (test, improve, test, improve) and advance very quickly.

 

  • Second, he was able to participate in competitions, which turned out to be extremely useful for boosting his project. Kentaro saw competitions as opportunities to improve his technology, and in each of them he innovated something new for his robots. He also considered competitions an excellent opportunity to gain visibility and make connections with potential investors and collaborators. Therefore, he carefully evaluated which competitions were worth participating in, whether they would have more open approaches because they were new or very established rules because they already had a long history, for example. In addition, he devoted a great deal of time to preparing his pitches to sound as convincing as possible: he memorized different versions in case something went off plan, recorded them and listened to himself over and over, rehearsed with actors, studied the judges’ profiles and what might interest each one, and prepared everything so that he could, more than explain, demonstrate live what he was doing, to make it clear that his technology was functional and not just theoretical.

And that’s why he did so well! At the competitions he met many people interested in his idea, including people from the Japanese ALS Association, with whom he would develop the OriHime-Eye, for example. And also people with whom he began to form a team: at the ROHM Challenge 2010, he met technical mentors who helped refine his designs and engineering students who began to join the project. When, in 2012, he also won the Campus Venture Grand Prix, they not only gave him 3.5 million yen in prize money, but he also began to receive support from an incubator at Waseda University (one of the most important in Japan for tech entrepreneurship), where he learned a lot about how to do business.

 

It was with that virtuous circle of lots of preparation → investment → tests → competitions → prizes, validation, and allies → investment of what was won → more tests → more adjustments → more competitions → more prizes, validation, and allies → more reinvestment and adjustments, that in 2012 he was able to found Ory Lab.

 

That is, in just two years, Kentaro went from setting up a precarious workshop alone, at home, to having functional certified prototypes, prizes in key competitions (a lot of money), a technological base he could patent, relationships with medical institutions and users, and a great team to launch his own Lab! And it wasn’t luck; nothing was accidental: it was persistence turned into an ecosystem. Every step followed a simple rule: “If you can’t convince with the prototype, improve it and try again.”

Today Ory Lab is sustained by various sources of income that allow it to continue innovating and expanding its project:

 

In addition to the robot rentals, it has the profits from its café, which not only offers food and drinks like any other, but sells experiences (robot-served dinners for which you have to buy a ticket). It also makes use of its space to sell project merchandising (like books and T-shirts) to customers.

 

Another important pillar are the interns, who contribute their work. And collaborations with companies, hospitals, and patients, who provide key feedback so that the robots evolve based on real needs.

 

And YouTubers too! When the café had just opened — right during the Tokyo 2021 Paralympic Games — foreign YouTubers suddenly began to show up. They never knew exactly how it happened (whether it was because of the event, the technology, or simple coincidence), but the result was clear: their videos gave them massive exposure on social networks. That initial attention became a snowball effect that, to this day, continues to attract customers from all over the world.

Since Kentaro decided to turn his home workshop-laboratory into a company, he has been very careful to form a multidisciplinary team that shares his dreams and has something to contribute to them.

 

One of the founding members was Akihime Yuki, a friend he met at robotics competitions who, having spent a year confined at home due to tuberculosis, had a particular affinity for the avatar-making project. The other was Yoshifumi Shiiba, a programmer she recommended to him. Before officially inviting him to the project, Kentaro proposed that they first collaborate on a small exercise to see if they felt comfortable working together. This approach was part of his strategy to carefully build a team for an innovative project—a crucial step, since many people had already passed through the lab with whom he hadn’t worked well or who initially showed interest but later preferred to take another path. This strategy worked perfectly, as he and Yoshifumi Shiiba got along flawlessly.

 

Together, they worked for a year and a half almost without salary, in borrowed spaces, until they obtained 20 million yen in funding, with which they were able to formalize the company, rent an office, pay themselves salaries, and hire employees.

 

When decisions have to be made, the three founders discuss and debate the options, and once they reach an agreement, they divide the work into concrete tasks and assign them to the team.

 

Today, Ory Lab has managed to bring together an incredible team that has surpassed 200 people contributing from various fronts: scientists, programmers, administrators, medical advisors, publicist Keiko Hamaguchi — who dedicates to build new horizons for the avatars (and to whom we are enormously grateful for welcoming us with open arms to tell us about the project). There are the lab interns, the restaurant staff, and of course, the pilots!

 

Several of the pilots, by the way, have been key to the evolution of the robots and of Ory Lab’s project. Yuta Banda, for example, a young man who had a brutal accident at age 4 and had spent 20 years in a hospital bed, sought out Kentaro as soon as he learned what he was doing and collaborated with him by piloting a robot in his presentations to obtain support (so that people could see how it worked), by giving him lots of feedback and eventually even by becoming his personal assistant.

There is so much to be learned from Ory Lab’s project and from Kentaro’s experience in particular. Everything — from how they devised a response to the problem of loneliness, how they managed to put it into practice, how they are making their way — is a long story very, very worth getting to know in more depth. It is a space full of energy, where every day there is innovation, adjustments to details, and a search for ways to make these avatars connect people better.

 

But we want to close this post with some principles on innovation that Kentaro discovered along the way, which he wrote in his autobiography, and which we want to share because of how much we can all learn from them for our own projects:

 

  • Invest in experience and learn by doing (not just theorizing). When Kentaro realizes he doesn’t know how to do something he needs, he learns how to do it. Whether by seeking someone who can teach him, taking a course, looking for YouTube tutorials, or buying some similar commercial model to do reverse engineering —which is when you take apart something that already exists to learn its parts, understand how it works, and thus be able to improve it or reinvent it with a new purpose.

 

  • Listen to and observe reactions. Users don’t always know what they need… but their reactions don’t lie. Instead of only asking them what they want with a survey, Kentaro tries to visit them and observe how they interact with the robots in the café or in hospitals. A gesture of frustration or a spontaneous smile tells him more than any survey.

 

  • If you wait for the perfect moment, you’ll never start. Kentaro has never waited to know everything before starting. Many of the improvements to the avatars arise because, when he has a new idea, he doesn’t let time pass and, taking advantage of it being fresh, thinks about how it will be used, draws as clear an image as possible of what that thing he wants to make would look like, makes a prototype immediately with simple materials, tests it with users in the real world, and adjusts on the fly with their feedback, learning from mistakes and real needs as they arise. Perfection is the enemy of the possible.

 

  • Stubbornness is necessary. When one of his ideas — especially a new one — doesn’t convince others, Kentaro doesn’t let it die. He knows that innovating often means working in solitude. So he devotes his free nights to focusing, entering his own world, and turning those abstract concepts into something tangible: a prototype or something others can see, touch, and finally understand. Because one thing is to discuss ideas and quite another is to ignore a robot that greets you with perfect movements right before your eyes. If they don’t understand you, it’s hard for them to support you.

 

  • Finish what matters. In his early years he jumped from idea to idea. He later learned that to be able to innovate you have to choose: Better to complete something that works than have ten things half done.

 

  • Emotion drives hard work. With a goal so complex, Kentaro has never lacked obstacles and has constantly had to face the frustration that, despite enormous efforts, things fail or don’t turn out as he expected. How has he not given in? According to him, he has used several strategies to stay motivated and keep going: One is that when he doesn’t know what to do, he keeps himself busy with other things to clear his mind — he goes for a walk, sings, whatever. Other times, he doesn’t stop working but focuses on very specific small tasks to, step by step, achieve progress that excites him. In other words: divide the problem into small steps (e.g., “today I’ll just fix this motor”). And the other strategy he uses when he feels like throwing in the towel is to remind himself of the reasons why he is doing what he is doing, which in his case is imagining the faces with which the people who will use it are going to react. That image definitely motivates him to continue!

 

  • Patience: the balance between what you like and what you have to do. For Kentaro, it’s better to endure a bit doing what you don’t feel like, if in the end you can devote yourself to what you love. Putting up with boring meetings is worth it when the reward is spending the night perfecting a new gesture of your avatar.

 

  • Do what you believe is right (with responsibility). For Kentaro, one should trust one’s own judgment when there are grounds for it. Test alternatives that others ignore. And measure risks with the only limit being not harming others. After all, everything we’ve told here began as the idea of a high school student!

What began as an experiment in an improvised workshop today has global reach. Ory Lab’s robots operate where they are most needed: in hospitals where bedridden patients regain some autonomy, in schools that reintegrate isolated children, in companies that are daring to discover new ways of remote work.

 

Recognition has come from all over: in 2012 they won the Human Power Award for combating loneliness technologically. In 2016 their capacity for innovation was recognized in Forbes 30 Under 30 Asia. In 2021, they received the Good Design Grand Award 2021, the highest honor in Japanese design. And in 2023 they were finalists for the Zayed Sustainability Award.

 

Today, Ory Lab continues expanding the circle, seeking collaborations with laboratories and companies to bring avatars to new contexts.

 

Behind each of these achievements is someone who, thanks to this technology, can be where their body does not allow them to be. That remains the core of everything.

title: Ectagono · Mexico
introduction:
info 2016

Mexico City’s metropolitan area concentrates a large portion of the jobs and financial activity of the country as a whole, which is why its population has grown dramatically and today surpasses 21 million inhabitants. In many areas of the city, growth has been irregular and unequal, and the lack of oversight of real estate developments has had a negative impact on its nature. This is what happened in the city’s Western districts, famous for housing the financial area and its neighboring residential zones: their growth has damaged the flora, fauna and general ecosystem of the region –a ravine of enormous environmental importance for Mexico City– in addition to creating huge gaps between low-income families and new residents who have built luxurious and exclusive living spaces.

 

 

How can cities dwellers take better care of their natural surroundings and foster more harmonious ways of living?
short_description: Ectagono incubates projects in Mexico City with a view to promote healthier lifestyles in harmony with nature, and to support its main project: the restoration of the Tarango ravine.

paragraphs.body_html: In 2016, the Civil Association Ríos Tarango got a 30 year-long government lease to rehabilitate the Tarango ravine, a very important natural parcel of Western Mexico City. The organization knew that achieving this goal would entail integrating the different communities of the region and tackling the way city-dwellers understand and approach development. The team also understood the importance of coming up with a cost-effective model for rehabilitating the ravine. For this reason, some of the members of Ríos Tarango created Ectagono, a social enterprise aimed at exploring and promoting healthier and more harmonious lifestyles, positively impacting the lives of the different communities that live around the ravine and, at the same time, bringing in revenue to fund their main project: the rehabilitation of this natural environment.

Ectagono uses a plot of land next to the ravine to host and incubate several subprojects that are in alignment with its socio-environmental objectives: food production, education, health, sports and culture. These different workshops, restaurants and places of interest are meant to foster healthier lifestyles while also creating revenue that is then reinvested in the environmental project. The result of this collaboration between Ectagono and the subprojects is an outdoor space where people can spend the day, eat a meal, partake in a workshop, and so on, while learning about ecology and sustainability.

To better coordinate with the subprojects, Ectagono legally registered as an Anonymous Society for the Promotion of Investment (S.A.P.I in Spanish) and designed a business model in which the subprojects pay an agreed-upon percentage of their income to Ectagono in exchange for the space to operate as well as various other forms of support, such as consultations, organization of events and workshops, and other actions that promote the businesses and bring clients in. Subprojects have a grace period to establish themselves, after which they must either deliver results or renegotiate the terms of their agreement with Ectagono.

To date, the organization has managed to convene subprojects of sustainable food production (urban agriculture, beekeeping, poultry farming, vermiculture and composting, artisanal tortilla production, cafeteria), environmental integration (a butterfly farm, bioconstruction, rainwater collection), health and sports (martial arts, mountain biking, yoga, a dog park, traditional temazcal) and even technology (drone workshops and automation of urban gardens). Ectagono looks for interesting, innovative and, above all, diverse subprojects because these can both support each other –an urban garden can supply the restaurant, for instance– and complement each other. After all, the more entertainment options available, the more attractive and pleasant the place becomes for visitors.
