This attraction factor benefits both Ectagono and each of the subprojects economically.

Even so, the owners consider that competition is healthy and do not promise exclusivity to any subproject. In other words, there may be more than one restaurant, for instance, and the success of each one will depend on the services or products on offer. This particular vision contrasts with the views of some other development models, such as alternative economies, which argue that complementarity, rather than competition, enables sustainability.

The workshops and trainings that Ectagono offers in collaboration with its subprojects also raise awareness on environmental issues among visitors and encourage new ways of relating to the city and to nature.

In this vein, Ectagono also collaborates with organizations and companies from both the private sector and civil society by offering comprehensive programs, workshops and coaching on sustainable practices and reduction of carbon footprints, as well as institutional integration activities with employees. These partnerships give the project visibility, foster new collaborations that can translate into different types of support and, in addition, increase Ectagono’s long-term impact because leaders can then learn from the project and promote similar or complementary ideas in other spaces.

Ectagono also collaborates with academic institutions by installing eco-technologies in schools and universities to reduce their ecological footprint, organizing school visits with problem-based exercises that support specific subjects, opening internships positions and volunteering vacancies, and offering workshops.

To further expand its reach and attract customers, Ectagono also has an ambassador program comprised of influencers, activists and well-known personalities who help publicize their efforts on social media to encourage more people to visit, engage with and contribute to the project.

Collaborations have also enabled Ectagono to navigate difficulties in creative ways. During the Covid 19 pandemic in 2020, for instance, the project teamed up with the airline Aeromexico and the Reinserta Foundation to organize a virtual reforestation campaign. With support from the airline, Ectagono came up with a “tree-sponsorship” program: small donations were collected through online crowdfunding, which Reinserta then used to train and temporarily hire people from the surrounding neighborhoods who lost their jobs in the pandemic to plant the sponsored trees. In previous years, Ectagono took on this same activity with volunteers, but this year they chose to integrate the local communities into their project and have a positive impact on the region. In addition, Ectagono asked for the support of ambassadors who live-streamed the activity, which helped promote the campaign and foster support.

Among other ideas on how to increase the scope of the project, Ectagono is thinking of an urban "ecovillage" model: that is, building houses on its plot of land for volunteers to spend six-months in, working on the different subprojects in exchange for food, lodging and experience. Whether these volunteers would have to pay for these training residencies has not yet been decided. According to the owners, this would make Ectagono a "living project" that truly comes up with alternative ways of living and not just one-day experiences.

title: The Health and Happiness Project · Brazil
introduction:
info 2013

The remote Brazilian Amazon is a region of incredible ecological and cultural diversity. In addition to being one of the “lungs of the world” for its extensive areas of rainforest, it is home to 29 indigenous cultures. However, several of these communities are not accessible by land and can only be reached by river. This has led to these populations being systematically excluded from the most basic services, such as education and health.

 

What can be done to expand access to basic services for remote communities?
short_description: The Health and Happiness project collaborates with Amazonian communities in Brazil, building comprehensive development programs that include health, culture, education, economy, territorial development and communication.

paragraphs.body_html: The Health and Happiness Project (Projeto Saúde & Alegria) began in 1987 as a health care program. In 2006, the organization acquired a large and beautiful boat called Abaré and began visiting communities that could not be reached by land. The boat went from community to community with an interdisciplinary team known as the Great Circus of Mocorongo, which presented a show demonstrating the importance of health care and disease prevention through fun, interactive games. The ship's staff also offered basic medical and dental care, family planning, minor surgeries, water supply and treatment technologies, home filters, wells, and others.

This first initiative to bring health services to communities on boats was so successful that it was taken over by the Brazilian Ministry of Health in 2010 and scaled up to the state level. Since then, the organization has completed its health mission, as it has achieved its goal of ensuring access to basic health services in the region. Health and Happiness’s main intention is to create, test, and scale up replicable models of development such as this one ¾that is, to design, test and systematize models that work and can be absorbed by institutions with greater capacity to finance them and to replicate them in different places¾ the State, the private sector, other organizations, or the communities themselves. In other words, Health and Happiness designs an exit plan as soon as it starts its projects, so that it can transfer them to these other organizations that can more easily sustain them or even scale them up within the region or even beyond its borders. Once this happens, Health and Happiness changes its role: it stops implementing the programs and dedicates itself to building management capacities in the communities, linkages between them and networks with its external partners, to ensure that the programs remain under community stewardship and keep the high standard of quality.

The Health and Happiness Project has been working for decades with these socially and geographically excluded populations in the Brazilian Amazon region. Because of its work throughout all this time, it has built credibility within these communities, which has enabled the project to expand and work in a more comprehensive manner by including new fields beyond just health, such as territorial development, education, economy, culture, and communication.

To start working in a specific area, Health and Happiness always begins with its territorial development program. This program is the most basic and the most important of the whole project. The team organizes meetings with the communities and, using geographical maps of the region, works with them to visually mark or identify their interests and needs and to stimulate reflection. This methodology for project diagnosis and planning is not only innovative but also very important, because sometimes it turns out that the community does not even agree on how their territory is defined! Thus, through this participatory mapping technique, the communities identify their most important problems on the maps and propose ideas on how to solve them together to strengthen their community, adapting the program to local conditions.

Health and Happiness not only designs its programs in collaboration with the communities, but also works to ensure that they take ownership and keep them alive. To achieve this, in addition to participatory mapping, it implements strategies such as training and strengthening local leaders and organizations that can manage and disseminate these programs without the intervention of Health and Happiness. Another program to foster local ownership of the project is the Mocoronga Communication Network, which prepares young people to document and disseminate, through writing and videos, their own version of what is happening in their lives, in the region, and in their homes; recording life, culture, and everything that is important to them and to the Amazonian communities.

Health and Happiness also works with communities to strengthen their economy by promoting entrepreneurship programs such as ecotourism and the sale of local handicrafts. The aim is to make the most of the Amazon's special resources in a sustainable way and to promote local production, which has been disappearing due to a lack of good management of community resources and because many communities have become heavily dependent on direct government support.

Although Health and Happiness does not have its own schools, it has sought to complement the activities of the Amazonian schools to promote a local education that becomes more relevant to the communities ¾which means that the content taught to children also has to do with their immediate reality and, therefore, migrating once they finish their studies becomes only one of their options. To achieve this, it has partnered with schools, foundations, and the local government to implement the participatory mapping technique described above, but this time with the children. With this technique, the children themselves draw maps of their communities that help them identify the elements of their context that are most familiar and meaningful to them, and from there, official learning materials are adapted and tailored to be more locally relevant ¾including local characters and animals such as the sloth, for instance.

Health and Happiness understands that several of its areas of work (health, education, environment, etc.) are intertwined in the community development process and that carrying out interventions in isolation ¾instead of integrated amongst each other¾ is not sustainable. Ultimately, the beneficiaries are the same and change in one of these areas affects all others. However, many of the organization’s financial donors are looking for results in a specific area and push to see these results. To turn this situation around and not lose this support, Health and Happiness established an Institutional Integration Team that is responsible for linking the organization's various programs together and establishing mechanisms so that they can share their resources (human, infrastructural and financial). Thus, even if resources are only obtained to support one area of the project (health, for instance), they will indirectly serve other areas that were not able to obtain them (such as education, if the health program includes care for students, for example). The circus also serves Health and Happiness to promote transversality among its programs, because it encourages people to engage with all project areas using different forms of learning (dancing, singing, talking), and even to express the connections they see between these areas that could be leveraged. Another technique that the organization uses to promote and assess the transversality of its programs is to review them annually with the Planning, Monitoring, Evaluation and Systematization Cycle ¾its own version of the Small and Medium Enterprise Cycle, a methodology used by many projects to improve their organization.

Fortunately, Health and Happiness has surrounded itself with the support of other initiatives to serve Amazonian communities. Health and Happiness knows that many foreign partners take advantage of the experience, knowledge, and credibility that its initiative has cultivated in the region to access the Amazonian communities it serves. It therefore devotes much effort to systematizing its models and presenting both its processes and results as transparently as possible so that external communities and all kinds of public and private institutions can identify ways in which they can join its efforts to expand the communities' access to a greater number and variety of social programs, which can mutually support each other to generate a more comprehensive development process. Besides, these efforts to systematize its experiences also serve to replicate its models outside the region, offering consulting services to companies, NGOs, social movements, and the public sector.

Health and Happiness's work model is not expensive, but so far it has been overly dependent on external funding, so much of its effort is focused on seeking financial sustainability by diversifying its sources of support as much as possible, so as to be able to implement its models with the least restrictions. In this sense, Health and Happiness takes great care to ensure that the management of its funds is transparent, in order to maintain the support of the donors it has managed to obtain and attract new ones, providing them with certainty. It does this by hiring an independent auditor, for example. To attract more support, the organization uses strategies such as inviting famous public figures to help give visibility to the project. It also charges for consulting services to other organizations and takes advantage of its registration as a Non-Governmental Organization to obtain donations. In addition, it makes it as easy as possible for interested people to donate money online, give them equipment, or get involved as volunteers.

To ensure that its projects and methodologies are replicable and scalable in the long-term Health and Happiness's institutional integration team develops a multi-year strategic plan in which it plans how to expand its model and how to strengthen its organization both internally and in its links with other organizations. This plan considers how it can fulfill the role that the organization has decided to adopt to solve the social problems it works on (that of creator of demonstrative models that others can absorb and scale), how sustainable its model is, which programs can be scaled up and how, and possible exit routes that would enable it to eventually withdraw, and leave its projects up and running.

This project has become a leader in the region in sustainable development programs and demonstrates that it is possible to improve the quality of life of remote rural populations through community participation and cross-cutting attention to social, economic, and environmental problems.
